Title: The transformation of union-employer relations in the postwar era: An analysis of Delaware labor leaders
Abstract: Organized labor is under attack. As a result of the transfer of production to nonunionized work forces, vigorous management opposition, and the failure to organize white collar and service workers, the organized proportion of the American work force has dropped to less than one-fifth. As the quarter-century of postwar prosperity has given way to an era of increased international competition and a sluggish growth rate, employers have broken their old social contract with organized labor in which the acceptance of collective bargaining was traded for a stable work force. Because the union movement has been the only institution to continually represent the working class, its current weakness has caused concern. Aronowitz and other commentators have suggested that the labor movement could be revitalized by broadening its goals, pursuing class-based politics, and joining with other social movements to forge a new progressive coalition. To assess the possibility of revitalization on the local level, I examined the recent history of the Delaware labor movement through newspaper files and interviews and surveyed the local leaders. I looked for recent events which would indicate new activism and progress and focused on the ideological orientations of the local leaders that might facilitate or hinder the pursuit of class-based politics and the formation of progressive coalitions. I found that while Delaware has experienced most of the same problems as the labor movement nationally, local unions are pursuing new efforts to organize, the DuPont workers, once part of a system of paternalistic labor relations, have formed a new international and are becoming more active in their own interests, and new union-sponsored legislation to protect workers has been passed. The survey shows that the majority of leaders have a broad view of union goals, believe that unions should play a role in politics, and are willing to join in coalition with other local groups. Most identify themselves as moderates and the responses to various opinion questions do not represent a consistent ideology. Support for egalitarian change in the workplace and in society is strongly associated with both youth and higher education.

Title: Challenge from the left: The socialist press and the progressive reform movement, 1900-1917
Abstract: Through the medium of the socialist press, this dissertation examines the relationship between socialism and the progressive reform movement during the first two decades of this century. It has become popular in recent years to observe that socialism influenced progressivism, and this study examines specific issues to gauge the degree of that influence. By analyzing particular areas of reform during the Progressive Era, the dissertation demonstrates the role socialism played in generating, accelerating, and accomplishing progressive change. The socialist press provides a valuable resource to study socialism's effect on progressivism, since it represents so well the thoughts, ideas, and practical goals of Debsian socialism. While many socialist publications were plumbed for this purpose, five publications comprised the heart of the research: the Appeal to Reason, the National Rip-Saw, Wilshire's Magazine, The International Socialist Review, and the Social-Democratic Herald. These publications represent a broad spectrum of socialist opinion, taking into account ideology, regional differences, and format. Chapter II examines these publications, the personalities involved, and their relationship to the socialist movement. The heart of the dissertation studies specific issues in the general categories of politics, economics, and social questions. Under politics, progressivism itself is discussed, also trusts and government reform. The economic aspects include public ownership and the labor movement, while the "Woman Question," education and child welfare are examined under social issues, including the disappointing failure to address reforms for Black Americans by either socialists or progressives. Finally, the dissertation examines the familiar question "why is there no socialism in America?" and considers the legacy left to the nation by the Debsian socialist movement. The results of this study demonstrate that the socialist movement did have an impact on the surge of progressive reform in the pre-World War I years, progressive reformers did feel pressured from the left and, consequently, moved more aggressively to correct national problems. While the Socialist Party faded from national importance after the war, the study concludes that the party's agenda in the area of immediate reforms has been enacted into law and forms a substantive part of America's social, economic, and political reality.

Title: The unexpected resurgence: Ethnic assimilation and competition in Taiwan, 1945-1988
Abstract: Taiwan recently witnessed a sudden increase of opposition political activities among the Taiwanese. Given that the social, economic, political and cultural developments Taiwan experienced during the past four decades were expected to facilitate assimilation between the Mainlanders and the Taiwanese, the Taiwanese insurgence at this time was somewhat unexpected. To account for this development, this dissertation examines: (1) the causes and pattern of ethnic assimilation between the two groups; and (2) the connection of ethnic assimilation and the recent insurgence. The central thesis of this dissertation is that development of the opposition movement after 1986 was a result of a successful ethnic mobilization among the Taiwanese who rose to request for renegotiating the ethnic distribution of political power. The ethnic mobilization was facilitated by the change in the external environment of the movement, which included: (1) the increase of regime permissiveness, (2) the emerging opportunities of political competition, and (3) the emerging regional persistence of ethnic differences. Ironically, all three elements were caused by the pattern of ethnic assimilation. The main body consists of six chapters. Chapter 1 raises the question of the unexpected resurgence among the Taiwanese and proposes a framework of ethnic mobilization to its explanation. Chapter 2 provides a historical overview of the formation of the two ethnic groups, and patterns of intergroup relation during the past four decades. Chapter 3 examines two dimensions of cultural assimilation among the Taiwanese: language shift and identification with China. Using a survey data set collected by the Global Views Monthly in 1987, chapter 3 shows that the two major elements of ethnic differences were well preserved among the less-educated Taiwanese who reside outside the northern region of Taiwan. Chapter 4 investigates the alleged ethnic discrimination in the labor market by analyzing a data set coded from the Managers of the Creditable Enterprises in the R.O.C.. A pattern of ethnic assimilation similar to chapter 3 is found. Chapter 5 examines the various forms of participation in the opposition movement to test the ethnic mobilization argument. The development of the opposition after 1986 was found to begin in more assimilated areas and rapidly spread to the less assimilated areas through the tactic of ethnic mobilization. Chapter 6 draws a brief conclusion of what has been found.

Title: Privatization in Algeria: Implications for development theory
Abstract: As governments around the world today continue to converge in their embrace of economic liberalization and restructuration, a tremendous challenge is posed for scholars of the development process. The movement towards privatization taxes theories of development which are anchored in the traditional "great debate" between capitalism and socialism. Analytical tools which remain fundamentally state-centric in their unit of analysis and economistic in their definition of development are ill-suited to adequately account for either the historical origins of entrepreneurial forces or the transnational dimension of the privatization movement. This thesis proposes that a power-based analytical framework centered on the study of social forces is more capable of shedding light on the political nature of privatization. Algeria provides a particularly valuable context for the study of the politics of privatization. Renowned for its revolutionary origins and its experiment in collective self-management, Algeria has surprised the world with its recent turn to "market forces:" restructuration in the public sector, decentralization in both public and private economic enterprises, and liberalization of private economic activity have become the order of the day. However, these reforms should not be interpreted as a repudiation of Algeria's commitment to socialism. This work shows that the new strategy for development is rooted in both the historical origins of private capital and the common ground of public and private economic activity in Algeria. The current overtures to private economic activity suggest neither a reversal of the past nor a retrenchment of the state, but remarkable continuity in the ongoing process of social reconstruction and regime building.

Title: Modern community housing: New responses to the shelter problem in the 1920s and 1930s
Abstract: The modern community housing movement of the 1920s and 1930s aimed at changing urban residential patterns in the United States in order to lower housing costs and increase neighborhood life. In part, this reform effort can be understood as the American expression of the international mass housing movement--characterized by a commitment to raising general living standards and concern for strengthening social bonds within large urban centers--which emerged in many of the industrial nations after World War I. In the United States the movement built on a number of native traditions of housing reform, and on previous attempts to create a greater sense of community. The movement gained adherents in this country partly because, even in the midst of the prosperity of the 1920s, shelter conditions for large numbers of Americans were unsatisfactory and not improving much. In the early 1930s social and political conditions allowed for more radical initiatives in housing than before or since, and ideas associated with the modern community housing program influenced the design and administration of some publicly financed residential developments. The dissertation investigates how these reform ideas worked out in practice, both socially and architecturally, based on documentary evidence and oral history interviews with early residents in two prototypical housing complexes constructed in this period. The first case study concerns the Carl Mackley Houses, a development sponsored by the Hosiery Workers Union in Philadelphia and constructed with funds loaned by the Public Works Administration (PWA). The second deals with the Harlem River Houses, built by the PWA in conjunction with the newly-formed New York City Housing Authority. The union housing had its roots in the "new unionism" of the 1920s; the Harlem development was a product of social movements initiated by urban African-Americans. The study contains an analysis of the political forces which later pushed federal policies in another direction. It concludes with a discussion of the ways in which elements of the modern community housing program have remained influential, particularly in relation to efforts in the 1980s to improve the quality and expand the supply of affordable housing.

Title: Uncertain opening: The Catholic Church and China in the contemporary international order
Abstract: This study examines the contemporary relationship between the Roman Catholic Church and the government of the People's Republic of China (PRC) within the perspective of international relations theory. It is the thesis of this study that China's current policy of religious toleration is a necessary response to the strategic need to participate in the contemporary international market system. China's participation in the international system forms the basis for renewed and expanded contact between the Church and China after thirty years of tight state control under which the local Chinese Church was subordinated in classic Communist fashion through the formation of the Party-controlled Chinese Catholic Patriotic Association (CCPA). Both China and the Church have adopted significantly more open attitudes and approaches to the contemporary secular world: the Church since the Second Vatican Council and China since the death of Mao Tsetung. Elements in the expanded contact between the Church and China within this expanded context include the cultural obstacles between the still Western oriented Church and the traditional Chinese ecumene, ideological differences between Communism and Christianity, and the role of the Church in Chinese strategy. Chinese acceptance of the U.S. strategic role in the late 1970s coincided with a rising movement within the Church to criticize that U.S. role from the perspective of social justice and Liberation Theology. Juxtaposition of the changing Chinese and Church positions with regard to the international system and the U.S. role within the system puts into sharp focus the question of the Church's role in the world and the issue of a Church theory of regimes. This study argues that Church values, in particular with regard to individual and institutional freedoms, in essence are consistent with values and principles of contemporary liberalism, and that the Church can play a positive role in China's integration into the international order and development of its modern political economic system.

Title: The relationship among the four professional nursing organizations and woman suffrage: 1893-1920
Abstract: The purpose of this investigation was to explore the tension between the politically conservative image of nursing that has been presented in the current professional nursing literature and the four professional nursing organizations' actual involvement in the suffrage movement. An historical method was used to identify the four professional nursing organizations' opinions, actions, and intentions relative to their positions on women suffrage. The timeframe for this study was 1893 through 1920. The primary and secondary sources that were used were professional journals; published and unpublished proceedings of each of the four professional nursing organizations; nursing and suffrage archival collections; and historiographies of nursing, women, and the suffrage movement. The four organizations were: The National League of Nursing Education (formerly the Society of Superintendents of Training Schools for Nurses), The American Nurses' Association (The Nurses' Associated Alumnae), The National Organization of Colored Graduate Nurses and the National Association of Public Health Nursing. Findings indicated that among the four national nursing organizations, organizational endorsement of women suffrage was voted on seven different times. Six votes represented the membership of the National League of Nursing Education and the American Nurses' Association. The additional seventh vote was a report of the international organization's vote. Only two of those seven votes resulted in opposition of organizational support of suffrage. Nursing organizations, instead of being conservative were progressive. They sought to change the social system by advocating women's suffrage, education, and practice. To explain why nursing's ties with women history has been incompletely portrayed and often omitted from some historiographies of women, may lie in an underlying prejudice towards nursing and its role by society. The term "nursism" was conceived for the purpose of explaining the prejudice and omission witnessed. How we evaluate the preconceived notions of nursing will impact the solutions to issues facing nursing today.

Title: Black feminism: A comparative study of women in Ghana and the U.S.
Abstract: Discourses on racism, ethnocentrism, sexism and classism abound, but much of the work of theorists and practitioners who seek change in these areas have failed to adequately and appropriately address the concerns of Black women. This dissertation explores the evolving contemporary Black Feminist perspective which is developing, in part, as a response to these deficiencies. Black Feminism recognizes and acknowledges that Black women incorporate race or ethnicity, class and gender into a multifaceted integrated identity. Developing out of a recognition of this complex identity, and as a critique of the deficiencies in the existing social change activities, Black Feminism seeks to explore the multiplicative impact of gender, race/ethnic and class oppression which have placed Black women on the margins of society. Although much of the Black Feminist literature is authored by Afro-American women, African women are also contributing to this newly emergent phenomenon. This dissertation describes common problems shared by women in two very divergent societies--Ghana and the United States--and argues that a Black Feminist perspective informs the efforts of many Black women to change or transform these societies. Black Feminism is viewed as a complex mechanism adopted by Black women to survive in hostile environments. Its flexibility and complexity is a result of its propensity to respond to problems arising from multiple oppression which have been defined as critical in specific situations. Its uniqueness is derived, in part, from its emphasis on an expansive conceptualization of the mothering role. Thus it incorporates not only the individuals right to pursuits of self development and personal fulfillment but also parallel communal concerns for the welfare of children and men. This comprehensive concern elevates Black Feminism into the realm of international Critical Social Movements that seek to imagine and conceptualize a more humane world in the quest to establish just societies.

Title: Ethnography of Rumba: Dance and social change in contemporary Cuba
Abstract: Rumba is a dance that reveals changing values and the efficacy of an aesthetic system as it interrelates with other systems in Cuban society. Rumba is set within the social, economic, political, religious and aesthetic systems of contemporary Cuba. Since the Revolution, Rumba has not only assisted efforts to celebrate national identity and cultural heritage but it has also made clear official commitment to new values. It has changed from a recreational dance of lower class Cubans in the nineteenth century to a symbolic dance that promotes egalitarian efforts of post-revolutionary Cuba in the twentieth century. Social change in Cuba has initiated change in dance. As part of Cuba's mammoth undertaking towards education and cultural awareness, Rumba has emerged as an important form of expressive behavior that assists national goals, reinforces Caribbean solidarity and promotes international prestige. The professionalization of performers, the organization of performance spaces and the proliferation of performance opportunities have prompted new paradigms and altered previous understandings of Rumba. In terms of space, Rumba has moved from the barrio and streets to the theater and stage. In terms of time, Rumba has changed from limitless to limited time. In terms of energy, however, Rumba has continued to ignite and sustain feelings of communitas. Unlike some other arts which lose their interest and vitality with changing values, Rumba's potency has been nurtured and its energy has been channeled towards the restructuring of Cuban society. Rumba's power and the power of dance are articulated in the effect of Rumba on both audiences and performers. As an example of dance anthropology within the Caribbean, this study illuminates values and attitudes which are embodied in dance. Meaning in dance is revealed at the world-view, ritual and performance, symbolic, group, individual and movement levels and the multivocalic nature of dance is demonstrated. The cultural contexts of Rumba facilitate an understanding of the profound complexities surrounding change in contemporary Cuba.

Title: The Saudi drug control policy: Aspects of its historical development
Abstract: As a result of the spreading worldwide illicit drug movement and problems hindering national and international drug control systems, many societies, including Saudi Arabia, have become new targets of the illicit market. This study examined the development of Saudi Arabia's drug control policy in response to the recent spread of drug use. The spread of drug use in Saudi Arabia was related to the international and regional drug situation and recent changes in Saudi society. Because of international drug control problems, the worldwide illicit drug movement, and the swift economic development and social change in Saudi Arabia, the government's response to eradicate drug-related problems has developed. Future research is needed, especially an investigation of problems limiting the effectiveness of Saudi drug law enforcement.

Title: "Shout the victory": The history of Father Divine and the Peace Mission Movement, 1879-1942
Abstract: This dissertation focuses on the origins, philosophy and impact of Father Divine's Peace Mission Movement from 1879 to 1942. Father Divine was an African-American minister, born in poverty in Maryland in 1879. During the 1930s he forged a prosperous international movement that received widespread attention. Past studies of Father Divine concentrate on the secular aspects of his ministry, which some scholars characterize as basically liberal. But an examination of the Peace Mission Movement's theological foundations in relationship to its social activities reveals that Father Divine was primarily a religious leader. On one level his campaigns against racism and his social relief projects were progressive. But the movement pursued such programs within the confines of a socially conservative theology. Father Divine was exposed to various religious traditions, including Methodism, Catholicism, Quakerism, Pentecostalism, and the positive thinking ideology called New Thought. He blended these into a syncretic theology, centered on the notion that he was God, and offered eternal life and prosperity to followers. He advocated mind power and believed that negative thinking produced misfortunes. He instructed disciples to channel his spirit through positive thinking to achieve spiritual and material success. He championed individualism and did not provide charity. Those who entered his Peace Missions received not only religious instruction, but job-training. As well as attracting the poor, the Peace Mission Movement lured African-Americans and Euroamericans from all income levels who had previous affiliations with New Thought. During the depression disciples helped formulate of the movement's secular programs and ultimately steered a Father Divine into direct political activity. Nevertheless, the Peace Mission remained a religious movement. To Americans threatened with dislocation by the uncertainties of the twentieth century, Father Divine offered a theology that allowed followers to combat feelings of helplessness and achieve a sense of control over their lives.

Title: The history of the first Ecumenical Council in the Netherlands--also in its international context--10 May, 1935 to 10 May, 1946
Abstract: An Ecumenical Council could be founded on 10 May, 1935, after a period of preparations in several Western Countries, in the Netherlands. This Council set out to bring together the different activities in this field, such as peace between nations, coordinated efforts in the sector of social-economic problems, demand for unity of the Churches, their mutual relief, etc. The dissertation is devoted to this subject. Formation, developments, activities, significance in the years before, during and in the first period directly after the Second World War are described. A careful inquiry into sources was necessary to fill up the existing gap of a consistent description of this historical period. By personal knowledge of several ecumenical pioneers during that time, the author could process these remembrances. Nine chapters treat successively: (I) The foundation of the Council, covering three international movements developed since 1914. (II) The completion of the Council by the Ecumenical Society in the Netherlands (in which the parishes would be involved), the mission work of the Dutch Missionary Council and the Dutch Ecumenical Youth Committee bringing the activities of the Dutch Christian Student Federation (NCSV), the Liberal Christian Youth League (VCJC) and the Amsterdam Youth Society (AMVJ) next to other Youth Movements in relation to the Ecumenical Council. (III) The very first years of the Council. (IV) The Dutch position in the international ecumenical movement. (V) The dilemma of Ecumenical solidarity. (VI) The Ecumenical Council during the occupation and the confrontation of the Churches bound together in the "Interchurch Deliberation" (IKO) in Holland concerning the answer of the Churches to the measures of the Nazi occupation. (VII) In the meantime the Dutch Reformed Church was reborn during the occupation. The Ecumenical Council continued its work in the shadow of this unexpected and surprising renewal. (VIII) The leaders of the Dutch Reformed Church (Kraemer, Gravemeyer and Banning) tried to redefine the responsibility of the Church towards the nation and at the same time towards the Ecumenical Movement. (IX) Towards a new organisation of the Ecumenical Movement in the Netherlands. The work ends with some conclusions from the history described and gives some new ideas with a view to the future. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: Perceived quality of life of deinstitutionalized chronic psychiatric patients in the New York State community support system
Abstract: The subjective well-being of chronic psychiatric patients, initially one of the motivations for the deinstitutionalization movement, can be studied systematically with the same sorts of survey instruments used with the general population. By definition, the chronic mentally ill cannot be cured, and so alleviation of suffering and improvement of their quality of life is an important goal of treatment programs. Of the factors which impact on their quality of life, social support has been shown to have major impact on mental health and psychological well-being, and the analyses here made this a major focus. The perceived quality of life of 729 chronically mentally disabled adults enrolled in seven state-supported Community Support Services (CSS) programs was studied. Clients were interviewed by their case managers, who administered to them several measures of perceived quality of life (PQOL) including domain-specific and global items on a Satisfaction with Life Domains Scale, and the positive affect and negative affect components of the Bradburn Affect Balance Scale. The case managers also supplied information about client demographic characteristics and level of adaptive functioning, characteristics of the clients' living environments, and the degree to which clients had social support networks. Bivariate analyses of the relationship between the perceived quality of life measures and the variables hypothesized to be correlated with it were done, as well as exploratory multiple regression analyses. Overall level of client psychological functioning was correlated with PQOL, as was self-related health. Social participation by the clients was strongly related to global PQOL and positive affect, while perceived inadequacy of social support most strongly correlated with negative affect. Opportunity to gain self-esteem through activities and contributing to the welfare of others showed a particularly strong correlation with global PQOL and positive affect. Although measurement problems precluded much reliance on the multiple regression analyses, it was clear that the physical environment contributed little variance to the explanation of client PQOL.

Title: Nongovernmental organizations as catalysts of policy reform and social change: A case study of the International Planned Parenthood Federation
Abstract: The goals of non-governmental organizations (NGOs) vary from charity to advocacy, and from functioning as government supported service delivery agents to catalysts of radical change. The International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF) was founded in 1952 by eight national planning associations (FPAs) to promote family planning and to stimulate the development of local FPAs. The IPPF was in large part responsible for moving family planning from a forbidden subject to a global policy priority. The purpose of this study was to identify and analyze the forces that promote or hinder the role of an organization as a catalyst of policy reform and social change. The dissertation addressed two primary questions: how the organizing processes and structures promoted or hindered its role as a catalyst for family planning and why the IPPF is no longer considered a social movement or catalyst in the field even though a number of individual affiliates still have this reputation. The changing roles of the IPPF were analyzed over three periods: the Social Movement (1952-1966); the Expansion of the IPPF (1967-1977); and the Identity Crisis (1977-1988). The study concludes that a dynamic network structure was one of the major factors contributing to the success of the IPPF as catalysts. Characteristics of network organizing predominated during IPPF's early history: horizontal linkages, multiple leadership, a few simple rules and procedures, an emphasis on flexibility and personal relationships, all unified by shared values. The combined efforts of the IPPF led to changes in attitudes and policies and attracted government funding. During the period from 1967-1977 the IPPF experienced an exponential growth in government funding and dramatic increases in the number of staff and FPAs. The subsequent growth of volunteer and administrative hierarchies along with a focus on accountability and centralized decision-making led to the development of bureaucratic characteristics. With the decline of the network and the failure to redefine its once radical mission, the IPPF became less known as a social movement and catalyst and more known as a professional bureaucracy dispersing funds to FPAs to support family planning activities. (Copies available exclusively from Micrographics Department, Doheny Library, USC, Los Angeles, CA 90089-0182.)

Title: Migration and social change in a Jordanian village: A sociocultural perspective
Abstract: The dissertation studied the everyday life of migrants and non-migrants in a Jordanian village. The socio-cultural perspective used in this study assumes that migration is a process of socio-cultural transformation of individuals into migrants. Migrants acquire with their movement a new social status. This new social status produces new behavioral patterns and attitudes which is alien to traditional societies. As a product of these behavioral patterns cumulative changes at the local level were observed. These changes were the result of behavioral patterns and attitudes toward traditional and national institutions as well as women and consumerism. In conclusion the dissertation introduced the fact that migrants re-integration in the village social life depends on their behavioral patterns and attitudes during their international migration period.

Title: Nineteenth century regional women artists: The Pittsburgh School of Design for Women, 1865-1904
Abstract: This study examines the social, economic and political circumstances, both European and American in origin, which promoted the establishment of the first design schools in the United States. Specifically, it credits two contemporary movements--one concerned with women's rights and the other with national trade--with the establishment in 1865 of the Pittsburgh School of Design for Women. In the early years of the School's history, the mercantilist board members sought to create an art training program in order to reform the design of manufactured goods. During the second phase, starting around 1870, artistic trends gradually replaced the original quasi-industrial concepts. Because of the paucity of archival data on the School and the scarcity of paintings by Design School artists, it was necessary to document and interpret the institution's actions, ideas and motivations using circumstantial evidence. Contemporary newspapers, periodicals and biographical encyclopedias were indispensable for this work. Exhibition catalogues and contributions from relatives of former Design School members have also been vital to an understanding of these women artists in the context of regional artistic activities. The thesis attempts to determine the art education at the institution using the example of the English design school training and the curriculum at the Philadelphia School of Design for Women. The study examines the Pittsburgh women's social backgrounds and their changing goals within the context of the city's industrialization; it discusses their involvement as artists, art teachers and as local and national exhibitors. As their contributions to exhibitions reflect an important aspect of their activities, appendices listing works contributed by Design School women to local, national and international exhibitions supplement the text. A name-index is provided to assist future scholars. In spite of the School's increasing popularity, the governing board closed it in 1904. This study offers suggestions on why this decision was made, using the social gender context to demonstrate contemporary ideas on women and on their role as professionals. In conclusion, although the data in this study is specific to Pittsburgh, a similar methodology can be applied to other regional centers, thereby helping us to gain a more comprehensive understanding of art and artists in nineteenth-century America.

Title: Umeko Tsuda and educational reform in modern Japan: From bicultural child to international feminist
Abstract: Umeko Tsuda was one of the first female students and the youngest person sent to America by the Japanese government in 1871 to study the social and educational position of American women. Tsuda spent ten formative years with the Lanman family in Georgetown. Her socialization in America including Christianity had a critical impact during the remainder of her life. In 1882, when she returned to Meiji Japan, she experienced severe reverse culture shock. Struggling to find out what she should do to better the conditions of Japanese women, she decided to return to America to study at Bryn Mawr College (1889-92). In 1900, after returning to Japan, she founded Tsuda College, one of the first women's colleges in Japan. This study addresses five interrelated questions regarding Tsuda: (1) the influence of her American Christian upbringing on her later life, (2) the impact of her American socialization upon her ideology of educational reform for Japanese women, (3) the significance of her attendance at Bryn Mawr in forming her ideas for women's higher education, (4) the issue of whether her motivation to establish a women's college can be seen as an extension of a more general American reform movement heavily influenced by Christian ideals and values, and (5) the influence of gender on Tsuda's involvement in international relations. Tsuda left a substantial body of literary documents including about five hundred letters to Mrs. Lanman, numerous articles, speeches, and diaries. Tsuda's bicultural upbringing was a positive asset in her personal development. Her bicultural experience facilitated her creation of an international network of women to support her efforts to provide higher education to Japanese women. American women reformers who devoted their energy to Tsuda College had a important impact abroad as "International Housekeepers," which illustrates a sharp contrast with the competitive, acquisitive male public sphere that dominated formal U.S.-Japan relations in the first half of this century. The achievements of Tsuda and her friends represent a pioneering example of the international struggle for women's rights and autonomy.

Title: Suburban jeremiads: Religion and social criticism of the American dream in the 1950s
Abstract: This dissertation is a study of religion and culture in the United States in the 1950s. It is an examination of the relation of two social facts: that America enjoyed unparalleled international influence and domestic prosperity in the early years following World War II, and that religion was enormously popular in these same years. Contemporary observers developed a variety of popular and elite theories about the place of religion in society. For some, religion was the moral, psychological, and political underpinning of American life. Others, particularly secular intellectuals and religious elites, criticized popular religious conceptions for being personally and nationally self-serving. The work of these opponents of religion in its popular manifestations is treated as a genre of literature to which the name "suburban jeremiads" is given. The narrative proceeds from an examination of postwar society's major secular trends, to the consideration of its religious aspects, and then finally to the debate about these religious aspects. The first chapter sets religion within the context of changing postwar society. Major social trends are discussed in relation to the religious ethos of the day. In the second chapter the postwar "return to religion" is described and analyzed. It is in this chapter that three aspects of religion--ecclesiastical, popular, and elite religion-- are discussed, and where a model is introduced to help interpret the relationship between these aspects and to set the context for understanding the conflict which arose between partisans of these aspects' competing conceptions about what religion should be. The third chapter focusses on the fifties' social and cultural critics and serves as a background for the fourth chapter which examines in detail the work of three religious critics-- Will Herberg, Gibson Winter, and Peter Berger-- who built upon the work of the secular writers of suburban jeremiads to produce their own sweeping condemnations of popular religion in America. The religious criticisms of American society and religion are seen as deriving from a common background of theological neo-orthodoxy and being the intellectual precursors of 1960s religious social protest movements and radical theologies.

Title: The political economy of urban restructuring: The case of downtown redevelopment in Chicago
Abstract: The research focuses on urban spatial restructuring. The starting point of the research is the relation between crisis and restructuring which is one of the central issues of Marxist theory. The economic restructuring, which has been caused by the economic crisis in the late 1960s and early 1970s in the United States has brought a spatial restructuring at different geographic scales. The research concerns itself particularly with downtown restructuring which is caused by local economic and fiscal crisis due to decentralization at a regional level, deindustrialization at a national level, and the new international division of labor at a global scale. The decentralization of capital and population at the local scale, national economic restructuring from industrial to corporate capitalism, the growth of new cities, and suburbanization, together have led to the decline of the older central cities of U.S. These brought about a tendency to urban economic and fiscal crisis, in turn leading to a search for new political regimes and for different perspectives to encourage economic development. Downtown restructuring has appeared as an important response to such structural changes. Another crucial factor for downtown redevelopment, especially since 1980, is increasing inter-urban competition as a result of supply-side economic policies. Inter-urban competition has made urban governments an important factor for developing urban economies and for increasing tax bases. Chicago is no exception to the trend of downtown restructuring; however, the case of Chicago exhibits several inconsistencies with the structural approach. The research focuses on how Chicago has not experienced economic and fiscal crisis, unlike other older central cities, and how downtown restructuring has been so active without crisis. From this basis the research examines the relationship between Chicago politics and downtown redevelopment. Finally, urban social movements, which have been active in Chicago in the late 1970s and early 1980s, as a consequence of growth ideology of machine politics and as a crucial factor for political reform, are examined. In the light of the case study, I would like to argue that there is no necessary relation between crisis and restructuring. Urban spatial restructuring is brought about by national politics and economics as well as the local political, economic and social environment.

Title: Dilemmas of sovereignty: Mexican policy toward Central America under Presidents Lopez Portillo and de la Madrid
Abstract: This dissertation has two objectives. The first is to describe the patterns of Mexican diplomacy toward Central America under Presidents Jose Lopez Portillo and Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado. During this period, especially between 1979 and 1986, Mexico displayed a striking degree of autonomy vis-a-vis U.S. policy, supporting left-leaning regimes and movements and promoting the Contadora Group's three-year peace initiative. The second objective is to explain the sources and nature of Mexico's foreign policy autonomy. Like all middle powers, Mexico must make trade-offs in the foreign policy objectives it chooses to pursue. The dissertation seeks to show when and why Mexico chooses to exercise its autonomy through diplomatic initiatives that challenge U.S. strategic interests and when and why Mexico acquiesces in those interests to pursue autonomy in other areas such as economic affairs. To explain both the specific pattern of Mexican policy in Central American and the nature and level of the country's autonomy vis-a-vis the United States, I develop an interpretive perspective that draws upon Peter Gourevitch's "second image reversed" approach to international relations. In a two-step analytical process, I first examine the ways in which Mexico's interaction with the external world have shaped its political institutions, the social coalitions upon which state power rests, and Mexico's worldview and ideology. I then show how the nature of these institutions and social and ideological forces have in turn shaped Mexico's foreign policy in three particular ways. First, Mexico's history of vulnerability to and conflict with the United States has given rise to an anti-U.S. nationalism that successive Mexican leaders have used both to strengthen state power at home and to exercise their freedom of action vis-a-vis the United States. Second, this history has reinforced Mexico's legalistic worldview, leading it to seek to transform the international legal and economic structures underlying its unequal membership in the international system in order to reduce its vulnerability. Third, Mexico's increasing economic dependence on the United States and, especially after 1968, its decreasing internal legitimacy, have reinforced the domestic utility of its anti-U.S. nationalism. The interaction of these three sources of Mexican foreign policy explain why Mexico chose to demonstrate autonomy in Central America rather than other issue areas between 1979 and 1986 as well as the specific pattern of Mexican actions in the region.

Title: The struggle for hegemony in the trade union movement. Ideology and political activities in Iceland, 1920-1938
Abstract: The development of the Icelandic labour movement during the interwar period is analysed in both a national and an international context. The focus of the analysis is on the question of a split within the labour movement as it appeared in the trade unions, the affiliation to the Second International, the structure of workers' organisations, and in the ideology of the movement and its power resources. This last aspect is measured both in quantitative and qualitative terms. Hypotheses are formulated concerning the pattern of action one could expect to find at the local level in Iceland. As The Icelandic Federation of Labour (ASI) constituted a socialist party and a federation of trade unions, problems concerning the right to representation at congresses were seen to be inevitable. Restrictions were imposed against the Communist opposition. It proved more difficult to expel the Communists since they did not establish a party of their own until 1930, and since they enjoyed wide-spread support in some unions, mostly in the fishing regions of the northern part of Iceland. The regional federation was under Communist control and the Social Democrats decided to launch an attack upon this bastion. It is argued that the reasons for the Social Democrats to make such a decision, i.e., to isolate the Communists, and, earlier, to become affiliated to the Second International 1926, were rational, to be explained by their contact network (especially with the Danish Social Democrats) and by the fact that the Social Democrat leadership could take notice of the impressive growth of organisations working without Communists. But, and this is one of the main results of the dissertation, this rational policy of the 1920s proved difficult to implement fully in the thirties. The conditions prevailing during the depression limited the opportunities for political action. At the same time the competition between these rivals resulted in the formation of new unions in areas where wage-labour was not yet a dominant form of living. Wherever Social Democrats found themselves in a minority position they split the trade union when all other expedients were barred, i.e., the possibilities of changing the trade union from within. How and to what extent the Strasbourg theses of the Profintern (Red International of Labour Unions) was put into practice is taken under critical examination.

Title: Investigation of avant-garde literature in the 1960's in Italy and France: The emancipatory conception of literature created by Edoardo Sanguineti and Philippe Sollers
Abstract: The central question is the investigation of literary movements of renovation in Italy and France which formed themselves as a collective of writers--named 'Gruppo 63' and 'Tel Quel'--at the beginning of the 1960's. To grasp these parallel existing trends in their specific coinage and character we selected their leading interpreters--Edoardo Sanguineti and Philippe Sollers--and investigating the parallels and differences of their conception of literature we demonstrated the national and transnational characteristics of the literary movements of renovation in the 1960's in Italy and France. Founded on the specific interpretation of language by Sanguineti and Sollers the existing model of language is grasped by its formal structure as an ideologically marked system of meaning and interpreted as an instrument of bourgeoisie of dominion over society. In reorganizing language and the modality of giving sense, writing becomes an instrument of revolutionary social praxis, the literary product becomes a medium of deliverance of man out of the oppression of society through language and literature becomes a factor which contributes to effect the change of society.

Title: Voyage revolutionnaire: The life and career of Victor Griffuelhes (1874-1922), French labor's apostle of direct action
Abstract: This is the first book-length study in any language of the life and career of Victor Griffuelhes (1874-1922), the artisan shoemaker who, as general secretary (1901-09) of France's largest trade-union organization, the General Confederation of Labor, and the co-author of the seminal document in the modem history of French labor, the 1906 "Charter of Amiens," exemplified for his contemporaries the spirit and practice of revolutionary syndicalism, the turn-of-the-century labor movement which advocated the replacement of capitalism by a producers' commonwealth. A close examination of Griffuelhes' career, as traced through French archival and contemporary printed sources, including his own considerable output as a labor journalist and pamphleteer, adds to our fund of knowledge on French trade unionism and social movements in the following main areas: the role of the "proletarianization" of artisans in the radicalization of French labor; the considerable influence of the experience of the First International of the 1860s upon the precepts and strategy of revolutionary syndicalism; the greater than heretofore assumed role of the Blanquist wing of French socialism in winning the trade-union movement for revolutionary syndicalism; the substantial efforts of revolutionary syndicalists to organize the "big battalions" of industrial labor in France (traditional historiography holds that their main clientele was alienated artisans); the CGT's conception of itself as France's only genuine labor party; and the attraction of revolutionary syndicalists to Soviet communism in the immediate post-World War I era.

Title: Military Knights of the Golden Circle in Texas, 1854-1861
Abstract: The Military Knights were the least significant degree of The Knights of the Golden Circle, a national secret pre-American Civil War group that promoted territorial expansion of the United States into Mexico in the 1850s in order to end slavery through gradual emancipation. By 1860, the Southern branch of Knights altered their policy from expansion to secession. Texas Knights were active in both phases. Secondary sources and archive materials were utilized to identify eighty-nine Military Knight leaders in thirty-six Texas counties to determine who the local Military Knight leaders were, what encouraged membership growth in each phase, and why their goal changed from expansion to secession. International politics, national economic interests, and local environmental conditions influenced individuals during both phases of the political, economic, and social movement whose ideals have had a lasting impact on American society. Appendices contain maps, tables, county, and biographical information.

Title: History of the Ethiopian Student Movement (in Ethiopia and North America): Its impact on internal social change, 1960-1974
Abstract: The 1974 Ethiopian revolution was a product of several forces with separate issues and demands. Political activity of the Ethiopian Student Union in North America (ESUNA) was a key factor in the feudal regime's downfall. However, only a few studies have addressed Ethiopian student activism (Koehn and Hayes, 1978; Balsvik, 1979; Lemma, 1979; Demmellash, 1984). No coherent analysis exists of ESUNA's ideology, objectives, and activities, and its impact on social change in pre-revolutionary Ethiopia. The purpose of this study was to document ESUNA's political activities from 1960 to 1974, and to extrapolate its effects on social change. The study focused on the development of the Ethiopian Student Movement (ESM) with emphasis on the movement in North America. Four aspects of the movement were addressed: (1) ESUNA's ideology, (2) its objectives, (3) the means it used to carry out those objectives, and (4) major changes in Ethiopia from 1960 to 1974 relevant to the objectives of the ESM. The historical method of research was used to review books, journals, published and unpublished dissertation, newspapers, and correspondence between ESM leaders. ESUNA's ideology was anti-feudal and anti-imperialist. Its objectives were to agitate for overthrow of Ethiopia's feudal system and to air essential demands: human and civil rights, ethnic equality, speech and press freedoms, literacy, land reform, and national health care. To achieve these objectives, ESUNA published and distributed theoretical and strategic literature, politically educated its members, used the media, and organized public demonstrations. Economic factors leading to change were famine, agricultural stagnation, secessionist war, and the international energy crisis. These poorly managed crises, were insufficient to cause revolution. Educational exchange initiated by Haile Selassie, exposed Ethiopia's youth to ideas contradictory to feudalism. ESUNA transmitted these ideas back to its compatriots inside Ethiopia. From 1960 to 1974 the recurring economic stressors met head-on with the new concept that an alternative to feudalism might exist for confronting the problems at hand. This created a qualitatively different situation than had existed previously in Ethiopia's feudal history. ESUNA demonstrated its effectiveness as a change agent by sustaining the movement under intense feudal opposition. ESUNA's theoretical and educational focus and use of the media, liberated ESM members from the psychological and social constraints of feudalism, changing the course of Ethiopian history.

Title: Some sociological aspects of tourism in the Greek island of Paros.
Abstract: This thesis is concerned with some sociological aspects of international tourism in a Greek island named Paros. Throughout the following thesis, the focus of attention is on some effects of the arrival of tourism in the island, such as the interaction between tourism and certain social processes as well as the response of the local community to tourism, and possible social changes in the local society related at least in part with the development of tourism. Tourism is one of several modernising influences such as the mass media, education, urbanisation, technology, etc., that significantly affect the patterns of behaviour, the attitudes and values of people in all societies. But there could be as well some social changes which might be specifically attributable to tourism. An important point is that in the case of tourism every society responds to tourism in its own way and, although some effects of tourism are common in many destinations and tourist resorts in the world, there are some effects of tourism that are more or less unique or are related only to one tourism destination. Nowadays in many international tourist resorts mass tourism means more than just an increased volume of visitors and it has come to involve the growth of many manufacturing and service businesses which combine to offer a travel experience through scale economies and mass-merchandising. The same applies also in the case of the island of Paros. The following thesis was guided by three main points of view. First was the Greek society and specially the society of the island Paros; second, tourism as a general major international movement; and, third, the possible social changes in the society of the island Paros. Of course this research is interested only in certain limited sociological aspects of tourism in the island of Paros and also sometimes it does not cover them completely; and there is much more to be done on the same subject in the future of other sociologists.

Title: A world-historical-sociological perspective on the course of decolonisation in Indonesia 1945-1949.
Abstract: This dissertation examines the transition from colonial administration to national government that took place in the Indonesian archipelago in the aftermath of the Second World War. The primary concern is to assess the form and extent of social change that took place in the country as colonial rule was terminated. The question of social change in the Indonesian Revolution is explored here from a perspective which is dubbed `world-historical-sociology'. That is, aspects of the fields of International Relations, History, and Sociology are combined and synthesised with a view to producing a reconstructed framework of enquiry into global social-historical problems such as decolonisation. Part I of the dissertation develops a world-historical-sociological approach in general theoretical terms. Part II describes the various social movements that were involved in the Indonesian Revolution and surveys the four-year course of the decolonisation process. Part III constructs a suggested explanation of social developments that took place as the colonial era ended in Indonesia, building the analysis around the theme of a dialectical interplay of social forces in the world system. The central thesis of the dissertation is that the outcome of the 1945-1949 decolonisation process in Indonesia may be aptly characterised as change within continuity , and that this result can be largely explained in terms of world-social-historical dynamics of modernisation. Thus, it is argued that, on the whole, the continuities in the patterns of social relations which followed from the Indonesian Revolution were more substantial than the changes. Such societal reorganisation as did transpire essentially conformed to a trend ( i.e. , modernisation) which was already in train in the archipelago during the colonial period. It is further argued that this modernisation process was rooted not so much in Indonesia itself, but in the world society into which the country had become increasingly integrated during colonial times. Transnational interventions were therefore as important as domestic developments in shaping the course of decolonisation in Indonesia.

Title: The relationship between evangelism and social responsibility in evangelical thought from the Wheaton Conference of 1966 to the Wheaton Conference of 1983.
Abstract: In the second half of the twentieth century the Evangelical movement has rediscovered the heritage of social involvement which had been lost as a result of the 'Great Reversal'. However, its recovery raised the question of the relationship between social responsibility and the proclamation evangelism which had become the Evangelical movement's primary mission in society. During the past quarter of a century, the worldwide Evangelical community has been wrestling with this question, and it is this process which forms the subject of this study. The main forum for the debate has been a series of International conferences in which the Evangelical community has formed an alternative oikumene to the official Ecumenical movement, from which many Evangelicals were excluded because they did not belong to mainline denominations, and from which many Evangelicals wished to disassociate themselves because of its espousal of the so-called 'Social Gospel'. This study examines the progress of the debate in the scries of conferences bounded by the Wheaton conference of 1966 and the Wheaton conference of 1983. These conferences, while focussing on the mission of world evangelization, have constantly faced the question of its relationship with social responsibility, raised to the agenda by more radical, often Third Word Evangelicals. As a consequence, there has been a movement away from seeing social responsibility as subordinate to evangelism, through recognising them to be separate but equal, to a concpt of 'transformation', which sees them as integrated within a single process. This change of emphasis, often resisted by the more conservative Evangelicals, but gradually becoming a more prominent view, has been accompanied by changes in other aspects of Evangelical theology. This study seeks to show the relationship between the changing attitude toward social responsibility and changes in the methods of interpreting the Bible, the understanding of the Kingdom of God and Eschatology, and the nature and mission of the Church. The changes in attitude to the Bible have included a new hermeneutic which recognises the social dimension of scripture and its application to different cultures, which had largely been overlooked by Evangelicals in preference for an individualistic and trans-cultural application. The Kingdom of God has been recognised as having a present existence within social structures, as well as a spiritual and future existence, and a more positive cschatology has been developed. The focus of evangelism has moved away from the individual Christian or para-church organisation towards the Church as an institution. One result of these changes has been a broadening of the Evangelical constituency, and an increasing openness both to the Ecumenical movement and to the Roman Catholic Church, to explore common ground in the relationship between evangelism and social responsibility. However, a test of the degree of unity within the Evangelical community will be the kind of consensus that emerges from the next international conference in the series, Lausanne II, in July 1989.

Title: Labor movements in newly-industrialized countries: South Africa and Brazil, 1960-1985
Abstract: This study examines the emergence of militant, radical labor movements in Brazil and South Africa since 1970. In both cases, emergent labor movements were marked by strong factory organization, close ties to community groups, and rapid politicization of union demands. Recognizing obvious differences between the two societies--particularly South Africa's uniquely rigid racial segregation--the study seeks to explain the unexpected labor upsurge in both cases. These labor movements, it is argued, were shaped by similar industrialization processes, which changed the relationship between the business community and the state, and reshaped workers' capacity for shopfloor and community mobilization. Under authoritarian governments, industrialization strategies sought to attract foreign and domestic private capital into heavy industrial enterprises; through the 1960s, both countries experienced systematic labor repression and rapid growth rates in consumer durables. By the mid-1970s, however, while industrialists concerned over international vulnerabilities, shortages of skilled labor and restricted domestic markets sought greater access to state policy-making bodies, semi-skilled workers in heavy industry engaged in militant strikes, demanding direct negotiations with employers. Employer reluctance to replace skilled workers increased the likelihood of union recognition. Despite high levels of unemployment, both labor movements quickly expanded beyond industrial workers. Shopfloor organizations developed strong alliances with community groups: in the course of industrialization, unusually homogenous working-class communities had grown up near industrial centers. Factory-based organizations supported community demands, and both labor movements defined their constituencies in broad class terms. The study suggests that the state's denial of social resources to workers' community underlined links between production and reproduction, and that class formation and consciousness may be far more contingent than previous studies of labor mobilization suggested. The study reconsiders theories of working-class movements in light of these findings, suggesting that different industrialization strategies may create different constraints and possibilities for labor mobilization.

Title: Organized labor in the European Community: Perspectives on British, French, and German unions
Abstract: This thesis is a survey of the post-World War II relations of the British, French, and German labor movements with the European Community. Part I describes key structural, political, economic, and historical characteristics of each country's labor movement, particularly the activities of the major national labor federations. Part II traces the growth of the West European labor movement. It analyzes the European Trade Union Confederation as an interest group and how it operates in the European Community to shape public policy at the transnational level. Part III examines two policy issues which illustrate the current relations of European unions and the European Community in the context of 1992 reforms: the campaign for a social charter of workers' rights and the establishment of European-level collective bargaining and consultations. The conclusion speculates about the future impact of labor unions in shaping social and economic policy in the European Community.

Title: Text and context in the communication of a social movement's charisma, ideology, and consciousness: TM for India and the West
Abstract: Among classical theorists, Weber, Durkheim, and Marx all displayed a concern for meaning and social significance--for a sociology of knowledge, of ideas and culture. What does a society mean? and what does it mean to members? Because the social movement is a microcosm for society, its meaning and significance in historical context and in the context of members' interaction is a model for societal development. In study of the Transcendental Meditation movement, its process of historical development is defined by transformations in charisma, ideology, and consciousness. The social movement is further shown to be a social construction by agencies exterior to it and to exist as a message in itself. The dissertation demonstrates interpretive framing of a movement by application of sociological methods and conceptual devices in order to contrast the interpretation with official movement and members' perspectives. A cultural comparison is drawn between the movement in India and the West, implying acculturation and reintroduction into India of a formerly elite cultural practice, its exchange value increased by Westernization. The international social movement into which TM has evolved is an example of a Third World multinational corporation operating in the West that relies on elite contacts and an expanding worldwide middle class. A vital problem for radical social movements--maintenance of belief consistently--is then displaced by the discovery of communitas and liminality which results from collective ritual performance. Its occurrence in a highly bureaucratized organizational setting suggests general solution to overly managed, overly socialized Western society. Analysis locates the members' perspective in consciousness as a fundamental variable using ethnomethodological tools and contrasts it with the institutional worldview with which the movement has competed and the functional rationality into which it has become ideologized. Finally, a social movement is a living subjectivity that lies outside objectifying practices of more powerful institutions and distinct from the signifying practices of social science. This is shown by revealing the members' context through ethnographic film/video, by members' adaptation of sociolinguistic methodology, and by use of a non-neutral content analysis technique which makes evident consistent journalistic bias and hegemonic media operations. (Abstract shortened with permission of author.)

Title: Ethnicity and the emerging peasant class of northwestern New Spain, 1760-1840
Abstract: This dissertation examines in depth the cultural and economic components of peasant class formation among the semi-sedentary peoples of northwestern New Spain. It focuses on the Province of Sonora during the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries, observing a frontier colonial society in the period of transition to republican rule. The analytical approach intersects the ethnic boundary of Indian-Hispanic relations with the emerging stratification of social classes, in order to illustrate how both categories of societal division changed and merged over time. The dissertation interprets these processes of structural change in terms of the ecological, economic, and socio-political relations that define a regional society. It argues that ecological adaptation to a semi-arid environment shaped the Sonoran peoples' strategies for survival which, in turn, influenced the colonial institutions established in this region. This study links the process of class formation to expanding market relations of production in the colony and to its place in the global economic system. While regional in focus, the dissertation relates the patterns of social change observed in highland Sonora to Spanish imperial objectives in the Bourbon period of colonial administration. Research methods combine quantitative and qualitative analysis of evidence drawn from archival sources concerning demographic movements, agricultural production, and land tenure. Household, community, and class constitute key concepts for reconstructing the dual processes of social change and cultural persistence. The dissertation explores the values upheld by rural ethnic communities through their patterns of reproduction and their modes of resistance to colonial domination.

Title: The end of a crusade: The Student Volunteer Movement for foreign missions and the Great War
Abstract: This dissertation is a description of the effects of World War I on the student missionary movement. While the story of the Student Volunteer Movement has been recounted many times before, it has never been told in relationship to the colossal tragedies of the Great War. This is surprising, since the war challenged in fundamental ways both the premises and the practices of the Protestant missionary crusade. A Christian civilization's claim to moral superiority was savaged by the European war. International cooperation among Protestant denominations and missionary organizations received a devastating setback. The war crushed the cheerful hopes of the Social Gospel, that liberal alliance between the kingdom of God and American culture. The American missionary cause itself was badly damaged by its intimate association with a "holy war" whose moral luster did not last. The identification of the missionary and national causes in wartime led to a serious loss of credibility for missions in the decade after the war. This confusion of crusades, among a generation of disillusioned crusaders, dealt the Student Volunteer Movement a blow from which it never recovered. For half a century after Versailles, the SVM tried, without much success, to find a place in a Protestant student world for which foreign missions had become a marginal interest. By the time it had voted itself out of existence in 1966, the volunteer movement had seen its crusading vigor repristinated in a new evangelical student movement and its triennial missions conventions. The decline of SVM was the result of many forces, both internal and external to the movement. Inextricably linked to many of these was the pervasive influence of the First World War. Although the volunteer movement finally disappeared, its response to the Great War is a significant chapter in the ongoing story of Christian missions, and an important contribution to our understanding of the encounter of religion and culture in America. Its legacies could be seen at the end of the twentieth century both in a lively evangelical student missionary movement and in national and international ecumenical structures that had been nurtured by the early volunteers.

Title: New woman, new world: The life of Margaret Sanger
Abstract: This study reexamines the life and work of Margaret Sanger, American feminist and birth control pioneer, from her birth in 1879 in Corning, New York to her departure in the 1940's from active, daily involvement in the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, the domestic, institutional legacy of her sustained efforts as a publicist and organizer. Taking a fresh look at Sanger's coming of age, it challenges the widespread view that she was mentored by a socially visionary father and gives greater weight to the bourgeois aspirations of her overburdened but resourceful mother and older sisters, who inspired her abiding confidence in the potential of women for self-reliance. It looks anew at her emerging disillusion with the left as a result of labor violence and government harassment of radicals in New York City before and during World War I and explains her conversion to political pragmatism through a postwar alliance with feminists and social welfare reformers. Further analysis of the influence of Havelock Ellis and H. G. Wells illumines her emerging confidence in medicine and in eugenics as tools of empowerment for women. Her successes as an organizer for birth control during the twenties and thirties are credited to the extraordinary popular resonance she gave the issue and to her particular appeal to women looking to wed private and public concerns, her failings, to a combination of factors including organizational dissension within the movement itself and intense opposition from a newly mobilized Catholic Church, which became increasingly powerful in the New Deal political coalition. Overall the study attempts to refute an interpretation well-established among historians that Sanger turned birth control into a force for political and social conservatism in these years. Sanger reemerged after World War II as an advocate for international population control, and several additional chapters on the efforts she carried on in this arena until her death in 1966, will be added before this work is published.

Title: Energy, technics and postindustrial society: The political economy of inequality. (Volumes I and II)
Abstract: Twentieth-century U.S. society has experienced rapid, large-scale change. The movement from a manufacturing to a service economy, the demise of political machines and the rise of rational administration and management, the replacement of mechanical and hydraulic machine tasks with electric "information", the increasing scientization of society, the dispersal of populations out of large concentrated central cities into suburban, electronic villages, and the globalizing tendencies of economy, technology and even culture--all are regarded as evidence of a transition from industrialization to postindustrialization. A prevalent view of this social transformation is that modernity is entering a new phase of development and that technology and markets are replacing politics as the agents of social change. Postindustrial society, in this view, is evolutionary and represents an advanced stage over previous social development. This dissertation challenges the evolutionary thesis of postindustrial transformation and presents an alternative institutional analysis of postindustrial development. Borrowing from the work of Lewis Mumford, four institutions are conceived as working together in an integrated manner: centralized power, corporatism, "big science" (Price, 1963), and the technocratic state. A historical examination of each of these institutions is provided, including the growth of an international petroleum consortium and national electric network, the rise of the corporation as the dominant form of economic organization, and the establishment of a national science and technology R&D apparatus. The coordination of these institutions with the military and the state have produced a highly centralized, technocratic social order. Particular attention is given to the role of the energy sector as a staging ground from which organizational, technological, and political initiatives for the operations of postindustrial integration have developed. Rather than a progressive development, postindustrialism is argued to exhibit compulsive, deterministic social tendencies. In particular, this development path presumes a permanent underclass, the decline of the city as a basis for community and effective political action, the spread of a technocratic energy order which includes the export of nuclear technology, the perpetuation of conditions of unequal national and international development, and an exploitive relation with the environment.

Title: Young bilingual children's appropriations of dialogue journals as a literacy event: A study of literacy socialization
Abstract: This study described a dialogue journal literacy event within a classroom setting and analyzed how oral and written discourse were used by bilingual children to construct the social worlds in which their interactions took place. The social worlds constructed by the children helped define both the literacy event (the context of their interaction) and the social functions that literacy served. A dialogue journal was a journal in which students wrote personal narratives and responded to one anothers' personal narratives both in talk and writing. The setting of the study was an urban school district in the southwestern part of the United States. The data, which included audio recordings of the students' talk, the students' journals, and the teacher's observation notes, were collected during the last three months of first-grade and the nine months of second-grade. The teacher of the bilingual first- and second-grade classrooms was the researcher. Four bilingual students, two male and two female, were selected as case studies. The dialogue literacy event was a unit composed of five phases which occurred in a predictable sequence. Movement between phases was partially signalled through different kinds of openings and closings that served as boundary markers for the different phases and served as a sequencing strategy that students used to predict later phases and the type of interaction that commonly took place within those phases. Students' definition of the event was discussed through the use of global types of appropriations which identified the students' social purposes during the event that were related to the topic and time orientation of the narrative as well as the social function of the written dialogue phase of the event. Four general types of appropriations were identified, discussing past and anticipated experiences, name-calling and negotiating peer friendships. The students used oral and written language to establish three types of group interaction which varied according to whether students told conversational stories and participate in extended conversations. The different uses of the oral and written channels were used to arrange different configurations of social interaction between the students and the students and teacher.
