Title: Antiwar women: The role of the Feminist-Pacifist-Internationalist Movement in American foreign policy and international relations, 1898-1930
Abstract: This dissertation examines the thesis that the Feminist-Pacifist-Internationalist Movement (FPIM) was and is a social movement that has played a continuing role in the development of American foreign policy and international relations. FPIM members were anti-war women who saw themselves as a positive and functional movement attempting to influence both the processes and outcomes of political systems. Using interest group tactics, they attempted to create change within an established political culture that favored tradition and continuity. The first wave of the movement explored in this analysis extended from the 1898 Spanish-American War through 1930 and included efforts to influence decisions relating to World War I, Versailles Treaty and League of Nations negotiations, and the movement to outlaw war that culminated in the 1928 Kellogg-Briand Pact. A convergence of social movement, interest group and political culture theory has been used as a framework for exploration of the anti-war goals, strategies and tactics of the FPIM. Jane Addams and the Woman's Peace Party (later the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom) and Carrie Chapman Catt and the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War furnish the primary case studies that establish the existence of the FPIM. Along with many other individuals and groups involved in the movement, these leaders and their organizations faced considerable resistance from both private and governmental forces that were opposed to all three controversial aspects of this movement: feminism, pacifism, and internationalism. Movements such as the FPIM have been virtually ignored by political historians until very recently. However, as one aspect of the current wave of the ongoing women's movement, with its focus on women's studies, feminist scholars are now exploring women's participation in political processes historically and in contemporary societies. As part of that new tradition, this dissertation examines the first generation of enfranchised women college graduates who participated in Progressive era politics through articulation of their concerns, creation of public awareness, and provision of ideas and information into the decision-making system. An examination of their activities and responses to them indicates that although FPIM women failed to attain immediate goals, they contributed to the evolution of twentieth-century diplomatic thought and policy.

Title: History of the Oregon Teamsters: Politically conservative unionism in a moderate state
Abstract: Labor history in the Pacific Northwest has attracted relatively little scholarly attention. The few histories that have been completed have focused primarily on politically radical or violent labor events. This limited scope of historical investigation has created the impression that radical unions have dominated Oregon's labor movement. In stark contrast to this assumed heritage, this history of Oregon's Teamsters depicts a union that has been relatively conservative politically. Episodes of corruption and violence have marred the Union's larger record, but over the longer term moderation has been more typical of Oregon's Teamsters. This suggests that political, social and economic moderation have been more representative of labor's development in Oregon than earlier studies have reported. The Teamsters Union in Oregon has also been characterized by small, geographically isolated locals. This pattern resulted when the aggressive organizing philosophies of the International Union were applied to Oregon's relatively small, dispersed population. Bargaining units within these locals have tended to be extremely small and volatile. A final characteristic apparent in this history of Oregon's Teamsters has been reliance on a state-wide Joint Council. Contrary to much that has been written about the International Teamsters Union, it has been the Joint Council that has had the largest impact on Teamsters in the state. This suggests that the economic emphasis in most accounts of the Teamsters has led writers to focus attention on the upper levels of the International Union. In this history, the Union has been studied from a broader, social/political standpoint, revealing that the power center in the union in Oregon has been at the Joint Council level. Oregon's Teamsters have relied on the Joint Council to coordinate and express collective needs; higher levels of the organization have been perceived as narrowly focused economic or organizing structures with limited impact on the overall concerns of the membership in Oregon. Moderate action, small bargaining units, and Joint Council administrative control, when taken collectively, largely define Teamsters history in Oregon, making it important for an understanding of Northwest labor history. (Copies available exclusively from Micrographics Department, Doheny Library, USC, Los Angeles, CA 90089-0182.)

Title: Skocpol's theory and the Islamic Revolution of Iran
Abstract: Skocpol's theory of revolution, the main concern of which is to explain why social revolution has been the crucial vehicle of transformation in a number of societies, has been applied to the Iranian Revolution for the purpose of evaluating its generalizability and its predictive and explanatory power in order to explore further the possibility of generating a theory which can be applied universally across time and societies. Skocpol, with a new analytical emphasis on a number of factors such as the structural approach, the potential autonomy of the state, and the international and world historical contexts, has developed a comprehensive theory of revolution. She argues that the breakdown of societal control is due to international pressures, peasants' insurrections, and the presence of a marginal elite. The history of the formation of the modern Iranian state, the type and extent of inter- and intranational pressures, the structure of peasants' life and their relation to state and large landowners, the relevant historical background of Shia political thought, the Ulama's role in Iranian society and in oppositional movements of the last two centuries, have been reviewed in order to measure the applicability, validity, and generalizability of Skocpol's theory. The study concludes that Skocpol's theory requires a number of major modifications in the formulation of causes of state incapacitation, peasants' revolutionary movement, and the role of ideology and leadership. Her emphasis on the role of state and transnational realities was found to be, though with modification, an important contribution to the analysis of social revolutions. Finally, the study suggests that attempts should not be made to develop universal generalization because of logical-theoretical problems and the nature of social revolution, most notably its non-repetitiveness and rare occurrence.

Title: Stillbirth of a world order: Union internationalism from war to Cold War in the United States and Britain, 1939-1949
Abstract: The strange alliance between the western capitalist powers and the Soviet Union in World War II stimulated a period of intense international creativity. Notable among the hopeful products of this time was the World Federation of Trade Unions (WFTU), founded in 1945, which united communist, liberal, Social-Democratic and business unionists in an effort to establish a democratic world system. The chill of the Cold War quickly put an end to any hope for a unified working-class voice in world affairs, with the WFTU splitting along Communist/anti-Communist lines in 1949. This study of the background of the World Federation explores the relation between political and social movements and the seemingly remote sphere of international relations. Joining diplomatic, social, and political history, the dissertation uncovers one of the lost opportunities of mid-century diplomacy: the institutionalization of the cooperative spirit of the Grand Alliance. By tracing the growing ideological conflicts in international union affairs, it also sheds light on the popular bases of the Cold War. In the mid-1940s world politics seemed on the verge of a vast transformation which would usher in a new era of global cooperation. By the end of the decade, however, few could entertain such hopes. This dissertation compares the intellectual and social processes which encouraged Americans and Britons to believe in and work for a new world order based on union participation in heretofore elite realms. It examines both popular perceptions and union politics to discover how unionists came to accept Communist participation in the international side of their movement. The substance of the work begins with studies of working-class attitudes toward the USSR and world politics. It then details the political and diplomatic sources of labor internationalism in the US and the UK. In the conclusion, a comparison of American and British anti-communism provides the starting point for a synthetic interpretation of the origins of the Cold War and of that conflict's effects on the internal politics of the United States and Great Britain.

Title: The determination of wages for unionized construction electricians in New York City, 1953-1983
Abstract: The dissertation will use both econometric techniques and historical accounts to analyze the determination of wages in the unionized labor market for construction electricians in New York City from 1953 to 1983. I hypothesize that hourly wage change is significantly effected by union structure and membership involvement. Earlier wage studies have established a positive correlation between the percentage of an industry's labor force that is organized and the growth of wages. S. Sobotka's investigation of construction union wage effects, H. G. Lewis' classic re-evaluation of wage studies and more recent work by R. Freeman and J. Medoff have all demonstrated the existence of a union wage effect. However these studies have not fully developed the notion of a "union effect" in terms of the social relations of work and trade union structure. The object of my research is to investigate the union wage relation at the micro-economic level through a case study of wage change for electricians represented by Local Union No. 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers. Wage movements are explained through a two step procedure. The first part identifies a union wage effect by regressing the rate of wage change on a set of conventional independent variables. These include the degree of union strength and market factors such as unemployment levels and productivity. The second part of the inquiry examines the role of union structure and union activism by establishing proxies for a secondary pay scale, union meeting attendance and union organizing campaigns. The econometric results lend support to my arguments that conventional models of union wage are inadequate. The statistical improvements gained from my stylized social variables indicate a need to look more closely at the social aspects of wage determination.

Title: The political impact of Argentina's human rights movement: Social movements, transition and democratization
Abstract: This study examines the achievements and limitations of Argentina's human rights movement during Argentina's transition to democracy, the Alfonsin administration (1983-1989). The thesis documents the movement's role in producing significant reforms such as: Executive investigation of the scope of human rights abuses, the unprecedented trial of former military rulers for human rights violations, the restitution of kidnapped missing children, and the introduction of new norms and organizations throughout civil society. The unexpected influence of this relatively powerless social movement is traced to a symbolic logic of collective action--which used legitimacy and information as political resources to transform the public political agenda, appeal to an international "human rights regime", challenge emerging democratic institutions and reconstruct citizenship. But the very strategies which enabled the human rights movement to survive authoritarian rule and catalyze sweeping reforms are shown to have limited the movement's ability to institutionalize human rights, in the context of a conditioned transition to democracy. Finally, the dissertation explores the implications of Argentina's human rights experience for the consolidation of democracy, the role of new social movements, the boundaries of state accountability and the significance of collective memory. "The Political Impact Of Argentina's Human Rights Movement" is based on fieldwork conducted in Buenos Aires during July-August 1987 and throughout the calender year 1988. The author interviewed 96 persons representing each of the ten human rights organizations, government officials (including Presidential advisors, Ministers, legislators and the Secretary of Human Rights), political party and union representatives, lawyers, judges, journalists, academics and military officers. In addition, dozens of demonstrations, strikes and political rallies were observed. During 1988, the author also witnessed two military rebellions (the January 1988 Monte Caseros uprising and the December Villa Martelli rebellion).

Title: Elise Boulding and the peace movement: A study of leadership rhetoric and practice within social movement organizations
Abstract: The leadership of Elise Boulding, a 1990 Nobel Peace Prize nominee, is the focus of this study; specifically her rhetoric and influence in the peace research and education networks of the contemporary international peace movement. This descriptive case study explored the interior of a movement by examining what a leader says and does and asking constituents how they perceived her influence within the movement organizations to which they belong. To achieve this aim, the study blended aspects of an organic approach to rhetorical criticism with qualitative methodologies used in organizational culture studies. The scope was limited to two organizations in which Boulding was most centrally involved: the International Peace Research Association (IPRA) and the Consortium for Peace Research, Education and Development (COPRED). Two questions emerged to guide the study: (1) What rhetorical strategies does Boulding employ in her writings, speeches, and actions? (2) How are Boulding's rhetorical strategies in her writings, speeches, and actions perceived by fellow movement participants? Rhetorical strategies were defined as the selection of language, appeals, arguments, and evidence and their adaptation to a particular audience, issue and occasion (Campbell, 1982). Utilizing triangulation of methodologies, descriptive analysis was performed on 26 of Boulding's peace-related writings and speeches, and an inductive content analysis was conducted on transcripts from 35 interviews with key people in the organizations and on organizational founding documents and newsletters. A multiple methods analysis was performed to synthesize the results of the descriptive and content analyses and to distill the essence of Boulding as a rhetor and leader in the peace research and peace education networks of the peace movement. Three characteristics were identified as distinctive attributes of Boulding's writings, speeches, and actions: (1) empowerment, (2) connectedness, and (3) enactment. The most distinguishing overall feature of these characteristics was their inter-relatedness. Together they created a stamp, an Elise Boulding imprint on her rhetorical works and actions within the contemporary peace movement. This study underscores the rhetorical richness of an interior examination of a social movement, and is compatible with Gerlach and Hines' (1970) anthropological studies of social movements which characterized movements as networks.

Title: Dependent revolution: The United States and radical change in Bolivia and Cuba
Abstract: This study argues that the scope and nature of external intervention in social revolution is fundamentally shaped by the degree to which a country was bound by a dependent relationship to its international context before the revolution. Dependency is often the product of long-term interaction and exists to the extent that external actors have become a routine part of a country's economic and political systems. It conditions the behavior, attitudes and expectations of the revolutionary movements, members of the old regime and foreign actors. It also establishes the tools through which external actors work to influence the revolution. These propositions are investigated by examination of U.S. involvement in the Bolivian National Revolution (1952) and the Cuban Revolution (1959). Each case is divided into three phases: the revolutionary movements' first brush with power, the immediate prerevolutionary period and finally, the first years of the revolution. Throughout the three phases, Bolivia remained on the margin of the U.S. sphere of influence: its domestic and economic structures were not the product of interaction with the United States. It bred a revolutionary movement with goals of minor interest to the United States. Both the revolutionaries and the old regime sought assistance from the United States, which was slow to respond. When intervention did occur, it took the form of actions which cost the United States relatively little effort or money. Cuba, on the other hand, was well integrated into the U.S. sphere of influence: its political and economic structures tightly bound it to the United States. By 1958-59, Cuba had produced a well-organized radical movement which sought to strike directly at these structures. It gained power by disguising its ultimate intentions and building a broad coalition. The many U.S. interests in Cuba prompted great interest in the Cuban Revolution in the United States. However, the reformist facade of the revolutionaries and the ease with which the U.S. had traditionally curbed the nationalism of Cuban reformers bred a sense of complacency in both countries. The United States was slow to respond, but when Fidel Castro and the Twenty-sixth of July Movement moved in a radical direction after securing power, the U.S. government took strong measures to destabilize the Castro regime. The U.S. effort to use its many linkages to Cuba, however, was subverted by Castro's ability to substitute assistance from the Soviet Union for its traditional relationship to the United States.

Title: Differences in stress experienced by international and American graduate students
Abstract: This study investigated differences in stress experienced by International and American graduate students. The study was based on assumptions of eight major theories used to explain cultural shock and cultural adjustment among immigrant and long-term sojourners: Selective Migration, Grief and Bereavement - Movement as Loss, Fatalism - Locus of Control, Expectations, Negative Life Events, Social Support Networks - Reduction in Social Support, Value Differences, Social Skills and Culture Learning. The Stress Audit (SA) inventory was administered to 51 International graduate students (40 males and 11 females) and 58 American graduate students (32 males and 26 females). Data were analyzed by multivariate analysis of variance and Puri and Sen L Statistic in trace criterion form. No significant differences were found for the main effects or interaction affect of ethnic background and gender when the total stresses experienced in every aspect of life were considered. When Family, Individual Roles, Social Being, Environment, Financial, and Work/School were considered separately, Internationals appeared to experience higher stress relating to environmental adjustment (e.g., adjustment to new neighbors, unfriendly neighbors, ethnic or racial conflict, etc.) than did Americans. Also, the level of stress experienced by International males for Lifestyle/Events, Stress Symptoms, Environment, Financial, and Work/School were significantly more variable than for female Americans. Levels of stress experienced by International females for Stress Symptoms and Financial were also significantly more variable than for American females. International females also were more variable than were American males in levels of stress experienced on Family related measures. These findings led to several recommendations for future research: (1) The assumption that International students experience higher levels of stress than do Americans should receive further investigation, including replication of this study at various geographical locations. (2) Further investigation is needed of Stress Audit's content and construct validities, and its reliability on International populations. (3) Further research, including longitudinal studies and case studies, should identify possible factors which may explain the greater variabilities this study found among International graduate students; and (4) Further studies should employ both parametric and nonparametric data analysis procedures to explore the differences found in this study.

Title: Two musical perspectives of twentieth century pacifism: An analytical and historical view of Britten's "War Requiem" and Bernstein's "Kaddish Symphony"
Abstract: On 4 August 1914 the world changed. The first global war affected not only the course of international diplomacy and military strategy, but altered forever the way in which mankind views itself and its culture. As the world of the Depression, dictators, Holocaust, and nuclear weapons raced out of control, politicians and diplomats failed time and time again to overcome the new challenges of the twentieth century. Finally, when the Cold War cast a new shadow of danger over society, the intellectual elite and the working class, religious and secular leaders, scientists and artists, rich and poor, educated and uneducated all began to speak and march and write to make their fears known. Musicians, too--who as a group had not stood at the forefront of political activism before--added their voices and began using their talents to reach out to the political masses and incite them to action. The purpose of this dissertation is to examine the message that musicians were sending and the conditions which drove them to agitate for peace and social justice. The study is divided into two parts: "the analytical view" describes the music and texts of the War Requiem and the Kaddish Symphony and the manner in which those elements are combined to proclaim the social message of each work; "the historical view" gives an overview of the political and cultural history of the twentieth century--from the outbreak of World War I in August 1914 until the signing of the Partial Nuclear Test Ban Treaty in August 1963--paying special attention to the peace movement and to literature, both of which played an important role in the lives of these two composers. Our memories of anti-war demonstrations in the late 1950s have been overshadowed by images of counterculture protest rallies of the 1960s. Yet the late 1950s--the last glory days of the Old Left--gave birth to a new age of grassroots political activism which was later transformed into an era of Vietnam War protests and Woodstock; and it is those glory days to which this dissertation is devoted.

Title: The emergence and disintegration of modes of regulation in agriculture: Germany and the United States in an historical perspective
Abstract: At the center of the analysis is the relationship between the agrarian production process, the agrarian political and economic institutions, and macro-economic and social structures and dynamics. Utilizing the concepts of the French Regulation School, I focus on the recurrent agricultural crises in Germany and the United States, and ask the question why the institutional forms that had developed as part of resolving the crisis of 1873-96 were no longer able to absorb the tensions in the production process, and why this process then led to the new crisis of the 1930s. My research on agrarian crises does not support the often cited phenomena that agriculture is a quintessentially domestic issue, nor that the international political environment can be reduced to questions of foreign demand. In the period from 1873 to the 1930s, the development paths of German and American agriculture were strongly interrelated in terms of population movements, the international financial system, and world grain markets. Tracing the different financial structures and analyzing their impact on the German and American farm sectors opens new vistas that have remained largely hidden in conventional political economy studies. No longer does the inter-war appear as a retrenchment of international relations as suggested by most studies that deal with the 1920s. Indeed, there is considerable support for the thesis that the internationalization of national economies continued during the inter-war period. Moreover, I found little supportive evidence for the central tenets of state-centric and coalitional approaches. National responses to agrarian crises cannot be deduced from political structures, nor from changes in societal coalitions. Rather, the policy outcomes to the agrarian crises in Germany and the United States emerged from the interplay between state structures, private networks, class struggles, human agency, and the functional logic of the economic process.

Title: Cognitive-affective correlates of initial performance by African-American youth in a high school completion program
Abstract: There is movement in the literature on high school dropout (HSDO) toward addressing student perceptions of structural problems in school and society. The movement is away from a focus on student personal deficits. Consistent with this trend, the present study sought to examine cognitive-affective variables related to HSDOs' perceptions of self, school and society. These variables were: global and domain-specific self-perceptions of competence, cultural mistrust, alienation, and perceived importance of various domains of competence. Correlations between these variables and measures of initial performance in an adult education program were studied among low-income, African-American HSDOs. Relationships were expected to be consistent with findings from literature on Black student academic achievement in addition to the HSDO literature. Specifically, it was hypothesized that: (1) perceived scholastic competence and global self-worth would be differentially correlated with measures of initial performance; (2) importance ratings of scholastic competence would be positively correlated with measures of initial performance; and (3) cultural mistrust and adolescent alienation would be negatively associated with scholastic importance ratings, and positively correlated with each other. Finally, staff members' orientations toward the promotion of student autonomy versus control were studied. They were expected to be related to rankings of staff's helpfulness received from students. The results failed to support the hypotheses. However, there were several unexpected significant findings. Positive self-perceptions by students in the social acceptance domain were associated with high passivity ratings by staff, and one measure of negative student self-evaluation was associated with high aggressiveness ratings by staff. Job competence emerged as one of the domains most important to students' views of self and society. Cultural mistrust and self-perceptions of job competence were correlated with global self-worth. The results are discussed in terms of their educational and social implications.

Title: Materialist feminism and the politics of discourse
Abstract: From the standpoint of a postmodern marxist feminism, the dissertation addresses the current concern over who feminism speaks for, given that under the pressures of late capitalism, "woman" can no longer be thought of as an obvious monolithic category. Arising out of critiques within marxism and feminism, materialist feminism has contributed to the development of postmodern theories of the discursive construction of the subject, but this work for the most part has tended to privilege gender over other categories of difference and has adhered to a contradictory notion of the feminist standpoint as grounded in "women's experience." The aim of the dissertation is to contribute to the work of overcoming these impasses in materialist feminist theory in order to strengthen its radical oppositional force. I examine how materialist feminism articulates within its theoretical framework various and often contesting discourses and consider the consequences of this eclectic appropriation for the reformation of feminism's subject. I approach this issue by addressing the problems of social analytics, the materiality of discourse, and the discursivity of history. I argue that a post-Althusserian theory of discourse as ideology can supercede many of the contradictions in the materialist theories of discourse proposed by Foucault and Kristeva, especially--both of which have been widely appropriated by feminists, including many materialist feminists. Understanding discourse as ideology offers feminism a global--as opposed to a local--analytic as its mode of reading social relations. A global analytic provides feminism with a more rigorously materialist explanation of the systemic relations between the production of subjectivities across a range of modes of difference and other material practices. Within this theoretical framework feminist praxis can be understood as ideology critique and feminism's subject can be re-thought as a standpoint based not in an empiricist notion of experience but in a counter-hegemonic problematic. The dissertation develops the implications of this notion of standpoint for feminist history and for the project of aligning feminism's political agenda with those of other emancipatory movements.

Title: Strangers and citizens: The Irish immigrant community of Savannah, 1837-1861
Abstract: Historians have traditionally held that European immigrants avoided the antebellum South, and that the white population of the region was therefore ethnically homogeneous. Savannah, an international port, was an enclave for the foreign-born in mid-nineteenth century Georgia, and the Irish predominated in its immigrant population. Entering the United States in the northeastern ports, the Irish migrants made a second decision to relocate in Savannah. Their choice was shaped by contractors recruiting canal and railway labor during the 1830's when the first substantial movement of Irish to Savannah began. By the 1840's, the immigrant press reported on Irish social institutions that formed a welfare network for new arrivals in Savannah. Continuing economic expansion in Savannah created jobs for which there were not enough slave or free black hands. By the 1850's information about the social and economic opportunities available passed among the immigrants along informal channels of family and acquaintanceship, as suggested by the fact that most of the Irish residents of Savannah by 1860 came from six of the 32 Irish counties. In Savannah the immigrants carved out a community in the less expensive, less desirable neighborhoods. They lived near and socialized with the free black and slave population, the same group most likely to find itself in competition with the Irish for unskilled or low-prestige work. The Irish challenged the existing social order by their shoulder-to-shoulder relationships with African Americans, just as the drinking and ritual violence characteristic of Irish rural live troubled native-born Savannah. Firm support for the political system built on slavery made the immigrants fundamentally acceptable to the community, and no successful nativist backlash developed in Savannah before the movement of migrants was terminated by the outbreak of war in 1861.

Title: Media as an organizing tool: The use of film and video in social movements
Abstract: Not enough consideration has been given to the growing use of media resources by social movements. There is an abundance of interest in the impact of popular culture on social and political activity, but too little concern about the impact of media at the grassroots level. Certain questions related to the social psychology of the media experience--how media affects people, how the political system relates to media--have typically been too narrow in scope. This study looks at some of the ways that social movements use media--primarily film and video--in their work. It will focus on organizing more than publicity, local efforts more than national or international efforts, distribution more than production, particularly non-theatrical and non-broadcast dissemination more than traditional forms of distribution. Three historical periods of media activism are considered: the 1930s, focusing on the work of media pioneers like the Film and Photo League; the 1960s (and early 1970s), with emphasis on the radical film group Newsreel; the 1980s, emphasizing three social movements--dealing with housing, labor, and the environment--and some of the innovative developments in media technology--notably public access cable television. In all these cases, emphasis is on the targeted use of media--"narrowcasting"--in the context of social movement organizing. That means that impact is considered in relation to the quality of the viewing experience rather than the quantity of viewers. This study seeks to draw comparative/historical and theoretical conclusions from the data. First, there is an analysis of the practical implications of grassroots media use. In particular, relationships between the actors--media producers and media users--are considered. Finally, there is an attempt to identify key theoretical and empirical issues related to communications studies, social movements analysis and media criticism. A primary conclusion of this study is that the use of media by social movements at the grassroots level--one which emphasizes the quality and context of the viewing experience--offers new possibilities for democratic communication and participatory democracy.

Title: The Restoration's social origins
Abstract: This doctoral thesis discusses the restoring process which culminated in the coup d'etat that took place in December 1874. It sets forth the 1868 Revolution as a movement which displaced the bourgeoisie from the power spheres and analyzes the range and nature of the revolutionary phenomenon. It outlines, in turn, the popular forces' character which incited them. It tackles the unfavourable repercussion in the political and economical situation prevailing within the Valencian bourgeoisie, subjected to the appearance of a working class upheaval organized at an international level, conditioned in its colonial projection by reforms intended for Cuba and by the war developing in that island, and pressed by a very strict fiscal system against territorial properties, both through a real contributive burden and the new tax collectors' characteristic. The thesis investigates the interests which define this class and the conflicts accruing from their production relations: social matters, the colonial slavery supporter, and the agrarian reforms as to the conditional factors of the six-year period. As far as these three aspects are concerned work makes clear: (1) The formation of a working class movement independent from republicanism and its first trade-union experiences, reinterpreting the line of the First International one in Spain. (2) The Valencian colonial dimension on the Hispano-ultramarine context, giving particular attention to the controversial abolition of slavery and to the functioning of the pro-slavery colonial system. (3) The study is finally orientated towards the Valencia Proprietors' League configuration and its province which brought together agrarian, financial, industrial and colonial interests. It was an essential instrument for the mobilization, contributing to the instability of the democratic regime and led the Alphonsine conspiracy to the Restoration and reestablishment of the social bloc displaced by the Glorious Revolution.

Title: Equipo Cronica: Chronicle of team work (1964-1981)
Abstract: This study analyses the work and artistic trajectory of the Equipo Cronica, made up of Rafael Solbes and Manolo Valdes, and, for a short period, Juan Antonio Toledo, which was founded in Valencia in 1964 and dissolved in 1981, following the death of the aforementioned member. The object of study has been placed within its historical context, beginning with a concise examination of the artistic panorama during the Twentieth Century both in Spain and abroad. Secondly, the realist movements of the present century are reviewed in order to understand the aesthetic path followed by the Equipo Cronica from the start. After that, the focus is back on Spain and the existing continua between avant-garde art prior to the Civil War and its recovery in the fifties, when the international trends burst into our pictorial scene. In response to Informalism, "Estampa Popular" was then born, a movement circumscribed to the art of engravings involved in the social and political circumstances of the time. Within this movement emerged "Estampa Popular de Valencia", which had some characteristics of its own. The Equipo Cronica was formed in its bosom, aiming at, namely, approaching certain subjects in a thoughtful manner from the field of painting. At that time, some critics put it within the "Cronica de la Realidad" trend. We then discuss the main characteristics of style and the ideology of the said team work, and, finally, speak of its work, establishing serial groups such as its members conceived it. This study also includes a catalogue with the whole production of the Equipo Cronica, in its several sides, from 1964 until 1982. The reason for the adoption of this latter date is due to the fact that some series sculptures called "multiples" were still being finished. This study purports to be an exhaustive and necessary work of research on the most important and long-lasting team work of Spanish painting, which is also one of the most serious and interesting contributions made by Realism to Twentieth Century international painting.

Title: The Golden Fly. The Scandinavian Social Democracy's relations to the Icelandic labour movement in 1916-1956: Internationalism or intervention?
Abstract: The main subject of this dissertation is the development of foreign relations of the Icelandic Social Democracy and the Federation of Labour in the period, 1916-1956. From the foundation of The Icelandic Federation of Labour in 1916, there were considerable contacts between Icelandic Social Democrats and their Danish comrades. These contacts--which later became more international as the Scandinavian Social Democrats, the Second International and ICFTU became involved--were, for the most part, in one direction only. They did not consist of mutual help between the Nordic Social Democrats with equal involvement of the Icelandic Social Democrats. The Icelandic Labour party was generally the recipient of aid from foreign political comrades. The main questions are: Was the political and social development in Iceland in some way influenced by the one-sided relation such as the split within the labour movement or the structure of The Icelandic Federation of Labour? How much economic assistance did the party receive from abroad? Did the financial aid have any influence on the direction taken by the party leadership? Did the aid lead to the sort of results that the foreign supporters had intended? Were the foreign aids solely financial in their nature? Was the support just fraternal help provided in the internationalist spirit of the labour movement or were there ulterior motives? In brief: This research brings to light the fact that Icelandic Social Democrats enjoyed considerable help from their foreign comrades during the period, 1918-1956 and among other things often received significant financial support from them. These facts raise the question whether is is not more correct to say that support from Scandinavian Social Democrats was given in the spirit of Social Democratic internationalism rather than in the spirit of some vague internationalism of the labour movement?

Title: Colombian educational policy, 1978-1986
Abstract: The purpose of this work is to analyse the development of educational policy within the state's structure and economic policy in the period 1978-1986. The starting point is the cycle's theory and the capitalist economy's behaviour, going on to studying economic growth from the point of view of industrial expansion, the political situation and development plans. It is necessary to understand different aspects to talk about the education movement in all its different sides and to answer three main questions: Is the incongruity between economic growth and educational policy due to the relationship that exists between an increase in economic growth and an increase in social welfare? Are the changes in education (diversification and technification) the result of economic growth? Up to what extent do the multiple changes that took place in this period (World economic crisis, the neoliberal model and the predominance of financial capital) affect educational policy? Those and other questions compelled us to take this work from an economic and social point of view. There are two crucial moments in this century: First, a social conception of education as a result of a democratization during Lopez Pumarejo's term of office. Second, the education planning that shows the necessity to structure, organize and plan educational policy according to the interests of the international capital. All of this began about the middle of this century with Currie and Lebret's diagnosis studies which asked for a diversification and technification of education to increase productivity. This strategy was revised at the beginning of the 70s according to this idea: Education is an investment, so it should be profitable for the state or the capital invested in it. This is a financial conception. They agree in a rationalization of the social expenses whenever increasing productivity.

Title: Explaining international movements: A study of global activism among the world's indigenous peoples
Abstract: The estimated 300 million indigenous people of the world are, according to indigenous representatives to a 1974 world conference, distinct ethno-cultural groups descended from aboriginal, pre-colonial inhabitants of an area who do not now control their own political destiny. The movement to internationalize concern for their survival draws attention to a broader pattern of dominance by western political and economic institutional actors and the marginalization of nonwestern peoples and cultures. As "conquered" peoples, indigenous groups are among the most vulnerable. This pattern of dominance is not only physically destructive, but also frustrates basic human needs for recognition, positive group identity, and self-esteem, leading to profound social-psychological alienation and a host of attendant social problems. The questions raised by these developments center fundamentally on the relationship between subjugated peoples and the state on a global scale. Part of the problem, I conclude, is that the boundaries of ethnic identity have served to define a core moral community, which, when channelled into state-building activity, produces institutionalized patterns of dominance and subjection parallel to the boundaries of ethnic identity. Dominant ethnic groups will regard members of their own group with moral preference, leaving non-dominant groups vulnerable to the destructive force of moral exclusion at worst, and second-class political and economic status at best. In order to rectify this situation, the state, and the community of states must redefine the basis of moral community by expanding its boundaries through the promotion of legal protections, including cultural, social, economic and political rights given the force of national and international legal recognition. Through a series of international conferences, and by appealing directly to international institutions, indigenous activists are cultivating increasing support for such a program of legal protection. I analyze these developments from the perspective of an international movement directed toward the normative basis of an international political community. To account for normative global movements, which might also include the anti-slavery activism of the nineteenth century, or recent efforts by environmental and peace groups, I develop a "world society" model of international politics.

Title: Organization and mobilization in modern American peace campaigns
Abstract: This thesis examines the organizational contribution to the rise, course, decline, and legacies of the three major peacetime campaigns of the modern (post-WWI) American peace movement: the Emergency Peace Campaign (1936-1937) which promoted neutrality and international economic cooperation on the eve of World War II, the atomic test ban campaign of 1957-1963, and the Nuclear Weapons Freeze Campaign, 1979-1987. To analyze the role of organization in the histories of these campaigns, a framework is developed consisting of three sets of organizational tensions. Each set can be conceived of as managing two potentially incompatible tasks: (1) Building and maintaining a coalition of peace movement groups and other organizations, while establishing a potentially independent campaign organization or set of organizations. (2) Working at the local level to develop community support, while working at the national level to coordinate local activism and focus pressure on national decision-makers. (3) Mobilizing grassroots activism, while recruiting and raising funds to pay professional staff. In a series of case-study chapters, these tensions are shown to have an important impact on each campaign. Rather than leading to the formulation of "iron laws" of organizational development, however, use of this framework shows that a variety of trajectories and outcomes are possible, depending in part on how initial conditions and strategic choices affect the ways in which campaigns manage these tensions. Important trends across the campaigns are found to be a growing emphasis on local work and grassroots mobilization. These developments run counter to previous claims about general trends among social movements towards a national focus and professional forms of organization. Reasons for these apparent counter-trends within the peace movement are discussed. The framework developed and observations made about the nature of campaigns are of potentially broader application, and ideas for further comparative research are put forward.

Title: Investigation of policing policy in relation to 'domestic violence' in London in the 1980s
Abstract: This thesis is an examination of the social construction of the social response to a social problem. The social problem is refered to as 'domestic violence' and the social response refers to the police response. The first chapter of the thesis constructs a theoretical approach grounded in the sociology of knowledge. Drawing on some of the classical sociological literature, the ideas of historians and philosophers of science, political philosophy and current social theory the concept of 'linguistic-authority-structure' is synthesized. Subsequent chapters apply the theoretical framework that this concept implies to illuminate the unfolding history of the issue of domestic violence. The versions of the social problem as they were articulated on different institutional sites (including the Women's Refuge Movement, social science, the law, the police and several others relevant) from the late-1960s to the mid-1980s are traced in the second third and forth chapters. The thesis documents the international trade in information about the issue. Of cenral importance is the importation of a deterrence paradigm emergent from an experimental project conducted by police researchers in Minneapolis, Minnesota. The importation of these ideas was partly instrumental in persuading police policy makers in Great Britain to announce policy changes regarding the policing of doemstic violence. This formation of a paradigmatic police response to domestic violence is located at a historically low ebb in the legitimacy of British Policing. The fifth chapter charts the history of post-war British Policing. Drawing on sociological accounts of operational policing, and the relevant criminological literature, this chapter illuminates the emergent political contestability of the police institution. The sixth chapter shows how, in this context, the policy regarding the policing of domestic violence was generated. Two chapters, seven and eight, are concerned with the actual police response to calls for service regarding interpersonal violence and in particular violence between cohabiting partners. These chapters make use of semi-structured interviews with police officers and an analysis of police paperwork procedures to illuminate police practices with regard to these calls for service. The two remaining chapters continue the historical analysis up to the end of the 1980s.

Title: Alfred O'Rahilly: Social reformer.
Abstract: In this study an attempt has been made to describe Alfred O'Rahilly's role as a social reformer during a period of some forty years. During that time his commitment to social justice and his conviction of how that could best be achieved remained unchanged. For him the social teaching of the papal encyclicals was the only viable alternative to the extremes of capitalism, fascism and Marxism. O'Rahilly was not content merely to disseminate as widely as possible a knowledge of the social teaching which he considered could be the leaven of a just society. He attempted to persuade the influential Society of St Vincent de Paul to become actively involved in its implementation. Later he sought more successfully to have it implemented as an arbitrator in industrial disputes over some thirty years. As a delegate to the International Labour Conferences in Geneva in 1925, 1926 and 1932, his remarkable contributions in support of progressive labour legislation were inspired by the same motive. His obvious sincerity in the pursuit of social justice enabled him to have an extraordinary influence over many workers and their leaders. This he used to ensure that Irish Labour was represented by a party led by social democrats. To this end he led a sharp anti-communist crusade in 1940-42. O'Rahilly's commitment to Catholic social theory made him a powerful and insistent advocate of denominational education at primary, secondary and tertiary level. It also prompted him to be indefatigable in his support of Muintir na Tire, Macra na Feirme and Bantracht na Tuatha which he regarded as essential champions of the local community. Historians describe the attempt to organise the institutions of the State in accordance with Catholic social principles as integralism. O'Rahilly was one of the most important figures in this movement. He would have been proud to have been regarded as such.

Title: The rise and demise of third worldism with special reference to algeria
Abstract: This dissertation discusses the evolution of third worldism, an ideology shared by Third World political movements, independent states, and observers in both the developed and underdeveloped world. At the center of this ideology is an ethos of historical progress, a mystique of the popular will, and a cult of the centralized state. The demise of third worldism has led in recent years to the view that it was an alien ideology grafted upon ill-adapted social structures and espoused by Third World leaders simply as an instrument of domination. The present work offers a different interpretation. It is argued that the rise and decline of ideologies can be accounted for mainly by domestic social change in the context of international transformations and more subtle adjustments in political perspectives. Thus the emergence of third worldism in the period following the Second World War and its subsequent demise need to be explained in terms of an interaction between indigenous social structures, confrontation with the outside world, and shifting intellectual paradigms. To illustrate this thesis, the present work draws on the case of Algeria, although several of the arguments could also apply to other revolutionary countries of the Third World. Part I describes the historical origins of Algeria's third worldism. By analyzing the discourse and practice of the nation's early national movements, the wartime F.L.N. and the independent state, it sets out to clarify how the ideology of third worldism was reiterated and reinforced. Whilst the central tenets of this ideology first emerged in the West, the channels of its penetration in Algeria were primarily Algerian. This account hopes to explain the present evolution of the Algerian state and society. As Part II purports to show, specific economic, political and international factors can account for the de-legitimation of third worldism as an interpretive lens and a principle of political organization. As a result of these developments, the Algerian regime, opposition movements and observers have gradually turned to different ideological assumptions. The mythology of historical progress, reification of the unanimous `people,' and celebration of the messianic, providential state have been victims of the post-third worldist outlook.

Title: An investigation of policing policy in relation to `domestic violence' in London in the 1980s.
Abstract: The thesis is an examination of the social construction of the social response to a social problem. The social problem is referred to as `domestic violence' and the social response refers to the police response. The first chapter of the thesis constructs a theoretical approach grounded in the sociology of knowledge. Drawing on some of the classical sociological literature, the ideas of historians and philosophers of science, political philosophy and current social theory the concept of linguistic-authority-structures is synthesized. Subsequent chapters apply this concept to illuminate the unfolding history of the issue of domestic violence. The versions of the social problem as they were articulated on different institutional sites (including the Women's Refuge Movement, social science, the law, the police and several others relevant) from the late-1960s to the mid-1980s are traced in the second third and fourth chapter. The thesis documents the international trade in information about the issue. Of central importance is the importation of a deterrence paradigm emergent from an experimental project conducted by police researchers in Minneapolis, Minnesota. The importation of these ideas was partly instrumental in persuading police policy makers in Great Britain to announce policy changes regarding the policing of domestic violence. This formation of a paradigmatic police response to domestic violence is located at a historically low ebb in the legitimacy of British Policing. The fifth chapter charts the history of post-war British Policing. Drawing on sociological accounts of operational policing, and the relevant criminological literature this chapter illuminates the emergent political contestability of the police institution. The sixth chapter shows how, in this context, the policy regarding the policing of domestic violence was generated.

Title: Region and power: The contested terrains of nature, race, gender, and class in Totonacapan, Gulf Coast, Mexico, 1492-1992
Abstract: My dissertation examines the historical dynamics of regional social relations--the intersections of nature/race/gender/class--on Mexico's tropical Gulf Coast, with emphasis on the social and ecological consequences of 20th century petroleum development for Totonac-speaking people. The analysis foregrounds global and regional regimes of power within which households, gendered and racialized persons, and classes attempt to maneuver. I treat the spatial units of analysis--region, community, household--as problematics rather than fixed entities, locales both embedding and determined by social relations. Using a multi-method approach of ethnographic fieldwork, collection of local documents, household surveys, archival and secondary historical research, I explore the discursive and material practices that have positioned indigenous people as subaltern in a specific historical space. Simultaneously, I bring to light the suppressed narratives of Totonac-speakers who (re)construct themselves as social agents, historical subjects. More concretely, I examine the modalities by which women and men who identify themselves as "Totonac" carve out a "lived-space" and negotiate social and environmental relationships in daily confrontation with the structural changes brought about by colonization, dependent development, and a regional oil boom. My thesis supports the hypotheses that the social costs of regional "development" are unequally distributed, and that local consequences include (1) increased social inequality along the axes of class, gender and race, (2) a crisis condition which threatens the reproductive capacities of pre-existing communities and peasant households, (3) deterioration in the human rights accorded indigenous populations, (4) socioeconomic change that endangers ecosystems in tropical regions. Furthermore, these negative consequences and social costs engender historically specific rural and urban social movements which (1) are simultaneously cultural and ecological movements, (2) affect the utilization of "nature"--resources and land--on a local level, (3) constitute new "social subjects," including indigenous women, who raise personal and political claims based on conditions that affect them daily. Rather than viewing indigenous peasant social movements and women's practices as "defence of tradition," I re-evaluate them as multiple, long-term, and tenacious contestations in domains of culture, economy, and the social. From this perspective, they have been pro-active efforts to safeguard conditions for the reproduction of life. At specific historical conjunctures, everyday forms of resistance culminated in large-scale insurrections--yet, even when they remain "socially invisible," microprotests constitute anonymous resistance, subtle tactics operating in the fields of power of the local situation.

Title: The 1980s educational reform movement in England
Abstract: This dissertation applies world systems analysis at the macro and micro analytical level to the recent reforms in Education in England. Using the educational research approach found in Comparative Education especially in the work by Altbach et al., the dissertation provides a case study of the recent reform movement which has international implications. As a case study of reform within the perspective, it uses analysis at the level of the state and the economy and applies the conceptual framework in order to understand the collective actions expressed by those involved. It analyzes why and how specific national and international events influenced the reform movement in a historically informed context. This study of conservative ideology points to a return to a pre-welfare condition in the modern British state. The theoretical work relating social relations at the level of the school relates the effects of reform to the likely consequences of the attack on educational opportunity within the state educational system. A closer examination reveals the movement away from comprehensive education or common school to a more divisive schooling within society. Vocational programs are seen as a result of this ideology and the impact of reform on the curriculum has been a focus of the analysis. The policy implication has been to identify a minimal provision for the curriculum at the state level with greater control by central government in order to exercise political aims. The findings of this study indicate at the micro and macro analytical level that the policy developed by the different private research institutes or think tanks has restricted provision for education in favor of the elites. The potential for this type of policy analysis in the Comparative Educational perspective or world systems analysis shows that social stratification will be affected by the reforms. There appears to be a lack of response on behalf of those adversely affected by the reforms in terms of political representation. This is understood as a time lag question. Time will have to elapse in order for the full implications of the change to be assessed. This research indicates that the provision for access to education as a consumer good is a contested political matter more than it has been in the past in British Education. However, it would appear that the system is moving in a direction in relative favor of the economic elites within British society.

Title: Progress and apocalypse: Science and the end of the modern world. (Volumes I and II)
Abstract: Since the 1930s, ecology has helped generate both scientific, religious, and popular prophecies of the collapse of civilization and the extinction of humanity. After World War II, scientists such as William Vogt, Rachel Carson, Barry Commoner, and Paul Ehrlich used the science of ecology to forecast the end of the modern world and the extinction of humanity. I argue that these apocalyptic ecologists are part of a larger social movement that is challenging the social and political structure of the modern world. Ecological apocalyptic scientists are struggling to replace the authority of progress and economic growth with the authority of ecology. Their apocalypticism grew out of the contradiction between technological and industrial progress and modern science's biological understanding of the Earth. These scientist-writers use a shared apocalyptic rhetoric and ecological world view to call for a popular crusade to save nature and humanity. This scientific apocalypticism helped undermine faith in progress and the modern world. By developing a biological history that challenged the human-centered history of the modern world, their writings ignited public opposition to progress. Apocalyptic ecologists helped form a post-war environmental coalition between conservationists, scientists, and an informed public. Using the authority of science and ecology and the threat of the end of the modern world, environmentalists developed a scientific and political critique of modern industrial society. They believed that unless global industrial civilization transformed its understanding and use of the natural world, it would collapse and humanity would be threatened with extinction. Ecological apocalyptics made ecology both a science and politics of human survival.

Title: Power and discourse: Development from the world system to the Philippine uplands
Abstract: Development is a discourse, a social construction consisting of theories and practices which emerged in the context of modernity. Historically, it is a continuation of the Enlightenment project, and the search for a common humanity realized through the deployment of colonization projects and the entrenchment of Economics as a dominant discipline from which intervention into the lives of people is legitimized. As a highly political terrain, it is able to produce subjects, objects, and structures within the rationality of positivist social sciences and the controlling mechanisms of the State. This discourse attained hegemony through moments of subjection, legitimation, and structuration articulated within the domains of an economistic logic. This occurred along various space and time dimensions, as seen in its reproduction not only across geographical spaces--from the world, to the nation state, and to the village--but also along historical time periods. This happened despite the presence of challenges from the radical Marxists and from revisionists within the development school. These challenges are effectively crushed, coopted, or reappropriated to become alternative forms of development. The only opening left to articulate a counter-discourse is to valorize local power/knowledge, the "other" of development, and to constitute new subjects, objects and structures outside the domains of development. In this dissertation, a genealogical and materialist interpretation of development is done to show the dynamics by which the discourse is produced at the global, national, and local arenas. This analysis includes an inquiry into the politics of how the Philippines and its upland societies are invested in a development discourse that emanates from the world system, and how grassroots movements of upland peoples founded on local power/knowledge confront this. It is shown that upland development, despite attempts to revise its tactics and strategies--seen for example in the emergence of Social Forestry, is always produced as a discourse of control, and that the emergence of resistance in the uplands will always face the risk of being coopted by and recruited into the dominant development discourse.

Title: Systems and social processes of international movement from the Philippines
Abstract: This study examines the relationship of social networks, government policy and economic processes involved in international labor migration from the Philippines. It focuses upon the dynamic characteristics of overseas movement from a small town over the past twenty years in terms of preferred destinations, occupations, and overall potential of households and individuals for economic gains. The research was designed to address the general questions of how individuals in the town obtained opportunities for overseas movement, how access to social networks is related to economic gains or losses from such movement, and how this varies over time. The results show that those achieving the greatest gains from overseas movement are those who were able to depart early in the process, were connected to influential social networks, and generally held a higher socioeconomic position in the town. The conclusions suggest that the persistence overseas movement when economic gains have declined steadily is the result of complex social processes operating through diverse links beyond government policy and strictly economic relationships.

Title: An historiographical review of the curriculum and pedagogy of American secondary school history courses in the post-Vietnam era
Abstract: By 1975, history education in American high schools was in a state of crisis. The purpose of this historiographical study was to review the trends and patterns of history curricula and teaching methodology in American secondary schools (9-12) from the post Vietnam era (1975) to the present. Earlier history movements from the Committee of Ten (1893) to the failure of the "new social studies" (1960-1975) were briefly reviewed in order to establish a historical perspective for the crisis of history education that arose by 1975. An in depth review of eight national reports from 1975-1985 highlights the lost identity of history as a field of study. A revival of interest in secondary school history education after 1985 emerged from a re-examination of the rationales for studying history. The establishment of rationales resulted in a global curriculum which emphasized a move away from textbook instruction to using primary and secondary sources, audio-visual materials and historical literature in the teaching of secondary history courses. Based on the review of professional journals, keystone studies, national reports on the status of history/social studies education, and the major history/social studies frameworks; eight recommendations for the continued progress in secondary school history education are made.

Title: On the front burner: How the greenhouse effect entered the public arena of the mass media
Abstract: The nature of how issues become news is examined in the context of the public arenas model of Hilgartner and Bosk. The idea that the mass media constitute an interdependent arena, operating in a reciprocal fashion with other public arenas, is proposed. In the case of the global warming phenomenon, politicians and scientists, as primary sources for the mass media, succeeded in portraying the greenhouse effect as an apocalyptic problem. Processes of group formation in social movements, particularly coalitions in the environmental movement, are examined. The idea of co-advocacy, in which two or more groups exist in equal, if unintentional, pairing is advanced. In the case of the greenhouse effect, the nuclear power industry and the environmental movement existed in co-advocacy roles in defining global warming as a social problem. Groups involved used the drought of 1988 as a dramatic event to focus attention on the greenhouse effect.

Title: The international diffusion and institutionalization of the new Entrepreneurship Movement: A study in the sociology of organizational knowledge
Abstract: This thesis studies the causes for the popularization in the 1980s of the idea of entrepreneurship in three countries at different stages of economic development: Britain, Mexico, and Spain. It is a dissertation on the social history of ideas--more specifically, on a sociological and comparative history of business ideas. There are two main focuses in the dissertation. The first is the diffusion and reception in these three countries of academic materials and social and ideological inputs regarding entrepreneurship, transmitted from other societies that are traditional exporters of management knowledge and ideologies, especially the United States. The second main focus is the legitimation and institutionalization of entrepreneurship, which includes four processes: (1) those by which entrepreneurship has come to be a part of formal management education, that is, academic research, programs, and courses; (2) those in informal management education (popular business press, works by publicists of managerial ideas) by which entrepreneurs--and not managers--have become the business role-models and heroes of the 1980s; (3) those by which the promotion of entrepreneurship has become a task undertaken by governments of all ideological stances; and (4) those by which the defense of entrepreneurship has become the core of probusiness ideologies in the 1980s. The main argument of the dissertation is that in order to account for the international diffusion and institutionalization of the idea of entrepreneurship in the 1980s, explanations based solely on academic or intellectual merits are insufficient. A framework--constructed from an analysis of the Neo-Institutional School of Organizational Theory and the Sociology of Knowledge and related fields and composed of sociological and economic processes and variables--is posed: economic and political crises affected the interests and motives of producers, carriers, and consumers of administrative knowledge and business ideologies. The reactions of these actors, based on their positions and dispositions and on their cultural and organizational resources, gave the Entrepreneurship Movement in Britain, Mexico, and Spain, its specific intensity and content.

Title: Indigenous movement behavior: The rise and expansion of the Native American Movement
Abstract: There is no question that Native Americans have faced a multitude of crisis since the arrival of the white settlers. Thus, it is not surprising that hundreds of books and articles have been devoted to the topic of Native Americans, and thousands of commentators have offered analysis and insights. Yet little of this work has attempted to adequately assess the conflict between government and Indians generated in the 1960s. The main objective of this work is to theoretically examine the rise and expansion of the movement in hopes of adding the Native American Movement to the social movement literature so that a political discourse may follow. This paper shows that a theoretical explanation of the emergence and development of native insurgency must take into account the unique historical relationship between Native Americans and the US Federal Government as well as the fact that the movement's demands were grounded in the philosophy of being "indigenous". Secondly, this paper illustrates that the basis of the movement was founded on the very idea that Native Americans are culturally distinct and that this distinction should become the focus of an autonomous political power. This distinction separates it from other movements, illustrates the importance of politicized indigenism as a variable when shaping strategies, and in the end generated the heavy government suppression which contributed to the movement's shift into the international arena. Finally, through the use of three models: internal colonialism, political process, and international organizations, and the supporting events data base, collected from the New York Times Index for a 25 year period, I am able to explain the rise and expansion of movement behavior. Overall, the data provides me with an abundance of information on movement activities, issues, targets, and demands. Thus, I was able to trace the rise of the domestic insurgency and the expansion of the conflict into the international community.

Title: The classroom as community: Composition pedagogy and the rise of the technical writing model
Abstract: In recent years, a pedagogical theory has arisen that not only is the teaching of technical writing a question of enculturation but that, more particularly, it is a matter of acclimatization to "the culture of technology." This dissertation is an examination of that hypothesis. Beginning with the model's origins in the work of Carolyn R. Miller, David Dobrin, and D. B. Smith, the study explores, then, both its wider foundations and its effects. First, it traces the origins of the recent shift in philosophical thought, from a referential, foundationalist epistemology to "social justification of belief," because it is this change which has provided the underpinning for a parallel shift in rhetoric, from writing as product (or even as process) to writing as participation and for the related possibilities of a new technical model. The dominant figure is Richard Rorty, who has both chronicled and abetted the change. Second, it looks at social construction's implications for rhetoric, where one is able to view not only the breadth and inter-disciplinary nature of social construction but also the role of this global movement-in-thought in the use of a socially-interactive model for the teaching of technical writing. The central figures are Peter Berger, Thomas Luckmann, Rom Harre, John Shotter, and Clifford Geertz. Then it investigates several theories of "technology as a cultural construct," and offers an overview of recent thinking in the philosophy and sociology of technology. Here the three central figures will be Jacob Bronowski from the philosophy of science and Wiebe Bijker and Trevor Pinch from the sociology of technology. Finally, in the last chapter it examines a socially-interactive technical writing model--a model of "technical writing as enculturation"--as well as the Classical roots in Cicero from which such a model springs. The model itself, which is now in use in the author's own technical writing course, is represented both by that course and by Paul V. Anderson's related social model.

Title: Money, management and manipulation: Environmental mobilization in the Great Lakes Basin
Abstract: This document examines variation in the responses of communities to local pollution problems affecting Great Lakes water quality. The study is based on research conducted at six such communities, at sites that have been designated as "Areas of Concern" by the International Joint Commission. The roles of economic dependency or diversity, access to scientific and political resources, community size, social visibility of pollution, and consciousness- and unconsciousness-making activities are examined as they relate to grass roots political mobilization in response to local, lake-related environmental issues. Of particular interest is the participation of national and regional environmental social movement organizations, Federal, State/Provincial and local governments and local industry. National and regional environmental social movement organizations appear to have a greater mobilizing impact on communities that are closest to the urban centers in which these organizations are based. Federal environmental agency/ministry jurisdiction over a contamination site, conversely, subverts local public participation structures established by State or Provincial agencies/ministries. State and Provincial environmental agencies play a centrist role in promoting minimal remediation. Local governments typically oppose the definition of local environmental disorganization as a problem. Finally, communities whose economies depend largely on a single polluting industry appear subject to a greater degree to the control capacity of private capital interests, and therefore are inhibited from pursuing environmentalists' political demands. Aggregating the six case studies suggests that apparently high levels of Canadian environmentalism may actually represent nationalistic commitments.
