Title: Bertha von Suttner's "Die Waffen nieder!": Moral literature in the tradition of Harriet Beecher Stowe's "Uncle Tom's Cabin"
Abstract: The dissertation evaluates the anti-war novel of the Austrian writer and pacifist Bertha von Suttner. The novel, written in 1889, tells the life story of a young aristocratic woman who becomes convinced of the futility of war through the personal losses she experiences in four successive wars. Suttner was able to capitalize on the popularity of this novel to found the Austrian Peace Society and became a leading spokeswoman for peace through her work in the international peace movement before World War I. Studies of Suttner's role in the peace movement do not assess the merit of Die Waffen nieder! beyond suggesting that it was the "Uncle Tom's Cabin of the peace movement," this comparison first having been suggested by a comment in a letter to Suttner from Leo Tolstoy. To follow up this comparison is the task of this dissertation. Certainly the most important point of comparison is the didactic purpose and moral message of each novel. The first chapter is an introduction to previous assessments of each author. While Stowe's reputation has undergone rehabilitation, Suttner's reception is limited to her historic role and scant attention to her writing. The second chapter discusses each writer's development of her role and her understanding of literature. Similarities are then discussed with reference to Tolstoy's theory of art as it illuminates their conception of literature as an ethical tool. The third chapter discusses Uncle Tom's Cabin as a work of moral suasion that succeeds through its communication of feeling. The fourth chapter evaluates Die Waffen nieder! and its analysis of militarism in Austrian society. The final chapter concludes that both novels have in common critiques of social and political institutions. Their differences lie in scope and form but also in their success as sentimental novels. While Uncle Tom's Cabin succeeds because of its unabashed appeal to feeling, the self-conscious use of sentimentality as a convention detracts from the effectiveness of the substantial criticism in Suttner's Die Waffen nieder!

Title: A nation's sovereignty under siege: The United States in an age of global interdependence
Abstract: Transnational activities have rapidly increased in the postwar period. Such activities challenge basic presuppositions of sovereign nation states. While political scientists have paid much attention to transnational relations' impact on international politics, sociologists have largely ignored the implications of transnational activities for different societies or for sociological analysis itself. In this context, this dissertation studies the impact of transnational activities on the relationship between state and society in the United States. Using the case study method, the impact of transnational activities on the United States are considered along three dimensions: economic, social and ideological. The three case studies are respectively the FSX fighter plane codevelopment arrangement between the United States and Japan, the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 (IRCA), and the sanctuary movement. In the FSX case, the globalization of industrial production strained the tie between the state and American multinationals. In the IRCA case, illegal migration challenged classical understandings of citizenship in the nation state. In the sanctuary case, a movement challenged the very legitimacy of the state as a domestic and international actor. In order to evaluate the impact of transnational activities in each of these areas, the state's ability to regulate the transnational activity is examined. Insofar as the state fails to regulate that transnational activity, it is concluded that a loosening of the relationship between state and society has taken place in that particular instance. The study shows that the state is unable, or has only limited ability, to regulate transnational activities in the economic and social cases. Thus multinationals are becoming increasingly detached from the state and decreasingly identify with the state. The IRCA case demonstrated the limited ability of the state to control transnational (illegal) migration. This has major implications for the meaning and value of citizenship in American society. On the other hand, the sanctuary case illustrates the limits of the transnational challenge to the state. Ideological challenges to the very legitimacy of the state are successfully confronted. The implications of these results for traditional sociological assumptions are discussed.

Title: Josiah Strong: Practical theologian and social crusader for a global kingdom
Abstract: This study of Josiah Strong (1847-1916) is a theological biography of one of the least researched leaders of the Social Gospel movement. It takes into account both biographical information about Strong, and his published and unpublished writings. It focuses on the development of Strong's thought, particularly his conceptions of the kingdom of God, salvation and the church. His understanding of these doctrines provided the impetus for his career of crusading to announce and to promote the unfolding of the kingdom of God on earth. During his lifetime, Strong moved from a traditional American evangelical understanding of salvation which he later characterized as "individualistic," to a view which insisted upon both personal and social aspects of Christian salvation. This change was largely due to his appropriation of a post-millennial interpretation of biblical apocalypticism, combined with a quite thorough inculcation of social Darwinist teachings on the progress of history. This development in his thought fired Strong with an intense passion to augment the establishment of God's kingdom on earth, first through his activities as General Secretary of the Evangelical Alliance for the United States, then as President of the American Institute for Social Service. Strong's thought and work were influenced by both traditional and more modern currents of thought. His persistent belief in the sovereignty of God in history was melded together with an optimistic view of humanity which enabled him to preach and program for an imminent ideal global society, in accordance with his understanding of God's will. His greatest frustration was the reluctance of the church to accept his message of what was possible on a global scale when divine and human wills were united as one. His views reflected much of his own cultural bias, and the excessive popular optimism which would vanish with the coming of the World Wars and Great Depression. Together with other advocates of the Social Gospel, Strong helped to establish within U.S. Protestantism a renewed and lasting emphasis on the ethical and social implications of the Christian faith, including a stress on Christian cooperation and unity.

Title: The political economy of energy-corporate-urban integration in South Korea
Abstract: This study seeks to explain the institutional basis of the political economy of South Korea and its integration into the global order. Through an investigation of the rise of technological (especially energy), corporate and urban networks under military/state direction, the analysis documents and explains why and how the contemporary South Korean political economy was formed and demonstrates that recent material progress actually leaves the country in a state of dependent development with environmental degradation and social inequality as necessary, even functional, characteristics of this progress. The central thesis of this study is that the rise to power of what I term a centralized, technicized regime (or CTR) has placed the civil society of South Korea in fundamental conflict with the prevailing institutional conditions of national political and economic order. The interconnected network of energy, corporate and urban systems that have formed since the late 19th century serves as the institutional foundation for South Korea's political economy. This network arranges the society and its resources in a definite political-economic structure that at once gives rise to certain social problems such as inequality, environmental degradation and alienation, and shapes the society's search for answers to these problems. Building new energy, industrial and spatial structures compatible with political and economic democracy, cannot be driven by technocratic considerations and the rationalizing norms of conformity and compliance, but by the politically creative energies of a people who place social ends before instrumental means in deciding the shape and structure of the society. A crucial failure of mainstream social thought and practice has been the diversion of creative energies from the development of a critical evaluation of the society's energy-corporate-urban integration. Political conflict will continue because the aims of the CTR and civic society are opposed. Such conflict can only be resolved by the replacement of the CTR with institutions that realize Korean aspirations of political and economic democracy. This study assesses the prospects for democratic change in South Korea. The role of political opposition movements in exposing the conflict between the civil society and the conditions of institutional order is explored, and a proposed reconstruction of Korean politics is outlined. (Abstract shortened with permission of author.)

Title: Supporting civil society: Nongovernmental assistance to Costa Rica and Nicaragua
Abstract: Dominant approaches (whether neo-conservative, liberal, or neo-Marxist) to the growing role of non-governmental organizations in the delivery of development assistance tend to overlook the implicit power relations which shape and restrict NGO action. This dissertation explores this issue by examining the impact of NGOs in the two cases of Nicaragua and Costa Rica. NGOs have potentially important roles to play in the support of economic development and democratization. However, it is argued that the tendency to romanticize the activities of both NGOs and grassroots groups is misleading and dangerous. It is only by uncovering the power relations involved between donors and recipients and within local communities, that the contribution of these forms of organization can be assessed. It is therefore important for both international and domestic actors to develop a better understanding of what NGOs are, how they operate, what motivates their specific approaches, and how they are linked to states and social movements in diverse contexts. The study is set in the theoretical context of the relationship between state and civil society, and the role of NGOs in the development of civil society. For each of the two countries, the development of civil society and the state are examined, followed by a description by the development of NGOs and a discussion of the case studies undertaken in 1988 and 1989. Three NGOs were selected in each country: Catholic Relief Services, OEF International, and the Centro de Capacitacion para el Desarrollo (CECADE) in Costa Rica; and CARE Canada, OXFAM Canada, and the Fundacion Agosto C. Sandino in in Nicaragua. Rural development projects were evaluated and classified on the bases of their divergent approaches to three main themes: strategies for economic development; popular participation; and the role of international agencies in relationship to local actors. Conclusions are based on an analysis of the distinct strategies adopted, observed outcomes, and the perceptions of participants, given the requirements for the advancement of the popular classes within each society and Central America as a whole. While NGO projects are currently most commonly evaluated on the basis of their short-term contribution to the living standards of the poor, it is concluded that the impact of the projects examined was minimal in this respect. Problems were often associated with the inability of NGOs to influence broader national and international forces which are most important in determining the well-being of rural communities. It is argued, however, that the political impact of NGO activities is potentially of greater importance than short-term effects on material conditions. NGOs do not necessarily contribute to the strengthening of civil society vis-a-vis the state. For example, the support by the United States Agency for International Development for NGOs in Central America often leads to merely instrumental forms of participation by beneficiaries in projects, and tends to undermine participation in broader social movements. NGOs are most likely to contribute to long-term democratization if they support both real participation at the grassroots level and the constructing of alliances of subordinate groups seeking to challenge the balance of national political forces in their favour. As well, international NGOs can help create a model for more egalitarian relations between North and South by avoiding paternalism and contributing to the gradual consolidation of an international civil society.

Title: Roles for professional psychology in environmental action: Reframing the dominant social paradigm through ecofeminism and deep ecology
Abstract: This study addresses processes of defining problems and seeking solutions relating to psychology and the global environmental crisis. The purpose of the study was to examine the process of change from the Dominant Social Paradigm (DSP) towards a new paradigm, epitomized by the Deep Ecology and Ecofeminist movements, and to use this analysis to propose roles for professional psychologists related to environmental action. The literature on the DSP was examined and summarized, providing a socio-historical context for the analysis. This study adopted Watzlawick, Weakland and Fisch's (1974) theory of change as a methodological framework to examine the social change process. The concepts of second-order change and reframing were used in examining approaches to defining environmental problems within the DSP, and the deep ecology and ecofeminist movements. The approaches of current environmental movements were summarized, to illustrate their major underlying assumptions, and show how each movement has either remained within or broken from the DSP in attempting "solutions." The literature from the ecofeminist and deep ecology movements was then examined. The assumptions underlying the worldview of each movement were compared and contrasted to the assumptions underlying the DSP, and were found to provide a different model. The approaches of ecofeminism and deep ecology were then examined within the framework of Watzlawick et al.'s theory of change, resulting in the conclusion that they exemplified the principles of the theory and its techniques of second-order change and reframing. This investigation concluded that the concepts of second-order change and reframing can be helpful in defining problems and seeking solutions related to the global environmental crisis. The connections between ecofeminism and deep ecology were elucidated by addressing the processes of their approaches to change, and by acknowledging the positive functions of their differences. The present work of psychologists was reframed, using the views of deep ecology and ecofeminism, and seen as contributing to the solution of the environmental crisis. Expansion of these roles was discussed. Finally, examples were presented using the paradigm of deep ecology and ecofeminism to challenge the assumptions underlying psychologists' work as theorists, educators, community psychologists, and clinicians.

Title: Between art and industry: Design reform in France, 1851-1939. (Volumes I and II)
Abstract: This dissertation examines the origins and development of the design reform movement in France from the time of the Great Exhibition held in London in 1851 to the eve of World War II. In particular it focuses on the notion of a union between art and industry and the way in which this was intertwined with a need to reform the decorative arts, an important source of French cultural prestige and of national revenue. It was thought that union between art and industry could lead to a life of abundance, happiness, and rationality. This ideal underwent many transformations during the period in question, and was finally rejected for pre-industrial values with the economic crisis of the 1930s. Through an analysis of national governmental reforms and of private initiatives, this thesis traces these transformations and attempts to place design movements such as Art Nouveau, Art Deco and International Style functionalism into the social, economic and cultural context in which they developed. It analyzes French Art Nouveau's links to the turn-of-the-century socialist-backed movement for an art social, the Art Deco style's ideological and formal ties to the retour a l'ordre both before and after the First World War, and the return to French craft traditions during the 1930s as a way of reconquering more "humanist" values in the face of the economic and social debacle of the Great Depression. An essential aspect of the design reform movement was the search for a modern, and often, specifically French style. The responses to this research are treated in depth through the work and writings of individuals such as Francis Jourdain, Le Corbusier, Louis Sue and Andre Vera and through a discussion of the organization and salons of design groups such as the Societe des artistes decorateurs and the Union des artistes modernes. France's reaction to German developments in design reform and to the German idea of design modernity is of fundamental importance in this study. Germany became the greatest rival to France in the domain of the decorative arts through powerful organizations such as the Werkstatte and the Werkbund. French designers and critics constantly compared the more "artistic" and more "humanist" approach of French artists to what they perceived as the more mechanistic and strictly commercial qualities of German design. The objective of this study is not only to elucidate the French response to the possibilities offered by the machine to make good design available to a broad public, but also to consider the more general issue of why modern design in France meant something other than the technological ideals that were celebrated in Germany, even when the modernization of design was invested with ideals of social reform.

Title: The business corporation in history: The creation of its legal autonomy and legitimacy at the expense of nature
Abstract: This thesis is a substantive study into the history of the Western business corporation--namely, the English commercial association. The idea of the corporation is explored in the Classical period of Roman Law. The assimilation of this form in Medieval English law and the predominance of particularized commercial associations over municipal and social-religious organizations is also examined. The continuing particularization of the idea of corporation is further revealed in the Tudor Period. At this time, however, there is a strong indication that the corporate form was being universalized conceptually in the legal sphere through the right to grant charters. Its eventual universalization is made evident in the nineteenth century when general incorporation was legitimized by the state. Objectification of the corporation is further discussed within the context of the environmental movement, concluding that the creation of a transnational corporate form can pose some very interesting problems for the environmental movement as they criticize Western anthropocentrism through their own corporate forms. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: Choices and consequences: A cross-national evaluation of telecommunication policies in developing countries
Abstract: Telecommunications are increasingly being recognized as critical strategic infrastructure for ensuring the success of national social and economic development plans and programs, improving international competitiveness and integrating domestic economies into the world economy. In an effort to overcome chronic deficiencies in telecommunication performance and distribution of services, many developing countries have been engaged in liberalizing their telecommunication sectors. Liberalization here referring to the movement away from the traditional state-owned monopoly structure and towards the introduction of privatization and competition. This study examines the consequences of these developments by analyzing telecommunication developments in 81 developing countries from 1977 to 1988. The study is in two parts. The first part is theoretical and (a) identifies the technological and economic forces driving change in the sector; (b) reviews the policy options available to developing countries; (c) critically discusses the arguments both for and against the introduction of competition and privatization in the sector; and (d) outlines the importance of governmental commitment to the growth of telecommunications. The second part is empirical and presents the findings of a cross-national longitudinal evaluation of the impact of changes in policies governing sector structure for the supply and manufacture of telecommunications equipment, facilities and services, as well as the impact of governmental commitment, on sector performance and distribution. The evaluation is conducted in the context of the economic factors which are thought to condition the relationship between telecommunication policies and outcomes. It finds that movement toward liberalization has had little independent impact on telecommunications sector performance, but is associated with adverse conditions of access to and availability of services. In contrast, governmental commitment to the growth of the sector is found to be positively related with improvements in both sector performance and distribution at all levels of national income and under different compositions of economic activity. The findings suggest that if sector growth and development are important national priorities then attention should be turned more toward stepping-up government investments rather than towards sector restructuring.

Title: Agrarian relations in nineteenth century Bengal: The faraizi, Indigo and Pabna movements
Abstract: This thesis deals with the faraizi, Indigo, and Pabna peasant movements under one broad framework, and seeks to analyze the fundamental sources of agrarian unrest in nineteenth century Bengal. In specific terms, the grievances expressed by all the movements were: rent enhancement; the forced cultivation of cash crops; and the fluctuation of the prices of these goods in the international market. There were, however, particular elements at work as well, such as the structural changes in the land tenure system of Bengal. Each of the movements protested against these changes, and were not simple uprisings, or spontaneous outbursts of temporary economic discontent; they were reflections of a society that had experienced the adverse impact of colonial rule and should therefore be characterized as social protest movements. The poor peasants were generally affected by the cultivation of cash crops, as encouraged by the colonial rulers, and with this, the fluctuation in the market price. In contrast, though being affected by such fluctuations, the jotedar-ryots, or rich peasants, had the capacity to overcome this temporary economic inconvenience. Initially, the chief beneficiaries of the commercialization of agriculture under the British, they were motivated to protect their interests vis-a-vis other groups which had emerged under colonial rule--the zamindars and the indigo planters. The jotedar-ryots proved to have the requisite organizational skill and economic resources to galvanize all classes of peasants to protest against their adversaries in all these movements.

Title: A house divided: Conflict and cooperation in African American-Jewish relations. (Volumes I and II)
Abstract: This study tries to ascertain the sources of conflict and cooperation in African American-Jewish relations. It examines African American-Jewish contact in various historical periods to determine the structural and ideological processes which shape their relations at given points in time and to determine how and why those processes promote cooperation or conflict between the two groups. The central argument is that, historically, changes in African American-Jewish relations have been precipitated by global and domestic structural transformations which alter the objective relations between and the political consciousness of African Americans and Jews. The study examines African American-Jewish contact from colonial to modern times as well as several case studies of African American-Jewish conflict and cooperation. It analyzes the early and modern Civil Rights movements, the Black Power movement, the 1968 New York teachers' strike, the Middle East conflict, Israeli-South African relations, and affirmative action. Due to its historical focus, the study relies on personal narratives, historical documents, conference proceedings, news coverage, opinion polls, court cases, and secondary accounts, among others sources, for data. The study reveals that race is and always has been a significant factor in African American's relations with Jews. The author argues that African American-Jewish relations must be understood as part of a tripartite system of racial domination in which Jews occupy an intermediary status position between African Americans and white Gentiles. She finds that historically the structurally generated narrowing or expansion of social distances between these three groups has variously induced African Americans and Jews to view each other as competitors, enemies, or allies. This system of domination is affected when domestic or international structural changes encroach upon or alter the relative statuses, power, interests, social and material resources, and political consciousness of African Americans and Jews. The author concludes that it is the competitive positioning in a contest for political and economic power and resources that is largely circumscribed by race which contributes to most of the conflicts between African Americans and Jews and which fostered the unusual cooperation between the two groups in the Civil Rights movement.

Title: In good taste and wholesome for society: On Handarbetets Vanner and the Swedish hemslojd movement
Abstract: Foreningen Handarbetets Vanner, HV was founded in 1874 by 20 women of aristocratic and upper middle-class birth to promote Swedish textile handcrafts in the home. The Swedish hemslojd movement consists of some 50 handicraft associations developed during the 20th century to promote handicrafts. Activities, in which women have been predominant, include production in workshops and in the home, sale of patterns, materials and handcraft products, and consultancy work. Recently these associations have become less profitable; several shops have had to give up. The aim of this thesis is to analyse, describe and explain the background to these difficulties and conflicts. HV is described against a background of economic and political interest in supporting cottage/rural industries in the predominantly agrarian Swedish society c. 1870. The thesis deals with this by using reports and analyses of contemporary debates and resolutions passed in the Swedish Parliament. HV linked the current international renewal of design and home-furnishings with economic and political objectives, and also became part of the women's emancipation movement. They employed women designers, weavers, etc. HV's early production concentrated on the home and also gave women at home the chance to make their own textile furnishings. HV also organised the training of weaving teachers. Foreningen for Svensk Hemslojd was started in Stockholm in 1899 to improve the products of the rural/cottage industries and make marketing easier. Handicraft associations' activity went into improving craft products by renewal based on traditional Swedish folk designs. They followed the ideas of HV. "Hemslojd" is regarded by authorities as an economic and political instrument, while those actually involved look to its concrete results and products. By using the theories of Michelle Zimbalist Rosaldo et al. about separate male and female spheres and patterns of socialisation and Ulrike Prokop's theory about the life patterns of women, the author is able to explain this dichotomy. By using cultural analysis, the author shows how these activities are dominated by middle-class values. An examination is made of the success of HV and the handicraft associations with a growing middle class during the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Pierre Bourdieu's model is used, showing how lifestyles and taste relate to each other and to the social space where different groups in society act out their lives. The circumstances uncovered by this thesis, then, have contributed to the present difficulties and dilemmas within the Swedish handicraft association movement.

Title: Mistresses of their own destiny? A study of women's educational experiences at the Coady International Institute
Abstract: The general objective of this thesis is to examine within the context of feminist theories of women and development the inclusiveness of women and effectiveness for women of the Diploma Program in Social Development of the Coady International Institute, Antigonish, Nova Scotia. As a leadership and development training centre, the Coady International Institute (CII) is mandated to support Third World organizations engaged in social development by providing training opportunities for their leaders or staff. Based on the teachings and development philosophy of the Antigonish Movement, the CII is a unique Canadian educational institution that promotes social change through the empowerment of disadvantaged groups. The target learner population comprises adults working for indigeneous development agencies throughout the Third World. My interest in this subject and institution is prompted by my personal background and experiences. I am a Nova Scotian who graduated from the CII Diploma Program in Social Development in 1983. I have worked in both formal and non-formal education and development in west and southern Africa and have worked with Canadian non-governmental development organizations in Nova Scotia and New Brunswick. My interest in this research arises out of my academic background in feminist studies and my experience of development issues, particularly as they pertain to the situation and empowerment of women.

Title: The British labour movement and Israel: 1948-1951
Abstract: This thesis examines the attitudes of the British labour movement towards the fledgling state of Israel, commencing with the termination of the British mandatory administration in May 1948, and ending with the electoral defeat of the British Labour Government in October 1951. Emphasis is placed on the social, political and economic factors which determined the thought and actions of the various elements of which the labour movement was comprised. The question of relations with Israel are put into the context of the British position in the Middle East in the aftermath of the Second World War. Domestic considerations and the international climate of the post-war world are also discussed. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: Charles-Francois Cheve and French Christian Socialism in mid-nineteenth century
Abstract: This biography of Charles-Francois Cheve depicts the life and ideas of a "stormy petrel" of the Left against the turbulent background of France: 1813-1875. Using vital, notorial, and ecclesiastical records, studies of Paris, histories of social class, of education, and of psychological development, the study initially probes Cheve's evolution as a republican who "leaped into the ring" during the July Revolution in Paris, assisted Belgians and Poles in their battles for independence, and was arrested and tried for conspiracy against the July Monarchy. In these republican circles Cheve encountered the "jacobin-Catholic," former Saint-Simonian, Philippe Buchez, whose ideal of a renewed and progressive Christianity coincided with that of young Liberal Catholics, leaderless after Lamennais' excommunication. As a consequence of these associations Cheve converted to Catholicism in the late 1830s and dedicated his life to a Saint-Simonian "priesthood" of activism and education through the press. Biographies and general histories interweave with analyses of Cheve's writings from 1840 through the 1870s to establish the major themes and developments of Cheve's Christian-Social thought to embrace communism and mysticism. The focus, successively, is on his collaboration with Lacordaire in the re-establishment of the Dominican Order, with Montalembert on the freedom of education issue as editor of a Catholic journal in Dijon and Nantes during the 1840s, his work with Proudhon in Paris on the radical journal Le Peuple and successors to 1851, his time with Abbe Migne at Ateliers Catholiques under the repression of the Second Empire, and his subsequent co-editing of Catholic journals with Francois Beslay in the late 1860s, as well as on his independent writings. Cheve died in 1875, aged sixty-two, having seen the realization of many of his goals under the Third Republic. The legacy of his writing was known to a new generation of Christian Democrats in the 1890s, proving that Christian Socialism was an influential part of the Left throughout the nineteenth century. The study concludes that Christian Socialist ideas have also strongly influenced movements for social reform and international unity in post-World War II Europe.

Title: West Indian migration to Brazil
Abstract: This thesis deals with the migratory movement of labor from West Indies to Brazil from 1907 to 1912. The construction of the Madeira-Mamore railway between the Brazilian border with Bolivia accounts for this migratory flow. The main questions aim to clarify: (a) the interconnections between international capital and West Indian migration to Brazil; (b) the role of the state and private enterprises in the consolidation of the international capitalism through the legal codes of emigration and immigration; and (c) how racial division of labor is placed within this context. The major findings coming out of this research attest: (a) the state as unit of the broader world economic system regulates the flow, direction and size of spatial movement of labor through immigration laws; (b) racial division of labor emerges as a mechanism of social control; and (c) despite structural determinants workers act on their own behalf.

Title: Reason and resolution: Strategic and social rationality in resolving prisoner's dilemmas
Abstract: This thesis argues that the conventional game theory and social functionalist Prisoner's Dilemma (PD) resolutions are inadequate for understanding such processes and even laboratory games based on the PD. The resolutions assume agents or states in PDs are isolated individuals, rather than social beings facing each other in the context of a pre-existent relationship which they sustain or redefine through their actions. Their interactions and sequential actions are better reconstructed as dramas in which a social unit struggles and changes or as a process of coming to (or failing) agreement. Agents exercise both strategic and social rationality in experimental and empirical PD and SPD games. However, many agents bring to these games a rationality beyond strategic calculation or norm following. Their comments and the history of outcomes, allow us to reconstruct many SPDs as dramas, highlighting social conflict and order, as they generate phases and rhetoric of mutual cooperation, mutual defection and unilateral actions. The movement is stimulated by choices which an agent interprets as a breach of the presupposed relationship and the agent's subsequent search for a more appropriate one. Dramatic action thus redefines social rationality as a competence in defining situations, taking appropriate roles and improvising or changing roles when expectations generated by the definitions fail. The SPDs can also be reconstructed as processes of coming to agreement, with choices functioning as speech acts, particularly assertions or commissives. These choices carry claims for appropriate responses, which the other can however refuse or challenge. In this context, rational action is communicative action. This notion helps explain why many SPDs are resolved by the feeling of players that cooperation is "doing the right thing". But some players' arguments for their individual choices are strategic, justified by their anticipated success, rather than being oriented toward understanding the other and supporting her cooperation. As heuristics the SPD reconstructions provide much richer insights into international processes than given by the strategic and social normative approaches. These reconstructions help explain (a) the sense of dramatic development in international relations; (b) a social dimension and associated rules that is implied by the use of action as communication. (Copies available exclusively from MIT Libraries, Rm. 14-0551, Cambridge, MA 02139-4307. Ph. 617-253-5668; Fax 617-253-1690.) (Abstract shortened with permission of school.)

Title: Hegemony, counter-hegemony and peripheral societies: new approaches to international relations theory.
Abstract: The thesis is the development of a new approach to the analysis of international relations based upon the rejection of the liberal notion of the state as the basic unit of international relations theory, and the articulation of a concept of the state-society complex which emphasises the economic and ideological unity of a single world system. After an extended theoretical exposition of the expansion of the world capitalist system and the analysis of the Gramscian theory of the state and ideology, these two trends of thought are brought together to explain the organic crisis of peripheral states. The central working premiss of the thesis is that the domestic-international dichotomy is invalid and misleading to explanations of international relations, and that instead there is a continuum of activity which spreads from the local to the global environment. This continuum is expressed most consistently through ideology and class relations. Using Gramsci's theory of hegemony in the context of the development of El Salvador, particularly over the last two decades, the thesis seeks to demonstrate the strength and impact of such continuities. Any social theory must be capable of giving an account of change and transformation, and this is articulated in the concept of counter-hegemony (also developed from the work of Antonio Gramsci) and demonstrated through a study of the challenge of subaltern movements in El Salvador. The organic crisis of the state in El Salvador is interpreted as being of both structural economic derivation (location in the world economy, the nature of dependency, failure of domestic accumulation) and the inability to carry out a hegemonic project, these being consequences of the peripheral status. Throughout the thesis the relationship between economic and ideological order is maintained as the focal point of analysis, and the principal avenue of continuity between global and local forces.

Title: Lobbying the League: women's international organizations and the League of Nations.
Abstract: This thesis is an account of women's international work at the League of Nations. While feminists' shift from the national to the international arena has been noted in studies on the inter-war women's movement, most often it has been interpreted as a reflection of the heightened salience of peace work in the aftermath of the First World War. This is an important observation but it overlooks the fact that women's activities at the League embraced the full spectrum of feminist causes: social reform, women's rights and peace. This thesis gives prominence to inter-war feminist activity played against the backdrop of institutional developments at the League which encouraged women to believe their goals could be advanced under its auspices. One of the major goals of the Women's International Organizations was to establish a political role for women in international affairs. The first chapter describes the efforts of women's organizations to secure the representation of women in the League of Nations. Many recently enfranchised women in Europe and North America identified the League as an institution toward which they should direct their newly won political influence. This is assessed in the context of ideas that emerged in the aftermath of the First World War about the transformation of the international sphere through the infusion of female values. The second, third and fourth chapters present a profile of the women's networks operating in and around the League. The study reveals a high level of interaction between the Women's International Organizations and women in official positions at the League. Chapter 2 examines the aims of the Women's International Organizations and exposes tensions between social feminist and equal rights feminist organizations that led to a struggle for influence at the League. The third and fourth chapters assess the impact of gender-stereotyping on patterns of appointments to the League. However much appointments to Assembly delegations and League advisory committees should have carried with them national allegiances, women delegates were often seen to represent women and this both positively and negatively affected women's participation. The remaining chapters assess women's impact on the development of League activities with particular attention to the implications of the idea that women as women had a special contribution to make at the international level.

Title: The Middle East in China's united front calculations, 1957-58
Abstract: The study examines the Chinese leadership's assessment of events in the Middle East in 1957-8, with reference to its line over Socialist Camp support for popular movements in response to US intervention. Addressing Chinese categorisation of forces in world politics, it argues that this period was crucial in interpreting the changing role of the developing countries from an intermediate zone between two camps into the main progressive force. Events in the area were seen as a historical turning point, the focus being regional trials of strength in opposition to US intervention. In this connection, different levels of conflict analysis are explored. The study considers the foreign policy dilemma of uniting 'from above' with regional regimes or 'from below' with mass movements, the theme of historic links with the Arabs as a precursor of 'third world' solidarity, and China's direct contacts with the area, including a detailed study of relations with Yemen as an early instance of 'South-South' co-operation. While Arab nationalism was applauded, the attitude to Nasserism was cool, and Islam very much downplayed. A survey of articles by Chinese specialists pinpoints differing trends in the analysis of social conditions in Arab states, particularly post-revolutionary Iraq. Against the background of China's Great Leap Forward, links between radicalism in domestic and foreign policy spheres are examined, including the nation-wide mass demonstrations, an unprecedented experiment in domestic social mobilisation on an international issue. This provides a context for the decision to bombard Nationalist-held offshore islands. The study casts light on the issue of periodization in Chinese foreign policy, illustrates the origin of important themes which were to resurface in the Sino-Soviet polemic, and reflects problems confronting a radical actor having to adapt previously-held models to major changes in both domestic and international environments.

Title: Collective dissent in Mexico: The politics of contemporary urban popular movements
Abstract: This study examines the role of urban popular movements in the political and economic crisis that Mexico experienced during the 1980s. In an era of political transition from authoritarian to democratic regimes, in which social movements play a key role, Mexico along with China stands out as a major exception. This study provides a framework for understanding why the Mexican regime has been able to persist while others have failed. It does this by examining the relationships between social movements (with special reference to two detailed case studies of urban popular movements), political parties, and the state with reference to the international environment. The theoretical and methodological approach is developed primarily in reference to what has been christened the political process model. Tools, insights, and biases from new social movement theory and the historical-structural approach have also been incorporated into a synthetic interpretive framework. The time period examined here is 1979-1991, during which a cycle of protest emerged, prospered, and declined. This study describes and analyzes the contours of the most impressive challenge to the Mexican inclusionary authoritarian regime since its institutionalization during the 1930s. It is argued here that while economics was important at all stages of the protest cycle, politics played a determining role. The severity of the regime's crisis was exacerbated by policies taken by the de la Madrid administration (1982-1988), as well as in the way in which they were implemented. Likewise, the political recovery of 1989-1991, during which the regime regained some modicum of stability and legitimacy lost during the 1982-1988 period, was dependent upon the effective political management of the Salinas administration (1988-1994). Similarly, the rise and years of oppositional momentum were made possible by an increasing willingness by previously disparate political organizations to make alliances, by the emergence of new and powerful oppositional organizations, and by an increased willingness on the part of Mexican civil society to participate in forms of political action that undermined the regime. The cycle's decline has been characterized by a decreased willingness to participate in such actions and by deep and consequential divisions within the opposition that have made a multi-class oppositional alliance structure unlikely, at least for the short term.

Title: Bombard the headquarters: Local politics and citizen participation in the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution and the 1989 Movement in Shenyang
Abstract: This dissertation is a political history of the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution (GPCR) and the 1989 Movement in the Chinese city of Shenyang. Research on the GPCR was carried out using primary and secondary documentary sources and interviews with Shenyang citizens. Research on the 1989 Movement involved direct observation, the collection of documents from the "democracy walls," and conversations with participants. Several general arguments about social movements in the PRC are made: (1) In order to genuinely understand these movements, scholars must take into account the active participation of citizens in both movements, and must pay more attention to the political issues motivating the movement; and (2) PRC politics is a complex web of center and local politics, which together create the whole of national politics. Misunderstanding social movements infects explanations of the decline of communist systems, leading many to hail the decline of communism in the world through the emergence of "civil society" and to forecast the same fate for China, without realizing that the movements of the 1980s had their roots in earlier movements and may not signal a rise of a new civil society opposed to the state. Instead, the movements of the 1980s must be seen as part of a continuous thread of political debates occurring throughout the twentieth century in China. For example, participation in the twentieth century movements has influenced how citizens view politics: a shift in Chinese political culture altering the nature of the demands citizens make of their political system, and the methods used in translating political ideas into political activism. Although many of the issues debated in the two movements were the same, the 1989 Movement was not just a replay of the GPCR. Involvement in each movement introduced citizens to new ideas and to a new understanding of their role in politics. In the 1989 Movement, citizens were increasingly influenced by the new international language of human rights--just as earlier Chinese political thinkers and activists were influenced by ideas of democracy and political rights in the early part of the twentieth century.

Title: Intricate channels of resemblance: Albert Pinkham Ryder and the politics of colorism
Abstract: Colorism, as practised by Albert Pinkham Ryder and Walt Whitman, and critiqued by Charles de Kay and Charlotte Adams, functioned for late-nineteenth-century American art audiences with much the same force as Impressionism did for a French art public at the same time. But, to this day colorism is rarely recognized as a movement or phenomenon particular to art practice in the United States between 1873 and 1913. The purpose of this thesis has been to recover the force of recognition accorded the colorist work, and its discursive forms: apprehension, suppression, and revision. Colorist culture was an ideological expression devoted to the innovative and "modern", but along shifting and often conservative lines, committed to sifting received thought, from Paris, perhaps, for its most radical forms and reshaping them as "native" or "American." Origins were of the utmost importance to this culture and it was able to reconstrue most any attractive mode of representation of ideological symbol to mean something more in line with its own production of self-identity. Accordingly, genteel New York culturati sought ways in which to value colorist works of art, despite the violent "French" force of their illegibility and the broader social implications of that violence on American soil: race relations, radicalism, the new presence of the immigrant. One realm into which the colorist painting might be moved from that of high narrative representation was the decorative. As decorative work, colorism's purpose was not to tell a story, and thus risk defining a social world, but to enhance a world already securely defined and apprehended, dominated for and by the viewer. The same critic who equated international colorism with communism in 1878 secured his argument by eliding colorism with decoration, a professional sphere he claimed was next to useless, and feminine work at that. In an attempt to revalue colorism Charles de Kay mapped the necessary strategy of recovery and elevation, maintaining colorism's origins in the artistic practice of "native workmen" like Ryder, only to see that work reclaimed as international modernism, and eminently maleable to contemporary personal interpretations, by as influential a critic as Roger Fry.

Title: The emergence of a Latino radical evangelical social ethic in the work and thought of Orlando E. Costas: An ethico-theological discourse from the underside of history
Abstract: Within Protestant Evangelicalism, an emergent movement is shifting from previous polarizations (social/spiritual, privatistic/corporate) to a holistic convergence of faith and social witness. The movement includes Latinos recognized as "true non-pacifist radicals within the broader evangelical left." Our study focuses upon one of the foremost Latino evangelicals in contemporary history, the late Dr. Orlando E. Costas. Costas was a scholar, preacher, teacher, and administrator, revered by fellow evangelicals, ecumenical, and international Christians. Under the renowned missionary and scholar, Dr. Johannes Verkuyl, he received his D. Theol. from the Free University of Amsterdam, the Netherlands (1976). On November 5, 1987, at age 45, Dr. Costas died of cancer while Academic Dean and Judson Professor of Missiology at Andover Newton Theological School. Among his panoply of achievements was to be the first Latino Dean of an accredited Theological Seminary in the U.S.A. In his brief 15 years of scholarly endeavors, he authored over 100 books and articles, and made over thirty contributions to the books of others. The purpose of this dissertation is to identify and analyze a Latino radical evangelical social ethic in his work and thought. The problem suggests that we identify any such ethic from the available texts themselves. The latter approach will view this ethic in light of our findings. In chapter two we address the question of whether Costas work contains a social ethic. In chapter three we explore the question in terms of a Latino radical evangelical social ethic per se. In chapter four we analyze his hermeneutical methodology. In chapter five we offer a critical appraisal of his work and thought. In chapter six we summarize and conclude our findings and suggest further recommendations for study. We argue that the crucial framework for best approaching Costas' thought is a sociohistorical, ethico-theological inquiry from "the underside of history." This approach typifies the concrete dimensions of human social agony and struggle where the locus of salvation is found in the periphery--among the poor and the powerless as opposed to the world's rich and the powerful.

Title: The transatlantic dialogue: 19th-century American utopianism and Europe
Abstract: My interdisciplinary study, based on archival research spanning national boundaries, explores the surprising and undocumented extent to which 19th-century American utopian thought and practice influenced alternative as well as dominant discourses and practices in Europe, rather than just the influence on America by European utopian thought. I argue that 19th-century American utopianism reached its height of influence in Edward Bellamy. Bellamy, and the international utopian dialogue he inspired at a crucial juncture of European debates over the socialist alternative, constitute the core of my project. Bellamy's utopianism was nourished by a storehouse of memory; he relied on the historical experience of the Owenite, Fourierite, and Cabetite movements of the pre-Civil War era. Edward Bellamy's Looking Backward also played an important role in the debates within the European social-democratic movements between 1890 and 1914. In Germany and the Austro-Hungarian Monarchy, Bellamy reached the social-democratic rank and file impatient with the "war of attrition" of Second International socialism. The popularity of Bellamy among workers forced party intellectuals and leaders to acknowledge the significance utopian blueprints, and attempt to develop visions of the just society of the future. Karl Kautsky, August Bebel, and Ervin Szabo directly addressed Bellamy's work. Laurence Gronlund and Ignatius Donnelly published their best-selling utopias at about the time that Bellamy's Looking Backward appeared (1888). I deal with both the American and European responses to Gronlund and Donnelly. My work ends with an analysis of Daniel DeLeon's "industrialism" thesis. DeLeon's "industrialism", influencing Lenin and Gramsci, was in direct dialogue with Bellamy's theories. A re-assimilation of American utopianism into the European context reveals the ways in which the adherence of Second International socialists to their scientistic anti-utopianism, left the terrain of utopian politics open to neoconservative contestation. I demonstrate that, potentially, the most enduring achievement of American utopianism was to critique the corporative confinement of the working class, emphasize the need for cross-class coalitions, and broaden the political initiative to a number of new terrains.

Title: Central American organizations in Los Angeles: The emergence of "social movement agencies"
Abstract: This study examined the development and characteristics of thirteen voluntary organizations in Los Angeles that were established in response to the social and political concerns of the Salvadoran and Guatemalan refugees who arrived in significant numbers during the 1980s, following the onset of civil war in El Salvador and escalation of violence in Guatemala. The refugee communities in Los Angeles are characterized by lack of resources and lack of access to resources, thus, a major purpose of this research was to explore how a largely impoverished group was able to organize on its own behalf and mobilize support from others. A theoretical framework for the study was drawn from the literature on both social movement and human service organizations. The research design used was an exploratory multiple-case study approach. Qualitative data provided the major source of information, drawn primarily from 49 interviews with respondents affiliated to the organizations and augmented by examination of primary and secondary source documents and participant observation conducted by the researcher during 1990 and 1991. The results of the study, were derived from a thematic content analysis of all the data collected. The majority of the organizations in this study could be classified as "social movement agencies" in that they were established with dual purposes:--social reform and the delivery of services. Most are also characterized by a collective or participatory form of governance. A key factor in the establishment of the organizations was the leadership that emerged from the "indigenous" refugee communities which was able to mobilize both internal and external, or "non-indigenous" resources, despite hostile environmental forces. The established religious sector, in particular, provided essential support in the form of funding, sponsorship and legitimacy. During the course of their development, organizational stability has been greatly influenced by external environmental events, both national and international. The majority of the organizations remain "shoestring" operations, however, those that appear to be relatively stable and have experienced the most growth have been able to obtain and sustain a combination of diverse "indigenous" and "non-indigenous" resources and a social service goal more compatible with the external environment.

Title: Why countries support international environmental agreements: The regulation of acid rain in Europe
Abstract: The protection of the environment has become a major challenge for international public policy in the 1980s. While international environmental agreements are seen as a way to limit environmental degradation, little is known why national governments support these agreements. This study focuses on the research question: Why do national governments spend scarce resources on the protection of the international environment? In particular, the study both presents a public choice foundation and empirically tests the impact of (i) pollution-generated incentives as well as (ii) domestic political-economic interests on national support for international environmental regulation. Theories of interdependence, the foreign environmental policy approach, and more recent syntheses of both approaches guide the explanation of the impact of asymmetrical, international pollution patterns on national support for international environmental regulation. Then, theories of postmaterialism, new social movements, and support for green or ecological parties are combined with theories of domestic political economy (which account for the opposing interests of major polluting industries and abatement technology providers) to explain national preferences for international regulation. These theories are integrated with public choice models, namely an amended externality model and an endogenous policy model. Hypotheses were tested for two contemporary environmental agreements which mandate substantial pollution reductions by signatory countries in the empirical analysis of the transboundary air pollution problem (acid rain) in Europe. These tests employed mass public attitude data, responses to expert interviews, and international pollution data. Both pollution-based theories and domestic political theories were supported in the various analyses. In a wider sense, the research findings offer guidance for the study of the regulation of global climate change, and contribute to the growing literature stressing the (i) domestic sources of international politics and (ii) links between domestic politics and international politics.

Title: California populism, a case study: The Farmers' Alliance and People's Party in San Luis Obispo County, 1885-1903
Abstract: The experience of the Farmers' Alliance and People's Party in San Luis Obispo County, California shows that the Populist movement flourished best in rural regions that shared a combination of specific characteristics. These characteristics included: (1) post-Civil War entry into distant cash markets via rail, river, or ocean transportation links, (2) heavy dependence on a single cash crop that competed in national or international markets where prices were in steady decline, (3) insufficient crop yields that prevented farmers from compensating for falling prices, (4) a large percentage of small landowning farmers laboring under heavy mortgage burdens that made them susceptible to imminent dispossession of their real and/or chattel property, (5) a large percentage of farmers with previous experience in rural organizations and political insurgency, (6) the presence of one or more abusive monopolies that controlled credit, transportation, or marketing services required by farmers, (7) unresponsive Democratic and Republican partied whose leaders aligned themselves with urban and corporate interests, and (8) recent and rapid settlement that precluded the development of strong communities and social institutions prior to the onset of hard times. While developing and supporting these conclusions, this study's twelve chapters also examine in detail the history of San Luis Obispo County from 1850 to 1890, the rise and decline of the local and national Populist movements, the organization of the wheat industry in late-nineteenth century California, the membership and structure of the Alliance community, the role of women in the Alliance, the local Alliance press, the influence of Scandinavian immigrants within Populism, the workings of three local Alliance cooperatives, the relationship between the Alliance and the People's party, the relationship between Populism and the little-known DeBernardi Labor Exchange movement, the Southern Pacific Railroad Company and its affiliates in the upper Salinas Valley, and the coastwise trade involving the Pacific Coast Railway and Pacific Coast Steamship companies.

Title: The deregulation and privatisation of New Zealand telecommunications: An economic, political and ideological analysis
Abstract: Profound changes have been made to New Zealand society, the economy, and government over the last decade. These changes are due as much to world events as they are to national occurrences. New Zealand is part of a world-economy and, as such, is influenced by other nation states and global economic trends. These influences have extended beyond just trade in goods and services to include policies relating to enterprise, competition, and trade. In New Zealand, like many other countries belonging to the OECD, such policies have influenced key personnel in business and the government and, as a consequence, have led to fundamental changes in the political economy of the nation. This study goes beyond a political economic analysis of the deregulation and privatisation of New Zealand telecommunications and seeks to determine whether a dominant or hegemonic perception of the role of the state in society was a prominent factor in the restructuring of the economy initiated by the fourth Labour Government. It begins by taking New Zealand as a case study and through an historical analysis of economic and social dependency, outlines the political, regulatory, and ideological influences that underpinned the deregulatory movement. This sets the scene for an inquiry into the steps leading to the privatisation of the Telecom Corporation of New Zealand in an attempt to understand the reasons why Telecom was privatised and what this will mean in terms of opportunities for competitors and regulators. The study critiques the privatisation of the Telecom Corporation of New Zealand and discusses the organisation's future in relation to the opportunities available for telecommunications providers in a lightly regulated environment. The study concludes with an evaluation of current moves to reshape the New Zealand state including the implications this will have for telecommunications users and providers. Suggestions are made for further research into the role of ideas as social forces effecting social change, which does not neglect the public interest.

Title: Ideology and dependent deindustrialization: A study of local responses to Flint, Michigan's social and cultural decline from a critical theory perspective
Abstract: The central focus of this study is the description and critical analysis of the emergent ideologies implicit in the self-understanding of local, organized responses to Flint, Michigan's social and cultural decline. These responses include: (1) the "New Directions Movement" within the United Auto Workers; (2) Flint's "Center for New Work"; (3) the General Motors/United Auto Workers "Local Paid Educational Leave" program; (4) the film Roger & Me; (5) Flint's "Great Lakes Technology Centre"; and (6) Flint's "Genesee Area Economic Revitalization, Inc." As a result of extreme deindustrialization in the city's automobile industry, analysis of these Flint-based responses offers the opportunity to assess both the structural and conceptual challenges facing this city and similar "rust-belt" American communities in their efforts to respond to changes in the global capitalist economy over which they have no effective local control. This study is based primarily on qualitative data gathered in Flint during a two year (1990-1992) field study. Document and archival material, as well as interview and participant-observation data, are integrated with existing quantitative data and various theoretical and social philosophical perspectives (drawn primarily from Frankfurt School critical theory) in order to construct an "applied" form of ideology-critique. From this emerges a typology of local responses to Flint's experience with "dependent deindustrialization." These three ideological types are termed: (1) "enlightenment consciousness"; (2) "post-industrial consciousness"; and (3) "cynical consciousness." Each general type is illustrated through two separate cases. Analysis of these emergent ideologies suggests that each effort ultimately founders upon its inherent powerlessness in the global capitalist system, and that this is revealed in the distortions evident within their respective self-understanding of their objective social position. Considered particularly troubling is the cultural cynicism evident in the responses issuing from Flint's dominant institutional powers.

Title: Gender and the politics of underdevelopment and resistance in the Philippines. (Volumes I and II)
Abstract: The current research on women and development contains little information about Filipino women. Yet, the story of Filipino women suggests that gender is pertinent to the politics of underdevelopment and resistance. I did fieldwork in the Philippines in Summer 1989 to fill this gap in the literature. The objective of my fieldwork was to understand the everyday lives of organized Filipino peasant women and the politics of their resistance. I chose to study peasant women because they comprise the majority of Filipino women. The organization to which my informants belonged was AMIHAN, the National Federation of Peasant Women in the Philippines. I focused my study on one local chapter of AMIHAN, KAMMI (Kababaihang Mangbubukid ng Mindoro). KAMMI is the provincial federation of peasant women's organization in Mindoro, a province in the Southern Tagalog region in Luzon, Philippines. I examine the everyday village lives of the peasant women of KAMMI as they are enmeshed into the national/international structures that keep the Philippines underdeveloped. I present Filipino peasant women not as passive victims of the forces of underdevelopment, but as active creators of alternative social relations and ideologies of development. I analyze the dialectical dynamics of exploitation and resistance from the experience of peasant women. I postulate that while the power structures that benefit from the forces of underdevelopment attempt to repress political action towards radical change in Philippine society, repression creates contradictions that contribute to the organized resistance. These contradictions by themselves do not move people to act. Instead, the peasant women develop strategies and tactics of organized resistance. The women's resistance, while persistent, is not without problems. Repression and militarization is a major obstacle to their struggle for social justice. These women embody the forces of gender and class inequality and experience contradictions of their nation's colonial legacy. Consequently, Filipino peasant women's struggles for emancipation and empowerment are very complex, because they confront tensions arising from oppressive social structures as well as within the broader movement for change in the Philippines.

Title: "That they all may be one": Americans quest for Christian unity, 1918-1948
Abstract: This study explores the social, theological, institutional, and financial sources of support for American involvement in the ecumenical movement between the end of World War I and the First Assembly of the World Council of Churches in 1948. It explains how a group of Protestant leaders, who matured in the student YMCA and missions movement, gradually committed themselves to achieve visible Christian unity around the globe. It examines the network they formed and describes how they emerged as the dominant theologians in American Protestantism at the same time that they shaped the theology and organization of the World Council of Churches in its formative years. As cosmopolitan and liberally-minded evangelicals, they believed that the Christian unity movement could help create international stability in a time of convulsive social change. When fascism and the threat of a second world war loomed large, they focused on relations among the Church, the state, and the international community. In 1934, under the leadership of Henry P. Van Dusen, the core of this group formed an informal, biannual seminar of young theologians and interdenominational leaders called the Theological Discussion Group. Members included John C. Bennett, Samuel McCrea Cavert, Georgia Harkness, Francis P. Miller, Reinhold and Richard Niebuhr, and Paul Tillich. In the course of their meetings, they developed neo-orthodox theologies which provided a mediating alternative to the divisive extremes of fundamentalism and theological liberalism. At the same time, through preparation for and participation in the ecumenical conferences of 1937 at Oxford and Edinburgh, they identified the Church as the model and means which provided the antidote to the world's international ills. When World War II broke out, political concerns drove these theologians' work. Their convictions moved several of them to oppose American neutrality and to found the journal Christianity and Crisis. Through the Federal Council of Churches and under the leadership of John Foster Dulles, they became involved in efforts to identify and lay the building blocks for a just and durable peace. This prompted them to generate support for a political international organization which came to fruition in the United Nations. After the war, they devoted their talents to the creation of the World Council of Churches. Their movement gained momentum because it was essentially an evangelical, educational, and ecclesiological crusade whose leadership was religiously conservative but politically liberal, an appealing combination to Americans who faced an economic depression and the international aggression of dictators.

Title: Marching together: Women of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, 1925-1957
Abstract: "Marching Together" examines women's participation in the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters and Maids from the union's founding in 1925 through the dissolution of its International Ladies' Auxiliary in 1957. The dissertation analyzes the role of race, class and gender in the history of this famous predominantly African American male trade union. It describes the work of Brotherhood women and compares the union's treatment of Pullman maids and other members with its attitude toward the Ladies' Auxiliary. The study describes the historical context for black manhood rights, analyzing how this union demand shaped the Brotherhood story. Manhood rhetoric cast women as uxorial admirers in the twelve-year unionization struggle while it signalled to white railroad Brotherhoods that the BSCP intended to join their fraternity as equals. The Brotherhood treated female union members unfairly. It allowed the Pullman Company to assign train maids by race, not seniority. Union leaders then denounced the white stewardess-nurses who displaced African American and Chinese maids. Yet the union spent thousands of dollars to fight race discrimination against black locomotive firemen and for equal pay litigation for porter-brakemen. Brotherhood wives' participation went beyond the reproduction of (union) labor. The Women's Economic Council and its successor, the International Ladies' Auxiliary, developed their own political agendas. The Auxiliary helped other African American women to organize unions, and honored picket lines and Women's Trade Union League boycotts. As union wives, they promoted labor-conscious consumerism, founded a cooperative store in Chicago and a credit union in Montreal. As followers of BSCP President A. Philip Randolph, women joined the March on Washington and other U.S. and Canadian political movements, through the Montgomery Bus Boycott of 1956. Yet as porters' standard of living rose in the 1940s and 1950s, their families aspired to middle class status. African Americans conformed to (white) gender roles to show their respectability and to justify claims for first class citizenship. Women refuted the emerging social science discourse on black family pathology by identifying themselves as suburban housewives. Many women abandoned the union for civic and social organizations and in 1957, the BSCP abolished the International Ladies' Auxiliary.

Title: The limits of New Deal social democracy: Working-class structural pluralism in midwestern meatpacking, 1900-1955. (Volumes I and II)
Abstract: The New Deal dramatically fashioned legislative and administrative social welfare reforms. An important segment of New Deal policy makers, including politicians, intellectuals, social reformers, academics, businessmen, and farm and labor leaders, championed social democratic reform. Such reformers advocated national economic planning and improvements in housing, social welfare, and race relations to eliminate the inequities caused by social class divisions. Social democrats particularly viewed the Wagner Act and National Labor Relations Board as programs that could achieve a more just society. These legislative and administrative policies allowed workers to create America's first successful industrial union movement, the Congress of Industrial Organizations. Between the late 1930s and mid-1950s, CIO international unions were among the strongest proponents of social democracy through their political positions and reform programs. However, with the onset of the Cold War, organized labor's commitment to social democracy eroded. Without social democrats' contributions, an emphasis on the social and economic impact of class divisions faded from American liberalism by the 1950s. My research challenges the usual explanations for the failure of New Deal social democracy. Most historians explain the collapse of this social democratic tendency by emphasizing the revival of anti-communism, passage of the Taft-Hartley Act, and federal government control of organized labor. My dissertation--a fifty-year survey of twenty-one midwestern meatpacking communities--demonstrates that persistent ethnic and racial tensions among workers undermined the social democratic programs of the United Packinghouse Workers of America (UPWA-CIO). Because working-class communities differed in their political economy, social composition, and cultural concerns, workers' local unions were severely divided in their commitment to the international's reform effort. The supportive national legislative and administrative environment of the 1930s temporarily permitted workers to overcome their divisions. Following World War II, when this favorable political environment evaporated, workers' differences ultimately became fault lines, crumbling the fragile coalition that made it possible for CIO unions to be advocates of social democracy.
