Title: The labor movement in Costa Rica from the Great Depression to the Cold War
Abstract: This work examines how the relationship between the state, the Communist Party (CPCR) and the church in Costa Rica influenced the country's labor movement. The large areas of examination are four-fold: (1) the juridical evolution of the labor movement in the country's political economy; (2) the continual expansion of the state into the worker-owner relationship; (3) the relationship between the labor movement and their political supporters; and (4) the impact of international events and institutions on the country' s labor movement. The work is divided into two parts. The first begins in 1932 and ends in 1940. Chapters I and II explore the legislative solutions to the country's social and economic crises and the early efforts toward labor unification under the CPCR-led confederation. In addition some of the country's major strikes are examined. The second part of this work begins in 1940 with an in-depth examination of the tangible results of the efforts of the 1930s, and continues with a look at how the domestic and international alliances prompted by World War II caused fundamental shifts in the balance of power inside the country. Chapter III explores those shifts from a single, overriding vantage point: how they facilitate labor's obtaining direct access to the centers of national power. By 1945, adverse domestic and international political and economic conditions, caused the ruling alliance between the state, the church and the CPCR to fragment. This fragmentation was exacerbated by the development of a Catholic labor confederation and the increasingly antagonistic relations experienced between it and the older CPCR-led confederation. The deteriorating climate erupted into civil war in 1948 which destroyed the remnants of the wartime coalition, but did not roll back the labor gains of the past two decades. (Chapters IV and V.) Chapter VI explores the international connections and affiliations of the country's two labor confederations to determine the extent to which Costa Rican labor developments were marked by domestic/evolutionary traditions or discontinuities imposed by foreign ideas. Throughout the work, analytical references are made to the work force: its sexual, racial, ethnic, regional, and national composition; its standard of living; and working conditions.

Title: Human rights strategy for a changing international environment: The United States Anti-Apartheid Movement in transition
Abstract: The disintegration of the Cold War-defined international system brings with it fundamental challenges to both conceptual and applied efforts to advance human dignity and individual security. The broad concern of this study is to examine the implications of changing conditions for strategy construction for the global promotion of human rights. Strategy construction demands the integration of the traditional themes of power and influence in international relations and the non-traditional methods of political participation employed by transnational social movements. Effective strategies necessitate the analytical depiction of an operating environment in which international, regional, and domestic trends can be recognized for the opportunities and constraints that they present in influencing state practices that endanger human rights. The break down of the Cold War structure of the international system not only presents new opportunities for human rights work, but highlights the critical linkage of international system characteristics to grass roots human rights campaigns. This thesis analyzes the adaptation of one transnational human rights movement to opportunities and constraints presented by changing international, regional, and domestic conditions. The simultaneous and dramatic changes occurring in the relationship of the powers of the international system, along with the overtures taken by the De Klerk regime in South Africa to alter the Apartheid system, present a unique opportunity to examine how changing international and domestic trends influenced the capacity of the Transnational Anti-Apartheid Movement to advance its human rights agenda. The study draws from social movement theory examining political opportunity structures with theories of conflict resolution from the international relations discipline to advance a definition and power paradigm for the emergent phenomenon of transnational social movements. For purposes of concentrated research, a narrower focus upon the United States Anti-Apartheid Movement was taken through intensive survey research of activists and political officials as a means of abstracting a depiction of the strategy pursued in the eighteen month period between the onset of reform in South Africa and the lifting of United States sanctions by President Bush. An explanation is provided to account for the failure of the United States Anti-Apartheid Movement to significantly adapt its strategy to fit the altered environment in which it was operating in the period examined. Finally, a set of propositions is advanced regarding the implications of this study for assessing the future of human rights strategy construction by transnational social movements adapting to changing international conditions.

Title: Political parties and foreign policy: The German Social Democrats and international security, 1977-1986
Abstract: This dissertation analyzes the domestic component in German foreign policy making, more specifically the way in which the German Social Democratic Party (SPD) has affected Germany's international security policy. The central argument is that the party's foreign policy, when put to the test of popular pressure, was ultimately the product not of an "oligarchically" controlled decision making process (as theories from Michels through Kirchheimer would suggest), but of an anarchical struggle between factions. The analysis covers the INF debate, from its inception with the neutron weapon issue (chapter 1), the development and acceptance of NATO's "doubletrack" decision (chapters 2 and 3), through the growth of factional strife and rebellion (chapters 4 through 7), up to the framing of a platform rejecting the party's fundamental international security assumptions, assumptions that had governed SPD policy all through the 1960s and 1970s, and that had formed the basis of the party's (key) cooperation in NATO's doubletrack decision. The international security debate of that period is placed in the broader context of societal change and the rise of "new" social movements carrying "postmaterialist" values, and the party's response to these changes (chapters 8 and 9). The second part explores the major ideological ingredients of the foreign policy reversal consecrated at the SPD's 1986 convention. Examined are the Social Democrats' historically moot relationship to military power (chapter 10) and the various models evolved by the party elite in order to accommodate pressures for programmatic change with the constraints of domestic and international politics (chapters 11 and 12). Few of these models managed to harden into formal party policy, depending on the shifting alliances whose support they could muster (chapter 13). The new international security preference that came to be articulated by Germany in 1988 was primarily a response to domestic political pressures that had first been building up in, and also against, the SPD, given the rise of The Greens. The crisis this entailed turned not only around dilemmas faced by the German Left, but also around the re-definition of Germany's position in the international system. And here the SPD played a crucial role at a critical juncture--precisely because its debating and decision making processes were not, or no longer, "oligarchically" controlled.

Title: The radicalization of the Iranian students' movement abroad: The case of the World Confederation of Iranian Students
Abstract: Students have been an important force for social change throughout the world. Various socio-psychological and structural explanations have been advanced to account for the rise and radicalization of student-based social movements. They are found to be insufficient. Global political dynamics and state policies, it is argued, are also of consequence, for reasons that existing theoretical analyses have failed to recognize. The author's approach is illustrated with specific reference to the World Confederation of Iranian Students, an international organization that formed in Europe and the United States in opposition to the Shah. The development of the Confederation from its formation as a moderate student organization in 1960 into a more radical one is traced through an analysis of the Confederation's changing ideology, tactics, and organizations dynamics. The history of the Confederation is shown to have been affected by socio-political developments in Iran, including the Shah's policy towards political opposition, and by such international socio-political developments as national liberation and revolutionary movements and the work of human rights groups. Sociological analyses that focus on groups resources, the class base of groups, and the psychological needs of participants are shown to fail to account for the rise and transformation of the Confederation. The Shah's political intolerance and repression of his opposition, in particular, are shown to have had the unintended effect of radicalizing the Confederation. The Confederation's radicalism, in turn, proved to distance the movement from thousands of Iranian students who shared its anti-Shah objectives but not its militant philosophy. Influenced by Marxist-Leninist ideology and tactics, the Confederation lost its internal unity and the support of non-Marxists who opposed the Shah. Factions split with the Confederation to form their own groups. In the process, the Confederation lost its ability to represent Iranian students abroad. The study draws on interviews with Confederation activists and Confederation publications. A wide range of other sources, such an English newspapers, reports by international human rights organizations, and Iranian political organization publications were consulted as well.

Title: From social worker to crimefighter: A history of women in United States policing
Abstract: This dissertation traces the role of women in United States policing from the 19th century to the present. Policewomen's history began officially in 1910, but its roots trace to the early decades of the 19th century. This thesis reviews how the position of policewoman evolved from jail and police matrons, how women entered what is today the criminal justice field first as volunteers, then as paid workers of benevolent associations, and finally as municipal employees. Pioneer policewomen are presented as a case study of how women used the concept of "women's sphere" to enter the public sector and create a totally new profession as part of early 20th century social feminist concerns with temperance, prostitution, and child-saving. Early policewomen formed their own association (the International Association of Policewomen); its role in setting their goals and determining their career options is analyzed. The role of groups outside the police establishment in lobbying for policewomen, particularly the Women's Christian Temperance Union, the Progressives, and good government and civic associations, is illustrated and used to explain how policewomen were almost never sought by police executives but were forced on unwilling administrators by forces outside law enforcement. Policewomen's link to the earlier matron movement and to social purity advocates is illustrated by use of police department histories and annual reports, presentations made by and about early policewomen, and writings by and about the policewomen and their supporters. The expansion in the numbers of policewomen during both World War I and II is documented, as are demands for greater opportunities in the 1950s, culminating in patrol assignments in the late 1960s and 1970s. This thesis describes how policewomen, who entered policing as social workers, were forced to repudiate their past to achieve gender equality as crimefighters.

Title: On becoming a global citizen: Praxis in identity politics. A participatory development education project
Abstract: "Think globally, act locally," is a popular call to action that entails overcoming the central problems of social theory, namely: the micro/macro, agent/structure, public/private, and state/civil society dichotomies. To meet this challenge, this thesis integrates theory, method and practice within a social constructivist framework, understanding social theory to be a relation of theories of agency, order and change. The study is organized in two parts: theory and praxis. Identity theory is incorporated into social interaction theory. The thesis emphasizes that "multiple identities comprise the self" and proposes that the "ordering processes" entailed in multiple and over-lapping role-identities provide a dynamic for change in social interaction. It draws on the concept of "representations" as the outcome of reflexive processes which sustain or change social institutions now. Order is understood as the management of self-authorizing identity groups. The relationship of state and civil society are reshaped into concepts of non-sovereign states and civil society as the locus for citizenship within multiple policy arenas. Social movements are seen as constitutive of order that is "structured" but not "contained". This approach was applied to a project of development education which established (via interactive telecommunications) a "discursive community" of persons across four countries engaged in joint analysis of development policy and of their action strategies as change agents. Q-Methodology was used to enable participants to define for themselves their own understandings of development and their understandings of the role-identities citizen and global citizen. The Q-Study revealed a striking coherence of views among the participants, the deep alienation of most participants from the development policies of their respective governments and that the participants maintained both local and global identifications. The value of Q-Method as a tool for critical theory and as an instrument for measuring and communicating role-identities was demonstrated. The dialogic process strengthened participants' identifications and enhanced their appreciation for the possibilities of global/local citizenship. The transnational dialogue confirmed theory expectations while surfacing needed modifications in the project process. Suggestions for research and practice flow from this praxis.

Title: Mexican and Mayan environmentalism: Physical, economic, political and cultural factors that influence the environmental movement in Quintana Roo, Mexico
Abstract: The state of Quintana Roo on Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula has historically been a frontier area rich in natural beauty and resources. Recent development of the Cancun-Tulum tourist corridor, agricultural intensification due to in-migration and increased pressures on the forests have combined to create new environmental problems and, almost simultaneously, a new environmental movement in the region. The purpose of this study is to understand the factors influencing this environmental movement as it responds to local cultural values, international environmental discourse, modern economic pressures and the ecology of the area. The dimensions of the movement and the factors influencing it were determined through long-interviews and participant observation of over 40 Mayan and Mexican environmentalists in 12 non-governmental (NGOs) or quasi-nongovernmental organizations (QUANGOs) in the state and of several representatives of national and international agencies involved in local environmental affairs were also interviewed. In addition, members of the general Maya population were surveyed to obtain their views of environmental conservation. The origin and development of the movement is detailed using information from newspaper clippings, the archives of environmental organizations and interviews with founders and leaders. The social composition and environmental ideologies of local environmentalists are discussed. The history, objectives and programs of each NGO and QUANGO are also described. Pertinent factors were isolated and their influence on the projects and programs of the conservation organizations are described. Regional factors included the biodiversity, natural hazards and karst hydrogeology of the state, economic and political situations. Cultural factors included time perceptions, the meaning of place, and the values given to nature and human relationships. The character of this movement and form in which it addresses local environmental issues is compared with theoretical frameworks developed by scholars studying environmentalism in other cultures.

Title: The role of expanded social participation in the transition from stage three to stage four moral judgment in late adolescence and adulthood
Abstract: Adult role-taking opportunities are researched here as mediating factors of advanced moral judgment. Kohlberg (1984) maintained that many of these opportunities come through higher education and complex employment settings. Researchers have investigated contextual variables, such as career attainment, to determine their strength in prompting moral growth. A more basic endeavor, the aim of this research, is to focus on those basic elements that can be found across situations that facilitate moral growth. The primary research involved 490 subjects. The sample included a random college group and five selected sub-samples of adults. The Sociomoral Reflection Measure--Short Form (SRM-SF) was used to operationalize moral reasoning and the Post-Childhood Opportunities for Role Taking (PC-ORT) questionnaire was used as a measure of social participation. There were basically three phases to this research: Factor analysis of the PC-ORT, exploration of the role of social participation in movement to advanced moral judgment, and further investigation of advanced moral judgment through semi-structured life experience interviews. The exploratory factor analysis indicated that the PC-ORT contained four factors: Challenges on Issues, Organizational Involvement, Work Responsibility, and Peer Involvement. Three of the factors (Work Responsibility excluded) were fitted as a model to a new set of data through confirmatory factor analysis and produced an acceptable goodness of fit index. Analyses indicated that adult role-taking opportunities are related to advanced moral judgment. Advanced moral judgment was best predicted by the overall amount of adult social participation, and by Challenges on Issues and Work Responsibility. Analyses of sex differences indicated that when controlling for education and employment, males and females were achieving the same levels of moral judgment. The random sample demonstrated a strong relationship between advanced moral judgment and over-all adult social participation, and between advanced moral judgment and Challenges on Issues. Each of the five adult, selected sub-samples was analyzed separately. The life experience interviews indicated that the more advanced moral judgment participants did much more reading, demonstrated a global perspective, and were concerned with seeking the truth and with spirituality. The stage three moral judgment participants were concerned with conformity, interpersonal relationships, and the role of guilt.

Title: Policy-making and accounting change: Influences on the choice of measurement principles in Swedish accounting
Abstract: Accounting is studied in this thesis as a social phenomenon. This means that attention is paid to the importance of social institutional factors for accounting change. In examining this in the context of the changes of Swedish accounting standards the thesis is contributing to the knowledge about accounting. The thesis deals with both the different kinds of principles used in handling accounting calculations, and with what influences the choice of principle which accounting standard setters make. Two different kind of principles for calculation are identified, on the one hand, the matching principle with realism as ideal; on the other hand, the prudence principle with conservatism as its ideal. The occurrence of these principles is identified in a study of accounting recommendations in Sweden during a time period of 35 years, from 1957 to 1992. The prudence principle, a claim for disclosure of information and argumentation according to the law is common in the empirical material throughout the thirty-five years studied. There is a tendency for the prudence principle to remain, but its importance has diminished. Using a technique of combining the chosen accounting principle with the type of issue it deals with it was possible to understand why a certain kind of solution was encouraged, accepted or rejected. The matching principle is accepted if the issue has no consequences for the tax paid or if it is not regulated in law. The matching principle is used with reference to practice. The shift in attitude, and the movement in policy toward the increasing use of the matching principle is explained in the thesis by the growing importance of the international stock market.

Title: Gender relations and international organizations: The role of international women's movements in the League of Nations and the United Nations system
Abstract: The purpose of this dissertation is two-fold: first, to argue that an analysis of social movements is essential to explain the activities and directions of international organizations; and second, to explore the roles that international women's movements have played in the construction and maintenance of and challenges to gender relations within the United Nations and the League of Nations. To analyze the role of global social movements, this work suggests that social movements reflect changes in social relations within a global civil society and act to bring about change or sustain the status quo. Both formally organized groups as well as less formal meetings, networks and conferences constitute these movements. It is possible to distinguish among these movements by considering the type of organization, the purpose or orientation of the group, the political practice they pursue and their orientation to change. Within the context of international organizations, the work of social movements is most evident when there has been a change in a particular set of social relations. This may be evident in the discourse, practices or structures of the organization or may be seen in the material capabilities of the actors. This work uses the example of the international women's movements in relation with the League of Nations and the United Nations to explore the more general arguments about social movements. A contextual history of international women's organizing is given from 1840 until 1990 together with an analysis of the specific relationships between the women's movements and the two international organizations in their activities related to women. There have been international women's movements since the 1880s which have had some direct but predominantly indirect influence on the work of the two organizations related to women. International women's movements have helped to change the discourse and practices of the two international organizations but there has been little change in the material conditions of women around the world.

Title: Putting foreign policy to work: The role of organized labor in American foreign relations, 1932-1941
Abstract: International relations deteriorated between 1932 and 1941, as totalitarian governments in Europe and East Asia extinguished democracy in their own countries and became increasingly threatening to their neighbors. In the United States, the struggle to end the Great Depression gave way to the problem of converting from a peacetime to a wartime economy. Meanwhile, the American labor faced internal as well as external threats to its stability. Unity was shattered as the Congress of Industrial Organizations (CIO) arose to challenge the American Federation of Labor (AFL) for supremacy in the labor movement. Further, organized labor had to fend off attacks from company unions, strike breakers, and restrictive legislation. The foreign policy preferences of organized labor reflected its concerns with all of those issues. In the early 1930s, the AFL followed a largely isolationist course. It had withdrawn from the international labor movement years before and it resisted efforts to expand international trade through reciprocal agreements that would conflict with its own plans for economic recovery. Like the rest of the country, the American labor movement reacted to the rise of totalitarianism with trepidation, but also with a determination to prevent United States involvement in overseas hostilities. In the months leading up to American entry into World War II, however, organized labor came to support intervention. While motivated by patriotism and a desire to strengthen American security, organized labor also crafted its foreign policy positions in such a way as to complement its domestic programs and help achieve specific economic and social goals at home. International affairs even became a factor in the contest between the AFL and the CIO. And by contributing to the national defense effort and publicizing the repression of labor by fascist governments abroad, American labor hoped to weaken anti-labor forces in the United States. As the AFL and the CIO developed positions on international affairs, rank-and-file views on American diplomacy sometimes divided along regional or occupational lines.

Title: Mosques and misunderstandings: Muslim discourses in Tawi-Tawi, Philippines
Abstract: This is a study of how understandings and practices of Islam are changing among the Sama people of Simunul Island, Tawi-Tawi, Philippines. In this community, mystical interpretations of Islam are being challenged by individuals who strive to bring the beliefs and practices of their kin in accordance with teachings in the Qur'an and hadith. This dissertation focuses upon the conflicts that emerge and the changes that occur as some people try to defend their traditions while others struggle to affect change in their communities. This dissertation is organized in an introduction, four chapters, a conclusion, and appendices. In the introduction, I explicate my approach to the study of Islam. I argue that Islam must be understood as a discourse instead of a religion because discourse goes beyond religion by capturing the temporality of meaning and its contextualization in social practice. The first chapter focuses upon Sama reactions to the Ahmadiyya Movement, an international movement of Islamic reform. In this chapter, I examine Sama interpretations and constructions of the Ahmadiyya Movement as I challenge the ways other scholars have approached the study of Islamic movements. In Chapter Two, I examine a case that concerns the relationship between historic change, politics, and the authority of imam. In this chapter, I focus upon the ways imam re-establish the bases of their legitimacy in modern political contexts. Chapter Three examines how traditional ways of learning and knowing Islam are changing, and the consequences these changes have for local understandings of Islam. The final chapter examines disputes concerning the practice of death observances to explore the kinds of forces that keep traditions in place and the ways these traditions change. Although each chapter deals with a specific case in which the meaning and practice of Islam are in dispute, all chapters examine the ways Muslim discourses meet in Simunul, the ways they are interpreted and used by individuals, and the ways that understandings of Islam are being transformed in this Sama community of the southern Philippines.

Title: John R. Mott: A conversionist in a pluralist world
Abstract: John R, Mott's long life (1865-1955) spanned a decisive period of transition in organized Protestant missions. During his career American Protestants opened the confines of their denominational identities in a cooperative effort to achieve the global aspirations of a society that had become saturated with Protestant values. Mott's career was focused upon this great dream to evangelize the world. As much a visionary and pioneer as he was, however, Mott was neither a theologian nor a social prophet. Rather, his significance was found in the great degree to which he embodied the sentiments of American Protestant leadership in the first half of the century. The transitions that were represented in his career are indicative of the movements being made in many Protestant churches as well. Mott attained success early in life as the General Secretary of both the American YMCA and the Student Volunteer Movement. At age 35 he chaired the World Missionary Council in Edinburgh which thrust him into international prominence. At the end of his life, he was a Nobel Laureate, President of the World Council of Churches, Chairman of the International Missionary Council, the World Student Christian Federation, and the World Alliance of YMCAs. In the course of his career he received six honorary doctorates, five invitations to lead educational institutions including Princeton University and Yale Divinity School, and was asked by his personal friend President Woodrow Wilson to become the Ambassador to China. In 1919 Congress awarded him the Distinguished Service Medal for his leadership of relief organizations in the war. My own thesis is concerned with a different dimension to Mott's work that has yet to be examined--how could he function so successfully as a pluralist while seeking to convert the world to Jesus Christ? Through examining the major transitions in his life, a response to this question will emerge: Mott's evangelism did not pursue a particular religious experience, but a Christian vision of the world. At various points in his career he was closely associated with a diversity of international leaders. That he was deeply admired by all of them, while still professing to be a Christian evangelist, merits him a place in the current discussions of religious pluralism. Finding insights on the relationship of Christian missions to cultural pluralism is of importance not only to the field of missionary research, but also to all who seek to inform the struggle of religious communions to understand themselves in light of others. Mott's career provides a helpful contribution to the larger field of studies on proselytism and religious civility in a pluralist world. While this contribution needs to be seen within its particular historical context, it persists as a model of a conversionist who learned to accommodate and even appreciate religious pluralism. Mott's life offered an encouraging response to the dilemma of Christians who cannot forget the mandate to evangelize, but who want to see God at work beyond their own circles. On the one hand, this dilemma is the persistent stumbling block for 20th century mission agendas, and on the other it demonstrates a profound hope to find a place for particular faith claims in a pluralist world. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: The "Socialist Union of Catalonia"
Abstract: This Dissertation analyses the origins of a socialism specifically Catalan, characterized by its social-democratic formulations in the international framework. This model is patterned by a constant dynamics forward and upward the political and ideological foundations of the PSOE (Spanish Socialist Workers Party). The dissertation also underlies the interrelations and contacts between the Catalan socialists and the renouval movements of the Political Catalanism, and, in a special way, its cultural connections with the "Noucentisme". At the same time, the dissertation tackles the socialists political compromise in fighting the Primo de Rivera Dictatorships and supporting the Republican and Nationalistic civil liberties of Catalonia in the period of the 2nd Republic. From a stasiological approach, the study also analyses the organizational and programatic parameters of the Catalan socialist movement as well as its active participation at different institutional levels of the 2nd Republic.

Title: Subsidies, sovereignty, and liberalism: The Canada-United States quagmire
Abstract: This dissertation examines a phenomenon that is of increasing importance in international relations--the conflict generated by the use of subsidy negotiations to harmonize domestic social and economic policies. In these situations, a clash may emerge between domestic policy goals and the interests of larger trading partners. The effort to resolve disputes about domestic subsidies often involves states ceding some degree of sovereignty to a higher authority. However, determining the permissibility of subsidies is one area where states are extremely reluctant to relinquish sovereignty because it can threaten important domestic balances. This work makes use of a global political economy approach to consider the Canada-U.S. case in a broad context, drawing upon other attempts to deal with the subsidy issue at the GAIT and the European Community. A major theme of the study is the corresponding clash of ideas and interests involved in subsidy discussions. Pure laissez-faire notions conflict with more collectivist visions of society. It is more than an academic debate, however, as the question of who bears the costs of further liberalization has an impact upon people's lives. The distribution of costs is a political issue that is settled through institutions such as a Congress or a Parliament. While markets and corporations wield considerable influence and constrain the behaviour of other actors, political institutions and the factors that influence them retain a prominent position. The attempt to resolve the subsidy issue bilaterally has proven relatively fruitless and does not offer much promise for the future. Despite many similarities, Canada and the United States are unable to agree upon what is or is not an acceptable subsidy because of different historical experiences and perspectives concerning the role of government in the economy. Despite the desire of powerful social forces on both sides of the border for increased economic liberalism through trade agreements, basic disagreements prevent a meaningful transfer of sovereignty to a transnational arbitrator. If a permanent solution to the subsidy dispute is required, there must be some movement from market integration to the formation of a political community recognizing a higher decision making body. The inability of Canada and the United States to resolve this issue satisfactorily foreshadows increased conflict between the United States, Japan and the European Community.

Title: The decolonization crisis in New Caledonia
Abstract: This paper analyses the origins of revolutionary anti-colonialism in New Caledonia. The development of capitalism in the colony, under direct French imperial control, has created a territory witb the most advanced development in the South Pacific. New Caledonia has served as both a colony of settlement and as a producer of raw materials, chiefly nickel and other minerals. A combination of unique features and consequences of capitalist development in New Caledonia has determined both the abnormally prolonged colonial status of the country and has generated powerful social forces that have favored the advent of a revolutionary situation. The major factor contributing to the anachronistic colonial status of the country is its possession of the largest known nickel reserves in the world. The international political economy of nickel must be understood in order to understand why New Caledonia is subject to unusually prolonged direct imperial control well into the era of neo-colonialism. The conclusion is that while the unique characteristics of the development of capitalism in New Caledonia are the source of the subjective and objective prerequisites for the revolutionary anti-colonial movement, the superior coercive capability of the modern state and the ethnic divisions within the territory will preclude the possibility of successful social revolution in New Caledonia. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: Hegemony, counter-hegemony and peripheral societies: New approaches to international relations theory
Abstract: The thesis is the development of a new approach to the analysis of international relations based upon the rejection of the liberal notion of the state as the basic unit of international relations theory, and the articulation of a concept of the state-society complex which emphasises the economic and ideological unity of a single world system. After an extended theoretical exposition of the expansion of the world capitalist system and the analysis of the Gramscian theory of the state and ideology, these two trends of thought are brought together to explain the organic crisis of peripheral states. The central working premiss of the thesis is that the domestic-international dichotomy is invalid and misleading to explanations of international relations, and that instead there is a continuum of activity which spreads from the local to the global environment. This continuum is expressed most consistently through ideology and class relations. Using Gramsci's theory of hegemony in the context of the development of El Salvador, particularly over the last two decades, the thesis seeks to demonstrate the strength and impact of such continuities. Any social theory must be capable of giving an account of change and transformation, and this is articulated in the concept of counter-hegemony (also developed from the work of Antonio Gramsci) and demonstrated through a study of the challenge of subaltern movements in El Salvador. The organic crisis of the state in El Salvador is interpreted as being of both structural economic derivation (location in the world economy, the nature of dependency, failure of domestic accumulation) and the inability to carry out a hegemonic project, these being consequences of the peripheral status. Throughout the thesis, the relationship between economic and ideological order is maintained as the focal point of analysis and the principal avenue of continuity between global and local forces.

Title: Labor unrest and capital accumulation on a world scale
Abstract: The dissertation analyzes the interrelationship between labor unrest and capital accumulation on a world scale from the late nineteenth century to the present. Two central premises guide this study. First, that labor movements within different nation-states are linked by the existence of a world-scale division of labor and an interstate system. Second, that struggles and resistances by subordinate groups are a primary motor of change in the long-term evolution of the capitalist world system. Part I surveys the main trends in labor militancy in the world-economy from the late sixties to the present with specific focus on the United States, Western Europe, Brazil, South Africa and Poland. The weakening and subsequent decline in militancy among workers in core countries and the simultaneous emergence of strong and effective labor movements in numerous semiperipheral countries in the 1980's are analyzed as a single world-scale historical process of labor-capital conflict bound together by the global restructuring of capital accumulation. Part II discusses problems involved in conceptualizing and measuring labor unrest as a process of long-term, world-scale social change. The inadequacy of state-collected strike data for the purposes of this study is emphasized. A new database on world labor unrest--constructed by the World Labor Research Working Group at the Fernand Braudel Center from newspaper accounts--is introduced and its reliability is assessed. Part III uses time series of labor unrest derived from the World Labor Research Working Group database in order to assess the plausibility of theories which link long waves of capital accumulation (Kondratieff cycles) to a long cycle of labor militancy. It is argued that processes of world-scale labor unrest over the last century can be better explained by studying their interrelationship with processes of global political change, i.e., cycles of world hegemony and rivalry (world war and peace). The period from the crisis of British world hegemony in the late nineteenth century to the current crisis of US world hegemony is analyzed. A final chapter draws conclusions about the likely future trajectory of labor unrest in the world system.

Title: "To become a person": Immigrant women's experiences of gender, ethnicity, and work, New York, 1870-1924
Abstract: This study explores migrating women's part in the global population movements from peripheral and semi-peripheral to core regions of the world-system during the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. It analyzes and reassesses the impact of migration to New York on Russian Jewish and Italian women's lives. The principal organizing question is whether and to what extent migration diminished, intensified, and/or transformed the nature of women's subordination. The first chapter is a critical review of the main theoretical approaches to women's international migrations. The outline of an alternative interpretive framework that places the interconnected and global processes of gender, race/ethnicity/nationality, and class transformation at the center of the dynamics of women's migration experiences is developed. The specific political, economic, and social changes in the world-system that both prompted women's departures from Russia and Italy and shaped their modes of incorporation in the United States is the subject of chapters two and three. In chapters four and five I examine the varying nature of immigrant women's receptions in the U.S. by political and economic institutions, by the dominant population, by kin, and by pre-existing co-ethnic communities, all of which played a significant role in differentiating women's experiences from one another. Married women and mothers, both Italian and Russian Jewish, experienced migration to the U.S. as relatively disempowering in most dimensions of their lives. Young single women, on the other hand, experienced increased autonomy following migration. The single most important factor affecting women's experience of migration, however, was the nature of their reception by a pre-existing co-ethnic community. The extent to which these communities were differently organized to protect women against the effects of racial nativism, as well as gender and class bias, was largely a consequence of world-systemic processes which had shaped transnational population movements.

Title: A historiographical study of twentieth-century literature on the British women in the Raj
Abstract: Since the international women's movement of the 1970's, historical scholarship has undergone significant change. Gender-based analyses of history gave rise to a new genre of academic writing. This newer approach to writing history has had a considerable effect on the discussion of the history of imperial colonialism. Authors who have published roughly since the early 1980's contend that colonialism and gender are inextricably linked and cannot be considered independent of one another. Moreover, gender, race, and social class factors must be examined in order to fully understand the complex nature of the imperial colonial social hierarchy. This report seeks to examine recent trends since the women's movement in gender-based studies of imperial colonialism as exemplified by the British Raj in India.

Title: A geography of the new public health.
Abstract: Using the example of a locality this thesis examines the key elements of the new public health from a geographic perspective. Three voluntary groups (based in the London Borough of Tower Hamlets) have been examined as a case study of expressions of the new public health. The thesis argues that the new public health is an urban social movement, which has expressions at the local level which vary. It is argued that this variance results from the key elements which inform and shape the new public health. They are the nature of the public health activities and initiatives carried out; the organisation and representation of the groups that make up the movement; and the knowledge and activities informed by sense of the place that the groups have. The sense of place of the groups collectively, and the individuals within the groups, informs what public health activities and initiatives are implemented based on perceived need. The sense of place of the area is also the main mobilising factor for the agents who make up the public health groups and hence the new public health movement. The new public health movement is an urban social movement organised at a number of different geographical levels and in particular at the local and international levels. In discussing and describing how the new public health is a social movement, the thesis contends that previous exploration of social movements has failed to examine the importance that place has to the organisation and shape that movements take. This thesis, through a geographic analysis, constructs a new framework for looking at urban social movements with an emphasis on place. It also outlines how an geographical analysis of the new public health can broaden the focus of current research within medical geography by examining health within the wider context of society.

Title: A change of paradigm: the last years of Soviet-Greek Communist Party relations (1985-1991).
Abstract: This doctoral thesis focuses on the change in relations between the Communist Party of Greece (KKE) and the Soviet Union/the Communist Party of the Soviet Union (CPSU) from 1985 to 1991. It examines how KKE's domestic political behaviour was affected by Moscow, and how party to party (KKE-CPSU) and party to state (KKE-USSR) relations evolved. The thesis consequently provides an insight into the forces affecting the international communist movement at the time, and analyzes the attitudes orthodox communists held towards Gorbachev's `perestroika'. The thesis highlights how the reforms undertaken in the USSR had a major impact on the Greek political agenda both changing the post-war international divide and affecting the perception of what ideological cleavages meant. It therefore sheds light on how change in one's state's political affairs can have a direct impact on the conduct of politics elsewhere. Furthermore it shows how some of the social and economic driving forces that encouraged change in the USSR were also at work in other countries such as Greece and how they affect party cleavages. Studying KKE in this context provides a good case study of how an ideology-based party reacts to a changing environment and in particular highlights the relationship between policy choices and ideology in a rapidly evolving international system. The thesis therefore allows a better understanding of the dilemmas facing such parties when domestic social and international political cleavages change.

Title: The role of communication in the rise of the Islamic movements in the Muslim world with special reference to Egypt, Kuwait, Afghanistan, Pakistan and Turkey.
Abstract: This thesis examines the role of communication in the rise of Islamic movements in Muslim countries. It describes the channels of communication used by these movements to propagate their messages and discusses the effectiveness of different types of communication. In particular it lays stress on the importance of `alternative' or `traditional' media in the communication of the Islamic movements' messages. Such means proved better able than the mass media to reach audiences in closed societies and by-pass government censorship. The thesis begins with an account of the theory of Islam. It examines how Islam has been practised since 622 to the present time and describes the global distribution of Muslims since the collapse of the Caliphat in 1924. This section emphasises the modern day Muslim states. The thesis then describes the relationship between communication and social and political behaviour. It examines the role of the different media in the development of political communication. It argues that much of the emphasis in political communication research has been laid on mass media with a consequent neglect of other media. The thesis then examines the political systems in the five countries that make up this study - Egypt, Kuwait, Afghanistan, Pakistan and Turkey. Each country has a different kind of political system which has shaped the development of Islamic movements. However each places restrictions on the movements and each has been influenced by the trend towards secularism and un-Islamic practices which has led to the resurgence of Islam. The thesis then describes the movements studied as part of this dissertation, their growth, objectives and operations. The method used to collect data about the communication policy and strategies of these movements is then discussed and this is followed by analysis and presentation of the findings.

Title: Social concertation in a new democracy: Portugal's experience to 1989
Abstract: In the midst of political instability, economic crisis and social conflict, and against expectations based on some theoretical approaches to the study of societal corporatism, social concertation was institutionalized in Portugal in 1984. This dissertation studies the emergence of this societal corporatist form of policy making in Portugal. This study is informed by two principal theoretical approaches. The "power resources" approach relates societal corporatism to internal factors which are reflective of a balance in the distribution of class power in society. The "economic vulnerability" approach argues, on the other hand, that societal corporatism is positively related to the degree of economic vulnerability in the international economy experienced by small nations. The conditions which the "power resources" approach posits to be positively associated with societal corporatism are to a large extent absent in Portugal. Nevertheless, a Permanent Council for Social Concertation (CPCS) was created in 1984. Through this institution, the state, the employers and labor sign incomes and prices policies agreements and economic accords as well as discuss government bills before they are sent to parliament. Various tripartite committees in which the social partners participate in more specialized areas of policy making also emerged. After the revolution of 1974, with the loss of the colonial empire in 1975, and the institutionalization of democracy in 1976, this is what Portugal was faced with: (1) economic dependence and vulnerability to international economic shocks, (2) two major economic crises for which Portugal had to resort to the IMF and other international financial institutions, and (3) the need to engage in extensive economic restructuring in order to steer the Portuguese economy away from involvement in protected colonial markets and towards open international competition within the larger context of the European Community of which Portugal became a member in 1986. This dissertation argues that these latter variables can explain the emergence of societal corporatism in democratic Portugal. Portugal's experience, then, provides strong support for the international "economic vulnerability" approach, but it shows also that the extent to which societal corporatism emerges and its degree of stability and permanence is related to internal factors, such as the distribution of class power in civil society, the structure of the class movements, the political system and the state. This dissertation, therefore, proposes a synthesis of both theoretical approaches. Social concertation, by bringing about policy compromises among state, employer, and labor representatives can greatly contribute to the emergence of an overarching class compromise crucial for the survival of democracy in countries in transition to democracy.

Title: The causes and effects of women's participation in Latin American reform movements
Abstract: This thesis explores the role of women in Latin American reform movements. Until recently, this role has been limited. However, due to changes in the international economic climate and changes in the Catholic church's ideology, women have begun to participate in social and political reform movements. This mobilization was facilitated by women's traditional role in society.

Title: At the periphery of democracy: The binational politics of Mexican immigrants in Silicon Valley
Abstract: This dissertation examines the relationship between international migrants and existing political systems by employing a multidisciplinary methodology to study the politics of Mexican immigrants residing in Northern California's Silicon Valley. It contributes to the understanding of Mexican immigrants by transcending current conceptualizations which focus primarily on their relation to the productive process and thereby ignore other roles played by immigrants in the sending and receiving societies. Instead, in this study Mexican immigrants are regarded as citizens of a binational system. The binational character is the historical outcome of the patterns of migration which have been forged by more than a century of massive flows across the international border. This tradition has created a social group with vast and profound ties to both nations. The Mexicans in Silicon Valley express this binationalism in the political realm, through their ideas and activities. The study develops a critical interpretation of the relevant literature. It draws attention to the subordinate role Mexicans play in Silicon Valley and examines the political responses they formulate to the social inequality they encounter in the region. The binational character of Mexican immigrant politics is discussed in three other chapters which analyze: the artistic work of the norteno musical group, Los Tigres del Norte; the organization of a civic campaign against a statue honoring the nineteenth-century military conquest of the Mexican community of San Jose by the United States; and the development of a local movement affiliated with a political party in Mexico, the Partido de la Revolucion Democratica (PRD), and its leader, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas. This study has five major arguments: (1) Mexican immigrants are political beings who have the potential to contribute to the democratization of political systems. (2) Studies of Mexican immigrant politics must consider the possible relation between the process of migration and politics. (3) Explanations of Mexican immigrant politics require the employment of a binational perspective to understand their relationship to the sending and receiving societies, as well as their roles within the broader arena of bilateral relations between Mexico and the United States. (4) Mexican immigrant politics are influenced by the hegemonic regimes found in the sending and receiving societies. (5) The conceptualization of Mexican immigrant politics must be broad enough to include electoral and non-electoral affairs.

Title: Analysis of multicultural crew factors for international manned spaceflight missions
Abstract: The objective of this study was to provide manned spaceflight personnel from the world's space agencies with information on how key cultural and interpersonal communication factors can impact multicultural crew operations and interaction. American, Canadian, European, and Japanese manned spaceflight personnel and officials participated in this study as research collaborators and/or subjects. A two-phased procedure was used to identify key multicultural factors and assess their potential affect on international manned spaceflight crews. In Phase 1, we conducted a literature review, interviews with retired and active astronauts, and administration of written surveys to identify 14 multicultural factors: language, nonverbal communication styles, task- and relationship-oriented behavior, patience and tolerance, assertiveness, decision making processes, interpersonal interest, respect for other cultures, personal hygiene and cleanliness norms, gender roles/norms/stereotypes, conflict management and resolution, trust in people, sense of humor, and crew-machine interfaces. In Phase 2, a detailed questionnaire was developed and administered to our American, Canadian, European, and Japanese manned spaceflight personnel contacts to assess cultural differences and similarities on these 14 factors. The questionnaire grouped the 14 multicultural factors into four sections: language, cultural flexibility and personal space, management styles, and crew-machine interface design. The questionnaires revealed that the four cultural groups have both similar and different attitudes regarding the following areas: (1) verbal communication styles (e.g., slang, profanity, accents, idioms, formal versus informal language), (2) discussion topics (e.g., humor, sex, religion, politics, emotions and personal feelings), (3) cultural norms for work ethics, social behavior, and traditional practices, (4) personal hygiene and cleanliness norms, (5) cultural norms for proxemic and haptic behavior, (6) gender roles in operational settings, (7) management styles and approaches to conflict resolution in different types of situations, and (8) movement stereotypes and color conceptual compatibility for crew-machine interfaces. A conceptual multicultural education and training program for international manned spaceflight crews is proposed and briefly described.

Title: God and Caesar at the Rio Grande: The Sanctuary Movement and the politicization of religion in the United States
Abstract: This dissertation analyzes a religio-political coalition known as the U.S. Sanctuary Movement. The movement was officially inaugurated during the March 1982 public declaration of Sanctuary by Southside United Presbyterian Church in Tucson, Arizona, and comprised a network of churches and synagogues which offered "safe haven" or "sanctuary" to Central American fugitives denied political asylum by the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS). Between March 1981 and May 1986 Sanctuary became a highly volatile locus of U.S. church-state confrontation, eventually resulting in the conviction of eight Sanctuary workers. This ethnography argues that the U.S. Sanctuary Movement is part of a larger "discourse" about U.S. church-state relations and the "articulating presence" of religion and faith in American society. It explores how a particular group of people used religious beliefs and practices to interpret and respond to state authority, and how, in so doing, they reconstituted their cultural world--from their place in the family and church to their identity within the nation and global community. Chapter One discusses some of the theoretical issues that the movement raises for the study of "religious" phenomena, contending that Sanctuary raises important social scientific questions about the relationship of religion to power and social change, and underscoring religion both as a dynamic social force and as a powerful medium of experience. Chapters Two and Three provide an historical account of the Sanctuary Movement between 1980 and 1987. These chapters familiarize the reader with the principal actors and events of the movement, as well as the culture of church-state conflict framing Sanctuary. Chapters Four and Five analyze Sanctuary as an historical tradition, and discusses the different church-state cultures underlying ancient Hebrew, medieval Christian and U.S. sanctuary practices. They also look at how each culture uniquely shaped the nature of the sanctuary "space" at different times in history. The remaining chapters take the reader into "ethnographic" terrain by returning to the sanctuary "spaces" of the contemporary movement. Chapter Six focuses an Tucson's Sanctuary Movement as a cultural phenomenon that "articulates" individuals into a novel social group, specifically by recasting the way in which they perceive and experience themselves as a "church." Chapter Seven explores the unique experiences of Central Americans in Sanctuary and highlights how differences of language, class, culture, religion, and political views profoundly shape the ways in which Sanctuary has "articulated" Central Americans into the movement. Chapter Eight examines Tucson's underground and discusses how "border work" is an expression of both the broader Sanctuary church and a "faithful community." Lastly, Chapter Nine examines Sanctuary's relationship to, and impact on, the reconfiguration of U.S. church-state relations in the 1980s. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: Dialogic critical approaches towards educational reform: An interpretation of change at three middle schools
Abstract: This study experimentally explores a newly developed tool, Dialogic Critical Ethnography (DCE). DCE is grounded in other anthropological and critical interpretation strategies. DCE expands interpretation by addressing the shortcomings of present, applied, ethnographic methodologies--particularly their failure to address the larger social context and to incorporate self-reflexiveness. It is illustrated by employing an idealized heuristic social model, the eco-pacifist future, to document and interpret change for three middle-level school case studies. The future model is based on projections of sociocultural trends, such as constantly changing demographic and economic profiles, and continual movement towards global interdependence. Scholarly, critical and social ideas, such as, holism, community vs. corporate loyalty, evolutionary change, emancipatory democracy, and participants' roles are used to describe educational reorganization. The study proposes five essential elements for a process-oriented curriculum using scholarly, pedagogical ideas, such as, participatory learning, developmental education, and expanding human dimensionality. The interpretive process of DCE compares the eco-pacifist model heuristically--sifting through case study data to discover policy implications to support further change. DCE interpretation is intended to generate a discussion rather than a solution. DCE can result in four outcomes--(a) creating a social context for discussing the purpose of public institutions, (b) documenting change with reference to a predetermined future, (c) deciding how to implement policy, or (d) negotiating and designing another community-based future to act upon. The results of this reflective study are two-fold. First, comparing three case studies to the eco-pacifist future model generates several policy implications for effective schooling. The implications suggest that policy should address both the holistic and the participatory nature of schools including the larger social and economic context, curricular and instructional elements, community base, and roles of participating teachers, administrators, and families. Second, the study indicates that educational research needs to become, in all phases, an advocacy-based, collaborative-, and an action-oriented endeavor. Educational research should incorporate seven characteristics to support this role: (a) seeking pragmatic knowledge; (b) insisting on grounded knowledge; (c) being systemic in inquiry; (d) using multiple perspectives; (e) including multiple time dimensions; (f) being critical; and (g) being reflective.

Title: The impact of oil revenues and government programs on agricultural development in Nigeria
Abstract: This study critically examines the impacts of oil revenues on agriculture and other socioeconomic sectors in Nigeria during the period between 1970 to 1990. Major socioeconomic indicators are regressed against oil revenues to determine the significance of statistical relationships as bases for in-depth analyses of social and economic impacts. The period of the initial oil boom in Nigeria channeled large sums of money into government programs which temporarily benefitted urban sectors, but neglected agriculture. These developments resulted in massive rural-urban migration where workers left the farming areas in anticipation of high paying jobs and better living conditions in the cities. The rural exodus contributed to serious declines in land in crops and agricultural output. Agricultural exports, which had previously contributed substantially to the balance of trade, declined to an insignificant level. Nigeria, which had previously been self sufficient in food production, became a major food importer, further contributing to the decline in the balance of trade. The agricultural sector's contribution to gross domestic product declined from 60 percent in 1960 to less than 10 percent in 1978. The huge oil revenues impacted on the exchange rate, which was favorable during the early phase of oil industry development. Both oil sales over time contributed to currency appreciation with a consequent damaging effect on international trade. The excessive movement of rural workers into the cities for presumed job opportunities related to oil revenue expenditures resulted in massive unemployment. This led to insufficient housing, extreme hunger, unsanitary conditions and crime. During the late 1970's and early 1980's, the Nigerian government initiated several assistance programs to address the decline of agriculture, including national food programs, the green revolution and farm credit programs. These programs, although initiated with good intent, were misguided and mismanaged and thus had minimal impact in reversing the dire economic and social conditions of the agricultural sector. The decline of agriculture and related economic and social conditions is ironic considering the wealth of national and human resources in the country. The study offers suggestions for increasing the effectiveness of agricultural assistance programs to take advantage of the resources available.

Title: Capital accumulation and social change in South Korea and Brazil: An examination of regulation theory and its application
Abstract: The purpose of this study is to suggest an alternative framework with which to understand the capital accumulation and crisis of newly industrializing countries. Because of the limitations of existing liberal and Marxist theories, the potential of the French regulation theory as an alternative framework is explored in this study. An advantage of regulation theory is to see the economic accumulation (regime of accumulation) as occurring within politically and socially institutionalized frameworks (mode of regulation). In spite of this initial vantage point, the structuralist tendency exists in the French regulation theory, which places political and social institutions subordinate to the economic logic of accumulation. Therefore, its utility to analyze internal social structures and class struggles is limited. Eschewing this problem of the French regulation theory, the social structure of accumulation approach, a related framework presented by the North American radicals, can be resorted to as a complementary framework. The social structure of accumulation approach sees the pattern of accumulation as the outcome of power relations among social actors, especially the international and domestic capital, labor, the state, and citizen groups. The SSA approach explains the boom and crisis of accumulation with changes in the power relations among major actors. This framework can be applied to the accumulation and the current crisis of the NICs. South Korea and Brazil, as examples of NICS, have not only similarities as dependent, peripheral Fordism, but also differences in their structures of accumulation and crises. The differences are drawn from specific modes of social structures of accumulation which were created and consolidated by the internal political and social class relations, that were also conditioned and constrained by historical movements of capitalist world system. From the perspective of the French regulation theory and the SSA approach, the capital accumulation of the NICs ran into a crisis, with the deepening crisis in the center of the world system. The demands for political democratization in South Korea and Brazil are, therefore, viewed as part of political struggles to create a new order in the current crisis.

Title: Immigrant music and transnational discourse: Chinese American music culture in New York City
Abstract: The subject of this dissertation is contemporary Chinese American music culture in New York City, and the immigrant musicians, music groups, as well as cultural institutions that are part of it. Significant changes have taken place in the last decade in Chinese American life stemming from a complex process shaped both by the American context and a transnational flow of resources. Recent anthropological and ethnomusicological theories of cultural displacement and cultural complexity serve as the theoretical basis for this inquiry. Local immigrant experience and its musical expression, it is proposed, are conditioned by diasporic movement and a triangular relationship between the host country, the homelands, and the immigrant society. These constant multilevel interactions result in a strong historical consciousness, internal cultural conflicts, and the divergent aspirations of individual musicians. The dissertation is structured to highlight each of the above points, with individual chapters bringing into focus particular elements of the multifaceted Chinese American musical world. Beginning with the social history of Chinese immigration in America, the dissertation evaluates some of the earliest extant musical materials, and discusses the major musical groups which became active in New York City before the end of 1970s. It then turns to the contemporary prism of Chinese American music making, refracting its diverse elements by focusing on musical genres, performance contexts, musical transmission, media products and networks, individual aspirations, modes of interaction, and cultural meanings. The dissertation concludes that the ambiguities and dilemmas faced by Chinese American musicians are paradigmatic of those experienced by other peoples living between two or more worlds. The study further reveals that traditional categories and classifications are no longer adequate, or at least flexible enough to analyze the multifaceted reality of urban immigrant music cultures.

Title: A psychoanalytic study of the cross-cultural encounter between China and the West and its implications for political theory
Abstract: Iconoclasm is an undeniable feature of the past one hundred and fifty years of political, social, cultural, and intellectual change in China. The principal aim of Chinese iconoclasts remains the creation of a "new" or "modern" China constructed in the image of the social and political ideologies they have assimilated during the course of their cross-cultural encounter with Western nations. Drawing upon the psychoanalytic perspective of ethnicity and nationalism developed by the Committee on International Relations of the Group for the Advancement of Psychiatry, I argue that Chinese iconoclasm is a thoroughly dysfunctional approach to the challenges to presented by contact with the West. The history of the past century holds an unbroken chain of violent and destructive political and intellectual campaigns that are guided by the iconoclastic images and rhetoric of the "Chinese Enlightenment", the "New Culture Movement", and the "Cultural Revolution". At the core of the ideology of the "New China" is the particularly Western concept of "modernization", which, because it is misconceived as a universal historical process initiated by Western civilization, leads "modernized" Chinese to inherently negative and fundamentally incorrect views of their individual and collective identity. Vital aspects of the individual Chinese sense of self and society; personal and group concepts of race and biology, history, religion, and language, are consistently impoverished and distorted by the idea of a universal cultural of modernization, science, and technology, an idea introduced and promoted by Western social scientists, journalists, and area specialists. The horrible effects of the concept of "modernization theory" in China call into question its value as a theoretical approach to the relationship between politics and culture.

Title: Learning the hard way: Women labeled with mental retardation describe their "way of knowing"
Abstract: The problem investigated in this qualitative study was as follows: What do women labeled with mental retardation have to say about their lives--their daily experiences, their inner reflections, their learnings, and understandings? And is the epistemological framework proposed by Belenky, Clinchy, Goldberger, and Tarule (1986) in Women's Ways of Knowing broad enough to include the "way of knowing" characteristic of the women in this study? Six women, aged 21 to 55, who had been labeled with mental retardation at some point in their lives, were interviewed several times. Initial data analysis suggested tentative placement for each woman in one or more of Belenky et al.'s five epistemological positions, but no placement seemed to be secure or fully representative of the six participants' way of knowing. The placements were "cameo appearances" which lacked breadth and depth and were unsatisfactory in describing the quality of the women's individual styles of knowing. A fresh perspective, called "knowing-in-action," was developed that incorporated three themes found in the interview data: Action, Control, and Time. The complex mix of social interactions, personal disability, and public policies was discussed in order to highlight the social implications of disability. The study's theoretical perspective was based on concepts of symbolic interaction derived from the work of George Herbert Mead and John Dewey. This study, demonstrated that with a little effort, these women could have been included in the original Belenky, et al. study, and that their presence would have provided a broader framework for understanding a wider spectrum of people. The author asserted that knowing-in-action offers a framework for understanding a particular position of knowing, and that it provides a global base for understanding all "ways of knowing" and movement among the five or six positions. Knowing-in-action is a fresh perspective on the social interactional theory of human growth and development. The knowing-in-action framework was explained, and two models of learning-in-action were suggested as a way of activating the framework in practice. If "voice" is today's metaphor for people whose language is fully developed, "action" was proposed as an additional metaphor for describing how this group of women know their world now. This study concluded that its subjects can be encouraged to develop their "voice" via the context of action.

Title: Theatrical territoriality: A geographical enquiry into protest occupations and mass communication
Abstract: Territoriality is used as a theatrical technique, in the form commonly called the protest occupation, by groups seeking to attract attention through the mass media. Media audiences become involved in distant political struggles because their presence has an effect on the decisions made by the authorities which the protesters are challenging. The act of seizing territory for the purpose of protest sets in motion a complex geographical sequence of events. From the small area seized, images and words move outward through the media to distant audiences. If these audiences are supportive of the protesters, then their support, in effect, moves back in, converging on the place where political decisions are made affecting the protesters' lives. If decision-makers implement new policies, then these policies move out again through space to affect a state or nation, and ultimately shape geopolitics. This chain of effects, although set in motion by a territorial action (the protest occupation), itself transcends territorial boundaries, forming an ephemeral community at the international or global scale. Protests depend upon, and also increase, the interdependence between places, a condition central to modernization. Modernization can be understood as the progressive subordination of the local to the distant. It is the replacement of coherent and essentially closed systems of social relations and human-environment relations, with increasingly open, fragmented systems where boundaries between communities are permeated by flows of goods, people, capital, information, and ideas, as well as moral commitments. By using media to vault over territorial boundaries, building international communities, and appealing to universal rather than local values, protests contribute to modernization. At the same time, protests can provide relief from certain problems of modernity, for both participants and audiences. Three case studies, the U.S. civil rights movement, the 1986 EDSA revolt of the Philippines, and the 1989 occupation of Tiananmen Square in Beijing, examine the protesters' perspective of these processes. The studies illustrate responses to three different structures of national communication and political authority. Each study illustrates how protest is involved in changing conceptions of space, place, and distance in a particular historical and geographical context.
