Title: Interwar peace movements in Britain and the United States: Changing the boundaries of societal participation on security issues and international organization
Abstract: This dissertation evaluates the effects of peace movements in liberal democratic society on security issues, using the movements in Great Britain and the United States between the two World Wars as case studies. It focuses on three problems: (1) when and how the values and actions of peace groups in liberal democratic society constrain or enable states' security policies, (2) to what degree such groups foster standards for state behavior (norms) on security issues, and (3) the impact of the interwar movements on the evolution of international organization. The interwar period continues to fulfill the role of a negative point of reference, of 'how foreign policy should not be conducted,' for social scientists and historians. Analysts have criticized the role of peace movements and public opinion in Great Britain and the United States in upsetting traditional forms and practices of diplomacy and unwisely attempting to institutionalize liberal democratic principles designed for the domestic arena in the international realm. The specific influence of peace movements on policies such as appeasement and neutrality, however, remains unresolved. Where international organization is concerned, not much attention has been given by theorists to the question of why states bothered to re-create a universalist institution after the failures of the League of Nations. The dissertation finds, through examining governmental and movement archives, that the importance of peace movements on issues of disarmament, arbitration, appeasement and neutrality lay in their ability to wield agenda-setting and legitimizing influence, or power. Likewise, where the evolution of international organization is concerned, the dissertation finds that peace movement "agents" also legitimized internationalist norms of universal participation and equality of status, thereby setting boundaries around the type of institutional order deemed possible by governments after the outbreak of World War II. These findings challenge assumptions in international relations theory concerning the role and effects of domestic forces on security and international organization, provide a more concrete understanding of the influence such forces wielded on the contested issues of appeasement and neutrality, and suggest a theoretical framework for understanding and clarifying the relationship between social forces and international change.

Title: The emergent scientific epistemology and international relations
Abstract: Theory in the field of international relations is based on multiple epistemological views, a situation referred to as one of "multiple paradigms." Incommensurable epistemologies render cumulation of knowledge in international relations problematic. At the heart of the controversy over epistemology is this issue: can the field of international relations acquire the attributes of science? Following World War II until the mid 1970s, many social scientists attempted to position their subjects in the scientific tradition. The major instrument was the adoption of the epistemology and methodology of the sciences, especially classical physics. The epistemology was explicitly deterministic, following Newton, Laplace, Saint-Simon, and the philosophy of science known as positivism. Social scientists called their effort the behavioral movement and argued that only observable behavior could be scientifically studied. Research was directed toward the discovery of regularities and laws. Critics pointed to the inability of behavioral studies to explain features of the international system, especially change and discontinuities. The critics included traditionally-oriented scholars, normative, relative, and ideological theorists; and, more recently, postmodernist theorists. The force of the critique and the failure of deterministic epistemology led to the abandonment of the goal of adopting the methods and epistemology of the physical sciences to international relations. The critiques assumed the epistemology was required to be explicitly deterministic and positive. In the natural sciences and mathematics, however, this requirement has come under question, and a new natural science epistemology is replacing traditional Newtonian epistemology. Researchers in other social sciences are already applying the epistemology and resulting methodology. This emergent scientific epistemology is well-suited to the construction of international relations theory since principal features--nonlinearity, indeterminacy, emergence, conditionality, and complexity--typify the international system. The emergent scientific epistemology is non-behavioral; it acknowledges the importance of phenomena which are not directly observable, including thought. It is argued that international relations scholars should revisit scientific epistemology to return the field to the goal of knowledge cumulation. An accompanying case study examines how a deterministic model for crisis bargaining could be adapted to produce an emergent model. Mathematical and theoretical appendices are included.

Title: Unionization trends in postwar capitalism: A comparative study of working class organization
Abstract: This dissertation tries to explain variability in unionization in advanced capitalist countries during the postwar period. I investigate the effects of two labor market institutions--centralized collective bargaining and union-controlled unemployment insurance schemes (or "Ghent systems")--on unionization. Bayesian statistical methods provide a unified approach to comparative social research, and these inform the subsequent analysis. Examination of union density time-series from 18 OECD countries reveals three unionization trends: a small group of (mostly Scandinavian) countries grew continuously; a larger heterogeneous group changed little; a third group, including the United States and Japan, declined from the mid-1950s. A comparative historical discussion suggests union growth is associated with national level bargaining and the Ghent system; industry bargaining prevailed in the middle group; local bargaining was common in countries with declining unions. Evidence for these relationships was augmented by a Bayesian regression analysis. Time-series analysis showed the effects of the business cycle and other longitudinal determinants of unionization depended on the institutional setting. Unemployment is generally negatively related to union density, but this relationship is reversed under Ghent systems. Strike activity only positively influences unionization if collective bargaining is fragmented. Analysis of social survey data indicated the link between union membership and the industry, occupational, and demographic characteristics of workers was also conditional on institutions. Centralized bargaining narrowed differences in unionization rates across industries and occupations; the Ghent system reduced the gender and age gaps in unionization. Despite divergent trajectories for most of the postwar period, union movements were commonly declining in the 1980s. A hazard rate model of union decline was used to examine the effects of increasing global competition, collective bargaining decentralization, and social democratic electoral decline. Results indicate that state and labor market institutions widely drove union decline from the late 1970s. The results suggests that unions grow where class is an organizing principle embedded in highly encompassing labor market institutions. More generally, the institutional existence of class is a mechanism for working class organization in trade unions.

Title: The meaning system of North American adherents of Hindu-based beliefs and practices: Its reconstruction and its implications
Abstract: Hindu-based spiritual traditions offer North Americans an alternative philosophical, spiritual, and ethical stance within the dominant culture. The radically different views of reality, self, and human goals offered by these traditions prompt the question of what particular meanings the adherents embrace. My study reconstructs the adherents' meaning system and discusses its personal and social implications. The paradigm for investigation is that reality construction is a subjective and intentional act. The participants were ten adherents affiliated with the Siddha Yoga Dham of America, the Himalayan International Institute of Yoga Science and Philosophy of the U.S.A., and Transcendental Meditation. I employed ethnographic methods of conversation-interviews and participant-observation. My approach was informed by phenomenological and hermeneutic perspectives necessary to deal with the subjective, symbolic world of the spiritual seeker and to accommodate my own subjective horizons. The participants' seeking is integral to creating meaning. Four patterns emerged: early yearning for the direct experience of "God"; extensive exploration: periodic "inner" awakenings; and, an interplay of complex personal, familial and religious factors. Meanings are created through an interactive dynamic of ideas, gnostic experiences, and growth experiences. Daily spiritual practices undergird the participants' efforts, thus creating a "way of life". Their fundamental beliefs are that unitary consciousness underlies manifest reality; that pure consciousness exists within the individual as the Self; that the guru embodies this Self; and, that spiritual evolution includes concepts of reincarnation, karma, and dharma. Shifts in perspective constituting personal growth enable participants to recognize that life is interconnected; the universe is benign; the presence and wisdom of the Self manifest when the mind is stilled; body and mind are an entity and a vehicle for the Self; and, spiritual development fosters mastery over self. The participants negotiate the dominant culture and the Judeo-Christian tradition yet remain within the mainstream. However, their efforts constitute important ontological and epistemological experimentation that may point to a social trend. If the Hindu-based systems are to have lasting impact, it will likely be in conjunction with parallel social movements, such as, feminism, environmentalism, eco-spirituality, and alternative healing.

Title: Class policy within the nation: The Social Democrats and the defence of Finnish autonomy, 1905-1917
Abstract: The Finnish Workers' Party was founded in 1899, a few months after the actual conflict between Russia and Finland broke out. In 1903 the party adopted a socialist programme and changed its name to the Finnish Social Democratic Party. From the very beginning the combination of social and national demands was an essential feature of the workers' movement in its struggle for autonomy. In parallel with the international social democratic patterns in Finland, there also developed a special concept of patriotism, different from that of the ruling class. An essential aspect of the workers' movement concept of patriotism was the demand for social, as well as political, reforms and the calling into question of the existing undemocratic political institutions. In this study the party has been researched as a political organisation articulating the interests of its supporters such as it understood them within the struggle for national autonomy. The main goal of the research was to explain how the party theoretically argued and in practice solved the problem of the relation between revolutionary class struggle and the national question. The Finnish Social Democratic Party was international in ideology and programme. The issue of nationalism and internationalism was closely linked to the attitude of the party towards the Russian revolutionaries. After the Great Strike of 1905 the Finnish Social Democrats were convinced that the progress of the Russian revolutionary movement was in principle, as well as in practice, the solution to the Finnish issue. This revolutionary perspective of the coming upheavel in Russia remained mostly unchanged within the Social Democrats during the First World War.

Title: Asian scholars in the United States: Careers, roles and contributions to the international knowledge system
Abstract: This study focuses on the careers, roles and contributions of Asian-born scholars in US academe to the international knowledge system. Asian scholars are important for study in order to understand patterns involving the international movement of highly-educated personnel from the stage of learning to that of production and dissemination of knowledge and technology in the changing context of the world economy. This study employed in-depth interviewing as the methodology for data collection. Forty-six Asian scholars from six Asian countries--China, Hong Kong, India, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan, in three major research universities in New York state were interviewed. This study finds the following: First, Asian scholars are identified by their tripartite role in the international knowledge system as learners, producers and distributors of knowledge and technology. The role of Asian scholars illustrates the international division of labor in knowledge production and dissemination in relation to the uneven development of higher education systems and research environments. Second, in US academe, Asian scholars view themselves primarily as researchers rather than teachers or administrators. Third, Asian scholars' scientific relationships with their countries of origin are based on the supply-demand formula in the use of knowledge and technology. The association of supply and demand reflects the changing economic and political domains in their respective countries. Results suggest that Asian-born scholars in US academe are a valuable resource for facilitating economic, political and academic contacts between the US and Asian countries. The roles of Asian faculty in the US higher education system are increasing in the fields of science and engineering where they have contributed to advancing science and technology. Asian academics in the humanities and social sciences have also played a significant part in encouraging cultural exchange and broadening of perspectives in the academy and society.

Title: A quest for self-determination: The African Methodist Episcopal church during the age of imperialism, 1884-1916
Abstract: Many African Americans at the turn of the twentieth century concluded that the increased racial prejudice and violence that they suffered was a part of the political, social, and economic domination that European and American imperialists were attempting to impose upon the rest of the globe. In the face of this imperial agenda--an agenda by which the stronger nations of the world seemingly led a worldwide movement against darker people--many of the men and women of the AME developed a black political and theological consciousness that expressed the need for universal human rights and emphasized self-determination and equality for oppressed people at home and abroad. Aided by official AME publications, minutes, and records as well as a wealth of secondary sources, this study examines the responses and actions of the highly political, confident, and outspoken AME clergy and influential lay people to American, European, and Asian imperialism and related international event and issues. As international spokespersons of color, many of the women and men of the AME sought to gain and preserve the autonomy of indigenous and oppressed people across the globe from the Philippines to Ireland to South Africa. Moreover, they sought to overturn the prevalent racial theories and pseudo sciences that confirmed white supremacy on the basis of the supposed inferiority of people of color. In doing so, they maintained a firm belief in western, especially American and Christian, principles of liberty and equality, often leading to conflicts, contradictions, paradoxes, and dilemmas for AME members. Nevertheless, they continuously expressed a cosmopolitan outlook that was concerned with the future of the world and their place in that future.

Title: Organizing and improvising: A history of Philadelphia's Black Musicians' Protective Union Local 274, American Federation of Musicians
Abstract: This dissertation is a social historical study of the emergence, formation and demise of "colored" musicians' union, Local 274 of the American Federation of Musicians which existed from 1935 to 1971 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Utilizing primary source data, it analyzes the evolution of Local 274 as a social phenomenon rooted in the consciousness and collective behavior of Black musicians in Philadelphia. This study provides a detailed account of the history of one of the most significant efforts by Philadelphia's Black working-class musicians, acting as organized workers, to form a union to service their needs. Examining African-American musicians as an urban-based working class group, this study provides an account of Black musicians' activities as participants in the American labor movement. The majority of Black musicians' union activities examined in this study took the form of racial discrimination and segregation in the labor movement as well as the city of Philadelphia. This study documents the determination of Black musicians to overcome racial discrimination and segregation through collective action. Seldom have the organized labor practices of working class Black musicians been studied. This study provides an account of the experiences of African-American musicians as politicized urban workers in the music and entertainment professions. Special attention is given to specific civil rights legislation and AFM's union mandates to adhere to laws in the form of a nation-wide merger program. The AFM's merger program resulted in the eventual demise of over fifty "colored" musicians' unions in the AFM. Ironically, the institution of certain civil rights policies and the AFM's merger program contributed to the assimilation of Black musicians into white majority locals that did not address issues directly related to the welfare of African-American musicians. As a consequence, Black musicians lose representation and power because of the AFM's desegregation program. This study provides an account of Local 274, the last independent Black musicians' union in the AFM, efforts to resist consolidation with white Local 77 and its subsequent expulsion from the international for refusal to merge.

Title: The center will not hold: Contests of meaning in culture and education
Abstract: Antonio Gramsci wrote that "every relationship of 'hegemony' is necessarily an educational relationship."$\sp1$ In this context Gramsci was not simply referring to the forms of teaching that one commonly associates with the classroom, but the profoundly political process through which citizens are socialized to recognize and validate state power. This process infuses all components of the social apparatus: the office, the library, the museum, and particularly the school. This dissertation addresses the way knowledge is regulated and meaning is shaped within these various social locations. It analyzes how such notions as patriotism, citizenship, community, and family are contested within institutions, both public and private. The analysis departs from conventional critiques of purportedly "dominant" discourses by positing the "negotiated" character of power and the reciprocal nature of communication. The dissertation argues that democracy is enhanced by a relationship of dialogue that defers universal "truth." To lend specificity to these textual exegeses, I examine the deployment of signs within a range of social practices and commodity forms. Only by studying the ways metaphors are actually used within movements and communities can one gain a full understanding of their operation. I am interested in this relationship of textual production and reception on both individual and collective levels. Not only do these issues bear heavily on issues of identity and agency, they are also important in the articulation of potentially unifying (and alienating) public spaces. Specific chapters will address the following topics: an overview of theoretical issues and concerns relevant to this study; the history and current state of government cultural and arts education policy; the role of official reports and foundation documents in policy formation; conflicting arts and curricular materials surrounding issues of work and family; and the influence of media literacy on national identity. The study closes with a chapter summarizing the implications of this research as they relate to a democratic society. ftn$\sp1$Antonio Gramsci, Selections from the Prison Notebooks, Quintin Hoare, ed. (New York: International Publishers, 1972).

Title: Fela, the Afrobeat king: Popular music and cultural revitalization in West Africa
Abstract: This is a study of the role of popular expressive culture in change in Africa. It examines musicians and the forms they create, showing how music and musicians can serve mediating and revitalizing purposes. The data for this study were gathered in West Africa, particularly in the city of Lagos, in southwestern Nigeria. They derive from participant observation, interviewing, and collection and analysis of musical compositions, song lyrics, public speeches and events, and press coverage. Chapter 1 discusses roles of African music in dynamic social contexts, and the idea of cultural revitalization. Chapter 2 provides general contextual background and musical background on Nigeria. Chapters 3 through 5 cover the nature and implications of the popular music profession in Nigeria. Chapter 3 deals with fundamental occupational aspects such as recruitment, leadership, and career development. Chapter 4 covers professional concerns and problems, as they pertain to the music industry in west Africa, and Chapter Five explores issues of cultural development related to music and musicians. Chapters 6 through Chapter 10 contain a case study of the famous musician and political figure Fela Anikulapo-Kuti. Chapter 6 covers relevant aspects of ethnic, family, personal, and musical background. Chapter 7 analyzes, in musical and sociocultural terms, the creation of the Afrobeat musical idiom by Fela Kuti. Chapters 8 through 10 follow his career in political and musical terms, with particular attention to the interaction of personal considerations with larger societal issues. This study finds that there are strengths and liabilities perhaps inherent in charismatic leadership in Africa. In the case of Fela Anikulapo-Kuti, the thrust for cultural revitalization and political power is aimed at local problems, but also at a large, international system of neocolonialism and multi-dimensional dependency. Such a movement can be created dynamically in response to changing conditions and threats. Although charismatic leadership is "uncommon" and personalized, there are historical antecedents and contemporary models of movement and action in Africa--especially here, Pan-Africanist and populist models. Communication through music, for this kind of movement in Africa, is a particularly powerful tool in social criticism and action, and in presenting new models of identity.

Title: From thinking like a machine to thinking like a mountain: Educational restructuring or ecological literacy?
Abstract: Many prominent environmentalists contend that current patterns of consumption and population growth are seriously undermining the resource base and biological health upon which the well-being of future generations depends, creating what they assert is the most critical issue on the public agenda, the "crisis of sustainability." Offering different perspectives on this issue, representatives from the world's less affluent nations, meeting with other heads of state in June, 1992, at the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development ("Earth Summit") in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, noted that both poverty and environmental degradation had increased substantially during the 1980s, and concluded that current economic arrangements and the dominant model for Third World development were rigged against ecological health and economic justice. The dominant response from national governments has been to advocate "sustainable development," a strategy purported to meet the needs of the present generation without jeopardizing the welfare of succeeding generations, through stimulating "more rapid economic growth in both industrial and developing countries." They consider faster growth the best means for creating the wealth and new technologies required to alleviate poverty and "clean up" the environment. Many environmentalists have strongly disagreed with this strategy. Meanwhile, educational reform proposals within the United States have targeted the promotion of economic growth while excluding ecological concerns and sustainability altogether. During the late 1980s and into the 1990s, consensus developed within the dominant reform discourse that changes in the global economy required "systemic" change in American education, convictions culminating in the educational restructuring movement. This movement, strongly supported by President Clinton and members of his cabinet, aimed to reduce existing inequities and resulting social tensions in America by generating more vigorous economic growth and wider prosperity. The strategy intends to increase worker productivity, primarily by restructuring businesses and schools into "high performance workplaces," and thereby accelerate economic growth. Through reviewing the salient literature in the discourses of educational restructuring and ecological health, I critique the assumptions of the restructuring movement, recommending instead a proposal for redesigning our educational processes to promote "ecological literacy," a blending of ecological thinking with the cultivation of civic competence.

Title: "Into the sunlight of a new day": The beliefs and work of two women peace activists in the Vancouver area during the Cold War
Abstract: Women of European ancestry have participated in social movements for hundreds of years. The peace movement in particular has enjoyed the significant involvement of women. Initially inspired by strong Christian tenets and comprised of an expressly Christian membership, the Euro-American peace movement became increasingly secular in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Such associations provided venues for the analyses, leadership and organizing talents of women who viewed peace as the vital underpinning of a just and good society. In these groups women developed and refined universal political skills that advanced their political status as women. Even while employing certain domestic traditions evolved largely in private, patriarchal family contexts, women peace-makers publicly challenged Western patriarchal traditions of militarism and war. In British Columbia, a Canadian province with a history of primary-industry labour militancy and varied, persistent, self-defined progressive groups, a women's peace tradition began in 1921, persevering through World War Two and beyond. This thesis describes and analyzes the beliefs and work of two Vancouver-area women peace activists during the Cold War period. Sheila Young and Mildred Fahrni assumed major roles and responsibilities in the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, the Fellowship Of Reconciliation and the Voice Of Women. This examination concentrates not only on motivations but also on methods used by Young and Fahrni to establish networks and relationships, organize events and achieve and exercise leadership. Insofar as they represent socialized gender norms in their era, Young and Fahrni demonstrated beliefs and practices consistent with the ideology of maternalism. The claim is made that their pioneering work, personal tenacity and political optimism proved crucial in perpetuating a viable women's peace practice in British Columbia. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: Interpretations of sustainability: Worldviews of environmental activists with the Save Georgia Strait Alliance of British Columbia
Abstract: This dissertation in geography draws on contemporary environmental and sustainability concepts to interpret the worldviews of a group of environmental activists from the locale of the Georgia Strait in B.C. The activists' worldviews are first described collectively and then examined for differences according to hypothesized influences on environmentalists' worldview formation. The worldviews are then evaluated against a set of sustainability principles for the broader purpose of examining this group's contributions and for evaluating sustainability theory in context and praxis. The worldviews of the activists have a broadly similar 'progress redefined' to 'ecocentric' orientation. This work makes clear that the group as a whole desires significant change to the existing institutional arrangements for decision-making in society - the market and existing 'democratic' decision-making structures and processes; and are critical of the primacy accorded to economic growth, consumption, the individual, and the criterion of economic efficiency. Further, they believe that ensuring equity between generations is a fundamental facet of the problematic, and that community-building and our relationship with non-human nature must be redefined as essential to resolving problems of the environment. The differences in worldviews across the activists were found to be associated with a number of factors, of which orientation of education, experience in other social movements, gender, and 'lived situation' proved most influential. Those with some background in 'green' theory and/or experience in other social movements proved to have more ecocentric-oriented worldviews in dimensions of social equity and appropriate rationality; women tend to emphasise processes of inclusion, consensus, community, and issues dealing with patriarchy more than men; and 'lived situation'--a composite of institutional setting, environmental issues of concern, and social and geographic attributes of the particular activist's community helped to delineate difference in worldviews, though with no general orientation in this difference. In evaluating the activists' worldviews it is evident that full comprehension of the social, political, and economic considerations intrinsic to the global discussion of sustainability is not generally the case though this varies across the group. Most of the principles of sustainability are acknowledged by the activists, but deeper understanding and efforts were found to be most strongly related to those principles which have greater relevance to their community and region. The more global-oriented issues of economic restructuring, meeting basic human needs and equity considerations were found to be less-well conceived aspects of the activists' worldviews. However, in consideration of thinking globally and acting locally, the contextual application of sustainability theory, evaluation suggests that the activists' worldviews and efforts are in many ways appropriate to the regionally prevailing socio-political, economic and environmental conditions of their 'lived situation'. Evaluation according to geographic context does suggest that closer attention be paid to issues of how to restructure local and regional politics and decision-making such that principles of sustainability are more adequately addressed both in process and in substance. The environmental movement as partially reflected by this set of key informants has much to offer to the unfolding concept of sustainability, as it is interpreted for time and place, and to the broader process of social transformation in society towards developing sustainability.

Title: The role of Canadian universities in the international development: A comparative case study of the University of Alberta and the University of British Columbia
Abstract: This research involved a theoretical and practical exploration of Canadian universities' role in international development in relation to Canada's Official Development Assistance policies. First, it was evident that the development roles of the University of Alberta, the University of British Columbia, and other Canadian institutions have been greatly influenced by the historical legacy of the first three development decades which were driven by on modernization and human capital theories of development. Secondly, the source of change in the current development roles of Canadian universities can be attributed to three key factors: the shift from industrial to information-based economies in OECD nations; the demand for increased global competitiveness through applied research and development, and a growing demand for fiscal accountability in higher education. The direction of change in the universities' development role is witnessed in the growing movement among OECD nations to 'internationalize' higher education. Canadian universities have responded by adopting varying models of internationalization such as the corporate, the liberal-democratic and the social transformation models. Based on the findings of this study, it appears that at an institutional level, the international development activities of the University of Alberta and the University of British Columbia fall mainly within the parameters of the corporate and liberal-democratic models of internationalization. The implications of this trend are a decline in institutional partnerships in the Third World and a corresponding decline in student enrollment from these countries, followed by an increase in university/business partnerships and rapid growth in applied research and development initiatives. The likely outcome is the increasing commodification of knowledge for profit. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: An examination of female genital alteration as an international human rights violation
Abstract: This thesis explores female genital alteration as a human rights violation. Because this practice is embedded in the social framework of numerous African countries, a substantial portion of this study is devoted to its cultural underpinnings. To establish a perspective from which to understand female genital alteration, Isabelle Gunning's article is critiqued as a model. Drawing from this analysis, a tripartite approach is introduced to explain how eradication strategies could or have been formulated. Through the examination of the local, national, and international levels, it was concluded that implementing educational programs at the local level remains the most viable alternative in eradicating this practice. Though many agree that female genital alteration fundamentally contradicts human rights accorded to women and children, law--whether national or international--has proven inept and counter-effective. Eradication movements need to start locally, disseminate information through education, and include those who perpetuate the practice.

Title: Evangelical parachurch movements in ghanaian christianity, c1950-early 1990s
Abstract: The thesis examines the origins, growth and indigenisation of parachurch movements, in their primary and secondary forms, in the context of established Christianity in Ghana in the post-war era. The historical accounts explore the operations of primary groups, particularly, Scripture Union and kindred Christian Fellowships, stimulating the development of secondary independent evangelistic and charismatic organisations. It includes early and later movements towards independency, culminating in "church formation" a metamorphosis in the whole parachurch movement. The indigenous and exogenous components of the parachurch phenomena - evangelical and Pentecostal, are discussed to indicate the complex multi-1ateral determinant factors involved. The very significant background factors include the traditional religion and national political and socio-economic situations to which the parachurch groups respond in diverse ways. Church relations emerges as the immediate problem in parachurch operations. Parachurch operations are intended to complement that of the Church, but they generate issues of conflict and mistrust which are discussed as they emerge in the historical accounts. Particular international and local efforts towards resolving conflict and promoting co¬ operation are considered. A detailed examination is made of the evangelicalism of the parachurch movements, expressed in terms of doctrinal affirmations, commitment to the Bible and evangelism, and particular modest acts of social concern. A radical brand of evangelicalism emerges with Pentecostal influence, involving the adoption of the music and spirituality of local Pentecostal Churches. Hence the engagement in fasting and extended prayer with glossolalia, particularly in all-night prayer meetings; focus on prophecies and visions; with the ministry of healing and deliverance emerging and enduring as evangelical Pentecostal response to the supernatural realities of the African world. The evangelical pentecostal impact of the parachurch movements on church life is evident in the rise of growth of charismatic renewal movements within the Protestant Churches, as indicated by the case of the Methodist Church which has been selected for special treatment.

Title: Scottish international skilled labour mobility.
Abstract: The topic of international skilled labour mobility has received growing attention within the field of population geography and other disciplines. This interest reflects the large growth of international skilled labour mobility, especially during the 1980s. Attention of prior research has focused on the migratory movement of managers and professionals as they radiate across the globe, recording and representing the dispersal of international investment and the overseas expansion of producers of goods and services. The research examines Scotland's participation in the international exchange of skilled labour. The research undertaken addresses the varying theoretical, conceptual and methodological approaches of prior research on international skilled labour mobility in geography, as well as in other disciplines, such as management studies and occupational psychology. In doing so, the interplay between work and non-work spheres in shaping Scottish international skilled labour mobility is highlighted, as is the differing temporal and spatial focus of existing studies. The author's research thus investigates both the economic and social contexts of Scottish international skilled labour mobility, these contexts being characterised at macro, meso and micro level. In addition, the research adopts a broader definition of skilled labour movements than prior research, and so the study discusses the place of short term business travel as well as longer term migratory movements and the relationship between them. In illustrating the economic context of Scottish international skilled labour mobility, the research outlines macro level changes in the Scottish economy and the role of foreign direct investment as a source and channel of Scottish skill exchange. In turn, the specific institutional characteristics of activities generating these labour flows are examined and related to the occupational status of mobile persons.

Title: Post-Marxist development praxis: NGDOs and new social movement theory
Abstract: This paper examines Non-Governmental Development Organizations (NGDOs) as a new transnational social movement which acts to extend the reach of civil society within the international aid regime and to democratize new and existing public spaces at local, national and international levels. The paper concludes that the movement is divided with regard to the degree that it contests the 'orthodox' meaning of development associated with market-led/state-managed export growth strategies under the rubric of structural adjustment. The terrain of civil society, occupied by the NGDO movement within the international aid regime, is itself the site of struggle between progressive/post-marxist and neo-conservative NGDOs. Therefore, the NGDO movement has a transformative potential only to the degree that the popular sector organizations with whom they work, act on 'participatory development' ideology to effect institutional insertions within the formal political arena, on their own terms, and in a way that transforms previously non-responsive state and multilateral aid agency structures.

Title: Political protest against economic loss in mid and late 20th century Canada: The role of beliefs regarding distributive justice
Abstract: Many Canadians experienced economic loss in the 1980s and 1990s, particularly loss of economic security. Yet this loss did not give rise to political protest of the kind seen in Canada in the 1930s. It did not provoke significant numbers of Canadians to engage in political acts such as marching, demonstrating, signing a petition, or working for a party. Some scholars have sought insights into the relative quiescence of the 1980s and 1990s by comparing these years with the 1930s. They have focused on the presence or absence of various preconditions for protest, such as social homogeneity. This study accepts some of the findings of others but argues that a variable that has had insufficient attention, thus far, is beliefs regarding distributive justice. More specifically, it argues that, while Canada's political culture has been dominated by market liberalism throughout the 20th century, it has also contained elements of populism, more pronounced in the early years of the century. In the 1930s, economic losers could press claims for redress with reference to a populist egalitarian notion of distributive justice that held that "breadwinners" willing to do "honest toil" were entitled to a "square deal." This notion formed part of several contending ideologies promoted by new parties. However, it declined over the next 50 years and its key concepts disappeared from public debate. Economic losers in the 1980s and 1990s had no comparable strong ground on which to challenge market liberalism, in particular, the liberal worldview that situated power in global economic systems and prescribed individual "flexibility" as the remedy for persistent unemployment. Such losers had only so-called "welfare liberalism," which demanded no more of the state than that it provide financial assistance, e.g., help with training, to individuals seeking "flexibility." The decline of the honest toil = square deal notion of distributive justice is explained here in part by changing economic, social and cultural conditions, and in part by the eroding effects of two strong ideological currents, both ironically viewed as "progressive": the Social Gospel movement, and the youth protest movement of the 1960s.

Title: A cultural mirror: The development of international education curricula in American classrooms
Abstract: This study will examine the international perspectives found within school curricula, with particular attention given to the fields of history, geography, and social studies. Deliberations on how to include international perspectives in the curricula began as early as the first decade of this century, were affected by both isolationist and internationalist currents following the first World War, and were broadened significantly after World War II. By the 1990s, educators were asking if international education was, indeed, a separate subject or merely a set of perspectives to be infused into the curricula. What were the parameters of international education? Should it be defined as a study of international themes, individual countries, or many different cultures? How does internationalism or multiculturalism "fit" into United States civics courses? Does the international or global curriculum in use today provide "balanced" viewpoints? This research offers an answer to these questions. Three states, Minnesota, Florida, and Virginia, have been in the forefront of the international education movement. Since the three states used policy statements, curriculum reform, professional development, and special initiatives to promote international education, they were selected for additional study to determine answers to two questions: What international curriculum is currently being taught to students in grades K-12; and what conclusions have been reached about the international education curricula that are needed by the American student today. To provide cross-national comparisons, the author examined international perspectives in the K-12 curricula of Japan and Great Britain. The survey instrument used in Minnesota, Florida, and Virginia was also translated into Japanese and distributed to principals in Osaka and Kagawa prefectures. Japanese educators have thus informed us about the scope of their international programs and offered their own proposals for the international content of K-12 social studies. Educators today must attempt to determine what our students have an opportunity to learn about the world and work proactively to put in place a global curriculum that creates broader opportunities. The research that follows will help to establish major features of current classroom practice and indicate what educators see as the desirable elements of more effective programs in international education. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: Total liberation: Spirituality for Green politics
Abstract: This cross-disciplinary dissertation linking Religious Studies with Political Economics examines research where the contemporary diversity criteria--sensitivity to gender, race, class, and species perspectives--guide investigation. An expanded theory of the temporal dimension of salvation linking these perspectives is generated. Salvation conceived as transformation from diverse foci of false-centeredness (false self, species, race, and gender) integrates spiritual and philosophical movements influencing the development of international Green politics. Complementarity is evidenced between movements (spiritual and philosophical, mainstream and counter-cultural) that otherwise contradict one another's claims to be addressing the deepest source of oppression. The introduction sets the context of diverse theories of evil. Chapter two, "Beyond Egocentrism," discusses transformation from false-self-centeredness to true self. This theme of Axial Age religions is illustrated and refined by responding to ethical, feminist, and psychotherapeutic critiques of self-denial with reminders of the religious two-self distinction. Chapter three, "Beyond Anthropocentrism," discusses transformation from human centeredness, with emphasis on post-Axial civilization and modernity, for the integrity of creation. Illustrations from deep ecology, eco-spirituality, and the Native American holocaust and spirituality are employed. Chapter four, "Beyond ethnocentrism," discusses transformation from ethnicity-and race-centeredness, with emphasis on Eurocentrism, to eco-justice. Illustrations from social ecology and the African-American holocaust and spirituality are employed. Chapter five, "Beyond Androcentrism," discusses transformation from gender-centeredness to gender partnership, with emphasis on patriarchy. Illustrations from ecofeminism and feminist spirituality are employed. Chapter six, "Toward Green Politics," explores holistic models of the interrogatedness of social institutions and the diuersity of liberation perspectives, integrating them in political economic philosophies that move beyond econocentric, cold war capitalism and communism. The culturally pluralist and ecological political economic philosophy of the international Green political movement and parties is introduced. A conclusion summarizes the findings: communism is dead, capitalism is unsustainable, Green political economic theory is being developed and tested, integrating personal liberation with the liberation of women, people of color, and the biosphere. The postmodern politics of difference and suspicion of totalism, however, necessitate progressive coalitions of Greens, feminists, people of color, and other marginalized groups.

Title: Print media coverage of the Beijing pro-democracy movement: A content analysis
Abstract: Considering news as a product of the complex interplay of the dominant political power, as a social construction of reality, and as a significant cultural form, this study analyzes coverage of the Beijing pro-democracy movement in 1989 across five newspapers. The five papers under study were The New York Times, People's Daily of mainland China, The Times of London, Sing Tao Daily of Hong Kong, and United Daily News of Taiwan. The period of observation was from April 18 to June 15, 1989. The first three paragraphs of news stories related to the Beijing pro-democracy movement in the five newspapers were coded and analyzed. The content analysis results revealed that thematic emphasis of the Beijing movement was similar across the five newspapers. Pro-democracy movement, government/party, local/foreign reactions, and military/police were the leading themes across the papers. However, the Beijing story presented by the five papers varied noticeably in tone, especially between the national and international coverage. Treating The New York Times and The Times of London as foreign papers, United Daily News and Sing Tao Daily as papers of mixed domestic and foreign characters due to Hong Kong and Taiwan's political and cultural ties to China, and People's Daily as an exclusively national publication, three versions of the Beijing story were revealed. In fact, each paper reflected its society's concern and presented its own meaning of the story. Similar patterns of reporting in the emphasis of broad news themes across the five countries appeared to be the product of the universal journalistic practices. Differences in the portrayal of the Beijing movement and the Chinese authority seemed attributable to government influence and sociopolitical conditions existing in the countries at the time the event occurred.

Title: Gaia, the planetary religion: The sacred marriage of art and science
Abstract: As the human race approaches the 21st Century, the world's spiritual, political, social, economic, educational, and scientific philosophies appear out of balance with the emerging global consciousness brought forth by today's advancing technologies. Former President Bush's New World Order is really the same old nation state order of international anarchy. All the ancient problems seem to have reached a critical point. Now, a critical idealism in education, which is a call for spiritual action, is necessary in order to have the power to bond like-minds to cure our ancient social diseases. The scientific and social movement which scientist James Lovelock named the Gaia theory, named after the Greek Goddess of the Earth, is on the verge of creating world-wide evolutionary change. My dissertation attempts to help create a Gaian philosophy of planetary education based on love between the sexes by analyzing the function of epic poetry.

Title: Envisioning a new America: The worldviews, praxis orientations and futuristic visions of three subcultures within the American Green movement
Abstract: This dissertation identifies three major subcultures within the American Green movement. I call these three subcultures Neo-Primitivism, Mystical Deep Ecology and Social Ecology. Chapter One introduces the scope of this project, the beginning assumptions, and the international Green movement. Chapter One further presents an historical overview of the Green movement and American Green roots. Theories concerning the rise of Green cultures in modern industrial societies (from sociological, historical, psychological, cultural and paradigm-oriented perspectives), are also featured. Chapter Two depicts the field of American Green studies, describes the modern history of the American Green movement and explores the worldviews of the three American Green subcultures (Neo-Primitivism, Mystical Deep Ecology and Social Ecology). Chapter Three details the vast differences in praxis orientations practiced by the three American Green subcultures. These praxis orientations should be of utmost interest to those involved in the study of political science, Green politics and the future. Green praxis orientations are transition strategies undertaken to attempt movement from the critiqued present to a better future. Chapter Four illustrates the futuristic eutopian visions embraced by members of the three subcultures of the American Green movement. A scenario featuring a day in the life of a typical member of each subculture has been created. Each scenario has been evaluated to determine subculture adherence to the four primary values advocated by the Greens: ecology, social justice, nonviolence and democracy. Chapter Five delves deeply into the "dark side" of the American Green movement subcultures. By projecting the dystopian potential inherent in the writing of major subculture theorists, it is hoped these dystopian possibilities can be guarded against. In each dystopian scenario presented in Chapter Five adherence to the four primary Green values has been subsumed by the more negative elements inherent in that subculture's worldview, praxis orientation or futuristic vision. Chapter Six examines the areas discussed in this dissertation in a conclusionary manner. The relationship between each subculture and the four primary Green values is analyzed. The probable futures of each subculture is also explored. An analysis of the role which each subculture could play in future political change in America is presented.

Title: Being at-risk: The communication of social support in ninth-grade
Abstract: Unacceptably high dropout rates continue to plague the American High School. The costs to the individual and society are profound and suggest an impetus for change. While most research has attempted to chronicle the reasons for why students dropout of school, few have examined more global and potentially mediating factors impacting the movement of students from being at-risk of dropping out to dropping out. This study addresses one possible mediating factor: the communication of social support. It is argued that the communication of social support, which has been demonstrated to be effective in mitigating the effects of acute and chronic physical and psychological health problems, may also be instrumental in keeping children in school. As exploratory research, this study focuses on the communication of social support as it was perceived by a sample of ninth grade at-risk boys who attended a large urban/suburban high school in San Antonio, Texas. The findings of this research suggest that the ninth grade boys' social support networks are not very extensive and that each type of support provider in the network is likely to primarily communicate different kinds of social support. Briefly, the results indicate that these ninth grade boys rely predominately on friends and mothers for social support communicating acceptance and assurance. Of particular interest, however, were the findings that the communication of non-support was also perceived as important to the ninth grade boys. Among those who provided more non-support than support were fathers, step-fathers, teachers, and counselors. That is, with the exception of mothers and weak links, adults in the lives of these boys were perceived as primarily non-supportive. The study provides a window into one aspect of the lives of these ninth grade boys and describes it largely in their own words. The implications for intervention are also suggested.

Title: Population dynamics in the revolutionary process: A historical interpretive approach to the tension between social structure and ideology, the Iranian revolution, 1979
Abstract: This dissertation explores and highlights the tension between ideology and social structure through the history of population dynamics. The focus of this study is the Iranian revolution of 1979. It examines the growth and decline of four opposition groups (the secular Liberation Movement of Iran; two guerrilla organizations, Marxist Fada'ian and Marxist Islamist Mojahedin; and lastly the Islamist activists under clerical leadership) that participated in the revolutionary process. By examining the tension between structure and ideology in relation to these four revolutionary groups, this study seeks the origin of the revolutionary movement focusing on sixteen crucial years preceding the revolution, starting in 1963 and ending in 1979. It argues that the resolution of this tension is to be understood as a matter of process in time, provided that history to be portrayed as a process. This dissertation raises five questions: first, what are the historical conditions that allowed Islam, particularly Shi'ism, to reenter the political arena? Second, what resources does it have at its disposal for political organization and mass mobilization? Third, what tools does Islam possess to articulate people's grievances and to become the vehicle of the discontent? Fourth, what are the social-structural conditions and the ideology of the pre-revolutionary regime? Fifth, what is the role of international factors in shaping the structure and affecting the ideology of both revolutionaries and the regime? To answer these questions, this study discusses the historical pre-conditions that facilitated the popular dissent by highlighting the tension between the prerevolutionary social structure and the state ideology and that of the opposing forces. The argument presented in this work is that we need to conceive a resolution historically, that is the extent to which the relationship between structure and ideology is to be understood as a process in time. To illustrate this process in time, the above mentioned four revolutionary groups will be studied. These groups are important to study because they represent the multiple forms of political radicalization of the Iranian opposition in terms of ideology and political strategy in the aftermath of the 1963 June uprising.

Title: Soren Kierkegaard and Anglo-American literary culture of the thirties and forties
Abstract: In the intellectual and literary histories of Britain and the United States the thirties are represented as the period when the mass medias ascended, and when the ideologies and attitudes of communism, international socialism, and the Social Gospel movement attracted mass appeal. In contrast to the group or collectivist theories and perspectives associated with this period, however, many writers also began to take an interest in the translations of Karl Barth's works and to pay attention to such theologians as Reinhold Niebuhr and Paul Tillich. Behind both Barth and the growing Neo-Orthodox movement stood Soren Kierkegaard and Christian existentialism. By mid-decade, Kierkegaard's popularity had itself begun to spread to the British and American intelligentsia, and the translation of his works had begun. Any attempt to understand the sudden importance of Kierkegaard in this period must view his Christian existentialism in a dialectical relationship with mass culture. In addition, although the fifties remade existentialism as a largely atheist philosophy, writers of the thirties and forties, responded to existentialism as a theology. For this reason, when reading the authors of this era one must know their intellectual context and the Kierkegaard they knew. As trend setters, T. S. Eliot and W. H. Auden show the importance of Kierkegaard's religion of angst and personal faith to the literature of this period. In Four Quartets Eliot reiterates Kierkegaard's theological interpretation of time and the paradoxes of Christian faith in allusions, paraphrases, and passages from the Kierkegaard available to him in English translations and monographs. Auden reviewed translations and published his own selection of Kierkegaard's writings, and in his four long poems of the war years (New Year Letter, For the Time Being, The Sea and the Mirror, and The Age of Anxiety) used Kierkegaard to formulate his response to the war. The issues which attracted Eliot and Auden to Kierkegaard during this autumnal period of literary modernism subsequently contributed to the rise of postmodernism.

Title: International solidarity: Space and class in the United States labor movement
Abstract: The emphasis within social analysis on space and spatial relations of production in recent decades has contributed greatly to the illumination of the structures that define social and economic life in the late twentieth century. However, the complex relationship between various aspects of social relations within the production process--the classic struggle between labor and capital, gender and racial divisions in the working class, the spatial divisions between workers in different locales--eludes precise definition. Furthermore, the significance of the spatial character of social relations of production for political movements that seek to transform society has not been explored. This thesis depicts and analyzes a social movement among organized American workers originating in the early 1980s as a response to changes in the structure of the global capitalist economy. International labor solidarity is a movement of individuals joined together with common goals arising out of their shared class interests. As a movement of workers, its primary function is to further the struggle of labor against capital. However, the unique purpose of international solidarity is to address spatial divisions within the international working class. This purpose situates the movement at the critical crossroads of class and space. Analysis of the movement affords us the opportunity to better understand this critical juncture in social relations and examine a contemporary political movement that is unique in its explicitly spatial agenda. Case studies of groups involved in international solidarity activities reveal the structural difficulties involved in formulating a spatialized politics. Criteria are developed by which to measure the tendency of each group to be either more or less accommodationist or transformatory in its approach to the global economic system. A possible correlation between group type and political tendency is explored.

Title: Women's places: The proprietary politics of cultural space
Abstract: This dissertation explores feminized spatial constructs in twentieth-century cultural texts that suggest a range of perspectives from which space appears and is experienced as problematic. Gender is seen as mediating a variety of social relations and sites of conflict, particularly under (real or imagined) conditions of wider political instability. The dissertation emphasizes representational strategies which symbolically endow space with gendered attributes, and which contribute to the spatial reorganizations and reorientations of groups and populations marked by gender, race, nationality, ethnicity and class. By "women's places," the dissertation refers to vexed terrain, in multiple senses of the phrase: to social positions allocated to sexed subjects, literary commonplaces, spatial abstractions of the female body, sites of contention in feminist cultural theory (such as the ongoing argument between essentialism and social constructionism), underrepresented patterns of human movement, disputed boundaries, and cultural constructions of blank, interstitial, unsettled and unsettling spaces. Rather than undertake a positivistic analysis of these topoi, the dissertation attempts to track the often unexpected and unstable trajectories they can take: through an activity of close textual interpretation that gives priority to feminist and postcolonial concerns. Chapter 1 traces the contradictory aesthetic and ideological impulses of Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness through to their reconstellations in Thomas Pynchon's V. and Francis Ford Coppola's Apocalypse Now, examining the ways in which crises in cultural representation reflect and refract crises in the west's administration of global territory. Chapter 2 addresses the question of the ambiguous, middle space in narrative with close reference to Flann O'Brien's At Swim-Two-Birds. Through a reading of Evelyn Lau's Runaway: Diary of a Street Kid, situated against the feminist dialogue with postmodernism, chapter 3 discusses one woman's attempt to narrate herself out of the predicaments within which she has been appropriated as the material of cultural, economic and social reproduction. Chapter 4 concludes the dissertation by considering contemporary feminist debates on the intersections of identity and location. As the partial representations and shifting configurations explored in this dissertation suggest, a "woman's place" may be virtually anywhere individuals and groups find, project, and/or welcome ambivalence and contradiction.

Title: The foreign policy of the New Democratic Party, 1961-1988
Abstract: The historiography of the New Democratic Party of Canada, extensive for domestic policy, has ignored the party's foreign policy. This work fills the gap by examining all aspects of NDP international affairs policy from 1961 to 1988. The central argument is that NDP foreign policy was a unique phenomenon both in Canada and within the global social democratic movement. Thus, all the traditional perspectives employed by political scientists and historians to describe Canadian foreign policy do not capture the essence of NDP foreign policy. A new term is required: Canadian social democratic internationalism. The dissertation also demonstrates that the long-standing division in the NDP over foreign policy was fundamentally a conflict between realism and idealism. The clash was particularly manifested in the party's attempts to formulate defence and Canadian-American relations policy. This study shows that the conflict was not about the objectives of Canadian social democratic internationalism but about the means to achieve these objectives. It also shows why the struggle between the idealists and realists was never satisfactorily resolved. Thus, the dissertation reveals that the NDP did not move from a radical movement stage at its beginning to a later more "conservative" party stage. Throughout the 1961-1988 period, idealists, who tended to be less influential party figures, attempted to push realists, who dominated the party's inner circle, into adopting more radical foreign policies and building a Canadian movement in support of social democratic internationalism's goals.

Title: "My passionate feeling about Africa": Maida Springer-Kemp and the American labor movement. (Volumes I and II)
Abstract: Maida Springer-Kemp was a pioneer in developing a relationship between the African trade union movements and the United States labor movement during the African independence struggles. Her political outlook of pan-Africanism and international labor solidarity was forged through her childhood experience with Marcus Garvey's Universal Negro Improvement Association and through her experience as a labor activist for the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union. From her start with the ILGWU in the 1930's Maida became the first Black female international representative for the AFL-CIO in 1945. In that capacity she played a pivotal role in gaining trade union educational opportunities for Africans and in opening up the American labor movement's involvement in support of African independence struggles. Her mentors included the civil rights activist, A. Philip Randolph, the pan-African network builder, George Padmore, and the former head of the United States Communist Party and the architect of the AFL-CIO foreign policy, Jay Lovestone. As a social history, oral history, and biography, this work situates Maida's labor activism within the political context of the Cold War, the United States civil rights struggles, the African independence struggles, and the post-independence split in the pan-African trade union movement. The representation of Maida's life experiences and work demonstrates the conflictual and complex nature of Black struggles for equality and justice. Although the AFL-CIO was fraught with racism and sexism, Maida's support for the Western labor movement derived from her membership in one of the more egalitarian unions, her special relationship with trade union leaders, and the opportunity union membership afforded her to gain an international perspective and participate in the pan-African movement. A study of the experiences and roles of Maida Springer-Kemp sheds additional insight into these historical moments and opens up historical events to new interpretations.

Title: Rushdie and the politics of postcolonial representation
Abstract: To examine Salman Rushdie's career is to confront profound embarrassments of communities and of critical theory. And such discomfiture extends to the intellectual movements with which he is most identified: many of Rushdie's critics also reject recent developments in colonial and postcolonial studies more generally. These embarrassments raise important questions about the nature of Rushdie's work, these theoretical fields, and contemporary transnational culture. How do we engage Rushdie's intellectually and politically provocative writings? What are the limitations of his model of hybridity and his political aesthetic, and how do these prompt questioning of other postcolonial theorizing? Do rejections of The Satanic Verses signify rejections of modernity of new formations of the modern? This dissertation investigates these broad questions by way of Rushdie's engagements with colonial and postcolonial politics; his remodeling of cultural identity; his inventive forms of social and narrative representation; and his politics of the word. Theoretically, then, the study draws upon and critiques developments in colonial and postcolonial studies. And it examines Rushdie's work in both its historical and political locations: the Indian diaspora and multiracial, postwar Britain. An introductory chapter examines the embarrassments attending Rushdie's work, contending they disrupt several intellectual movements of which they are part. Investigating the evolution of Rushdie's political aesthetic begins with chapter two, which rehistoricizes Grimus and its engagement with British politics of race and the dilemmas of the postcolonial intellectual. Rushdie's engagement with the power of representation to postcolonial concerns in Midnight's Children; chapter three examines his portrayal of economies of coercion and empowerment in nation and narrative. Focusing on Shame, chapter four explores Rushdie's indictment of postcolonial pathologies of historical imagination, and his production of an alternative historiography through reoccupation of colonial translation practices. Such historical and cultural translation fails spectacularly in his political travelogues, The Jaguar Smile; chapter five engages this text's mortifying resemblance to colonialist ethnography. Finally, the study presents The Satanic Verses as a revisionist moment in Rushdie's theorizing of postcolonial history and cultural politics, and suggests that novel and its critics differentially reinscribe postcolonial modernity as an archaic present.

Title: The Bernstein debate: Party trends and party ideology in the German Social Democracy Party, 1898-1903
Abstract: In my dissertation I examine the reception of Eduard Bernstein's (1850-1932) revisionism, or the so-called Bernstein debate in the German Social Democratic Party in 1898-1903. My aim was to explain: (1) how the debate contributed to the genesis of the orthodox Marxist and revisionist lines of thought, (2) how is it possible at this stage to separate the orthodox Marxists from the so-called Left, (3) what the debate tells about the Marxist self-understanding of the party, and (4) how the structures and continua of the German Empire influenced the reception of revisionism. My study reveals that Bernstein's revisionism certainly did hasten the party's ideological split, but it did not cause this split; the party was discordant already earlier. The ideological disintegration of the party manifested itself in that some orthodox Marxists demanded from party executives a more decided fight against revisionism, although one cannot yet talk about a distinct Left--in the same way as in 1905. The study also shows that the Marxism of the Social Democratic Party cannot--any more than that of Karl Kautsky (1854-1938)-- be characterized as mechanical-fatalistic; the party did not passively wait for the fall of capitalism. Furthermore, the study tells that it was easy for the orthodox Marxists to dismiss Bernstein's proposals by referring to the reality of the Empire. Knowing the themes of the Bernstein debate helps one to understand the later division of the International Workers' Movement into communists and social democrats. The October Revolution in 1917 was not the birth period of communism. In its germ-state it already existed in the orthodox Marxism generated by the rise of revisionism. The Bernstein debate is also an expression of the modernization of western society. Universal suffrage produced a way of making politics in which the setting of a goal is not based on the unyielded principles of a political movement, but on bargaining. As a movement and a line of thought, revisionism was an insight according to which pleading the workers' cause presupposed adjusting to existing (bourgeois) values and political balances of power. "Opportunistic" politics and "opportunist" as a species of politician were born with the debate. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: The emergence of refugee women as a social issue, 1978-1988
Abstract: This dissertation examines a social change that occurred in the decade 1978-1988 when refugee women were constituted a social issue by advocates who lobbied for social change in their own countries and in international organizations. In 1978, there were no policies that acknowledged the resources or special needs of refugee women. Many suffered gender conflict when they were forced to flee from a familiar environment without protection systems and when they were denied the opportunity of participating in the organization of their own protection and survival needs. Human rights abuses went beyond violation and abuse to discrimination in the social world where gender differences in forced migration went unrecognized in immigration laws and refugee policies. It was this overall lack of recognition of refugee women as a persecuted social group that motivated advocates toward conflict resolution. In the mid-1980s, advocates of human rights and women's rights made the connection between human rights and refugee women's rights through domestic and workplace contacts and through their work in refugee helping organizations. Many of these women had become highly politicized and had gained credibility and mobility through their work. This enabled them to develop strategies and carve out spaces of control. Using refugee women as a symbol, they developed a geopolitical network which made contacts continuous from refugee camps and grass roots groups to organizations in Nairobi, Geneva, Washington, and Canadian cities. Information from the field was transformed into mutual knowledge. Key players operated as a floating bureaucracy which functioned as a control mechanism for amalgamating power resources and moving the issue through an international political arena to policy-makers. In 1988, Canada instituted a policy for refugee women in dire need. The UNHCR created a new post and began implementing protection policies and programmes. Both initiatives influenced other member states and refugee organizations. Those policies signalled social change which, in turn, signified the empowerment of women working with women for women. The data sources which record this historical process include documents and interviews. The theoretical framework is developed from elements of Giddens's theory of social agency and social structure, Foucault's work on power/knowledge, social network and social movement theory, and feminist discourses on women, bureaucracies, and empowerment.

Title: The relevance of H. R. Niebuhr's 'ethics of response' to Korean Christian context: A critical inquiry into Niebuhr's ethics from a non-western context
Abstract: Korean Protestants have faced serious challenges in regard to the issues of their relationship with Korean nationalism, their social ethical contribution to Korean Society, and their constructive role for the re-unification of the divided South-North Korea. Since Korean Protestant Christianity has been generally viewed as pro-Western, the criticism of its lack of national subjectivity is exacerbated. Its social ethical accountability has been seriously questioned since the corruption of Rhee, Syng Man's government in which many Christians actively were involved. Finally, since Korean Christianity has been on the frontier of the anti-communism movement, its role for the re-unification is regarded as a crucial one. One of the fundamental problems which hinders the Korean Church from positive participation in the emerging issues is internal schisms. To demonstrate the wide spectrum of their understanding of faith and its relationship with social ethical attitudes in Korean churches which causes internal schisms, Park, Hyung Nong, Cho, Yong Gi, and Suh, Nam Dong are intensively analyzed through Niebuhrian analysis. This dissertation seeks to contribute to a theological understanding of the Korean Church by providing a theoretical basis for a theological social ethics. The heuristic adoption of Niebuhr's 'ethics of response' will help Korean churches to acknowledge that the differences among them are not so essential that they cannot seek their social solidarity, and that the core of Christian faith is not in its absolute obedience to a doctrine, but in its dialogical (responsible) character initiated by the sovereignty of God, who is the Creator, Governor, and Redeemer. However it is very difficult for Korean Christians to adopt Niebuhr's 'ethics of response' until the relevance of Niebuhr's arguments are critically reflected in the light of the Korean context. Theologically Niebuhr's binitarian view of God needs to be revised with the Trinitarian God. One of the inherent problems which prevents Niebuhr's 'ethics of response' from being a more implementable ethic is Niebuhr's inconsistent view of God, i.e., 'Radical monotheistic God' vs. 'God of Trinity'. Based upon Trinitarian ethical criteria, Korean Christians can participate in the new task of re-forming Korean society and maintaining Korean identity with global solidarity after relativizing its phenomenologically different modes through Niebuhr's 'ethics of response'.
