Title: The social representation of children with Down syndrome: An interpretivist analysis
Abstract: This is a qualitative study analyzing the social construction of children with Down syndrome in schools. The professional disability literature has historically framed Down syndrome as a pathological condition resulting in global intellectual incompetencies often called mental retardation. Traditionally, students with Down syndrome have been forced into the margins of education, often separated from neighborhood schools and regular classrooms. Recently, a trend towards greater acceptance has occurred allowing for the teaching of children with Down syndrome in what are termed inclusive classrooms. This trend, however, maintains intellectual impairments as a central feature of students with Down syndrome. Ascribing to both critical production and phenomenological perspectives, I set aside predominant interpretations of Down syndrome. Using qualitative research methods including participant observation and interviewing, I entered schools that brought children with and without Down syndrome together in order to understand how students were represented in the actual sites where teachers and children came together to negotiate social meanings and understanding. Following 10 children with Down syndrome in five separate schools and 9 different classrooms lead to a qualitative analysis that argues Down syndrome is a complex series of shifting, unstable social constructions. Images of competence and incompetence intersect in the classrooms observed resulting in tension over where children with Down syndrome should best be educated, and what type of curriculum best meets the needs of the students. Interestingly, in several classrooms, children with Down syndrome were represented, at times, as competent students, an image rarely found in the disability literature. Teachers came to understand children as competent by interpreting certain performance behaviors not as evidence of cognitive deficiencies, but rather as communication and movement differences that resulted in difficulties negotiating the everyday world of the children's classrooms.

Title: The Baha'i Faith in Atlanta: On the religious construction of a global identity
Abstract: The Baha'i Faith is one of the least studied of the world's globally-oriented religious movements. Not only does its ideology inculcate a universal religious/human identity for its adherents, but the Baha'i "Administrative Order" establishes a network of local, national and international institutions that link local Baha'i communities to its world center in Haifa, Israel. The goal of the Baha'i Faith is to promote "unity in diversity"--to establish religious, racial, ethnic, and national diversity within the Baha'i community, and in so doing, act as a model for the rest of humanity in overcoming divisive prejudices. Yet, it also seeks to establish unity among its members through adherence to a Baha'i worldview and through obedience to the explicit authority institutionalized in Baha'i organizational structures. This dissertation provides empirical evidence of the "unity in diversity" of the Atlanta, Georgia Baha'i community, utilizing multiple research methods (a survey questionnaire, participant observation, in-depth interviews, and archival research) to answer relevant research questions. Research results indicate that Atlanta Baha'is are a highly diverse group demographically that display a significant degree of ideological unity. This measurable "unity in diversity" is facilitated through both the ideological and organizational resources within Baha'i institutions, which succeed in sociologically linking global and local levels of Baha'i social life, and in creating a global Baha'i identity. This research is important because the Baha'i Faith helps us understand the full range of religious responses to Globalization processes; it is an example of a "universal" religious response that seeks to reduce the barriers between social groups, as opposed to fundamentalist movements which tend to heighten social and religious boundaries. The Baha'i Faith, as a case study, also gives us clues as to how a universal movement uses ideological and institutional resources to link the global and the local--partially solving what Roland Robertson calls the "universal-particular problematic."

Title: Socialism, nationalism, and "the German question" from World War I to Locarno and beyond
Abstract: Drawing on its Marxist identity, European social democracy consistently presented itself as an internationalist movement capable of pursuing goals rooted in working-class solidarity. Internationalism suffered a crushing defeat in August 1914, and the events of 1914-1918 laid the foundation for the permanent fracturing of the international working-class movement. The First World War also marked the victory of nationalist revolutions in East Central Europe. The defeat of the three imperial powers that had dominated the multinational region for over a century led to the emergence of new nation-states whose existence the peace treaties ending World War I officially sanctioned. In international relations, "the German question" in East Central Europe thus took on a new form, as German territorial revisionism came to dominate diplomacy involving the region. European social democracy--traditionally subject to strong German influences--rejected the post-1918 territorial settlements in East Central Europe. As a result, Czechoslovak and Polish social democrats confronted the need to reconcile their ideological allegiance to working-class internationalism with their commitment to independent statehood. This study addresses questions of international relations within the European social democratic movement, in the process demonstrating how socialism served German nationalism. After World War I, European social democracy formulated foreign policy prescriptions which subsequently found acceptance at the state level. The most important aspect of social democratic diplomacy lay in its willingness to countenance a bifurcation of the European continent into a stable, western part and an eastern part subject to change. This latter principle was inscribed into the interwar state structure by the Locarno treaties of October 1925, the most important diplomatic event in Europe before 1933. By focusing on the implications of social democratic theory and practice for state interests, this study also illustrates the divergent implications of social democratic internationalism for Czechoslovakia which succeeded in harnessing the International to serve Prague's official foreign policy, and Poland, which found itself alienated from European social democracy, the first institutional political movement to propagate European integration.

Title: Rehabilitation and reconstruction in Uganda: The political economy of structural adjustment programmes from 1980 to 1994
Abstract: In the two decades of the mid-1960s to mid-1980s cumulative political and economic atrophy, precipitated by domestic and external factors, reduced Uganda from a once promising and potentially prosperous and resilient political economy to a worst-case scenario in Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA). However, since 1986 the National Resistance Movement (NRM) has adopted comprehensive IFI-sponsored structural adjustment programmes (SAPs) which are animated by a neo-liberal, market-oriented, agriculture-based, primary commodity export-driven and private sector-led strategy. It has also put in place political initiatives to establish and sustain peace, security and democracy. This thesis argues that whilst the World Bank and International Monetary Fund (IMF) -inspired SAPs have halted the free-fall of the 1980s, contributed towards macroeconomic stability, recaptured part of the informal sector and enhanced national and external confidence in the economy, they have failed to go beyond stabilisation to structural adjustment and change. Uganda's dependent "development" trajectory remains tenuous, unsustainable and even reversible. In the meantime, SAPs have impacted adversely on many social and economic groups. Yet, Uganda, given domestic, regional and global imperatives, has no choice but to adjust its economy with borrowed funds. Within very limited room for manoeuvre, Uganda is likely to enhance its future prospects by pursuing the establishment of a strong and proactive state and adopting a small-scale, agro-based, value-added industrialisation strategy aimed at regional and international markets. These domestic measures will need reinforcement from continued democratisation of the polity, enhanced regional cooperation and a more responsive and supportive global economic system. For now, however, it is premature to elevate Uganda's emerging, if fragile, economic and political renaissance to an unrealistic and unsustainable teleological status.

Title: International Co-operative Alliance during war and peace, 1910-1950
Abstract: The International Co-operative Alliance was founded in London in 1895 as the international federation of national co-operative movements. Because of co-operatives' traditional affinity with trades unions and workers' parties the Alliance was likely to have links with their international counterparts, the Socialist International, and the International Federation of Trade Unions. Whereas these divided under the pressures of total war and divisions of doctrine, the Alliance survived remarkably intact and in a clearly recognisable form. Moreover it became one of the largest International Non-Governmental Organisations and, in 1946, was one of the first three to gain Category A consultative status with the UN's Economic and Social Council. This thesis therefore sought to answer how and why the Alliance survived. Theories of degeneration in value-based organisations were noted, (Max Weber, Economy and Society, 1968 ed. and Robert Michels Political Parties 1915) together with offsetting arguments, (Yohanan Stryjan Impossible Organisations 1989.) Thereafter secondary sources relating to international relations, the two World Wars and the Cold War were examined so as to place the ICA in context. Three earlier Alliance histories were also studied, though none focussed on war and peace. Work on primary sources followed including ICA correspondence, minutes, special reports. ICA published material, namely Congress Reports and the monthly International Review of Co-operation, were also studied, as were primary sources relating to the ICA in the Archives of the International Labour Organisation and the League of Nations, Geneva. Historiographical methods were used to examine these sources first on questions of war and peace, but later on the Alliance's responses to communism and fascism. Evidence soon grew that two important factors in the Alliance's survival were its organisation, i.e. its constitution and governance, and its ideology. Subsequent research focussed on determining the degree to which they did account for it. After describing its origins the thesis examined the ICA's organisation and ideology between 1910 and 1950 so as to provide a background for the largely chronological treatment of the 1914-18 War, the ICA's response to communism and fascism, the 1939-45 War, and the Cold War, which followed. Sufficient evidence was assembled to be able to conclude that although there were contingent factors, the Alliance's survival could be largely explained by its organisation, characterised by ideological consistency, a cohesive membership, clear accountability and control, and flexibility and durability, and to its ideology comprising adherence to Co-operative Principles and a form of social ownership distinct from socialism, observance of religious and political neutrality, and a commitment to world peace.

Title: "Men moun yo"; "Here are the people": Rara festivals and transnational popular culture in Haiti and New York City
Abstract: This dissertation is the first monograph on the parading musical festival called Rara, traditionally practiced by peasants in Haiti during Lent. The work draws from cultual anthropology, history and cultural studies to chart the practices, beliefs, symbolic systems, religious meanings, social organization, gender relations and political uses of this popular festival. A tradition with roots in plantation slavery that has continued throughout Haitian history, Rara is the most popular community-produced music and celebration form in Haiti It grows out of the Afro-Haitian religious complex called Vodou, and is used to launch political criticism of local and national leaders. It is now practiced in local gatherings and protest demonstrations by Haitians in diaspora, to become a key performance style in the emerging transnational progressive rasin ('roots') cultural movement. Rara values move back and forth between private and public spaces, as well as between sacred and secular protocols, between Caribbean male and female value systems, between the spheres of the living community and its recently deceased, (when Rara bands capture the spirits, or zonbi, of the recently dead and mystically carry them in the parade), between royal-priestly and military principles of social organization and between popular laughter and engaged popular politics. Rara music and performance has emerged as one of the signifiers of progressive ideology in the transnational cultural arena of the Haitian diaspora. This study examines Rara beliefs and practices, power dynamics and politics in the volatile years 1990-1996, from the first government of Jean-Bertrand Aristide through the period of coup d'etat and embargo, until the United States military intervention. It is based on field research, interviews, video recordings and audio recordings.

Title: An exploration of the role of a smaller power in the situation of greater power rivalry
Abstract: The thesis deals with the Great Power Rivalry in Iran throughout the period 1921 to 1979. As the impact of this lengthy rivalry has had significant consequences for the social, economic and political structures of Iran, the primary purpose is to evaluate the foreign policy of Iran in coping with this situation. It makes a preliminary attempt to generalise the factors of this rivalry and examines, three basic parameters necessary for its outbreak: the inequality of the states at the international level which led the triumphant great powers of the two World Wars to dominate the major issues of the international system, the power vacuum resulting in disunity and instability at the domestic level of Iran, which paved the way for the great powers to seek their aspirations in the "victim" state. The last but not the least important factor was rivals' vital interests in Iran, such as oil and the strategic corridor. To explore the formulation of Iranian foreign policy, the study investigates the anatomy of power in both eras of the Pahlavi Kingdom, including the role of the Shah's personality, the opposition movements, the economy and the administration of the country. It argues that the Shah, on top of the small oligarchy, was the actual key decision-maker in formulating the main policies of both domestic and foreign affairs. The pervasive opposition of the Iranian people, from autonomous revolts to that of communist radicalism and from religious to that of democratic movements, and the Shah's suppression of them all, made the state unstable and hence vulnerable to foreign pressures by dividing its sources of resistance. In tracing the implementation of Iranian foreign policy to secure oil resources and territorial integrity, the thesis concludes that because of the lack of any popular participation in the politics of the country, and its relative economic vulnerability; the personal interests of the oligarchy and also for psychological and religious reasons, there was no independent foreign policy toward the two great power rivals. Instead the foreign policy was always in alignment with the West against the Soviet Union.

Title: The working class in the world of organisations: A comparative study of the social and historical conditions for the development of the labour unions in Sweden and in Greece
Abstract: This thesis is a comparative study of the social and historical conditions for the development of the labor unions in Sweden and in Greece. The study is based on literature from different social sciences such as history, economic history, political science, social anthropology, and sociology, but also on archival work in Greece. The study consists of two parts. Chapters one to three are theoretical in their focus. Chapters four to eight are empirical. In the theoretical part insights from prior labor movement research and from comparative historical sociology are used to develop a theoretical frame of reference. The emerging frame of reference is based on organizational realism and combines the contingency, ecological and new-institutional approaches in organizational theory. Using the idea of the social landscape, historical sequentiality, organizational inertia, timing, organizational capacities and open social spaces are related to one another as concepts. Special attention is paid to how different sequences of organizational establishment create at different times and places open social spaces with different qualities. In chapters four to seven the idea of the social landscape is used to empirically examine what types of social spaces were created for the working class due to different organizational founding sequences. Sweden is described at the end of the nineteenth century when the labor organizations were first established and in Greece in the 1920s. Family forms, enterprises, several state authorities and the existing political parties are compared. In chapter eight differences in the qualities of the open spaces are related to differences in the established labor organizations. A major point in this study is that the qualities of the open social spaces in the local arena and the ideas of how to organize labor which were developed in the international labor movement are crucial in understanding differences in the ways the working class was organized.

Title: Sport and social control
Abstract: The work herein represents research in to the practice of Olympic sport in a socio-cultural aspect and its social and pedagogic implications. It has been structured and formed according to the theoretical-methodological theories of Dr A. Sanvisens who directed us towards an understanding of sports as an open system which is maintained and inter-related with the means which envelops it through an informative exchange, thereby regulating its functioning. Sport presents both an internal and external structure which are organized by means of networks of relationships as much in a vertical, hierarchical scale as a horizontal one. Research was done on two social-sport clubs in the city of Porto Alegre in Rio Grande do Sul Province in Brazil. Their social structure consists of 31.796 and 58.547 members respectively. 2.500 and 4.095 students are enrolled in their beginning sports programs. In their competitive teams there are about 640 and 570 enrolled in their sports federations. In this particular study the clubs are comprised of units of a functional sub-system and the COI of a control sub-system of the international Olympic system. The process of collecting data of a descriptive nature will be developed along with those techniques resulting from interviews and (written) documents. Formal and informal interviews have been utilized, both structured with open, frank questions. They have been carried out with 2 sports administrators, 15 technical sports coordinators and 8 sports-mode trainers. Diverse types of documents have been gathered with the ultimate aim of an approximation of qualitative order while trying to discover the decisive norms of international Olympic organization as well as the origin and actual socio-cultural, sport-oriented situation of the clubs. The facts obtained during the investigative process have given evidence of certain distancing of Olympic sport from sports pedagogy. The latter was the basis of founding of the international Olympic movement and the building blocks of the first Olympic Congresses. It is to be stated here that the practice of Olympic sport is sustained in an almost unilateral manner by means of scientific and technological contributions afforded by "sports-science".

Title: Winning consent: The protracted campaign for an anti-corporatist "common sense"
Abstract: The thesis argues for a new understanding of the dramatic changes which took place in industrialised western countries during the 1980s associated with a decline of the corporatist perspectives of what is known as the Keynesian "consensus" and an erosion of the power of meta-narratives. Adapting to a new purpose an investigative approach in the social movements tradition, it identifies and traces a movement campaigning against large-scale state intervention and for a more market-based social order and pushes its origins back to the 1930s. It takes issue with and puts forward a reformulation of what the dominant accounts have called the "New Right," generally seen as a response to the "crisis" of the late. 1960s and 1970s and interpreted through the metaphor of base/superstructure, where historical developments are rooted in economy. Selecting the period from 1931 to 1981, this study traces the development over 50 years of a movement whose growth began with the arrival in Britain of Friedrich Hayek in 1931 and which since that time has fought a concerted international campaign for limited government and more market-based approaches, creating and developing the research and policy institute, or think-tank, as an important organisational form along the way and consistently foreshadowing political/policy change in the thrust of its movement activities. Methods associated with field work are used, such as observation of the activities and practices of the intellectuals in their various fora; focused, semi-structured interviewing, used as a method within the methodology of both survey and case study; as well as what is referred to as unobtrusive measures, such as the examination of documents and other archival material. An account of material not in the bibliography is included in a set of appendices. The originality of this thesis lies in two things: Firstly, in showing that the more robust market policies of many Western governments in the 1980s were the result not just of currents of ideas but of 50 years of struggle by a social movement with intellectuals and organisation; secondly, in using a social movements approach to study a grouping generally conflated with the Right. The study examines in detail the process in which the movement intellectuals were engaged and makes links between their protracted, organised intellectual campaign and the changes which have undermined the postwar Keynesian welfare state. Direct contact was made with the intellectuals in their organisational settings, notably the think-tank, and relevant documents stretching back close to the turn of the century were consulted. The study also identifies Hayek not only as a central figure in the revival and reformulation of classical liberalism and resolute organiser of the movement campaigning against centralised, large-scale state intervention, but also as an important player in contemporary epistemological themes. His critique of positivism in particular has been a contribution to an intellectual strand eroding the dominance of positivist notions in the post-World War II social sciences. Overall, his work has contributed to keeping the movement vital while raising his own profile in the last quarter of the 20th century in what is being called the knowledge or information society. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: The Mexican business class and the processes of globalization: Trends and counter-trends
Abstract: This thesis discusses the globalising processes undergone by a segment of the Mexican business class, notably: the spaces of the world economy they control; their links to social and political networks of global scope, as well as to global movements and currents of thought; and the interests, strategies, projects and perceptions which they share with their counterparts around the world. It argues that they have become one of the main and most powerful forces for the integration of the country in the global capitalist system. Globalising processes lived and promoted by the Mexican business class are contradictory in several respects: on one hand, modernisation, institutionalisation and depersonalisation of corporate structures and of the system of business representation is hindered by business clientelism and corruption in party funding. On the other hand, increasing opportunities of expansion, globalisation and modernisation for Mexican corporations do not always correspond with prospects for growth and development for the national economy. The formation of a global business class in Mexico is conceived as a process in which big businessmen reconstitute their identity, projects and aspirations in a process of collective reflexivity whereby they discuss, negotiate and share experiences with business communities around the world.

Title: Structures, strategies, and strife: An organizational analysis of the Canadian environmental movement
Abstract: It has been suggested that interest organizations have a predictable life cycle. They begin as ad-hoc, single-issue, resource poor groups that work on the fringes of the policy process. As they mature, groups begin to assume a more formalized, bureaucratic structure. It is claimed that new social movement groups (of which environmental groups are a part) will not follow this developmental pattern. Their relatively simple, non-hierarchical organizational structure is usually attributed to the unique ideology and socio-economic background of movement activists. Few empirical data have been collected on the organizational structure of environmental groups, particularly in North America. This thesis seeks to address this deficiency by setting out to accomplish three goals. These are: (1) to examine the organizational structure of the environmental movement(s) in Canada; (2) to analyze the factors that shape this organizational structure; and (3) to examine the impact that movement structure has on consultation processes between environmental groups and the government. The thesis develop an analytical framework that is used to explain the factors which underpin the observed structure. Using the Canadian Environmental Network's computer data base, a profile of Canadian environmental activism is developed; these data are supplemented by case studies of B.C. and Ontario. The study concludes that: (1) There are thousands of environmental organizations across Canada that do not have hierarchical organizational structures, and are loosely linked through membership in provincial environmental networks. There is, however, a small core of professionalized groups that exhibit traditional organizational patterns. In both B.C. and Ontario there is little communication between large, urban-based professional groups and small, grassroots groups. (2) The determinants of organizational structure of Canadian environmental groups are complex and muiltivariate. Casual variables include: the economic and social base of the province; international influences; and the structure and orientation of the state; resources of groups; and the ideology and social background of activists. The relative influence of these factors differ by province, and as a consequence the lines of cleavage within provincial movements are not the same. (3) The fragmented nature of the movement and the complexity of issues makes it difficult for the state to aggregate the wide range of viewpoints. Moreover, fragmentation raises important questions regarding the legitimacy and accountability of the environmental groups that provide input into policy-making.

Title: Creating alternative visions: the role of national and transnational social movements in the demise of polish state socialism
Abstract: The accompaniment of the collapse of Eastern European state socialism by a visible manifestation of "people power" has raised questions concerning "system collapse ... and the role of social movements in this" (Manning 1993, 1319). Some Western peace activists have already offered an answer to this question, claiming that Eastern social movements, supported by Western counterparts, were instrumental in the collapse of state socialism. This thesis addresses these questions and investigates this claim, by analysing the origins, philosophy and ultimate impact of national and transnational social movements in the disintegration of Polish state socialism. Although state socialist Poland provided an inhospitable context, it will be argued that problems of system disintegration besetting the Polish state opened up the political opportunity structure enabling social movements to originate. Moreover these movements were not simply exploiters of political opportunity but were inspired by a moral vision of creating a civil society. Sources and interviews drawn from Polish movements will be used to demonstrate these arguments. At the International level it will be suggested that Superpower detente opened the political opportunity structure for transnational interaction between social movements across the Cold War divide. Furthermore, these movements were inspired by a moral vision of how the international system should be. An empirical enquiry into the relationship between a British peace movement and Polish movements will investigate the efficacy of this interaction but will simultaneously demonstrate the difficulties caused by these movements' possession of conflicting moral visions. Having analysed the origins and activities of these movements - their interaction with each other, the socialist state and the international system - conclusions will be drawn both about the specific role of social movements in democratic transition at the Round Table and from a more general perspective, the significance of the practical and moral challenge offered by social movements to the socialist state.

Title: Native wisdom: Indigenous identity and community activism
Abstract: This study explains how contemporary indigenous identity positively affects the relative success of community based social movements. Using a predictor outcome matrix, the study examines the impact of identity upon internal community support, community agendas, and effective outside support, comparing the resistance efforts of two indigenous and two non indigenous rural communities. Qualitative data compiled from field work, interviews, and archival resources helps explain the influences of such factors on successful resistance. The results of the study have implications for academic understandings of identity. The results also inform pragmatic discussions relevant to community based organizing and non-governmental organizations supporting grass roots community development. Contemporary indigenous identity is dynamic, influenced by cultural ties to first peoples, a history of oppression and resistance, adaptation to the dominant state culture and degrees of assimilation. The identity of indigenous communities manifests itself through a number of social variables relevant to resistance. Indigenous communities have broader social networks, more flexible leadership structures, and more reasons to want to preserve relations to a given geographic area. For these reasons, indigenous identity increases internal community support for resistance and results in quantitatively greater and qualitatively better resistance strategies. Indigenous community identity increases external contacts to a community out of shared interests, sympathy, or study. These contacts often become sources of support for activist resistance to state policies that threaten rural communities. Thus indigenous resistance in the contemporary period is more likely to improve land rights, political autonomy, sustainable economic development, and social development. The extensive pressures being brought to bare upon rural communities in a broad, international context demonstrate the frailty of independent community movements as they attempt to counter state forces whose own objectives do not account for their survival needs. There are negative environmental effects of current rural land use policies in many regions of the globe. The coercive enforcement of state policies threatens human rights guarantees in many regions. The lessons learned from successful indigenous community activism are potential tools for use in the broader struggle of rural communities and broader efforts to attain more humane, sustainable lifestyles for our global population.

Title: The farmer's revolt: Arms and fraternity in California, 1870-1880
Abstract: Any systematic examination of American history reveals a chronicle of remarkable political stability since 1776. Instances of violence certainly exist dating back to the seventeenth century and generally reflect attempts to control and direct public policy. Many of the organizations responsible for such attempts have received significant study in historical annals as aberrant behavior. The farmers and their earliest known organization, the Grange, is not one of these groups, never having been perceived as a violent or pro-active brethren. To date, the Grange has been examined for its role as a social and as an economic entity. Certainly these components are valid, but it is naive to deny the Grange as a social protest group, a vital cog in the movement for social and political change in late nineteenth century, and one of many worldwide. Thus the Grange, as a fraternal organization predating the Farmers' Alliance and the Populists, is deserving of re-examination as an integral part of that era's wave of international unrest, as a politically charged, sometime violent protest organization, distinct from the merely economic and social body previously assumed. In asserting this perspective it is first essential to identify a population of farmers by focusing on three counties, distinct in terms of geography, agriculture and transportation: Ventura, Tulare/Kings and Butte Counties of California. Using census statements, newspaper and journal accounts, as well as Grange records, it is possible to determine such a sample population. The records provide demographic details: economic standing, political affiliation, religion, ethnicity and gender. It is the task of the researcher to discover and verify behaviors which might raise the farmers from their previous status as a simple, poverty stricken "folk" looking for a social outlet. Rather they formed a brotherhood committed to shared goals--economic, political, and fraternal. Research indicates that typical farmers were not landless, immigrant peasants. Demographics attest that they were propertied, often Republican, pietistic and political. As long suspected, these individuals displayed a strong economic motivation for their Grange participation in tangible rewards through Mutual Benefit Societies and cooperatives. However, and more importantly, the farmer used the Grange as a voice of public policy and as a fraternally based protest organization engaging in vigilante activity. It is evident that the Grange was another manifestation of fraternal and violent protest in the United States dedicated to stemming the growth of corporate bourgeois America in the late nineteenth century. Rather than reflecting the continuity of American political life the farmer actively objected to this move toward corporatism. It is time to reconstruct the overly simplistic and inadequate perceptions of the farmer and the Grange and place them within their appropriate historical context--a brotherhood of protest and a catalyst for action.

Title: Sexual imaginings: The cultural economy of British pornography, 1800-1914
Abstract: My dissertation looks at pornography as a representation of how people think about sexuality, rather than what they do sexually. Through close readings and analysis of nineteenth-century British pornography, I explore changes in the methods of narration and the meanings of sexuality. In addition, I tie these changes to shifts in the access to pornography over the course of the nineteenth century. The exploration of content and access demonstrates the ways that the nineteenth-century social context--defined by class, race, and gender hierarchies--informed ideas of sexuality. My work differs substantially from scholars who view pornography as an unchanging phenomenon. I show that the form, function, content, and audience for pornography all changed and changed dramatically in the nineteenth century. To do this, I have used a variety of source materials including texts, stereoscopes, postcards, mutoscopes, photographs, and daguerreotypes, as well as Home Office papers, police reports, and other governmental documents. These sources demonstrate changes in both the form and content of pornography. My investigation has revealed three distinct phases in pornographic representation in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries; libertine c. 1800-1850, empiricist c. 1850-1875, and fetishistic c. 1875-1914. In each phase, representations combined ideas of sexuality and sexual intercourse with constructions of race, gender, and class. Nonetheless, access to representations remained restricted to bourgeois and upper-class white men until the 1890s when women, the poor, and people of color gained their own pornography in the form of cheap postcards, mutoscopes, and transparencies. Even though the new representations built upon older ideas of sexuality, the state cracked down on pornography because it believed that the shift in the social location of the sexualized ideas would fundamentally destabilize the social and sexual order. The change in state repression demonstrates the connections between sexual signification and social ordering. The study locates transformations in pornographic representations, ties them to cultural movements, places them within the context of social formation, and positions them within the global economy.

Title: Transnational responses to AIDS and the global production of science: A case-study from Rio de Janeiro
Abstract: AIDS challenged most assumptions about the medical defeat of infectious diseases. A global health problem replaced the traditional contrast between the epidemic-free developed world and the infectious diseases ridden developing countries. In the U.S., communities burdened with the impact of AIDS reacted to the absence of a medical cure by creating their own expert knowledge on prevention, support, drug development, clinical trials, and basic science. The interaction between this social movement and the scientific establishment generated new formulas for treatment and research. To implement action throughout the world, WHO created the Global Programme on AIDS. GPA's influence raised awareness about the social dimensions of AIDS and promoted alliances between the different social partners involved in the fight against the epidemic. With a transnational and transdisciplinary rhetoric, the agency built partnerships with local governments, non-governmental organizations, and research agencies. For a period, the movement lived an atmosphere of "health revolution." Asking whether these innovations might have a real impact in the global production of knowledge about AIDS, I conducted ethnographic research among medical, scientific and activist settings in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, chosen due to its well-connected albeit peripheral situation within the world system, plus its autonomous production of biomedical science with a strong component of infectious disease, social medicine, and epidemiology. Research showed that during the period of 1989-90 networking and interdisciplinary efforts energized the action against AIDS in the local as in the global setting. However, after the replacement of WHO's revolutionary commitment by a more medicalized approach to AIDS, the efforts towards a major transformation declined worldwide. The social forces involved in the struggle became fragmented; the transnational alliances reproduced dependency in situations of scarce resources; knowledge flows followed hierarchical patterns; each discipline retreated to its specialty; overwhelming clinical demand competed with research. Some of the transformative ideas and the possible basis for a paradigm shift in immunology and infectious disease remain very close, yet on the side, of the field of AIDS.

Title: Traditional music in a new social movement: The renewal of "bele" in Martinique (French West Indies)
Abstract: This is a study of the relation between art and politics. It examines the grassroots renewal of a traditional dance/music, Martinican bele, as a social movement. In contemporary Martinique, there are several cultural and political movements, in different realms: literature, environmentalism, and local politics, as well as music. All of the movements can be considered oppositional, yet at the same time they accommodate to Martinique's neo-colonial circumstances. Each movement is limited in its aims and its appeal to the public, and they are fragmented from one another. In addition, bele contrasts to the many Caribbean musics that have played important roles in politics and culture. It has not become a major symbol of Martinican identity. Why not? I explore the institutional and grassroots development of the bele renewal and other Martinican movements. Since World War II, Martinican resistance to the French State, and since 1981 French decentralization, have led to a degree of local autonomy. But this autonomy is largely defined by the State, and circumscribed by political and economic dependence. Dependency leads local actors to focus on small-scale actions, exploiting and accepting the State in a peculiar dance of opposition and accommodation. I also examine the various movements' ideologies and their representations of tradition (including the bele tradition). The movements share a similar anti-essentialist discourse that seeks to embrace both local specificity and global cosmopolitanism, tradition and modernity, resistance and compromise. Sociological theory on "new social movements" provides a guide for my ethnography, highlighting the intertwining of politics, grassroots organization, expressive culture, and identity that characterizes Martinican movements. It allows me to describe both opposition and accommodation without reducing one to the other. The reciprocal construction of music, politics, and identity is a central theme in contemporary ethnomusicology. Studies of this theme have focused on commercial pop music, rarely on traditional styles, and then only on traditions associated with uncompromised oppositional politics. This dissertation looks at a traditional style in a more ambiguous situation. In addition, this dissertation constitutes the first full-scale account in English of a French Caribbean traditional music (excepting those of Haiti).

Title: Subjective landscapes and resource management on the Chinese grasslands of Inner Mongolia
Abstract: Since Chinese officials first authorized decollectivization and land privatization, an unfamiliar and disruptive spatial order has increasingly spread across pastoral areas of Inner Mongolia. Recent fieldwork conducted among ethnic Mongols in a township of Chifeng City Prefecture reveals that barbed wire fences are dramatically reshaping the ecological environment and redefining access to community resources. These changes in the structure of local space exacerbate problems of land degradation and intensify economic disparities among independent herding households, setting off a chain of transformation across both the physical and social landscape. This dissertation presents an ethnographic report from a village that has been at the forefront of the expanding household enclosure movement since 1980. It documents in detail some of the obvious and more subtle changes that have occurred. It argues that the recent proliferation of fence-wire and the changes that ensue are intimately related to a national modernization project that directly links local residents to an encroaching capitalist world system. It further argues that local landscape transformation, and the specific phenomenon of land degradation, cannot be fully understood apart from the cultural context of group identity and environmental symbolism. Ideologically informed spatial and ecological perceptions prove to be highly relevant in shaping and contesting both national rangeland policies and the local practices of daily land use. Evidence is presented that social forces at global, regional, and local levels all contribute to the acute state of environmental reconstruction now underway on the northern grasslands.

Title: The politics of orthodoxy in South Korea: Christian radicalism and the heterodoxy of minjung
Abstract: This dissertation project examines the social phenomenon of minjung in South Korea, as observed within the convergence of Christian radicalism and transformational politics during the 1970s and 1980s. Minjung, a marker for a "class" of marginalized social groups which emerged in a context of rapid and fundamental social change, developed into a powerful symbol in and of an anti-state struggle mobilized to transform a repressive and highly charged social order. I argue, through a theoretical framework I call the "politics of orthodoxy," that the historical conjuncture of religion and radicalism in South Korea represented the manifestation of heterodoxy--the minjung heterodoxy--set in contradistinction to the political orthodoxy embodied by Korea's authoritarian state-capital alliance and its twin pillars: anticommunism and developmentalism. Thus, minjung is interpreted as an anti-systemic set of ideas and practices radically opposed to the state-defined orthodoxy and its linkage to social injustice; it constituted a discursive formation that argued for a competing understanding of a "right" social order for the Korean people, an understanding which included a call for social democracy, distributive justice, gender equality and reunification. I further argue that the emergence of minjung and the minjung movement were reflective of an underlying effort to restore "purity" to the moral-ethical underpinnings of Korean society and revive the Korean people's sense of national and cultural integrity. The analysis of the discursive formation of minjung and its connection to Christian radicalism is based on eighteen months of fieldwork over a period of four years (between 1987 and 1990); unstructured elite interviews with Christian-based activists and intellectuals, English-language documents from Christian-based organizations which identified with the minjung movement, and newspaper and mass media accounts of Christian-based social activism provided the empirical data for the Korean component of the dissertation. Archival research on comparable social formations of religion and radicalism contributed to a comparative framework for understanding the role of the religion in contemporary politics. Minjung theology, a body of theological articulations set forth in the course of political struggle against the Park Chung Hee and Chun Doo Hwan regimes, developed in dialogue with the "transnational liberation theology movement" from the 1960s onward. Opposed to both the dominant secularity of the modern nation-state and the conservative nature of organized religion, i.e., the Christian church, the varied trajectories of the transnational movement (further substantiated by the multiple projections of "fundamentalism," e.g., the rise of radical Islam) suggest that the role of the sacred continues to be an important issue in political analysis.

Title: The Folk-Craft Movement in early Showa Japan, 1925-1945
Abstract: When the term mingei, or "folk-craft," was first coined in 1920s Japan, it meant little to anyone outside a small circle of cultivated young men in the metropolitan centers of Kyoto and Tokyo. Yet its advent took part in an ideological shift that directed growing numbers of Japanese to seek value in the native and the everyday. As a result, over the next several decades both the idea and the category of folk-craft were transformed. Formerly a type of curio associated with literary collectors, by the 1940s folk-craft was becoming a household word that referred to a growing field of native manufactures, and to the national moral-aesthetic value that was said to reside therein. The transformation of folk-craft between 1925 and 1945 was effected in large part by the Folk-Craft Movement. This study seeks to explain that transformation by telling the story of the Movement's rise from an informal, antiquarian club to a national and even international organization with sweeping aspirations for social and cultural change. An account of the Folk-Craft Movement is embedded in several larger narratives. One concerns the development of Japan's overseas empire in Asia. The Folk-Craft Movement first grew out of Japanese colonialism in Korea. Later, Movement leaders worked to construct a Japanese-led, Greater East Asian material culture in Korea, China, Manchukuo, and Taiwan. The diffusion of folk-craft as idea and commodity was also connected to the growth of domestic consumerism, and to efforts by the wartime state to control that growth. Finally, the discovery of folk-craft played an important role in the Japanese quest for a modern national identity defined by indigenous things as well as spirit. During the 1930s and 1940s the Folk-Craft Movement helped to build the notion of a native modernity for a nation at war. Study of that process suggests that it was central to the larger, transwar project of modernizing Japan.

Title: Mobilizing for Tibet: Transnational politics and diaspora culture in the post-cold war era
Abstract: This dissertation is a multiple-site study of the Tibet Movement, a transnational social movement comprised of Tibetan refugees and their Western supporters. It is based on field research conducted in sites which reflect the spread of the Tibetan diaspora and represent important "nodes" in the global Tibet network, including New York City, San Francisco, Washington, D.C., London, Geneva, and Dharamsala, India. Unlike most refugee groups, Tibetans have a set of religious and cultural traditions which are deeply appealing to non-Tibetans. This dissertation explores the various ways in which Tibet activists engage with stereotyped representations of Tibet as "Shangri-la" in order to mobilize political support for Tibetans' struggle against China's occupation of their homeland. Part One demonstrates the ways in which representations of Tibet have become part of an extended discursive space in which Tibetan identity is constructed, circulated, and contested by refugees, activists, Chinese officials, and scholars. Part Two examines the resettlement of Tibetan refugees in India, Switzerland, and the United States and traces the emergence of a Western support network. Part Three analyzes the co-production of Tibetan Buddhist "culture" by activists in New York City during the "International Year of Tibet." The dissertation explores connections between the ways people narrate personal experiences and transformations--both spiritual and political--related to Tibet and their participation in the Tibet Movement through an analysis of "diaspora" and "Tibet" narratives. To do so it draws on recent theoretical work on cultural production and poststructuralist and postcolonial theory, but attempts to ground these often abstract debates in a complex ethnographic reality. The thesis argues that with its global organization and interventions, the Tibet Movement represents an emergent form of political activism, one that is profoundly intercultural and dependent upon the complex production of representations. As such, it provides a case study of "postnational" social formations which are increasingly playing an important role in the mediation of diasporic or "ethnic" identities in the post-cold war era.

Title: Alternative video at a crossroads: Towards a strategy of extended participation
Abstract: The study of alternative video has been characterized by micro analyses of individual experiences and a proliferation of imprecise terms. This dissertation is a macro level study of the phenomenon of alternative video, based on the analysis of 72 organizations, accessed through documents and interviews with 42 representatives of organizations and leaders from around the world. The relationship between video technology and progressive social practices is theorized. The various concepts being used in the alternative video literature and their corresponding practices are defined and systematized. The development of the alternative video movement worldwide is described and analyzed. Appendices present a detailed listing of the different types of alternative video organizations studied, a systematization of the distinct practices which make up alternative video, and a listing of national, regional, and global alternative video organizations and organizational structures. This dissertation argues that video's potential to mediate time, if actualized, is key to the development of collective praxis. The concept of extended participation is advanced, and the concepts of video process and video product are redefined. Popular video and alternative video are theorized in relation to grassroots struggles, the opposition to mainstream commercial television, and the development of a social project against hegemony. It is argued that a global movement of alternative video is forming, and that this movement is standing at a crossroads between two strategies. The first is a participatory strategy based on uses of video articulated with grassroots struggles. The second is a mass video strategy based on video tactics seeking infiltration into existing structures of television. This dissertation recommends a third videotelevision strategy combining principles of popular participation with the widespread reach necessary for the development of an anti-hegemonic project of society. The dissertation concludes that the alternative video movement suggests the possibility of a global alternative to hegemonic global forces.

Title: Mass migration, nonviolent social action, and the Cuban raft exodus, 1959-1994: An analysis of citizen motivation and international politics
Abstract: The study collects and analyzes data on over 63,000 citizens, known as balseros (rafters), who made illegal exits from Cuba by sea between 1959 and 1994. It describes the phenomenon of rafting and explores the rafters' demography and self-reported motivations, as well as their interaction with the Cuban state and with interstate migration policies. These data are analyzed using theories of migration, social movement and strategic nonviolent conflict. The rafters divided into two temporal cycles that demonstrated a repetitive pattern of interaction with the state. The cycles began with dangerous, individual, citizen-initiated exit. When the number of exits became high enough to create societal awareness of the phenomenon, the Cuban state intervened, simultaneously demonizing those who were leaving as anti-social elements, and inviting the increase of their numbers by temporarily withdrawing legal sanctions against departure by sea. The resulting surge of rafters created an international migratory crisis for the United States and produced negotiations between the U.S. and Cuba. Once negotiations were concluded, the Cuban and U.S. governments jointly increased enforcement measures to end the exit of balseros. The rafters denied any intent to struggle with the Cuban state in an ongoing way. Rather, they indicated an intent to defy the state in order to free themselves of it permanently. Their decisions to leave were taken in consultation with small, domestic networks of trusted friends and family who served organizational and planning functions. Four reasons for leaving were repeatedly reported, including: the necessity of wearing "a mask" of political compliance in Cuba; the inability to know who was who in Cuban society due to pervasive state security; the necessity of trading in the black market and the risks attendant upon it: and the fear that violent revenge may accompany increased social deterioration. Variation in the effectiveness of the Cuban government's strategy for manipulating the rafter phenomenon is considered in light of the changing political/social/economic circumstances of the Cuban people, the Cuban state, and U.S. foreign and migration policy. Implications for regime change in Cuba are offered.

Title: Trace, ecart, carte: Beyond the exotic nation
Abstract: The present thesis, "Trace, Ecart, Carte: Beyond the Exotic Nation," questions the relevance of Negritude as the referential framework within which most critics have sought to assess the past, present and future states of development of Africa and the Caribbean. The study will uncover evidence of a consolidated rhetoric established in an ontological, theological, and teleological register--griotism. Within this register, political, economic, and social discourses find legitimacy only by virtue of their identification with the transcendental griot or storyteller. By tracking Negritude back to its sources, the study will show two important moments in its developments. The first period is characterized by an intense recuperation of "Western" relativism and exoticism, prompted by an ideological shift in the humanities (anthropology, ethnography) in the 1920s and the advent of surrealism. That moment allows the Francophone black writers to make the arguments of the existence of a valuable authentic black essence against the ideology of white supremacy, which formerly predominated all social sciences. The second moment--that of the post-negritude movement--works in the margin of the first one, whose oedipal links to the West it seeks to disturb--either by proposing that "appropriate theories" suitable to "black realities" be developed or by relativizing such notions as "culture," "identity," "difference," "otherness." This thesis will then demonstrate that both moments remain fixed within an essentializing spirit which, by claiming authenticity, keeps the individual trapped in a cultural perlocution that does not foster political, economic, and social awareness. By suggesting that culture is transnational rather than regional or racial, the study will argue in favor of a mutiny by the Francophone African and Caribbean against the antiquarian order established by the sacralizing characteristic of Negritude's literatures. The study will suggest that solutions to the problems faced by African and Caribbean independent states be looked for by problematizing traditionally traveled paths. This thesis will conclude that in order for theory and praxis to be politically, economically and socially relevant to one another, the notion of Francophone African and Caribbean culture needs to be approached with a post-modern spirit.

Title: Speaking out: Right-wing American women, 1933 to 1945
Abstract: This dissertation focuses on women in the right-wing movement during the era of FDR, 1933-1945. During this time large numbers of right-wing women organized to speak out regarding both national and international political issues. It was also a time when American society was undergoing tremendous change as it completed its transformation to the modern world. In examining the lives and activities of these women, this study reveals the extent to which their actions in the political arena were reactions against the perceived breakdowns of traditional values, such as those involving family and community life. Social, cultural, political, and women's history form the parameters of this work. This approach allows a broad analysis of connections between women's status in American society and their participation in politics, comparisons of concerns and actions of women across the political spectrum, and an examination of similarities, differences and interrelationships among right-wing men, women, and their organizations. By examining the groups to which right-wing women belonged, and through research into the lives and ideas of many women and organizations of the period--across the political spectrum--the dissertation explores the reasons why women joined these groups, the extent to which issues of the right differed from those of liberal and leftist organizations, and why right-wing women chose to organize separately from men. It explores the backgrounds of these women to determine what roles race, class, gender, ethnicity, religion, and geography played in the right-wing movement of this period. This dissertation contributes to the field of women's history by providing a greater understanding of how women of the 1930s and 1940s perceived their roles within American society. It will also help to determine the extent of women's gender consciousness during the decades following the passage of the Nineteenth Amendment when they no longer had the common goal of attaining the ballot. And, by standing back and looking at right-wing women in the context of the whole of American society, the dissertation shows how right-wing women were both products and shapers of American social, cultural, and political history.

Title: Revolutionary enough: Black power and state repression New York, United States of America and Kingston, Jamaica, 1964--1976
Abstract: This dissertation is an analysis of the relationship between social movements and dominant institutions, particularly the state. The case studies for this research are the relationship between the Black Panther Party and the U.S. government, particularly in New York City; and the Black Power Movement and the Jamaican Labor Party government in Kingston, Jamaica. The Jamaican case study also examines the relationship between the People's National Party government, elected in 1972, and the U.S. government. The period of focus of this work is between 1964 and 1976. The evidence for the U.S. case was obtained through the examination of issues of the Black Panther, the "Black Extremist" file of the Federal Bureau of investigation, interviews with former Black Panther Party members, and various secondary sources. The evidence for the Jamaican case was obtained through interviews with former Black Power activists and associates of the People's National Party, in addition to secondary sources and newspaper articles. The analytical approach of this work is guided by, what I call, the political implications approach, which focuses on the role of the combination of the political consciousness and actions of movements in shaping the nature of their relationships with dominant institutions. The evidence in this work indicates that the consciousness and actions of the Jamaican Black Power Movement and the Black Panther Party led to a repressive response from the state rather than an embracing or co-opting one. Although the People's National Party in Jamaica actually came to maintain control of the state in the wake of the Black Power Movement, its consciousness and actions led to repression from a more powerful state force outside of its boundaries--the U.S. government, particularly the Central Intelligence Agency. Outside of consciousness and actions, various contextual factors influenced these repressive relationships, such as race, class and political economy, the international context, the local historical context, the relative power of states, and the internal capacity of movements.

Title: The politics of social development in Costa Rica and the Dominican Republic: Social agents, the state and the international political economy
Abstract: Theories of social change share the goal of advancing development, and commonly emphasize the economic conditions for development motivated by an assumed positive relationship between economic growth and social development. These theories differentially prioritize internal and external obstacles to growth, but the problem of social development is usually framed as one of removing the barriers to growth. Costa Rica and the Dominican Republic challenge these explanations of development. Both countries had comparable levels of development before 1940, and similar aggregate economic growth rates and levels of structural dependence after 1945. Today, Costa Rica's high level of social development contrasts sharply with the low level in the Dominican Republic. A comparative-historical analysis reveals that these divergent outcomes pivoted on specific processes of class formation and of class struggle, shaped by international geopolitical conditions, commodity flows and ideological factors. In Costa Rica, during the 1930-1948 period radical labor leaders organized independent class institutions that translated political action into class power and successfully forced the divided agro-export elites to acquiesce on the social question. Through collective action, the Costa Rican labor movement challenged the political center and caused a realignment in class interests that culminated in the post-1950 social democratic path. The Dominican case demonstrates the implications for social development of ideology and the class origins of labor leaders. Like their Costa Rican counterparts, Dominican labor leaders had successfully organized several organizations by the 1920s, but the predominantly elite led movement, focusing on party politics and lobbying against the U.S. occupation, ignored the meta-regional and sectoral interests of the working class. The failure to organize around class issues aggravated intra-labor fissures, produced little social progress and minimized the popular challenge to Rafael Trujillo's usurpation of power. Once in power, Trujillo repressed the radical labor elements and coopted the conservative ones, deepening the ideological and partisan fissures that characterize the movement today. This research shows that raising the level of social welfare, while neither inevitable nor impossible, can be understood only as part of broader global social and historical processes.

Title: Entrepreneurialization, resistance and the crisis of the universities: A case study of the University of Texas at Austin
Abstract: Entrepreneurialization, the process by which universities are being restructured as overt profit-making multinational businesses, capitalizes upon the rationalization, industrialization and militarization of higher education. This case study focuses on the early stages of the entrepreneurialization of the University of Texas at Austin into a multinational corporation, a model for what is happening to universities throughout the US. This new stage of reorganization is a strategic response to the crisis of higher education in the US that resulted from the campus rebellions of the 1960-70s. While hardly complete, entrepreneurialization is in conflict with the "multiculturalism" movements, for example, that propose reforms that would further subordinate the universities to the needs and interests of diverse disempowered people. Entrepreneurialization has had an unintended side effect: as overt multinational businesses, we can better understand the central relationship of the universities in the international accumulation of capital and the importance of students in the class struggle. As the US model of entrepreneurialization spreads to universities in many other parts of the world as a result of global restructuring it also offers the possibility for fusing new transnational connections among student movements in different countries fighting common struggles. The culmination of a unique development of "adversarial methods," this dissertation combines participant observation, journalistic investigative methods, archival research, Freedom of Information and Open Records requests, budgetary analyses, and social movement research and activism to investigate and analyze a newly emerging multinational institution.

Title: Organizing Global Action: Transnational social movements and world politics
Abstract: Scholars of international relations increasingly acknowledge the role of multilateral institutions in shaping governments' policies. But existing research largely overlooks the processes by which governments come to perceive and define global problems and their possible solutions. This dissertation examines how one subset of international nongovernmental organizations, transnational social movement organizations, intervenes in multilateral politics to influence political change. Two kinds of evidence are brought to bear on the question of whether and how these organizations are involved in global political processes. First, data on the population of transnational social movement organizations over the past decade are examined, revealing dramatic but uneven growth patterns and a proliferation of formal and informal contacts between these organizations and intergovernmental organizations. Second, two organizations--Parliamentarians for Global Action and EarthAction--are analyzed to identify their organizational structures, strategies and their work in particular global campaigns. Drawing from existing scholarship on multilateral institutions and from sociological work on social movements, an analytical framework that describes three distinct but related decisionmaking arenas in global politics is introduced. The cases are examined according to how the activities of each organization target national, international and transnational political arenas as well as how the organizational structures and resources facilitate or constrain their activities in each arena. Finally, examinations of Parliamentarians for Global Action's campaign to shape global nuclear disarmament debates and EarthAction's efforts to advance the agreement reached at the 1992 UN Conference on Environment and Development are presented to illustrate specific ways these and other TSMOs work to affect policymakers perceptions of global problems and of the costs and benefits associated with different policy choices. This evidence advances the case that some nongovernmental actors significantly affect the environments in which government decisionmakers act. Although resulting policy may little resemble demands made by these groups, their intervention in national, multilateral and transgovernmental policy arenas helps bring government attention to global issues and supports more decisive national and multilateral responses to global problems.

Title: Globalization and the Canadian provinces: Costs, benefits, consequences, and responses
Abstract: This dissertation explores the issue of globalization in the context of Canadian federalism. In examining provincial roles in international relations from legal, political, and economic perspectives and incorporating an institutional analysis of globalization, it finds that the provinces face a trade-off between their sovereignty and their income levels. It argues, using both theoretical models (including a modification of Olson's theory of the state to account for federalism) and cases (ranging from provincial foreign debt to immigration policy), that provinces are increasingly finding themselves having to address the issue of globalization. It proposes several radical solutions to the problems confronting the provinces. Some of these require implementation at the federal level (a regional interest rate policy). The federal and provincial levels can both implement parts of some policies (regulating through the marketplace). A third set of policies requires provincial-level legislation (restrictions on foreign non-hedged debt). Using a Post-Modernist methodology, the dissertation identifies globalization as being consistent with a particular economic and political philosophy, that of laissez-faire conservatism. The neoconservative objective is the lessening of democratic accountability in the determination of what rules and regulations the market follows. The study argues that international rules and regulations are being established which serve the interests of multinational corporations and transient millionaires when, for the majority of people, capital flight will never be an issue and their movement will always be relatively costly. Unless nation-states and subnational governments reduce the interpersonal disparity of wealth by implementing equitable distribution policies, the public sector will atrophy, the social safety net will disappear, and the needs of Reichian "symbolic analysts" who have no loyalty to any flag will take precedence over the majority will.

Title: Social movements, political reform and the transfer of sovereignty in Hong Kong
Abstract: Hong Kong society is often regarded as politically apathetic. Yet, throughout her history, Hong Kong has experienced periodic waves of social movement activity. Why have social movements emerge? How do they act and create new avenues for political participation? These issues raise questions regarding Hong Kong's political structure and the post 1997 SAR government. This study focuses on the role social movements play in the political reform process. While most studies emphasize Great Britain's, China's and even the Hong Kong government's role, this study presents and analyzes the activities of social movements, so that a clearer picture of civil society and political change "from below" emerges. The study integrates the literature on Hong Kong, civil society and social movements into a multi-dimensional framework to analyze social movement influence in Hong Kong politics. The study's three case studies: the independent labor, the nontraditional Christian Church, and the democracy movements are analyzed using the multidimensional framework. The study evaluates the forces that drive and sustain social movements, such as, the issues, constituency, movement organization and structure. It analyzes the timing of protest and collective actions, asserting that social movements take advantage of policy and regime change to act. The study makes a contribution to the understanding of the relationship between grassroots efforts and the development of civil society in bringing about an autonomous society. Moreover, the study advances the understanding of social movements and international politics in non-Western and developing societies. In sum, this study argues that while the Chinese and British governments dispute the pace of political reform, the Hong Kong people have been neglected in the process. And as a result, Hong Kong social movements play an essential role in raising the awareness of the aspirations of the people and bringing to light the voices from below.

Title: The nation and its 'new' women: Feminism, nationalism, colonialism, and the Palestinian women's movement, 1920-1948
Abstract: This dissertation analyzes the rise and development of the Palestinian women's movement during the British Mandate period, focusing primarily on the urban, educated, elite women who founded, led and participated in numerous women's organizations. Palestinian women took part in demonstrations, held women's conferences, protested to the British authorities, participated in the 1936-1939 Revolt, and became involved in the pan-Arab and international women's movements. Using oral history, British government documents, and the Arabic press, I inscribe this movement into history. The dissertation addresses a central question: to what extent did Palestinian women's political activity contain expressions of feminism, or was their involvement primarily ancillary to the male-led Palestinian nationalist movement? When examined at all, women's activity in this period has until now been considered limited, "bourgeois" and conservative, due to its charitable nature and the upper-middle-class origins of most of its participants. I examine the historical and cultural context of the movement, part of which involves exploration of "new" concepts of middle class womanhood which were profoundly influenced by the intersections of nationalism and colonialism in Palestinian society. Out of this articulation came a form of "indigenous" feminism. Palestinian women, analogous to other Third World women living under colonial hegemonies, did not define themselves solely by gender, but rather, incorporated notions of their subordinate status along racially and nationally defined lines as well. Nonetheless, located within their activity is a type of feminism that constituted a critique of both internal patriarchal structures (Palestinian Arab) and an externally-imposed, colonialist patriarchal structure (British). Women protested limited gender constructs within their own society, debating the "woman question" in the press and other public forums; on the other hand, they manipulated their society's gender limitations, invoking transgressions against "tradition" as a strategy to alarm the British, who were fearful of potential social and religious upheaval. This manipulation of "tradition" represented expressions of subversive nationalism and indigenous feminism, both of which reflected ideological and social contradictions in Palestinian political discourse.

Title: Green spaces: Place and the constitution of environmental activism
Abstract: Place is an undertheorized aspect of political life. While the influence of place on politics and social order is often implied in the use of case studies or in explanations of diversity or deviance from expected global or national norms, its role is rarely conceptualized as constitutive. This work explores the constitutive relationship between place and politics through a comparative study of two forest activist organizations in Oregon, the Native Forest Council and Friends of Forest Park. In this exploration, places are understood to make a difference to political life as both settings for political activity and as orientations for or objects of political organizing. This understanding is developed through a theoretical framework that draws on: a largely geographical literature on place and politics, particularly Agnew (1987), Pred (1990), and Entrikin (1991); the literature of place-based political ecology, notably bioregionalism; and that of social movement theory, particularly Scott (1990), Jamison, Eyerman, and Cramer (1990), Eyerman and Jamison (1991), and Castells (1983). The research on the activist organizations consisted of individual and small group interviews and archival and documentary sources. This information was used to develop political profiles of each organization and to detail the place-contexts into which those profiles are situated. The main conclusions drawn from this study are that place shapes politics by involving activists in distinct histories of activism and commitment, particular contexts for communication, and differing scales of activity.
