Title: Modernity, sociology and social movements. Movements of modernity: Politics, modernity and collective identity in Europe, 1789-1989
Abstract: This abstract summarizes two interrelated books, published separately: (1) Modernity, Sociology and Social Movements and (2) Movements of Modernity: Politics, Modernity and Collective Identity in Europe, 1789-1989. The dissertation proceeds from two, partially related, theoretical debates and fields of research in sociology initiated during the 1970s and still generating important questions and inquiry. First, the dissertation is based on theoretical discussions and research concerning what has been called "new social movements". The question that is often posed in this context is: What is new about new social movements? Second, the dissertation reflects the debate on modernity/postmodernity and the related question as to whether we are facing the emergence of a new kind of society and, if so, what are the implications thereof. One aim of the dissertation is to offer a historical perspective on these two debates. As a point of departure, two general and reciprocal questions are posed: (1) Is it possible to bring new perspectives to the discourse on modernity/postmodernity by means of social movement theory and a historical inquiry into European social movements after the French Revolution? (2) Is it possible to bring new perspectives to the theoretical debate and empirical research concerning new social movements through the discourse on modernity/postmodernity? In the first three chapters of Modernity, Sociology and Social Movements these questions are addressed through the pursuit of a historical inquiry and critical discussion concerning the concepts, theories and methodologies of modernity and social movements as employed by the social sciences, mainly sociology. The book argues that the concept of collective identity in the context of social movement theory might be further developed by means of the conceptual framework and methodologies of the inter-disciplinary field of Cultural Studies. This is the point of departure for the final two chapters, that views social movements from the perspective of a renewed cultural sociology. A general aim of the second book, Movements of Modernity: Politics, Modernity and Collective Identity in Europe, 1789-1989, is to offer a historical perspective on social movements and modernity by employing the renewed cultural sociology discussed in the first book. There are two important aspects of the inquiry. First, the book provides a historical perspective on the issue of the "newness" of the collective identities produced by new social movements. Second, it offers a fresh approach to the discourses and collective identities constructed by "old" movements. More specifically, the historical inquiry is pursued through a discourse analysis of "movement texts" written in connection with the French Revolution, 19th century nationalism, the Second International and German Nazism (between the wars), as well as situationism (and the student movement), the new women's movement and the environmental movement of the 1960s and early 1970s. Two important conclusions of the dissertation involve the increasing importance of culture--taken in a broad sense to include knowledge, information, symbols, signs and images--in contemporary complex societies. First, one of the most important differences between the old and new social movements is that the new movements increasingly pursue cultural struggles and emphasize the symbolic dimension of political action, which implies its aesthetization. Second, this increased importance of culture accords a greater relevance to Cultural Studies as an approach to the study of social movements.

Title: Dogma or working hypothesis? The young Wigforss and the socialist project of society
Abstract: The dissertation analyses the political ideas of Ernst Wigforss, one of the prominent figures in modern Swedish political history. The study is focused on Wigforss' role in the social democratic discussion until the 1920s. I investigate how Wigforss tries to give Swedish social democracy a politically possible and an intellectually tenable understanding of the relationship between political theory and practice in a coherent strategy. Wigforss thus tries to lay the theoretical foundations for a socialist project for social change. Two main currents in the history of socialist ideas are distinguished; a discussion about social philosophy and a discussion about social organization. By social organization I mean the organization of national societies and the international order. The thoughts of Quentin Skinner on how to study the history of ideas and Karl Popper's discussion about scientific knowledge are used to construct a framework for analyzing the political ideas of the young Wigforss. Central concepts are problem, background and problem situation. The background, which comprises the prerequisites for Wigforss' thinking, consists of the Ideas of the Age, the political Situation and the intellectual Milieu. Wigforss is confronted with political problems which he tries to solve, and hence I study the different problem situations he is facing. He attempts to adopt a scientific approach to social problems and political discussion as well as to apply a scholarly perspective as a tool in his political work. However, in his social philosophy and in his discussion about social organization Wigforss fails to provide any close guidance as to how the socialist goals actually can be achieved. Wigforss never provides any precise answer to the question of how the relationship between political theory and practice should be given a tenable formulation in a strategy for social change. Not until the 1930s did Wigforss find a theory, in economics, which could be combined with political practice in a successful strategy for the Swedish social democracy. Wigforss thus introduced a strategy for economic policy and social change, which gained general support in the Swedish labour movement.

Title: Plomo o plata: Politics, corruption and drug policy in Colombia
Abstract: The purpose of this dissertation was to explore the problem of making drug policy in Colombia and to determine why Colombian officials have been unable or unwilling to bring international criminals to justice and how this has not only affected internal state order but external state relations in an increasingly interdependent world. A study of the politics and history of Colombia was first carried out through an examination of the contention that Colombia is the most violent country on earth. Next, the growth of criminal organizations in that country was traced over several decades. Factors such as indiscriminate violence, corruption, historical party rivalries, traditional oligarchical structures, extremes of wealth and poverty and guerrilla movements were also found to contribute to a very difficult environment in which to make and implement policies in the Colombian criminal justice system. Secondly, the international dimensions of this problem were explored through an examination of international criminal law, generally and extradition, specifically. The United States was found to have significant influence on Colombian drug policy in how it has, in effect, turned a domestic consumption crisis into a foreign policy problem. A focal point of relations between the two states has been the 1979 U.S.-Colombia Treaty of Extradition which the U.S. insists Colombia enforce. When Colombian traffickers have been extradited, however, the drug cartels' violent retributions have been so deleterious to the social order that desperate Colombian officials have been virtually coerced into finding political/legal barriers to the Treaty. Colombian policy makers have thus been subject to extremes of violence, coercion and international pressure from fiercely competing interests such that it is difficult, if not impossible, to make effective and lasting policy to combat drug trafficking. The results have been fatal for many Colombian officials and debilitating for the country's political system and international relations. The research for this dissertation has included an analysis of available literature, both academic and government sources as well as other communications relevant to the research subject such as media reports. A content analysis as a form of unobtrusive research was undertaken together with interviews with selected persons who have expertise in the area.

Title: Jane Addams: The reformer as pacifist
Abstract: This thesis explores the peace and reform activities of Jane Addams (1860-1935), architect of the modern women's peace movement and leader of the first international peace effort. Her opposition to armed conflict was informed by her years of settlement house work and rooted in her belief that war was destructive to democracy and social progress. This thesis will examine Addams' formative years, her leadership in the international women's peace movement, and her efforts to promote peace both during and after World War I. Her work will be examined in the historic context of the war hysteria that occupied America during the war, and the Red Scare that occupied post-war America. In addition, the thesis will provide a retrospective on the career of Jane Addams, a conclusion for the research, and an examination of some of the scholarship that has interpreted the unique pacifism embraced by this prominent reformer and pacifist.

Title: Protecting human rights: The dynamics of international nonviolent accompaniment by Peace Brigades International in Sri Lanka
Abstract: Peace Brigades International (PBI) uses international observers and nonviolent accompaniment to protect human rights workers and nongovernmental organizations (NGO) from political violence. This dissertation analyzes the social and political dynamics of accompaniment by PBI's Sri Lanka Project. It is based on participant observation with the PBI team in Sri Lanka during 1993 and 1994, and on 59 interviews with PRI members, those they accompany, NGO staffers, diplomats, and police officials. The study contributes to a small body of literature on research in dangerous situations, where the researcher faces similar risks of physical violence as the informants. International accompaniment's usefulness as a violence deterrent is shown to be partly dependent upon the degree to which those against which it is employed are nested in international agreements, networks, and financial dependencies. Its limitations against non-state forces in Sri Lanka are highlighted. Case analysis of the accompaniment of election observers demonstrates that PBI's accompaniment is multi-functional and occurs on multiple levels and contexts simultaneously. Accompaniment is shown to have both empowering and disempowering aspects. While the nonviolent escorting of those threatened is central, the less visible accompaniment of domestic social movement development and the rebuilding of political processes crippled by para-state and state terrorism is also significant. Case analysis reveals the interorganizational cooperation among human rights NGOs that under girds and strengthens PBI's accompaniment. Turnover on PBi teams makes the consensus decision making principle of full participation salient and has deleterious effects on team decision making. The dangerous nature of PBI's unarmed peacekeeping increases the importance of three consensus principles: individual ownership of group decisions, attending to the feelings of participants, and valuing process over product. Extended analysis of one PBI team's use of consensus demonstrates that it cultivated individual ownership of group decisions, increased group solidarity, and helped members deal with fear. PBI's reliance on white observers from western nations to deter political repression is found to engage the dynamics of racism, neo-colonialism, and white privilege. A five-part typology of PBI member responses to this engagement is presented and proposals for democratizing international accompaniment are suggested.

Title: Beyond iron laws: information technology and social transformation in the global environmental movement
Abstract: It was characteristic of the peculiarly modern conception of democracy that it had both to be centralized and that, in practice, centredness undermined it. This finds its expression in Michels' iron law of oligarchy. The contemporary idea of the global information society appears open to new democratic alternatives for organization which escape this double bind. This thesis explores whether these possibilities have any basis in the reality of contemporary organizing. To this end I investigate the global environmental movement, representative of contemporary conditions as the Social Democratic party was of modernity. Contemporary organizing is marked both by a relationship to globality and the importance of the use of information technologies. Friends of the Earth (FoE) was founded by transnational elites, yet is marked in the present by the empowerment of local groups. Thus the identity of FoE is not given over to the action and interests of elites, transnational or national, but rather is a product of the performance of ordinary members. Authority and power relations operate but not on the basis of the command of the centre over the rest but rather in relation to a fundamental negotiation about the requirements of organizing on behalf of he planet. This decenteredness requires us to theorize differently the way we make sense of the boundaries and boundedness of organizing. Globality becomes our focus rather than modern internationalism. Information technologies allow organizing to escape the double bind, since they demonstrate that it is not technically inevitable, whilst globality provides the dynamic emphasis that underlines the necessity to escape the problematic of centralization.

Title: On route 2020: Malaysia, modernity and the Multimedia Super Corridor (BL)
Abstract: This thesis is an examination of the processes which underlie social and physical transformation in Malaysia's Multimedia Super Corridor (MSC), a 50 km zone stretching southwards from the national capital, Kuala Lumpur. At one level, MSC urban redevelopment is understood in terms of increasingly global cultural and economic processes and the emergence of a dynamic (Southeast) Asian region. However, I focus rather on the way in which new urban spaces and 'natural' environments are bound up with a state vision of modern Malaysia (Vision 2020) which both promotes, and is dependent upon, a new Malaysian and a new national identity. State attempts to (b)order global processes connect with broader debates on how context can be brought into grand theories of modernity. Route 2020 speaks not only of social and physical transformation in line with state visions of Malaysian modernity, but also of movement in and through MSC. The case study sites in this thesis are connected by a 'Dedicated Highway' which has become known as 'Route 2020'. Each of the sites along the route is analysed in terms of both attempts by state and non-state authorities to define and promote appropriate conduct in citizens and everyday resistance or contest to these discourses of governmentality. More specifically, the Kuala Lumpur City Centre makes authoritative meanings visible to the nation and the world while these are, at the same time, reworked through everyday social life in the city; the MSC cities introduce new electronic administrative techniques and represent new social objectives and ideals - multicultural national unity, creativity, discipline - which seek to induce appropriate self-government in individuals; and Putrajaya and Kuala Lumpur International Airport, at the southern end of the MSC, are sites of contest to state aims and means of development from displaced and marginalised groups. Resistance in sites is related to a broader sense of everyday and authoritative reworking of would-be hegemonic state objectives and techniques.

Title: Charles stuart and the transatlantic antislavery connection
Abstract: The nineteenth century antislavery campaign was significant not only because of the importance of the mission, but because it represented one of the first social movements to operate on an international scale. The abolitionists, reinforced with Enlightenment ideals such as the brotherhood of man, liberty, and equality, which dominated the political thought of the day, were concerned with people beyond their borders. They found an outlet for their beliefs in the antislavery movement. Lending support to the humanitarian beliefs of the abolitionists was the argument of Evangelical Christianity which professed unequivocally that slavery was a sin. These views were shared by both British and American abolitionists. Any study of the antislavery movement is a study of the individuals involved in the movement. This dissertation argues that among the more influential individuals in the transatlantic antislavery movement of the nineteenth century is a man named Charles Stuart. While he has remained a little known figure, his contributions to the cause of abolition are significant and noteworthy. As a retired military officer in the British Army, with a pension that enabled him to devote all his efforts to the cause of abolition, Stuart worked tirelessly, travelling frequently between Britain and the United States, bringing antislavery information to the attention of abolitionists on either side of the Atlantic. As a prolific writer of antislavery pamphlets and articles, as well as a relentless lecturer and campaigner, Charles Stuart played a key role in turning the tide of public opinion away from the Colonization movement which had been gaining momentum and which threatened to undermine legitimate antislavery efforts. Perhaps the most significant contribution made by Charles Stuart to the cause of abolition, however, is seen in his influence on a young Theodore Weld. Through the influence of Charles Stuart, Weld was converted to the cause of abolition and would choose to make abolition his life's vocation. Theodore Weld, largely through his relationship with Charles Stuart, would become one of the most influential American abolitionists.

Title: Reimagining the umma: translocal space and the changing boundaries of muslim political community
Abstract: A wide variety of 'translocal' forces - diasporic peoples, transnational social movements, global & migratory cities, post-national institutions, information technologies - are challenging the traditional state-centrism of International Relations' political imaginary. Moreover, just as people are translocal, so are their theories. This thesis analyses Islam as a form of 'travelling theory' in the context of the global transformations outlined above. It seeks to understand how globalising processes are manifested as lived experience through a discussion of debates over the meaning of Muslim identity, political community and the emergence of something like a 'critical Islam'. After a critique of state-centric thinking in International Relations, the thesis goes on to suggest that more sophisticated treatments of translocal politics can be found in the literatures of anthropology, postcolonial and cultural studies. A non-essentialist conception of Islam is introduced, followed by a discussion of the conditions under which Muslim discourses on the umma (the world community of believers) have historically been produced. Three key theoretical tropes - travelling theory, hybridity and diaspora - are then discussed as framing devices for understanding translocal politics. Two case study chapters, one on the politics of Muslim diaspora communities and the other on Muslim uses of communications and information technologies, are presented. The first focuses on debates within Muslim communities as to the nature and meaning of modern Islam, the reformation of Muslim thought on politics, community and gender and the implications of travelling Islam's return journey to its various original settings. The second case study highlights the changing boundaries of religious knowledge by demonstrating how information technologies have been deployed as a means by which to contrast traditional sources of Islamic authority. In the concluding chapter it is argued that translocal forces are leading to the emergence of a wider Muslim public sphere. Furthermore, the critical discourses enabled by this translocal space amount to a reconceptualisation and reimagining of the umma.

Title: Seeds of change: conserving biodiversity and social movements
Abstract: This thesis consists of a case study of the seed movement, a contemporary social movement, which has as its aim to challenge the emerging global regulatory regime controlling the ownership of seeds. The current period is seeing a radical extension of private property into the realm of life forms through the patenting of genes and seeds. The application of patent law to genes and seeds combines the extension of an expert discourse with the enclosure of commonly held socio-ecological resources. This has taken the form of a global hegemonic project working through a number of international institutions. The linchpin of this project is the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPs) within the new World Trade Organization. I have explored the seed movement, opposing this hegemonic project, through interviews with activists and seed savers in the UK and observing international meetings and events. The seed movement has a political wing, consisting of counter-experts who challenge the dominant framing of seed issues at cognitive, political and epistemological levels. It also has a cultural wing, consisting of practical seed savers, who combine different approaches to vegetable growing with saving seed as a project to conserve biodiversity. The counter-experts develop networks that contribute to the emergence of a global civil society and engage with global political actors in shaping the seed patenting regime. Through my case study I have developed a new theoretical model, combining a macrosociology of global hegemonic projects challenged by global social movements; a mesosociology where social movements play a creative role in global regime change and the emergence of a global civil society and counter-experts challenge the embedding of global hegemony by disrupting any neat division between experts and lay publics; and a microsociology of the social movement processes of framing social conflicts, networking and developing new action repertoires.

Title: In search of the Quetzal: Guatemalan Mayan transnational migration and ethnic identity formation
Abstract: This study examines how the transnational migration process that links the Guatemalan Mayan (Kanjobal) community of Santa Eulalia with Los Angeles shapes the construction of ethnic identity in both the sending and host locales. It explores how this migrant community diversifies its transnational linkages with the home country in spite of restrictions on members' physical mobility due to recent changes in U.S. immigration policy. Several types of data were gathered during fieldwork conducted in both Santa Eulalia and Los Angeles: (a) individual and group qualitative interviews in both locales; (b) fieldnotes from participant observation of meetings and cultural events in both locales; (c) census surveys of 62 households administered in one village in the municipality of Santa Eulalia; (d) Diocese of Huehuetenango census data from Santa Eulalia; (e) 1990 U.S. Government census data for Los Angeles and; (f) primary and secondary historical and demographic data. The study finds that as migrants from Santa Eulalia confront higher levels of discrimination in Los Angeles, their cultural and religious organizations are increasingly influenced by the growing ethnic resurgence movement in Guatemala. This outcome leads actors affiliated with the Guatemalan church and state to forge relationships with these migrant organizations. By reintegrating into the social life of their home country, Kanjobal migrants express a transnational identity that revives and strengthens old forms of ethnicity and reflects the process of reactive formation. The process of transnational migration also contributes to the exacerbation of socio-economic divisions in Santa Eulalia, leading residents to engage in projects that promote community cohesion and to support the growing ethnic resurgence movement.

Title: Naming the enemy: The emergence of an international anti-corporate social movement
Abstract: This dissertation is the first systematic analysis of emerging social movements against corporations and economic globalization. These movements take three archetypal modes: Contestation/reform movements use existing democratic institutions and direct action to constrain corporate power. (These include the Corporate Welfare and Campaign Finance Reform movements, Peace and Human Rights movements, Explicit Anti-Corporate Movements, Anti-Profit movements, and Cyberpunk.) Movements that attempt "globalization from below" work to build new international democratic structures that will be populist, highly participatory, and just. (These include Environmental Justice, New Labor Movements, Socialism, Anti-Free Trade Agreement movements, and Zapatismo.) Relocalization/delinking movements cut themselves off from the global economy, rebuild small-scale economic institutions, and celebrate the pleasures of the limitations of locality. (These include Anarchism, Sustainable Development, Small Business Movements, Sovereignty Movements, And Religious Nationalisms.) The conclusions of the work include the importance of using a colonial analysis to understand the operations of the global economy, not only on third world nations, but on first world and sub-national areas. It finds that a diversity of non-socialist movements are serious about political economic analysis focused on critiques of growth, dependency, colonialism, and consumption. The study also draws attention to issues of scale and community both for political economy and democratic theory. At the same time, even the tremendous impacts of the destruction of national sovereignty, we may need to reconsider the liberatory possibilities within the delegitimized concept of nation. For social movements theory, the work finds that the movements are not organized as identity movements and do not use postmodern techniques of struggle. Promising new alliances have been forged and surprising new ones are suggested. Each of the movements studied makes important contributions to the project of delegitimizing corporate projects and to reimagining economies.

Title: Privatization and personhood: Transforming work in postsocialist Poland
Abstract: How does privatization affect workers' concepts of themselves as persons? How do changes in “personhood” relate to the economic and political transitions in Eastern Europe? How do they affect the way that Eastern Europe is integrated into the global economy? This dissertation investigates these topics through the study of workers and management techniques at the Alima-Gerber (AG) factory, a formerly state owned enterprise in Rzeszów, Poland, which was privatized by the Gerber Products Company of Fremont, Michigan. One of the first firms in Poland to be privatized, AG has been at the forefront of the movement to transform state socialist factories into capitalist enterprises. Using methods derived from Gerber's experience with Total Quality Management (TQM), AG's strategy is to increase consumption of its products by producing high quality goods for specific consumer groups. As part of this plan, it has instituted rigid quality control, job evaluation, and training methods. Underlying this is the belief that in order to produce goods for a capitalist market, they must produce workers for a capitalist enterprise. I focus on the new management methods introduced by Gerber, and how they attempt to change both the organization of production and workers' identities. Since the kinds of subjectivities that are produced are not always what the planners intend, the dissertation also examines how employees use Catholic, kin, socialist and Solidarity ideologies as well as Western management jargon to redefine themselves and to negotiate relationships within the firm. This dissertation contributes to social theory as well as Eastern European studies. I argue that economic transformation not only requires changes in macroeconomic structures, or the regime of accumulation , but also in the symbols and practices of everyday life, or the mode of social regulation . Using Foucault's theory of governmentality and Bourdieu's theory of habitus, I show how forms of personhood are an integral part of the mode of social regulation, and hence of change at the levels of the firm and the economy.

Title: The global servants: (Im)Migrant Filipina domestic workers in Rome and Los Angeles
Abstract: The contemporary outflow of Filipina women, reaching an estimated count of one to three million individuals, and their entrance into domestic service in more than 120 countries is a particular result of global restructuring vis-a-vis the Philippines. It is a movement representing one of the largest and widest flows of female migration in the world today. My dissertation enters the world of migrant Filipina domestic workers to examine the underpinnings and subversions of patriarchy and global capitalism in their everyday lives. My dissertation is based on 82 in-depth interviews with domestic workers and participant-observation conducted in the field research sites of Rome and Los Angeles. I compare and contrast the migration of Filipina domestic workers in the United States and Italy, the two Western countries with the largest concentration of Filipino migrants. Shifting from the two dominant approaches in migration studies, i.e., a macrostructural approach and intermediate level approach, I analyze the social processes of migration and settlement from the level of the subject. The three social processes I consider are: (1) the formation of transnational households; (2) the entrance into and performance of domestic work; and (3) the formation of the migrant community. By analyzing migration from the level of the subject, I examine the navigation of migrant Filipina domestic workers through these social processes. I maintain a dual objective of (1) identifying the dislocations elicited within the social processes of migration for migrant Filipina domestic workers and (2) identifying the reactions of the migrant to these dislocations. My dissertation offers a rich description of the practices undertaken by migrant Filipina domestic workers to determine their own lives. By assuming the agency of the subject, my dissertation does not seek to establish the agency of migrant Filipina domestic workers. Instead, it analyzes the meanings of agency. Following the contention of Judith Butler regarding the "bind of agency," my analysis of the reactions of migrant Filipina domestic workers against the dislocations elicited within the social processes of migration shows that their actions simultaneously involve the 'resistance' and'recuperation' of power. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: Border crossings: Transnational movements for alternative development and radical democracy in the United States-Mexico border region
Abstract: This project uses extended interview methods to study the means by which community-based movements for labor and environmental justice along the U.S./Mexico border--especially in the San Diego/Tijuana area--have interpreted and resisted neoliberal forms of North American economic integration, specifically in the maquiladora sector. It begins by historicizing the theories and practices of economic development and their social effects, tracing them to the current period of neoliberal restructuring globally--defined by "globalization," intensive foreign investment, export manufacturing, privatization, labor discipline, and free trade. Subsequent chapters reveal the subaltern analyses presented by borderland activists of neoliberalism and its lived everyday effects; the strategies and discourses of movement organizations as they resist neoliberal development agendas; and the hegemonic dilemmas of repression, incorporation, and internal disunity that constrain these organizations. The findings of this research suggests that export manufacturing in the region has been linked closely with many rapid changes--increasing urban growth, poverty, human rights violations, environmental injustice, shifting gender relations, cultural imperialism, and the disempowerment of government vis-a-vis corporate capital--all of which have prompted many new community-based labor and environmental movements to make sense of the new conditions of development and offer popular alternatives. Further, this project has found that the strategies and identities of border social movements, although beleaguered by various problems, are uniquely instructive in their opposition to neoliberalism and a capitalist transnationalism, by clearly defining a radically democratic and populist idea of social movements, by facilitating transnational and trans-issue coalitions among diverse constituents, and by articulating an anti-imperialist and feminist vision of global citizenship.

Title: Waves of decolonization: Towards an Inter-Americas Cultural Studies
Abstract: How is it possible to write a genealogy of cultural production that accounts for the persistent interest of author-activists in the Americas to define their local and domestic struggles in relation to liberation efforts in other countries? “Waves of Decolonization: Towards an Inter-Americas Cultural Studies,” addresses this problem through a comparative study of cultural expressions of decolonization by author-activists in the U.S., Cuba, and Mexico. By identifying continuities among authors who sought with W. E. B. Du Bois to forge the “coming unities” among the racially-oppressed of different nations, decolonization provides a theoretical model that builds on the Gramscian theory of hegemonic coalition-building, integrating histories of resistance that link a wide variety of U.S. author-activists to those in Cuba and Mexico through discursive and institutional commonalities. Such commonalities emerge through a periodization of a wide range of texts within two waves of decolonization, 1880–1940, the first preceeding the Spanish American War of 1898 and the second following World War I, with each wave defined by a set of transnational literary and social scientific discourses and narrative forms: sentimentalism, folk primitivism and ethnography. These discourses converge with various social movements, as in the case of 1920s nationalisms, Pan Africanism, and latinoamericanismo .

Title: The cultural politics of development: Nongovernmental organizations in New Delhi
Abstract: Grassroots non-governmental organizations (NGOs) have renewed hope in development and in particular poverty alleviation programs in many parts of the Third World. They have been praised by many different groups in the development community for making development human-centered and in particular for enabling the participation of potential beneficiaries in the development process. This dissertation, based on field research in New Delhi slum communities, explores the cultural politics of development in grassroots NGOs. By cultural politics I mean the combination of discursive formations and political economy in which NGOs participate. I outline this cultural politics by locating NGOs vis-a-vis other groups in the development field and by presenting an ethnography of the everyday practices and programs of NGOs. In this study, I argue that although NGOs have been generally thought of as local or grassroots organizations, this being viewed as their greatest asset, they are increasingly connected to movements, ideas, and institutions at the international level. In this sense, the role of NGOs in shaping the course of contemporary development is an important case study of the processes of globalization. By focusing on everyday practice, I show that NGOs practices and discourses do not reflect a single ideology or model of development. This heterodoxy of practice and ideology must be understood in terms of the broader political economy of development and is in part an important consequence of the increasing local-global connections of NGOs. Finally, through a combination of innovative approaches to development and activism NGOs have broadened the definition of development to include processes of political and social empowerment as well as economic growth. I suggest that those NGOs engaged in programs directed at all members of their societies, not only the poorest or most disenfranchised, will be best able to fulfill this vision of development and social justice.

Title: What is "good reasoning" about global warming? A comparison of high school students and specialists
Abstract: This study compares the knowledge and reasoning about global warming of 10 twelfth grade students and 6 specialists, including scientists and policy analysts. The study uses global warming as a context for addressing the broad objective of formulating goals for scientific literacy. Subjects evaluated a set of articles about global warming and evaluated policies proposed to ameliorate global warming, including a gasoline tax and a "feebate" system of fees and rebates on automobiles. All students and one scientist participated in a full treatment involving interviews and activities with a computer program (discussed below), averaging about 3.75 hours. In addition, five specialists participated in interviews only, averaging one hour. One line of analysis focuses on knowledge content, examining how subjects applied perspectives from both natural and social sciences. This analysis is positioned as an empirical component to the movement to develop content standards for science education, as exemplified by the recommendations of Science for All Americans (SFAA). Some aspects of competent performance in the present study hinged upon knowledge and skills advocated by SFAA (e.g., fluency with themes of science such as scale). Other aspects involved such skills as evaluating economic interests behind a scientific argument in the media or considering hidden costs in a policy area. By characterizing a range of approaches to how students and specialists performed the experimental tasks, the present study affords a view of scientific literacy not possible without this type of information. Another line of analysis investigates a measure of coherent argumentation from a computer program, Convince Me, in relation to policy reasoning. The program is based on a connectionist model, ECHO. Subjects used the program to create arguments about the aforementioned policies. The study compares Convince Me's Model's Fit argumentation measure to other measures, including ratings of 6 human judges about the quality of the arguments, a measure of the stability of subjects' views, and the number of statements in subjects' arguments. The pattern of significant correlations among several of these measures, plus interview findings, help to clarify cognitive and educational issues involved with using Convince Me (or related programs) in this area.

Title: The labor of love and bread: Professionalized and volunteer activism in the Sao Paulo women's health movement
Abstract: In the past 10 years, many professionalized organizations, also referred to as nongovernmental organizations (NGOs), have been formed in the Brazilian women's movement. This study examines the origins of this trend, linked to the boom of NGOs worldwide, to the return of formal democracy in Brazil in 1985, and to the still limited absorption by the international development establishment of part of the women's movement agenda, as well as to changes internal to the movement. Based on ethnographic research, this study compares the collective identity, practices and internal dynamics of two professionalized and two volunteer groups dealing with women's health in Sao Paulo. This study demonstrates that the women's movement is best understood as a social movement field with heterogeneous participants. Feminist NGOs are one of them. Yet, their organizational characteristics distinguish NGOs from classic social movement organizations. In search of the efficiency and management capability required by the logic of projects financed by donor agencies, NGOs have a more formalized and differentiated internal structure, less permeable for neighborhood women. The presence of extrinsic rewards alters the meaning of members' participation in feminist NGOs which becomes simultaneously a commitment for gendered social change and a means for earning a living. NGOs have an hybrid identity. Their emphasis on planning, linked to accountability to donors for funded projects, tends to steer NGOs away from, and to limit their potential for, consciousness-raising and mobilization. Yet, it stimulates publications, research activities and advocacy in policy-making arenas, a shift already promoted by the transition towards formal democracy. As a result, professionalized feminists have tended to reduce their involvement with Sao Paulo neighborhood women's groups. With professionalization, the movement also faces new challenges in terms of increased power differentials. Professionalized activist organizations and their associated institutional strategies do contribute to social change. Yet, a two-pronged strategy with a vibrant movement involved in cultural/micro-level change is essential for true democratization and gendered equity. Strategies increasing NGOs downward accountability to their constituency would greatly enhance the balancing act between their advocacy and their micro-level culture change projects.

Title: "Imperialism of righteousness": The influence of the American Protestant social gospel on foreign missions and expansionism, 1890-1910
Abstract: The main purpose of this dissertation is the examination and verification of the relationship that existed between the Protestant social gospel movement, foreign missions, and nationalistic expansionism at the turn of the century. More specifically, this dissertation seeks to examine the ways in which national social reform of the type preached by the social gospelers was linked in all kinds of obvious and not-so-obvious ways to international policy. Because of this linkage, reform language and reformist domestic goals led in all kinds of ways to the exportation of American ways abroad. This critical theme in American intellectual and religio-cultural history tends to get understudied in religious history.

Title: Poverty, patriarchy and prostitution: A study of the sexual labour of Nepali and Thai women in the sex industry in Asia
Abstract: This study engages in a detailed analysis of the incorporation of the sexual labour of Nepali and Thai women in the sex industry by focussing on the following aspects; (1) Nature of the sex industry in Asia and the movement of women and girls into it, (2) Socio-economic and cultural dimensions of social change in South Asia and Thailand in the context of globalisation, (3) Socio-historical processes in relation to the production of sexuality and the attendant discourse, (4) Feminisation of international migration and the transnational transfer of reproductive labour, and (5) The growing degradation of women's reproductive labour and the intensifying menialization as well as criminalization of it under the current phase of globalisation. This study relies on qualitative data collected and presented in the form of socio-histories or oral narratives of Nepali and Thai women working in the sex trade business. It is argued that on account of the pressure of globalisation, erosion of existing subsistence bases and the attendant immiseration have created a growing pool of younger women workers to be siphoned off into the sex industry. As such, it is argued that the form of prostitution which exists presently in many of the third world countries is quite distinct from the old form. Under this new form, not only has sex trade become a transnational industry but marginalized women are viewed as a resource item for export, and consequently constitute a vital ingredient in the national development of their countries. This study engages in a comprehensive analysis of key conceptual constructs such as patriarchy, poverty, prostitution and reproductive labour in order to grasp the multi-causal complexity of the contemporary sex industry. Above all, this study critically challenges the mechanistic narrative of marginalised women's victimization through a vast array of narratives of agency and complexity. Even when the system seeks to undermine the rights and dignity of these women as workers, they refuse to be incarcerated as victims and creatively seek out negotiating spaces to exercise their agency celebrate their humanity.

Title: Mahler's Seventh Symphony, modernism, and the crisis of Austrian liberalism
Abstract: Since its premiere in Prague on 19 September 1908, Gustav Mahler's Seventh Symphony has fascinated and befuddled musicians and scholars alike. Although early performances attracted many positive reactions, the Seventh has accrued an almost indelible negative critical legacy. The various extant analyses of the Seventh offer a reasonably clear picture of the sectionalization of the symphony, its thematic structure, the provocative harmonic language, and aspects of intervallic unity. Formal analysis alone, however, has not met the difficult challenges Mahler puts forth in the Seventh. We enhance our understanding of music considerably when we broaden our inquiry to include cultural, social and political considerations. My critical approach draws extensively on recent critical theories and analytical studies, and it takes into account the social and political milieu of the Seventh. I ground this work socially in order to understand more clearly its unusual structure, both on local and global levels, as a discourse on modernism and the crisis of Austrian liberalism. In the first movement, I argue that Mahler obsessively relies on and, simultaneously, brutally undermines nineteenth-century narrative procedures and organic principles, thereby engaging the myriad contradictions of fin-de-siecle Vienna. I hear Nachtmusik I as a montage constructed of cliches of German Romanticism, modernist concepts of Nietzsche and Freud concerning "Night" and dream states, melancholy reminiscences, sensual musings, and invocations of nature. In the Scherzo, Mahler takes a bitter look at Viennese society and explores the dark underside of its surface gentility through the interaction of the movement's central musical topics. In Nachtmusik II, Mahler speaks both to the expressions of erotic love and Christian self-denial (as found in Eichendorff) and to contemporaneous attitudes towards sexuality. I read the much maligned finale as Mahler's most overt attempt at social criticism, and I show how it provides a fitting close to this symphony, which embodies the contradictory impulses and paradoxes that resulted from the gradual disintegration of Austrian liberal culture and society, and the discontinuities characteristic of modernism.

Title: From Soviet to Mahalla: Community and transition in post-Soviet Uzbekistan
Abstract: This dissertation examines the impact of shifting power relations on the formation of ideology and community in post-Soviet independent Uzbekistan. Drawing on data gathered during 12 months of fieldwork (1994-95) in the city of Kokand, the author demonstrates how the mahalla--a traditional Central Asian form of neighborhood--serves as a useful barometer for gauging social change in a Muslim society. For over seventy years the Soviet state implemented policies aimed at transforming the social relationships and practices which constituted mahalla life in order to control local populations. The establishment of Soviet institutions alternative to those believed to be indigenous to Central Asia provided the ideological framework for monolithic constructions of tradition and modernity to serve a particular set of interests. Since Uzbekistan realized independence in 1991, the mahalla has become the intriguing centerpiece of state-sponsored and local movements invoking the need to restore "traditional," yet "progressive," morality and values to society. Informants' narratives about history and homeland, social networks and inter-ethnic violence, reveal how the mahalla functions as a political forum for negotiating community and ideology. The author argues that individuals' and groups' fights for and over particular traditions and traditional ways of life are not the irrational struggles over practices perceived as primordial, but rather are forms of protest against the State's politicization of tradition, and against the very consciousness that allows traditions to be politicized. The mahalla movement is not just a state-mandated revival of a traditional form of social organization; it also participates in the global proliferation of regionalist movements and transnational communities by resisting yet reproducing on a local level the larger scale programs of nation-states.

Title: In the name of civil society: Contesting free elections in the postcolonial Philippines
Abstract: This dissertation explores a curious anomaly to the "guns, goons and gold" commonly associated with Philippine post-colonial electoral politics: national citizens movements for free elections. Despite the pervasiveness of electoral manipulation, fraud, and violence in the Philippines, such campaigns, the dissertation demonstrates, have only materialized against the backdrop of concerted extra- and anti-electoral mobilizational efforts in the early 1950s, late 1960s and mid-1980s. Examining each of these conjunctures, the dissertation offers a systematic analysis of political crisis and reequilibration in the Philippine Republic between 1946 and 1986. The dissertation also contributes a critical rejoinder to recent scholarship on civil society and democratization by examining how political domination, contestation and class intruded upon the mobilization of national citizens movements for free elections in post-colonial Philippines. To that end, the dissertation focuses on the pre-existing social networks and emerging symbolic representations behind each of these universalist-oriented (counter) mobilizational campaigns "in the name of civil society". Comparing over time the supportive linkages and audiences of each such campaign, the dissertation delineates patterns of dominant class formation and processes of unfolding transnational relations which have contributed to shape the contours of Philippine post-colonial politics and society.

Title: Long-distance merit-making: Art at a Thai Buddhist temple in Wimbledon
Abstract: This ethnography of a Thai Buddhist temple in England explores the sociocultural production of art at the intersection of identity, authority, and value. At Wat Buddhapadipa in Wimbledon, England, in a classical-style ubosot (meeting hall) sponsored by Thai Elites and the royal Thai government, contemporary Thai artists have painted prestigious, yet controversial temple murals. Finished in 1992, the murals depict Buddhist narratives, other-worldly landscapes punctuated with sly references to global politics and popular culture. The artists have rendered their personal visions of “Thainess” ( khwaampenthai ) and Buddhist doctrine for diverse audiences. Observers judge their work as too radical to be painted in Thailand, yet seminal in the “neo-traditional” art movement, revealing conflicting epistemologies of temple painting (murals-as-stories, murals-as-art) and competition for cultural authority. Representing an expanding Thai middle class, the artists position themselves within a social field shaped by Buddhist merit and “Thai tradition,” as they seek status in a world extending beyond national borders. A mural detail poses this visually, as a Thai Airways plane replaces the symbolic boat that carries Dhamma practitioners to Nirvana. This work analyzes the sponsorship of the temple in an expanding economy of merit, trajectories of the artists' lives from Thai villages to London, exported hierarchies of authority, modes of artistic production, and the discursive practices (international and local) which interpret art, define the status of the past, and give value to the present. Based on ethnographic observation, interviews, and formal visual analysis, it fuses the work of the anthropologist and the art historian, viewing Wat Buddhapadipa as both aesthetic creation and as religious construction. These artists reverse an Orientalist narrative of the Asian Other, arriving in London to tell their own stories, and painting a Buddhist world that subsumes Western spaces. Schooled in international art trends, they manipulate categories of the “traditional,” “modern,” “neo-traditional,” “postmodern,” “Asian,” “Western,” “sacred,” and “secular,” collapsing oppositions constructed by scholars. Such categories become active verbs, indices of creative process and strategy. This study tracks globalized ideologies, categories, and institutional practices of “modern art,” as they are received, reworked, and re-interpreted locally, and projected back into an international arena.

Title: Theologies of work in the United States Grail Movement
Abstract: A theology of work asks about the role of work in the faith-filled lives of Christians. The industrial revolution gave this question new urgency by transforming not only the way people worked but also the very conditions of the social order. The Roman Catholic Church interpreted these social changes as loss of faith. By the 1920s, popes were urging the laity to become involved in the church's mission of "restoring all things in Christ." This involvement became "the lay apostolate" or "Catholic Action." Jacques Van Ginneken, a Dutch Jesuit priest, saw Catholic Action's future in women. In 1921 he founded the Society of Women of Nazareth, a predecessor to the Grail Movement. Lydwine van Kersbergen and Joan Overboss brought the Grail to the United States in 1940, where they soon became associated with the National Catholic Rural Life Conference and the Catholic Worker movement. In 1944 the American Grail established their headquarters on a farm in Ohio and began offering a year-long program for young women that set out a practical pattern of integrated Christian living. This dissertation examines the process of U.S. Grail women's theological reflection on work in each of the first five decades of their history. In the 1940s Grail women reflected on the manual and intellectual work of farm life in the context of the lay apostolate. In the 1950s Grail women expanded their reflection to include professional work. By the 1960s, Grail women were examining and revising the structures they had established for their own work. By the 1970s, their context for reflecting on work had become that of participating in building a universal society of justice, love and peace. Education, social analysis and theology became important elements of that work. In the 1980s Grail women studied the economic conditions of women's work in a global context. This dissertation's review of Grail theologies of work reveals a practice of theologizing that relies on the interaction of intelligent theory, committed practice within the larger society and communal reflection. In this way the Grail has functioned as an alternative institution supporting intellectual life in a faith context.

Title: Liberal hypocrisy and totalitarian sincerity: The social and ideological origins of the national nongovernment human rights movement in El Salvador, Pakistan, and Ethiopia
Abstract: Small human rights groups working in repressive countries undertake a daunting task. Facing a violent, often unpredictable government, activists in these groups listen to the victims of state terror and then criticize the state, domestically and internationally, for failing to respect the fundamental rights guaranteed to all human beings in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. State terror is as old as states, whereas "human rights" is an idea that has existed for only a few hundred years. The international agreements and institutions embodying human rights are younger yet: the Universal Declaration will turn fifty next year. Why would activists choose a new idea to confront an old problem? Framed in comparative terms, the question becomes: why do activists in some repressive countries found domestically-focused human rights organizations while activists in other repressive countries do not? By drawing on the history of liberalism and international human rights, sociological literature about the social origins of rights, and analyses of social movements and state terror, this dissertation proposes a general theory of the emergence of national human rights movements. State violence and national liberal traditions are proposed as the causal bases of human rights groups' formation. The analysis begins with a quantitative analysis of 100 countries world-wide. The quantitative work is complemented by three comparative case studies of El Salvador, Pakistan, and Ethiopia, representing high, medium, and low levels of human rights organizing, respectively. The study concludes with considerable evidence that both proposed factors do have significant effects, although the explanation is more complicated than originally proposed. State violence committed openly by agents of the state greatly inhibits the formation of human rights groups, whereas the clandestine use of violence by the state heightens state hypocrisy and can increase human rights groups' effectiveness. The age and strength of constitutional guarantees does explain differing levels of human rights organizing in Latin America, but does not adequately measure the liberal tradition elsewhere. Common law practices from the British colonial experience are a non-constitutional source of tactical space for human rights organizing.

Title: From rags to riches: America's "French Party" and America's Napoleon Bonaparte from 1796 to 1801
Abstract: The purpose of this dissertation is to examine the rise of two movements. These movements succeeded simultaneously in separate places. While there is no direct relationship between these success stories, no compelling arguments that one caused the other, there are shared and compelling issues that directly affected the development of two of the world's greatest nations--America and France. Why did America choose peace and Quasi-War? How "international" was the French Party and did that affect American domestic policies? Was the press used to influence the political and diplomatic affairs? Did Bonaparte's rise affect American views of the French Revolution and French Party support of France? Were French intrigues as significant as British in the development of the American system? America's Republican or "French Party" was far from successful in the late 1790s. They suffered from social, economic, political, and legal persecution by the Federalist majority. It was in 1800, however, that the French Party won the presidency and a majority position in the government. It was during this same period that Bonaparte rose to power in France, making a name for himself in America. A chronological approach is used to examine the rise of both the pro-French party in America and Bonaparte. The primary focus of each chapter is the French Party and Franco-American diplomacy. At the end of each chapter several pages are devoted to Napoleon Bonaparte, as seen by American editors, writers, leaders, and people. Several things make this study unique. The American perspective offers new insights into French government and foreign relations. Magazines and newspapers are examined from both political parties in America. Numerous collections of papers and correspondence are also examined, as well as the Early American Imprints Series, the American State Papers, and the Annals of Congress. Also included are the Correspondance Politique of France and Consular Despatches from France and Europe. Maritime operations are discussed, but only to clarify or explore domestic or international politics. Economic issues are considered vital to the events. The use of the Journal Des Debats of the French Legislature, to show the limited significance of America in French policy and to depict the contemporary French interpretation of Franco-American relations, is also vital. Finally, Napoleon Bonaparte's treatment by the American press and leaders is explored in this work.

Title: Virtual organization and perceived availability: The case of manufacturing assistance providers
Abstract: With the advance of information technologies and mediated channels for communication, new ways of organizing are possible. Despite human need and proclivity for face to face communication, strong ties develop and are maintained (at least in part) through mediated channels tied by bonds of trust and common interests rather than proximity and formal structure, systems based on virtual organization transcend the boundaries of time and space. The process of virtual organization suggests that the apparent dichotomy between proximate and mediated communication should be replaced with a model that remakes the forms communication can take into complementary categories of experience rather than mutually exclusive contexts. Virtual organization is a process of social construction (Gergen, 1985) for a system grounded in shared rules and resources (Giddens, 1981) that creates and maintains the availability of all task-relevant actors and objects in the minds of its members. To understand this process and its outcomes as they relate to perceptions of availability, elements of cognitive and structuration theory are integrated under the perspective of social construction. Cognitive theory addresses how behavior production occurs through memory processes, while structuration theory explains how the categories, norms, and routines used by individuals arise and are reinforced by social interaction. The content of memory at all levels above the most basic is a product of social construction; new memory traces are determined by the structural lens through which social actors perceive the physical world. Structures are the expected patterns of physical sensations that elicit meaning at multiple levels of abstraction. The key structure created by virtual organization is the actor's perception of available others who share the same purposes, as embodied in a transactive memory system (Wegner, 1987). It is this perceived network of available others that makes virtual organization possible for individual actors. This dissertation seeks to answer three questions: What structures are created by virtual organization? How do these structure come into being? What changes does virtual organization bring about in existing structures? These questions are explored through an instrumental case study (Stake, 1995) of manufacturing assistance providers who were recruited by a university project (NEM Online) developing online resources and services to improve the global competitiveness of Michigan manufacturers. Drawing on the author's personal experience as a member of NEM Online, archival documents of NEM Online's development, two network surveys, and interviews with assistance providers, this dissertation describes the world of assistance providers and identifies how they come to perceive certain resources as available. Perceived availability is identified as the mental labels actors have for objects and people, which are cued by the categories people apply to inquiries and reinforced by their movement through an interaction space defined by time schedules instead of territory. The theoretical perspective is found to be sufficient for analysis at the program, relationship and sequence levels of control, but in need of more detailed theory to frame research at more concrete memory levels.

Title: Shades of Red: The Communist Party and Chicago's workers, 1928-1939
Abstract: This dissertation is a social history of American communism within the context of Chicago's neighborhoods, industries and radical traditions. Using local party records, oral histories, union records, party newspapers, and government documents, this dissertation explores the relationship between the international Communist party with its headquarters in Moscow, and the local communist movement rooted in Chicago. Striking new, rich evidence from Moscows former party archive includes minutes of city and local meetings, correspondence between Chicago's functionaries, the New York leadership, and the Comintern, information about local financial matters, testimony from party trials, local newsletters, pamphlets, educational materials, and a great deal of other valuable material. These sources specifically address the functioning of the local party and suggest a more nuanced analysis of American communism. This dissertation argues that while the American Communist party was an international organization strongly influenced by the Soviet Union, at the city level it was a more complex organization riddled with irony and conflict. Thus, while working for a better welfare system, more representative unions, and racial equality in the city, Chicago's communists created a movement that at times worked differently than international party leaders intended. This dissertation challenges those written by an earlier generation of scholars who studied the Communist party from a strictly national and institutional perspective and who emphasized the Comintern's unilateral ability to enforce its teachings through party lines. By focusing on experience of Chicago's communists, who included a large working class, African-American and ethnic population, this study re-examines party members' actions as an integral part of the communities in which they lived and the industries where they worked. This perspective, more grounded in the life of the party activists than national studies have allowed, helps to explain the party's relative strength during the 1930s and suggests reasons for its weaknesses and ultimate disintegration in the 1950s. This study of Chicago's Communist party is an important contribution to our understanding of how ordinary people experienced American communism.

Title: "Movement of Jah people": Race, class, and religion among the Rastafari of Jamaica and New York City
Abstract: From its inception in the early 1930s until the mid 1960s, the Rastafari movement was primarily a Jamaican phenomenon or limited to a fear Anglophone countries in the West Indies. However, in recent decades the movement has managed to transcend its island home and is presently enjoying vibrant growth and a process of worldwide diffusion. Perhaps nowhere has the movement found more fertile soil to lay down roots than in New York City itself. The primary aim of this dissertation is to document and analyze the emergence and transformation of the movement in New York as it undergoes a precarious institutionalization. Employing a transnational framework, I explore the changing movement dynamics and identity constructions of this globalizing religion as it reaches out to and gains new adherents. The contemporary relationship between religion, politics, and social change under conditions of globalization is a complex and contested arena. An entire new field has opened within the social sciences in the past decade attempting to account, not simply for the surprising resilience and survival of religions globally, but for their active role in shaping and impacting public discourse on issues of race and ethnicity, democracy and civil society, public and private morality, among others. My research fits within this genre and contributes to it both by bringing the Rastafarians into the discussion and further investigating the theoretical and practical relationships between oppositional religious discourses, popular culture, and movements for social change.

Title: Transnational bordercrossings: Rethinking borderlands in a globalized world
Abstract: By reconceptualizing the notion of borderlands, this dissertation contributes to the ongoing reorganization of American cultural studies in the context of a new phase of intensified globalization. The worldwide triumph of neo-liberalism after the demise of socialism in Eastern Europe has resulted in the further global synchronization of cultural, social, and economic processes, predicated upon the existence of global markets and the spread of a universal consumer culture. In order to map this new synchronization, the dissertation moves border theory beyond its origins in Chicana/o cultural studies and its current use in American studies where it has become virtually synonymous with transnational analyses. Generalizing from the notion of a hybrid Chicana/o as well as the emergence of a pan-ethnic Latina/o identity, borderlands have been reified as a transnational region across Mexico and the U.S. that belongs exclusively to a particular ethnic or an ethnically-constituted diasporic group. The dissertation rethinks this construction, which undertheorizes the recent militarization of the U.S.-Mexico border, increasing geopolitical inequalities, and Latina/os inter-ethnic and transnational ties to other borderlanders, into a site of what I call people of color "cultural transnationalism." Establishing a comparative cultural studies framework that deploys the emergence of transnational movements of nostalgia in the Second World as occasions to study the emergence of postcolonial nostalgia in the borderlands of the Americas, the dissertation rescues the potential usefulness of certain kinds of cultural nationalisms for transnational analyses. It crosses the institutionalized academic divide that separates the world into geographical areas to show that the anticolonial search for ethnic and national belonging and "neo-socialist" attempts at recovering aspects of now devalued identities and cultures constitute two analogous, alternative forms of resistance against intensified globalization. The similarity of the two localized, transnational movements is based in the fact that the attachment of Second- and Third-World countries to First-World economic supranational organizations, such as the European Union and NAFTA, further formalizes analogous systemic positions of disadvantage by dismantling or subordinating production systems in these countries. Investigating the relationship between cultural internationalisms in the U.S., liberation movements in the Third World, and emerging "postmodern socialisms" in the Second World, this project theorizes mutually beneficial "transnationalisms" in order to enable border crossings across and within the First, Second, and Third Worlds.

Title: The French peace movement, 1821-1919
Abstract: Between 1901 and 1920 four Frenchmen received the Nobel Prize for their services in the cause of peace. These four laureates represented a peace movement whose congresses, publications, and public demonstrations influenced the attitudes guiding such historic initiatives as the Hague Peace Conferences of 1899 and 1907 and the League of Nations. Surprisingly little has been written about the French peace movement during the era leading up to Versailles, although the appearance of publications within the past decade shows that interest in the history of pacifism and peace movements has been rising. This interest is understandable in light of the developments currently reshaping Europe. The attitudes and accomplishments of this group of French pacifists provides a not-too-distant mirror for understanding the roots of many of the institutions of our own complicated era. Like many of those concerned about the volatile state of international affairs today, they attempted to construct a peaceful balance to the demands of particular national and ethnic movements in a world that was becoming increasingly transnational. The peace movement in France played a prominent role in that effort. This dissertation uses the conceptual framework of political culture to examine how some people in France sought to formulate and organize their efforts during the century that stretches from the Congress of Vienna to the Versailles Conference. It addresses how the French peace movement developed in a country faced with extreme political and social instability during that period and how different citizens of that country welcomed, criticized, and ignored those efforts.

Title: Defenders of true France: The nation in French military imagination, 1919-1939
Abstract: Through a study of the internal politics of the French army in the interwar years (1919-1939), this dissertation examines the remaking of French national identity in the twentieth century and the crisis in national self-image as alliances shifted rapidly in Europe, anti-imperialist movements intensified in many French colonies and the structure of French domestic politics changed. Specifically, the study analyzes these crises through the changing political culture of the French Army--charged with protecting France in Europe and maintaining control over the colonies--as its officers discussed the nation and its enemies. Drawing on extensive archival research in France, the dissertation examines the way in which many French military officers of the period engaged with the interwar crisis of national self-image and ultimately created a conservative, anti-republican military culture within the officer corps. Linking this to contemporary issues of the time such as labor movements, the rise of technocracy, and gender relations, the study argues that the French army's dissatisfaction with republican relations of authority is best understood in the manner in which many French officers created an alternative vision of France and French national values, emphasizing anti-parliamentarianism and authoritarianism. These changes in French military culture illuminated the social and political tensions of interwar France. The dissertation contributes to the literature and historiography of European nationalism and provides a concrete example of how ideas of nation and identity work through and are influenced by institutional cultures and practices. It also throws light on the problems that states and organizations face during periods of rapid changes in domestic and international relations.

Title: "Eradicating this evil": Women in the American anti-lynching movement, 1892-1940
Abstract: Between 1892 and 1940, more than three thousand people were lynched in the United States. Most of those lynched were African American males, and most lynchings occurred in the South. Lynching reflected a determination on the part of white southerners to keep African Americans in a state as close to slavery as possible. White supremacy, enforced by lynching, effectively kept black Americans from political, social and economic advancement. To justify mob violence, white southerners claimed that lynching was necessary in order to keep black men from raping white women. They further justified the crime by declaring that courts were too slow in meting out justice, and that the black community shielded criminals from law enforcement authorities. Those theories gained wide acceptance in the South and were commonly accepted in the North as well. In the 1890s, black women began a protest against lynching that eventually swelled into a sizable movement. Ida B. Wells, one of the first anti-lynching advocates, was an outspoken, militant crusader who attacked the theory of white women's protection by proving with statistics that most men who were lynched were never accused of rape, but were hung for a variety of offenses, including trivial offenses that were merely social transgressions at most. Wells systematically formulated a strategy of investigation and exposure to fight against lynching that was eventually adopted by all anti-lynching activists. The founding of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in 1909 drew women of both races into the anti-lynching fight as the association made their campaign against lynching a priority. In the 1920s, the NAACP began a two decade battle for federal anti-lynching legislation, a battle they never succeeded in winning, but that brought the spotlight of public scrutiny to lynching and publicized its horrors. Women were instrumental in the 1930s drives for federal legislation and large women's organizations, such as the YWCA and the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, became committed supporters of a federal law. In the 1930s, a large group of southern white women organized under the leadership of Jessie Daniel Ames to reject the protection that lynching supposedly offered in their name. Organized as the Association of Southern Women for the Prevention of Lynching, the women were opposed to a federal law, but sought to eradicate lynching through education and by engaging the support of local law officials. The decline in lynching by the late 1930s was the result of a combination of social and political factors; but women anti-lynching activists had an undeniable impact on helping bring about the decline of lynching.
