Title: Natalism and nationalism: The political economy of love, labor, and low fertility in central Italy
Abstract: This dissertation examines the cultural politics of family-making in Italy, where women in the 1990s reached record-low fertility rates. Gender, kinship, ethnicity, race and nationalism have become foci of social and individual conflicts in the context of Italian reproductive patterns. This interdisciplinary project, based on 22 months of anthropological fieldwork, explores the effects of this demographic transition on the everyday lives, emotions, memories and family-making practices of women and men in one historic central Italian comune (county) in the Province of Prato. Located in a rural-industrial region of Tuscany, individuals there recount the shift from a peasant agricultural economy based on sharecropping and straw weaving to an urban industrial economy based on rag regeneration and textile production, and link this to the ongoing “crisis” in the patriarchal family. It examines relations between productive and reproductive labor from the mid-nineteenth century to the present, and offers a historical corrective to scholarship on globalization. Integrating methods from sociocultural, linguistic and historical anthropology, this ethnography contributes to the understanding of fertility decline in a way that analyses of aggregate statistics alone cannot: namely, it reveals how ideologies about class and gender create social identities that lead couples to make small families. Influenced by feminist anthropology and political-economic approaches, the project places attention on power relations associated with old and new meanings of domicile labor, social space, marriage, patriarchy as well as parenting; a persistently intense role of motherhood is connected to the “culture of responsibility.” Discourse analysis is used to examine demography narratives, which depict the very low birthrate as “irrational” and as a “problem.” In the context of immigration into Europe, such scientific authority enables elite racism and sneaky pronatalism. Hence, this research participates in the movement of scholars committed to critical population studies and, as such, adds much-needed depth to global debates about changing family dynamics, population politics and women’s status.

Title: The political economy of the reinvented bureaucracy
Abstract: This thesis explores the political economy of bureaucratic change, specifically the reform movement known as the “new public management” (NPM) or, more colorfully, “reinventing government.” This movement has two characteristics that differentiate it from other recent bureaucratic reforms: 1. It is global in scope, at least so far as OECD countries are concerned, and 2. It appears to be independent of political ideology, since both conservative and liberal governments have implemented these reforms. This thesis systematically examines the theoretical foundations and controversies associated with the NPM. It will pay particular attention to the influence of the new economics of organization on the evolution of the NPM. Its main focus will be on a comparative analysis of the determinants of the implementation of this particular reform. Although the NPM is global in scope, for my purposes, fortunately, not every member of the OECD has embraced identically the same set of doctrines, applied them with the same rigor, or achieved the same results. Section I of the thesis examines the controversies within the rational choice paradigm in accounting for bureaucratic choice. The traditional rational-choice view holds that bureaucratic behavior is seldom strategic, except in interactions with nominal principals, and is strictly governed by self-interest. However, Herbert Simon and his students have developed a model of bureaucratic behavior based on the theory of bounded rationality: the so-called organizational process model. This piece explores the organizational process model as applied to budgeting and asks the questions: “What do these two approaches have to say about bureaucratic change and which approach is more consistent with recent events?” Section II explores reinvented bureaucracies utilizing basic methods from new institutional economics. The populations analyzed are the 121 US Department of Defense Reinvention Laboratories. Variables of interest include operations, hierarchical form, and the nesting of culture, norms, and social characteristics both before and after reinvention reforms. Section III examines the environmental factors that affect reinvention efforts within the US Department of Defense Reinvention Laboratories. The primary focus of this paper is on the practical lessons drawn from this experience and highlights the necessary conditions that are required to make substantial and sustainable organizational changes in a military operation. These conditions include factors such as commitment at the top of the organization, a meaningful clear vision, organization wide understanding of the vision, a sense of urgency, performance measures, and institutionalization of continuous improvement among other factors. Without one or more of these factors reinvention will not accomplish its goals in any meaningful way.

Title: Contested nation/Buddhist innovation: Politics, piety, and personhood in Theravada Buddhism in Nepal
Abstract: Beginning in the early decades of the twentieth century, a transnational Buddhist reform movement has been remaking ethnic, religious, and national identity among urban Newar Buddhists in the Kathmandu Valley, Nepal. This dissertation analyzes the relationships between religion and the state at various periods of modern Nepali history, and explores how changing notions of self and society intrinsically embedded in modernist Theravada Buddhism challenge the moral and political authority of the Hindu state with important cultural and political consequences. The study revolves around two intersecting themes: (1) nationalism and the production of cultural identity, and (2) religion and the transformation of moral subjectivity. The first two chapters draw on historical materials to examine the construction of Nepal as a Hindu nation-state, and the rise of Theravada. Buddhism as a semi-articulated strategy of Newar ethnic resistance to this project. Following this, it examines the social, personal and political negotiations that are taking place as individuals move away from the performative, ritual, and collective orientations associated with traditional forms of popular Newar Buddhism and assume the rationalizing, ethical, and individualizing focuses of “pure” Theravada devotees. Rituals, meditation, and the often taken-for-granted routines of caste, class, and gendered daily life are important sites at which subjects are produced and identities performed in Nepal. Theravada Buddhism repositions, its practitioners vis-à-vis Newar society and the Hindu kingdom by transforming their very experiences of body and self. As a whole, this dissertation explores the changing national landscapes and shifting subjectivities—personal, political, cultural and religious—associated with Hindu nationalism and Buddhist reform in order to understand the ways that religion, culture, and power transfigure each other in the formation of new identities and epistemologies. By demonstrating how Theravada Buddhism and the Hindu state have competed to control subjectivities and truths, it reveals the role of religion as a powerful subjectifying—and hence political—force in Nepal.

Title: Law's child: Juvenile court reform and the redefinition of childhood
Abstract: The dissertation presented here is a study of the reform initiative on behalf of children that brought into existence the first statutory juvenile court in the United States, the Cook County Juvenile Court. The Illinois Juvenile Court Act, passed by the Illinois legislature in 1899, served as model legislation for similar statutes in other states, and the Cook County Juvenile Court was the object of international attention for its innovative approach to the problems of children. The context for this study is the reform movement which American historians have called the Progressive Period. The child advocates identified herein saw the juvenile court as one of a wide range of reforms that they hoped would improve the condition of children in modern society. Their description of childhood drew upon the theories of the disciplines of the social sciences which were then being organized within American universities. The paradigm of development in childhood that informed the child study movement as well as the new practices of pediatrics and child psychology provided a convincing argument for the creation of new social practices toward children. This study seeks to identify the description of childhood that was formalized in the juvenile court law. This dissertation goes on to argue that whatever the intentions of the juvenile court reformers might have been, the effect of their effort must be appraised with respect to the legal practice that resulted from the reform. The conclusion of this study rests on a consideration of the legal category of the best interests of children, which came into being with the creation of the juvenile court and is fundamental to the court's practice.

Title: The world elsewhere: United States propaganda and the cultural politics of race and nation, 1945--1968
Abstract: This dissertation focuses on racism, the civil rights movement, and American cultural propaganda in the postwar era. Turning first to work by W. E. B. Du Bois and C. L. R. James, I demonstrate that the problem of the color line was a significant public relations burden for the United States at a time when both the Soviet Union and nations of color (India, China) pointed repeatedly to the failings of the self-appointed leader of the free world. The United States government tried to manage or “spin” the global scandal of American racism by sponsoring performers who would preach the benefits of capitalist democracy overseas. These propaganda ventures were somewhat successful in generating positive images of race relations in the United States, yet they were also, ironically enough, productive of a new kind of black oppositionality. Reading closely performances by Louis Armstrong, James Baldwin, William Faulkner (and his black interlocutors), and the players of a touring production of Porgy and Bess , I argue that African American cultural producers and intellectuals recognized in the government's propaganda program an opportunity to stage their own counterpropaganda theater—a counterpropaganda theater that typically involved exposing the nation to even more international critique. By reminding other nations that the United States somehow could not find a way to enfranchise its black citizens, these intellectuals and cultural producers placed pressure on the government to work for social change. For example, I demonstrate that through the clever use of a well-publicized challenge to the state, Louis Armstrong may have played a role in Eisenhower's intervention during the Little Rock desegregation crisis. Such counterpropaganda performances also played an important role within the African American community at home. The enormous black newspaper and magazine coverage devoted to black counterpropaganda performances by Armstrong and Baldwin suggests that such media-savvy and internationally-oriented performers helped construct the alternative black public sphere that would sustain the black struggle during the 1950s and 1960s.

Title: Cosmopolitan visions and municipal displays: Museums, markets, and the ethnographic project in Germany, 1868--1914
Abstract: This dissertation is a materialist and social history of cultural institutions and their guiding concepts. It is focused on the creation and development of ethnographic museums in Hamburg, Berlin, Leipzig, and Munich, and the ways in which the cultural and social interests and desires of scientists, civic associations, collectors, patrons and visitors, as well as the force of a growing international market in material culture, shaped the science of ethnology and German ethnographic museums. It explores the appeal of ethnology in Germany and seeks to explain why Germans, more than a decade before they began seizing colonial territories, created the world's largest ethnographic museum, and why German scientists such as Adolf Bastian, who isolated themselves from the race debate, energetically spearheaded a world-wide effort to “save” the material traces of humanity. It argues that the inspirations, motivations, and legitimacy for the creation of German ethnographic museums stemmed from a combination of cosmopolitan visions. German cultural scientists drew on the cosmopolitan character of the Humboldtian tradition to fashion their world views, and their ethnological efforts were driven by a strong liberal humanism and a powerful historicist tradition. They created museums to support their search for global explanations about the essential nature of what they regarded as a unitary humanity, and they gained assistance from a range of worldly provincials in these German cities who were enticed by the idea of participating in this international science and sought to use it to enhance and advertise the cosmopolitan character of their cities and themselves. These Germans developed a powerfully future-oriented ethnology, that eschewed evolutionary schemes, and racialist contentions. But once they began to pursue their ethnographic project, it was channeled and shaped by scientists, collectors, boosters, and competitors inside and outside of Germany. The cosmopolitan ideals that initially drove this movement gradually combined with, and were eventually overshadowed by, more modern, professional, and materialist concerns. As a result, between 1868 and 1914, a project that began with attempts to locate the most essential elements of humanity, ironically ended by articulating the fundamental difference between Europeans and peoples in faraway lands.

Title: Praying together: A Chinese Catholic village in the People's Republic
Abstract: The rapid penetration of transnational processes into the People's Republic of China since the opening of China's global frontiers during the post-Mao era has resulted in the re-definition and creation of new social structures and cultural forms for rural communities that re-examine what it means to be local. Based on fieldwork conducted between 1993 and 1997, this dissertation focuses on the re-surfacing of a Catholic Church in a Hakka village in Jiaoling County, Guangdong to ethnographically analyze how transnational processes affect what it means to be part of a global and modern rural community in China. The Hakka are a Chinese diasporic group that have in the past few decades mobilized international campaigns to solidify ethnic solidarity. Catholic villagers in the Hakka homeland, after surviving various campaigns of persecution during the Maoist period, incorporated their village church into the state administrative religious structure while remaining faithful to their Catholic traditions. An examination of life-cycle rituals such as baptisms, weddings and funerals, community-wide events such as the building of a new church and a celebration of Christmas, and other daily activities in village life illustrates how a multiplicity of national and transnational processes—the privatization of local sectors of the socialist economy, the global movement of people as workers, students, and tourists, the rapid modernization of Chinese production and consumption, and the participation in a world religious tradition—coalesce into a social narrative that creates locality. Catholicism has simultaneously defined deterritorialized local community boundaries while connecting people to the global world.

Title: The erosion of free trade: Political culture and political economy in Great Britain, c. 1897-1932
Abstract: This study explores the erosion of Free Trade as a central part of British political culture in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Instead of treating Free Trade as an issue of party politics or expression of economic interests, the thesis examines its changing significance as a popular vision of society, politics, and economy. It makes a methodological contribution to the understanding of the importance of ideas, values, and collective representations in shaping political economy. The popular movement against Tariff Reform in the Edwardian period was driven by a cultural momentum that restated the centrality of freedom of trade to “civilisation”, “political purity”, social emancipation, and international peace. Narratives of food and hunger created a historical vision of consumption and civil society, in which Free Trade and the autonomy of society became a single achievement. Far from being a manifestation of free market capitalism, Free Trade spoke a language of social trust, “good” consumption, and active citizenship. Its anxieties about commercialisation and group interests and its assumptions about nation and gender set limits on its vision of social emancipation and political inclusion. The debate within the business community, the left, and internationalists during and after the First World War reveals the declining significance of Free Trade in three communities of argument: about modernization, social democracy, and international relations. Businessmen turned towards ideals of combination, co-ordination, and productivism. To Labour and co-operatives, social welfare came to depend on trade regulation and linkages between state and civil society, not cheapness and free imports. And a “new internationalism” rediscovered the political and looked towards international institutions, rather than commerce, to promote social democracy and international peace. The final introduction of a general tariff in 1932 marked the culmination of a larger reconfiguration of political economy in which Free Trade as a secular religion was displaced by a new vision of regulation, productivism, and institutional bridges between state and civil society.

Title: A stranger in the house: American ambivalence about immigrant labor
Abstract: This dissertation explores the apparent contradiction underlying the contemporary politics of immigrant labor in Southern California. On one hand, there is continuing and even growing demand for immigrant workers to fill low-skilled jobs. Since the mid-1980s, much of the growth in demand has been for workers to provide services for private households in the suburbs. On the other hand, the past decade has also witnessed an active anti-immigrant movement—manifested in both popular practice and policy—the origins of which have also been in the suburbs. These trends suggest hypocrisy or at least a profound cultural ambivalence about immigrant labor. They have most often been explained in terms of competing economic interests; instead, this study examines some of their social logics. Based on a multi-site ethnography in Orange County, California focusing on Latina immigrant women working in household service, I suggest that the demand for immigrant labor and the ‘fortressing’ against immigrants are related phenomena. I argue that they reflect a negotiation of citizenship, and particularly the problem of who must do subordinated work in a democratic society. Importing immigrant labor to do the jobs which are undervalued or considered ‘dirtywork’ helps solve the problem, but only insofar as these workers are understood to be consummate outsiders and social or legal inferiors. The materials from my field sites illustrate that: (1) the market for Latina immigrants as household workers rested strongly upon perceptions of their suitability for the subordinated role of a traditional woman in the household; and (2) many of the anti-immigrant practices occurring in Orange County suburbs functioned not to eliminate the immigrant presence, but rather to maintain social hierarchies and distinctions between “citizens” and “aliens.” In this way, these anti-immigrant practices served to reproduce the cultural and legal construction of foreign workers as ‘appropriate’ for subordinated work and therefore perpetuated the social logic of an economy dependent upon immigrant labor. More generally, the dynamics this study identifies in Orange County illustrate the complexities of membership in an economy undergirded by a transnational labor force, and how social and political geographies are shifting on a local level.

Title: Dams, democracy and *development: Transnational struggles for power and water
Abstract: By the 1950s, big dams had become the leading technology for water resources development in the world. Today, opposition erupts against virtually every big darn project proposed or under construction. And since the 1970s—despite being promoted by a range of transnationally allied, powerful interests including politicians and bureaucrats, landed elites and industrialists, multinational corporations and intergovernmental organizations—the global completion rate of big dams has fallen dramatically. Although technical, financial and economic factors primarily caused this shift in the first world, a major explanation for the unexpectedly rapid decline in big dam building the third world has been the rise of transnationally allied opposition to these projects. In the past, domestic opposition to big dams failed to independently make a significant impact in developing countries. But since the 1970s, transnational coalitions and networks of environmental, human rights, and indigenous peoples' nongovemmental organizations linked with historically marginalized but progressively empowered local groups and grassroots movements have emerged to vigorously contest these projects. The increasing success of these transnational coalitions and networks “from below” against the far more powerful proponents of big dams over time has been conditioned by the progressive global spread and international institutionalization of norms regarding indigenous peoples, human rights and environmental conservation. But the impact of struggles around dams has not been uniform across space. Such campaigns have been more effective in democratic regimes because of the greater opportunities to gain access to and leverage state institutions offered in these political systems. Cross-national variation in the likelihood of success has also depended on the degree and organization of domestic social mobilization against big dams. This theoretical argument is evaluated through a combined cross-temporal and crosssectional empirical analysis based on original fieldwork. The cross-temporal comparisons involve within ‘case’ process-tracing of the historical trajectories of big dam building dynamics in India, Brazil, Indonesia, South Africa/Lesotho and China. The cross-sectional analysis involves comparison of big dam projects and conflicts across these countries as well as at the international level with respect to policies and practices of the international aid agencies, transnational professional organizations, and multinational corporations.

Title: The year of the angry young men: Performing gender at championship tap dance events
Abstract: The patterned sounds and movements of American tap dancers resonate with values embedded in their culture. Although predominantly rooted in West African music and dance traditions, tap dance is intimately linked to the rhythmic exchanges occurring within the last three centuries between individuals of various social groups as they gather on the streets and stages of America. Tap dance is commonly associated with men and masculinity despite the enduring involvement of women in tap communities world-wide. Certain qualities of movement emphasize the value placed on differentiated gender roles in America. This study examines how gender is performed and valued in one of many contemporary arenas of the tap dance community, championship tap dance events. The ethnographic work I conducted as a former event competitor and current independent professional tap dance soloist focused on five American soloists competing for both the 1998 national and international tap champion titles. Through observations, interviews and movement analyses, the performativity of gender was perceived in the words and movements of event participants. The spectacular performances also deepened the value of gender as set apart from everyday activities. This research revealed that in dance, notions of femininity and masculinity are constantly encountered and performed in tap dance movements during championship tap dance events. The asymmetrical value afforded to tap dances performed by males to that afforded females was observed at both events attended. The division of gender roles blended as soloists combined masculine and feminine identified movements. In these androgynous instances, tap dance performances potentially shift what it means to be woman, man, and tap dancer. The future division of soloists into separate titles for women and men in these championship events leads to further questions concerning the ways performances both resist and conform to gender roles institutionalized by the events and widely sustained in American culture.

Title: Politics, culture, and nostalgia: The fight over the American past, 1969–1999
Abstract: This dissertation examines the debate over the American past that has pervaded recent popular culture and national politics. In the 1970s, nostalgia pervaded popular culture; since Ronald Reagan's election to the presidency in 1980, various political figures and movements have drawn upon this nostalgia to generate usable narratives of post-1945 national life. They have relied upon representations of the country's cultural and political past to provide historically-rooted justifications for their own present-day politics. In contemporary America, popular culture and political discourse have become complexly interlaced—working together to shape collective understandings of the national experience. The marshaling of themes and symbols from the repository of popular culture has emerged as a primary way for political agents to shape public memories according to their own needs. This emergence complements a more traditional use of explicitly political iconography in the fashioning of the American past. A key factor in the shaping of public memories has been the debate about the significance of the 1950s and 1960s to contemporary political and social life. The 1950s and 1960s have had such a powerful hold on the public imagination because they are so easily viewed in strongly dichotomous ways. The 1950s are depicted on the one hand as an era of American global dominance, personal security, and economic prosperity, and on the other as a time of stultifying social convention and racism. The 1960s, conversely, are depicted by critics as a time marked by social unrest and chaos, the trauma of Vietnam, and the failure of Great Society programs, and by their defenders as a time of energetic idealism, personal liberation, and vibrant popular culture. The decades, iconic power is strengthened by their concurrence with the youth of the Baby Boom generation, and with the emergences and ascendancies of television and rock and roll. My method of analysis combines theories of hegemony and discourse. I analyze film, television, popular music, and political and public affairs communications, including media accounts of presidential elections and administrations, scholarly monographs, and popular histories.

Title: Women's leadership roles in the Student Christian Movement and the rise of the new woman, 1880-1920
Abstract: At first glance, two components of late Victorian, Anglo-American society stand in stark contrast to each other: the image of the New Woman, and the women leaders of the Student Christian Movement (SCM). Popularized in the press, drama, and periodicals and reflected in the lives of real women, the New Woman appeared to revolt against the dominant social order by her independence, college-education, athleticism, cigar-smoking, disdain for marriage and irreligious or anti-religious attitudes. The SCM's women leaders, in theory, epitomized mainstream society. These women were connected with major Christian bodies and centers of political and social power. They helped direct the first international, interdenominational society for Christian students. By World War I, their mainstream organization was the largest student organization in the world. Out of their movement sprang some of the twentieth century's most influential Christian movements. The special claim of this dissertation is that the image of the New Woman and the SCM's women leaders are not opposites, but in fact, have many common traits. I will demonstrate that the most significant connection between the two is that the SCM's women leaders were, in effect, New Women. Because this study recognizes the importance of cultural contextualization and the reciprocity between the environment and specific individuals, chapter one surveys the development and features of these two facets in the context of late Victorian life. Chapters two through four explores the various leadership roles assumed by SCM women with special reference to mixed or men-only groups. Using the data from chapters one through four, chapter five discusses the connections between the New Woman and the SCM's women leaders. Chapter six, the conclusion, adds non-white, non-Anglo-Saxon, fashionably dressed, social feminist and religious images to the established version of the New Woman. It expands what is known about SCM women leaders by providing information on their background, education, and approaches to marriage and career. Inherent in this project is the proposal that religion and feminism have connections that have not been explored, but which can contribute to understanding turn-of-the-century Protestantism and the women's movement.

Title: NGOs, agenda-setting and the UN: Violence against women and reproductive rights and health
Abstract: Over the course of the past decade international women's organizations have been successful in placing women's issues on the agenda of the United Nations. While their achievements have led to the establishment of international programs and institutions and enabled women's groups at the domestic level to hold their governments accountable, they pose a puzzle for students of international relations. International women's organizations are among the weakest international actors; they possess few if any material resources. How, why, and under what conditions were these organizations able to define and shape the agenda of much more powerful states? Drawing from various elements of the social movement and agenda-setting literature, this dissertation posits that international women's organizations influenced the UN agenda through the intersubjective construction of frames of meaning thereby making strategic use of changes in the political opportunity structure in which these organizations were embedded and the mobilizing structures they had at their disposal. To illustrate the usefulness of these elements for the study of international relations, the dissertation contrasts the case of violence against women with that of reproductive rights and health employing data obtained from three different sources—interviews with representatives of international women's organizations and UN officials, participant observation and UN documents and publications of international women's organizations. The study is significant in several respects: First, it contributes to the literature on non-governmental organizations offering a better understanding of the ways in which they exert influence. Second, it traces the political processes through which ideas become interests about which thus far relatively little is known. Finally, it adds to the small but growing literature on women and international relations detailing empirically how existing international power structures can empower or constrain women.

Title: Jane Farwell: Adult educator and social recreation leadership trainer
Abstract: This dissertation is a historiography of the lifework of Jane Farwell, formerly of Dodgeville, Wisconsin, noted adult educator through her work in social recreation leadership training. Jane Farwell was an adult educator through her work in, and contribution to, the field of social recreation over a 55-year span through her social recreation leadership and folk dance instruction workshops conducted throughout the United States and twelve other nations. Farwell successfully used the rural roots of her childhood for social recreation leadership training in urban settings. Among Jane Farwell's lasting contributions to the fields of social recreation and folk dance: trained, inspired and influenced thousands of adult recreation leaders across the nation, teaching leadership skills and recreation practices that have continued to teach through second and third generations; founded Oglebay Folk Dance Camp in 1941, Mount Horeb Christmas Festival in 1948 and Maine Folk Dance Camp in 1949; inspired Recreation Laboratories in a dozen states; founded Folklore Village, a rural folk center near Dodgeville, Wisconsin. She promoted folk dance and play party games as vehicles for personal and group development and advocated for the place of dance in the schools. Farwell was part of a small group of folk dance pioneers responsible for preserving, and popularizing, authentic international folk music and dance, beginning in the 1930's. The interlock between Farwell and the context of location and life circumstances gives definitive insight into Farwell and her work. Of importance is Farwell's rural childhood and family, Antioch College, the history and defining of social recreation, folk high schools, recreation laboratories, folk dance, the settlement of southwest Wisconsin. Prior to this work, little was known about influences on Farwell's personal and professional development that led her to a career in social recreation and folk dance. While at Antioch College, Yellow Springs, Ohio, Farwell did work study in settlement houses in Cleveland and New York City where she met social work and recreation professionals, who used folk dance as part of social recreation programs in settlement houses. At Antioch, she also became acquainted with folk high schools and their use of social recreation to develop socialization and citizenship skills. Farwell began developing her own social recreation leadership style. This study: (1) documents her work and method of work, providing a base for further research in social recreation, folk dance and adult education; (2) looks at Farwell's method of social recreation leadership training and how that style and Farwell herself influenced others; (3) looks at Farwell's contributions to the fields of social recreation and education; (4) places Farwell's work in the context of the history of the social recreation and folk dance movement in the United States during this century and the contribution social recreation and folk dance makes to the field of adult education and the American culture. Much of the information about social recreation is scattered and without coherent definition: This study deepens and broadens the definition and understanding of social recreation, based upon the work of John Dewey, Charles Cooley, Neva Boyd and Grace Coyle. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: Making China part of the globe: The impact of America's Boxer Indemnity remissions on China's academic institutional building in the 1920s
Abstract: This dissertation examines modern China's movement to study abroad, marked by the inception of the Boxer Indemnity education program in 1909 with funding from America's first indemnity remission, and the impact of the movement on China's academic institutional building in the 1920s. From the perspective of a global movement of ideas and knowledge, in which individual Chinese who took part in this movement proved themselves to be active, engaging players, rather than passive imitators or followers of Western ideas, the author attempts to explore how, and to what degree, Western education affected Chinese students' perceptions of themselves and the outside world, and how such changing perceptions affected the development of modern China's academic institutional building in the 1920s. The author contends that the direct and extensive government involvement of the Boxer Indemnity education program created much space, in which the mutual benefits of this program were romanticized and materialized through the imaginations by people at different levels of society. The imaginations and expectations not only affected the academic performance and life experiences of a large number of Chinese students in America, especially those sponsored by the indemnity funds, but also proved to have strong repercussions in the 1920s, when Western-educated Chinese students began to return home continuously in large numbers and formed a rather special cohort in Chinese society. Parallel to the social repercussions, the 1920s also witnessed Qinghua's transformation from a preparatory school into a national university and the creation of the China Foundation for the Promotion of Education and Culture. Both events, the author argues, best illustrate the immediate outcome of Western education and represent the beginning of the continuous and conscious efforts of a new and confident generation of Western-educated Chinese to integrate China into the world academic and science community. Because of the political and economic disparity between China and the United States and the powerful Chinese nationalistic sentiment in the 1920s, the process of such efforts was marked by constant conflict within Chinese society, involving at once absorption, integration, cooperation, and resistance.

Title: Struggle for national survival: Chinese eugenics in a transnational context, 1896-1945
Abstract: My dissertation is a historical investigation of the relationship between science and society through the comparative study of eugenics movements as they developed in both Japan and China from the 1890's to the 1940's. Overall, I envision this project of eugenics as a specific case study against a greater background of the transmission of Western science. The dissertation is organized into an introduction, five chapters, and an epilogue, The introduction lays out the theoretical terrain and outlines the historical landscape from which eugenics came forth as a subject of interest. The second chapter delineates the emergence of “science” as a set of distinct disciplinary subjects, out of the holistic category of Western Learning (J. yôgaku and C. xixue ) contributed by the Jesuits and premodern Eastern intellectuals. Subsequently, this chapter examines how modern scientific terminology was coined and refashioned within the interlocked linguistic context of Japan and China, and the parallel process that the eugenics ideas were going through in this context. After the initial stage of mere introduction of ideas into East Asia, the third chapter accounts for the process of eugenics being received as a branch of “science,” and for its transformation locally, by considering the Galtonian biometric strategy as a route toward scientific justification. With the progress of eugenics and its transformation into a form of public knowledge and a social movement in both countries, the fourth chapter examines their multi-layered social debates on, and politics of, heredity versus social influence on the body. As part of the social development of eugenics, the birth control movement was embraced by the feminists and socialists, but it soon ran up against the hard-line eugenics agenda. Focusing on the eugenicist perception of morality as inherent in sexuality, the fifth chapter analyzes the scientific basis assumed for the gendered assignment of biological function and the intriguing positions of women scientists. The sixth chapter studies the second Sino-Japanese War (1937–1945) which was perceived by both Japanese and Chinese eugenicists as a war of population. It deals with the eugenicists' representations and the scientists' efforts to forge a cohesive self-identity and national identity in the mobilization campaigns of both governments. It also analyzes the eugenicists' involvement in the State's implementation of population policy and eugenics bills, which were the embodiments of their conception of ethnic nation and racial body. The epilogue brings together prewar and wartime issues of eugenics in a discussion of the revision of the eugenics bill in Japan and the reinstatement of the eugenics bill in the People's Republic of China in the postwar era. Throughout the thesis, I develop an understanding of “comparativism” as a methodological approach to simultaneity which encompasses plural nonsynchronic consciousnesses and temporalities, in addition to the conventional use of comparativism as juxtaposition to locate parallels of similarity and difference. I also develop a framework of “transnational science” as a more flexible concept to incorporate both local science and colonial science, and other possible forms of international cooperation, competition and circulation of the sciences and technologies. By analyzing the understudied subject of eugenics movements in Japan and China, this study contributes to our understanding of how science in its global transmission was transformed and grew in its local habitats.

Title: The race question: Racial hierarchy and the *state in post-Revolutionary Cuba
Abstract: My dissertation asks the question: why does racial hierarchy persist in modern societies? Social theory has generally contended that racial and ethnic divisions would disappear as societies moved into modernity. However, in many cases quite the opposite has occurred. An important opportunity to examine this puzzle is the case of Post-Revolutionary Cuba. The dissertation explores the case of Post-Revolutionary Cuba where despite a sweeping revolution and efforts to end discrimination and redistribute resources, patterns of racial hierarchy have remained. None of the available theories of racial politics in Cuba account for the movement toward racial equality brought on by the revolution and the ensuing stagnation and recent retreat in that process. I contend that racial formation and the persistence of racial hierarchy also require a better understanding of ideology, the state, and the impact of transnational forces. Both Liberalism and Marxism have been relatively silently on race; leaving the problem of racial hierarchy unanswered or reducible to class and market forces. This is aided by formulations of a national identity in the Cuba context that marginalizes Afro-Cubans at the expense of a unified Cuban identity. States have competing interests when it comes to race and often have a lot at stake. Race is a primary means through which citizens define the state and the state defines itself. In Cuba, the state's interests have been in promoting the ideal of racial equality at home and abroad without creating an ongoing dialogue and critique of the regime's record on the issue. It is these competing interests that contribute to the persistence of racial hierarchy in Castro's Cuba. Finally, I argue that theoretically social scientists have also wrongly used the nation state as the boundary for an analysis of race and politics. The case of Cuba demonstrates that perceptions of racial politics on the ground are, often inherently comparative. In this case negative perceptions about racial politics in the US and South Florida tempers Afro-Cuban responses to problems at home, constrained racial politics on the island, but at the same time pushed Cuba in bold new directions on the international front.

Title: Progressives for peace and social justice: The Minnesota Branch of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, 1921-1941
Abstract: On October 24, 1922, nine women officially organized the Minnesota Branch of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom (the Minnesota WIL). Hundreds of other women quickly joined the peace cause in Minnesota. Together they created one of the largest and most active WIL branches of the 1920s and 1930s. They were a key component and significant grassroots expression of the international women's peace movement in the years between the world wars. Members of the Minnesota WIL retained a Progressive approach to social change throughout the 1920s and 1930s, relying on study, education, publicity, and lobbying. This approach also exemplified women's “voluntary” style of politics of the pre-suffrage era. But Minnesota WIL members moved out of a separate women's political subculture, partly of their own volition, and partly because that subculture crumbled after the 1920 suffrage victory. At the same time, the group embraced new issues and allies. In the 1930s, the Minnesota WIL constructed, along with its allies in the labor movement, political parties, the African American community and eventually the Communist party, a dynamic left in the state. In the process, the Minnesota WIL broadened its definition of peace to encompass political and economic equality for all. Thus, by the 1930s the Minnesota WIL was combining a Progressive approach to social change with a left-wing concern for justice and equality. Uniting a Progressive approach with left-wing concerns was not easy, however. Some Minnesota WIL members were uncomfortable with the group's interracial work or its support for organized labor. Others objected vociferously to working with Communists in the anti-fascist Popular Front of the mid-1930s. Electoral politics, too, threatened to disrupt the Minnesota WIL's work, exacerbating divisions among group members. The WIL's “unity within diversity” policy, which recognized and even celebrated disagreement and conflict among members while promoting consensus style decision-making, enabled the Minnesota WIL to withstand these divisions. Ultimately, however, the war in Europe brought the WIL's commitment to nonviolence into conflict with its social justice work. For many members, neither “unity within diversity” nor a Progressive approach to social change were adequate answers to fascist aggression.

Title: International contributions to the mobilization of ethnic conflict: Sri Lanka, Iraq, and Rwanda
Abstract: The involvement of the international community in internal situations of ethnic conflict is becoming more common as international actors intervene to restore order after the outbreak of violent ethnic conflict. This dissertation addresses the assumption that these multilateral fig leaves will provide a “Band-Aid” and assist in ethnic conflict resolution because in many situations this has not been the case. Three examples of the failure of intervention in identity-based contention are found in Iraq, Rwanda, and Sri Lanka. The dissertation explores the historical context and content of international actor involvement (specifically outside states, international organizations, and transnational kin-groups) in countries experiencing ethnic conflicts prior to the outbreak of violence. The project presents a substantive cross-national comparative analysis of foreign interference from colonialism to the contemporary political environment in three current conflicts: India and the Tamils in Sri Lanka (1987), the United States and the Kurds in Iraq (1991) and the international communities involvement with the Hutus in Rwanda (1994). The dissertation presents a framework for examining what international actors bring to identity-based contention. In each case, a mobilization model is employed to illustrate how international actors contributed to the explosiveness of these ethnic situations as they advanced the factors of mobilization (the politicization of ethnic identity, resources, and political opportunity structures). The model synthesizes ethnic conflict studies with work on resource mobilization and international intervention. The dissertation offers both theoretical and practical contributions to research on international political interactions, comparative ethnic studies as well as work on transnational social movements. The project also explores changing norms of international intervention, the nature of ethnic identity, and the policy consequences of meddling in unstable contentious political environments. The study finds that there are several problems associated with international intervention in ethnic conflicts as foreign actors are often pulled into local and regional political struggles.

Title: Revolution or revelation: A Gramscian approach to the rise of political Islam in Palestine
Abstract: The phenomenon of ‘Political Islam’ has increased in both scope and importance over the past two decades. Beginning with the revolution in Iran, its impact in the Middle East and the international theatre have made it potentially the most destabilizing development in the region. It is because of these circumstances that the phenomenon of political Islam, while eliciting a very strong response in a number of Western capitals, remains, for the most part, greatly misunderstood, as the West continues to assume a uniformly aggressive stance against all these movements, regardless of their professed aims. This dissertation has sought to deconstruct some of the myths and biases that surround the expansion of political Islam. In examining this phenomenon through a Gramscian framework, the aim is to present primarily indigineous movements specific to a certain region through Western concepts and terminology, and in the process, make it more easily understandable to Western audiences. Thus, the alien nature and discourse of the Islamist movements should not confuse the fact that these movements, are most specially political movements, which originated in response to a universal phenomenon of modernization epitomized by relative material disadvantage and a closed political system. This study first conceptualizes the phenomenon of political Islam in both its theoretical (political doctrine) and practical (bases of social support) forms. After presenting the specifics of the Gramscian theoretical framework, the theory is then applied to both Muhammad and the current case of Palestine (e.g., Hamas and the Muslim Brotherhood) to demonstrate the underlying link within political Islam from the time of jahiliyyah to the present. In this sense, the conclusion reached is that a Gramscian framework provides a distinct interpretation of a complicated phenomenon and is a more appropriate method through which to examine political Islam.

Title: The I.C.W.: A study in non-formal adult education
Abstract: The following study of the International Council of Women (ICW) examines its educational agenda during the inter-war years. It uses as the main body of evidence, the monthly organ, the Bulletin , which illustrates a concerted consciousness-raising effort to urge the translation of feminist knowledge and organizational skills into forms of practical politics. Several questions related to non-formal adult education for women frame the discussion—how the ICW disseminated its programs for the purposes of educating women in the processes which would lead to participatory democracy and how such programs were gender specific being among them. To illustrate the inquiry one aspect of the social and moral reform movement during this time period has been analyzed—the Traffic in Women and Children—which had its historical antecedents in the social purity movement and the campaigns for an equal moral standard of the nineteenth-century. These issues are examined as discourse, and as implementation at the level of the national councils and on the international stage at the League of Nations. Several historical constructs had heuristic value in understanding the distinctions and inter-dependence of printed materials as both education and propaganda as well as interpreting the phenomenon being analyzed. These include arguments about the practices and restrictions of social feminism when political and reform roles were circumscribed by this limited view of women's activism, the inter-section of the private and public spheres for female social action during the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, and the triumph of a transnationalist perspective (“mothering”) in a male constructed and male dominated international forum. While dramatic world events frustrated such efforts nonetheless a growing international movement of women's organisations and their consolidation of female non-formal education to which the ICW contributed substantially, laid the foundations for the emergence of the second wave feminist movement generally, and, in the structures that participated in the post-war, the United Nations specifically.

Title: Pacifist feminism in Britain, 1870–1902: “The truest form of patriotism”
Abstract: This thesis examines the relationship between the women's movement and the peace movement in the period 1870 to 1902, and argues that specifically pacifist strands of feminism emerged by the 1890s. Within these, analyses of the effects of military force were combined with feminist understandings of women's oppression. Ideas evolved which encompassed both the claim that women had the right to define their own place in society, and the desire to renounce war and establish alternative models of conflict resolution. As a result, although both terms are applied here anachronistically, specifically 'pacifist feminist' standpoints can be identified, which denote a politics where the two modes of analysis are applied together to an understanding of the social and political order. Four clear strands of pacifism are identified within the women's movement: free trade radicalism; evangelical feminism; conservative internationalism; and international citizenship. Many of the feminists who developed these ideas also recast popular notions of patriotism, using arguments rooted in ideas of sexual difference, to apply conceptions of women's moral superiority to the national stage. They argued that patriotism could mean upholding what was morally or ethically right for the nation, rather than demonstrating unswerving loyalty to it. The Anglo-Boer war of 1899 to 1902 is discussed in relation to a range of pacifist and feminist movements to show that some women pacifists envisioned alternative constructions of imperialism which were based on ideas of progress and cooperation rather than domination.

Title: Flag on the field: The popular construction of the Black athlete
Abstract: At its broadest level, this is a study of racial and national identity formation in the twentieth century United States. Specifically, it cultivates the “black athlete” as a contested ideological site within popular culture, shaping crucial intersections with political issues of black collectivity and consciousness, and cultural collisions among notions of race, nation, and gender. It begins by demonstrating the advent of an expert scientific dialogue in the 1930s regarding race and physical ability, which promoted a series of rationalized social theories of racial difference that were inserted into mass mediated discussions of sport, and generated expansive speculation about the “nature” of the black athlete. This examination makes clear how race, despite its eminent “social construction,” continues to be discerned in counterfeit biological terms. Given the centrality of sport to popular constructions of the nation, such unreconstructed sentiments of racial difference have remained tenaciously pivotal in contemporary American culture. The dissertation then shifts to how such popular (mis)understandings of the black athlete have been contested by African Americans, particularly the Olympic Project for Human Rights (OPHR). This organization produced a collective politicized movement of black athletes by the late 1960s, culminating in the black power protest at the Mexico City Olympics in 1968. It served as a moment of resistance and confrontation with dominant forms of racial identity as it negotiated with hegemonic concepts of national identity and subjectivity. In addition, it was intimately connected to a broader international forum of racialized politics, particularly the issues surrounding independent African nations and South African apartheid and the student movements in Mexico City, developing a critical relationship between the black athlete in the United States and a global discourse of human rights. The concluding segment of the dissertation examines the contemporary commodification of black athletes within media industries, and how the struggles for equality so crucial in the 1960s have receded into an expanding disjuncture between African American prosperity and poverty. The black athlete mediates this post-civil rights context, creating a bifurcated image that oscillates between black criminal youth and black upward mobility, consolidating scientific and social implications.

Title: Adios Jim Crow: Afro -North American workers and the Guatemalan Railroad Workers' League, 1884–1921
Abstract: Adios Jim Crow: Afro-North American Workers and the Guatemalan Railroad Workers' League 1884–1921 examines Afro-North American labor migration to Guatemala from its origins in the 1880s. It describes the demography and Politics of Afro-North American migrant laborers and contextualizes the evolution of the Guatemalan railroad labor movement. During the period 1884–1921, Guatemala presents an excellent context in which to study the foundational years of voluntary global labor migration. Consequently, one can assess the present-day rhetoric of corporate and labor groups over the socioeconomic virtues and vices of multinational investment and commerce. Moreover, the study's focus on the place of Atlantic workers in the turn of the century international political economy contributes to efforts to close knowledge gaps in cultural studies scholarship, as well as U.S. and Latin American labor history. During their foundational years (1880s–1930s), foreign multinational corporations operating in the Atlantic lowlands of Central America and Mexico began concerted race based samplings for the most appropriate workers. Afro-North American workers represented but a portion of the large number of people from around the world that labor contractors imported to the region. Part of the history of this lowland labor odyssey was the weekly arrival of between seventy to eighty Afro-North American workers to Puerto Barrios, Guatemala on steamships from New Orleans. This scarcely known period of Afro-North American migration to Guatemala lasted from the 1880s to the world economic depression of the 1930s. This study also examines the history of Afro-North American populated railroad communities within Guatemala. Theoretically, the study will show that, like other contemporary working class groups, Afro-North Americans who migrated to and within Latin America did so as a source of working class resistance and social advancement. Sources from U.S. and Guatemalan archives show that the composite images and personal histories of Afro-North American migrants in Guatemala varied significantly according to the local conditions that restricted their social mobility. These conditions included labor and production demands, individual and collective attributes, and the actions of employers and state officials. The methodology of the study consists of an examination of a wide range of sources including U.S. and Guatemalan government records, private collections, periodicals, and travel accounts.

Title: Den alternativa staden: Stockholms stadsomvandling och byalagsrörelsen
Abstract: The purpose of the dissertation is to examine the so called “'byalags”-movement in Stockholm, a protest movement against the rationalistic rebuilding of the city that took place in the period 1968–1980. As a background the rationalistic and humanistic traditions in Swedish town-planning are described. Different aspects of the rebuilding of the city of Stockholm in 1930–1980 are discussed, including politics and early criticism. The “byalags”-movement has been investigated with the help of 60 interviews as well as contemporary written sources. The movement had all the typical features of a so called new social movement: a network structure of groups without formal connections, no appointed leaders, no membership and participatory democracy as a main principle for all activities. Ideologically, the movement had its roots in the New Left, but in concentrating only upon issues concerning the neighbourhood, the movement succeeded in assembling participants of all ages, with different political opinions and different social backgrounds. The leading activists, however, consisted of young people with leftist views. A striking feature of the movement was the lack of stability. An economic recession in the Stockholm region in the early seventies, together with the extensive protests from the movement, resulted in that most controversial city-planning projects were abandoned. The motivation of the neighbourhood groups weakened after that, and nearly all the groups disappeared within a few years. The empirical results are analysed and compared with international research on social movements. The dissertation also contains photos and other illustrations of the movements activities and the rebuilding of Stockholm in the described period.

Title: A Study of the Transition from Authoritarianism to Democracy in South Korea
Abstract: South Korea has successfully launched the political transition from authoritarianism to democracy since l987 after it achieved rapid economic growth and social structural transformation during the l960-70s. This dissertation aims at the systematic analysis of the dynamics, process, characteristics and prospects of the democratic transition in South Korea. It is divided into six chapters. Chapter one: The theory of political transition. To form the framework of analysis for the study of Korean democratic transition, the author reviewed and reevaluated the two schools in comparative studies of the transition from authoritarianism to democracy, the civil society theory and the strategic choice theory, and pointed out their advantages and disadvantages. It is argued that the civil society theory advocates focuses on the macro-analysis of the social and economic background for the democratic transition; and the strategic choice theory advocates focus on the micro-analysis of the motivation and behaviors of the political elite who engaged in the democratic transition. Only by the combining both the civil society theory and the strategic choice theory approaches can the logic of the democratic transition is adequately revealed, and the dynamics and process of the transition fully understood. Chapter two: The context of Korean political development. Many of the factors, which exert influence on contemporary Korean politics, are considered. (1) The historical background, including the Yi dynasty, Japanese colonial rule and the failed "democratic experiments" of the l950s. (2) The constitutional structure, including the constitutional changes from the First to the Six Republics and the characteristic features of the existing constitution. (3) The economic context, including the Korean government-directed development model and its influences on the political development. (4) The cultural background, including the characteristics of the traditional Korean Confucianism, the conflict between traditional and modern political cultures, and between Oriental and Occidental political values in contemporary Korea. (5) The geographical environment, including the relations between the geographical environment and political development, the importance of population change and regional cleavage in Korean political development. (6) The international environment, including the relations between Korea and the United States, between Japan and Korea, and Korean north-south relations. Chapter three: The authoritarian regimes and social transformation. Using civil society theory, the author analyzed the conditions and constraints for the democratic transition according to the changes of relation between the State and society. First, the salient features of the developmental state in Korea are pointed out. Then the economic and social structural transformation driven by the developmental state is analyzed. Finally, the rise of social opposition brought about by the economic development, the consequent changes between State and society especially the continuous and violent demonstrations and protests against military rule and the legitimacy crisis of authoritarian regime, are studied in detail. An overall assessment of the military authoritarian regime would indicate both positive and negative aspects, such as advancing rapid economic growth and rising national living standard and enhanced Korean international influence on the one hand, and ignoring the political procedures, fostering military intervention in political Process, expanding the power of chaebol (big business), oppressing the labor movements, enfeebling the political parties and creating regional cleavage on the other. The economic development driven by the authoritarian regime had two different effects on the political legitimacy of the Korean authoritarian regime. It strengthened its legitimacy by successful economic development, While on the other hand, it also weakened its legitimacy by creating imbalances between the economic success and the political shortcomings, which became the great driving force for the transition from authoritarian rule. Chapter four: The democratic transition and strategic choice. Under the guidance of the strategic choice theory, the author analyzed in detail the dynamics and process of the democratic transition according to the interaction between/among the authoritarian rulers and opposition leaders, including the collapse of the "Yushin regime", the postponement of democratic transition, the liberalization of authoritarianism, the division and unification of the oppositions, and the end of military authoritarian rule because of the strong pressure from the demonstrations and protests throughout the country. After the Roh Tae Woo's democratization declaration, the new democratic system was constructed and consolidated through the constitutional amendments, direct presidential elections in December l987, National Assembly elections in April l988. The crucial factors for the successful transition in Korea was that the opposition movement was unified into concerted action in June l987 and also that the reformist faction within the regime emerged and became autonomous and independent from the hard-liners. Chapter five: The democratic consolidation. After the collapse of the military authoritarian regime, political reforms were undertaken to consolidate the newly-established democracy in Korea, for instance, eliminating the legacies of the past authoritarian rule, subordinating the military to civilian control, promoting local autonomy, expanding the freedom of press and freedom of association. Nonetheless, there were some obstacles to democratization, such as political corruption especially the corruption of the political parties and politicians, regional cleavage, inappropriate political influence of chaebol. Because Korean democratization was brought about by the concession of authoritarian rulers, the three combined opposition parties got a solid majority in the national assembly elections of April l988, the settlement of the past military authoritarian legacies became to some extent a kind of political revenge. On the other hand, although antigovernment forces drove the Korean democratic transition, it did not result in a rupture in the old governing party or a clean break from the previous regime, which made the democratic consolidation long, gradual and sometimes conservative. Chapter six: The conclusion and prospects. The analysis of the characteristic features of the Korea's political transition indicated that Korea's political transition is the result of a combination of many factors, for example, mass demonstrations and foreign pressure, economic development and the choices of political elite, the protests from social movements based on civil society and the compromise and concession of military rulers. It was the dialectical combination of these factors that made the Korean democratic transition successful. Although the Korean democratic system was established in l987 and many political reforms have been conducted since then, there remain shortcomings in Korea's democratization process, for instance, the instability of the constitutional system, the imbalance between the presidency and the legislature, and the low level of institutionalization of party politics. It is necessary for Korea to undertake further extensive political reforms to build a functioning democracy and realize the democratic ideal.

Title: Why can't we all just get along: Japanese American women build cross -cultural alliances post-World War II
Abstract: The purpose of this dissertation is to look at the concept of intellectual affirmative action, what it is, how and where it can be implemented, and its significance. The primary methodology is qualitative and ethnographic. This dissertation argues that the most printed text, official knowledge, and curricula have been constructed within one dominant epistemological framework and, therefore, in order to examine other forms of knowledge one must look at different forms of frameworks, grammars and constructions such as oral discourse and traditions. This dissertation attempts to distinguish the theory of intellectual affirmative action from those of critical multiculturalists by extending their theories and those of critical race theorists. This is done by using different epistemologies to examine the stories of one sample group of 12 Japanese American women who acted to transform their social and political contexts by building cross-cultural alliances and coalitions post World War II. It is also my hope through this dissertation project to build on the body of knowledge that is available on liberatory pedagogy; to discuss how people come to understand their role and history in society and act to transform their social contexts for equity and shared responsibility in a pluralistic democratic project. In order to provide the context for the women's stories, this dissertation researches the events surrounding the exclusion, forced removal and internment of civilians and permanent resident aliens of Japanese ancestry through their and their descendents' oral histories. It focuses on activists who carry the legacy of imprisonment and forced removal in their work as living testaments to these events. As a third-generation Japanese American woman whose family was imprisoned in Rohwer, Arkansas, I am particularly interested in Japanese American women activists who have participated in movement and resistance work since World War II. The concern of this research, a case study, is with voice: Whose voices and perspectives helped shape our understanding of history and our roles in the making of that history? An understanding of how those voices and perspectives influenced our actions and identities in the current transnational context is critical to our survival. With the flow of transnational labor, hate crimes, primarily directed towards racially identified groups, have been on the rise. Asians and Asian Americans and, among them, Japanese groups, have been on the rise. Asians and Asian Americans and, among them, Japanese Americans, have been the target of these hate crimes in the United States. Strategies, including educational ones, are vital for coalition building.

Title: Reorganizing the rust belt: Social movement unionism and the SEIU in Pennsylvania
Abstract: This dissertation explores the difficulties faced by contemporary US service-sector trade unions attempting to make use of social-movement strategies and tactics. The idea of social-movement unionism is gaining popularity, not only among academic observers of labor but also within the US labor movement, and many have taken optimistic views about its possibilities. However, there has not been sufficient attention to the obstacles that movement unionism must overcome or the processes by which unions confront these dilemmas. The research therefore analyzes the processes of transition between bureaucratic business unionism and new forms of action relying on face-to-face organizing and collective action. The dissertation examines organizing and mobilization campaigns involving Pittsburgh-area nursing home workers represented by the Service Employees International Union (SEIU). By studying social-movement union campaigns of increasing scope, the dissertation shows how the dilemmas of movement unionism accumulate and deepen as it expands. At its most basic level, movement unionism must enable workers to reinterpret their own lived experience and images, not only of the power of management but also of business unionism itself. But as it widens movement unionism must also find ways of dealing with the complex organizational legacies of business unionism, since mobilizing existing union members is difficult within the confines of representational structures oriented toward bureaucratic servicing of members rather than collective action. Finally, the dissertation shows that in order to defend initial victories against employer counteroffensives—which always threaten to destroy the fragile solidarities and new organizational structures that have been built up through struggle—social movement unionism must find creative ways to exploit the extreme anti-unionism of American capital, to turn this ideological inflexibility against capital itself. The dissertation concludes with the suggestion that in order to be sustainable, movement unionism must ultimately develop its own vision of a new model of labor relations capable of replacing the failed New Deal system.

Title: An analysis of environmental conflicts involving transnational corporations, states and environmentalists in Latin America
Abstract: This study analyzes environmental conflicts involving TNCs, states, and environmental groups and concerned individuals in Latin America by examining cases in Chile, Costa Rica, and Venezuela. Of interest are conflicts that arise over the use of resources or environmental degradation resulting from corporate operations. The combination of actors involved from both domestic and international levels makes the environmental conflicts in this study a good tool for addressing the broader question of the interaction between domestic and international actors. For this, it is helpful to view the conflicts as an example of the point at which local and global forces collide in the international arena. It is important to not only analyze the conflicts, but also the larger political, social and economic structures within which they take place. Data collection for the project involved focus groups and interviews with corporate representatives, government officials, and members of communities and environmental organizations engaged in environmental conflicts. Primary interviews are supplemented by documentation from governments and international organizations, news articles, World Wide Web postings, and corporate documents. This study contributes to the larger body of work on international environmental policy by analyzing areas that are not fully developed in the existing literature concerning globalization, social movements, corporate and state power, environmental policy, and international development. This study's findings suggest that environmental conflicts involving TNCs, states, and environmentalists are much more complicated than is often portrayed. The greatest potential for resolving and avoiding these conflicts is through increased transparency and greater inclusiveness. Just as the conflicts cannot be oversimplified, neither can the actors who engage in them. Results of this investigation demonstrate the continued importance of state institutions and local level actors in conflicts involving international actors. The findings of this investigation will facilitate the work of others examining other issues, such as the role of states in global society and the relationships between national and transnational corporations.

Title: What the study of tiger preservation in India reveals about science, advocacy, and policy change
Abstract: There is a growing movement throughout the world that is becoming more vocal in challenging the efforts by international environmental organizations to promulgate the wilderness ethic as the solution to the problem of habitat and species preservation. Because the ethic is promoted largely by western or northern based international environmental organizations for use by all nations, the international wilderness movement is increasingly being labeled as “imperialistic.” This dissertation aspires to provide a dispassionate account of one nation's efforts to adopt and adapt this model as a means of staving off the degradation of its forests and wildlife with an eye to the expressed concern about undue western influence. The case study chosen was India's use of the wilderness concept in its effort to save the Bengal Tiger. Four empirical puzzles framed this analysis. First, what reasons and forces motivated India's policymakers to move from an “agrarian” ethic to “wilderness”? Second, given that nongovernmental organizations, as the primary movers, cannot power their way to a policy change, what tools and strategies were used by them to entice the Government of India to change its policy? Third, what role does science play? Fourth, can the actions of public interest international non governmental organizations be rightfully labeled “imperialism”? Using a public policy as social experimentation heuristic with the Issue-Processing Approach to policy change, I found the following. A pre-condition for policy innovation is an acknowledged and repeated history of policy failure. In addition, the skilled use of a politicized and carefully circumscribed conservation science was required in order to subdue alternative interpretations of the cause of habitat and species degradation. Once the standing policy had lost its legitimacy and an alternative model was sanctioned, policy change occurred. The actions of international organizations are far more complex than the tag “imperialism” would imply. Future research on international nongovernmental organizations must develop appropriate concepts of “power” to capture the workings of these institutions: focusing on their sophisticated use of science, public praise, and condemnation in their effort to instigate policy change.
