Title: Geographies of difference: Mapping multiple feminist insurgencies and transnational public cultures in the Americas
Abstract: This dissertation investigates how questions of difference and diversity have been negotiated within the discursive and political practices of second wave women's movements in Mexico and the U.S. and how these negotiations around difference structure transnational organizing. It explores how race, sexuality and socio-economic class play a constitutive role in the formation of women's political subjectivities shaping the way in which political interests are articulated and represented. My dissertation argues that crucial to the possibility of a transnational feminist project is the ability to recognize, respect and build solidarity between vastly different social terrains and structural confinements placed on women's lives while being attentive to power differentials that exist among women both on a local and global level. Drawing from over thirty oral histories and numerous archival sources, this dissertation maps the genealogies of new gendered racial formations and sexual identities within Mexico and the U.S. in the post-WWII era through a series of case studies. Examining the mechanics of erasure within second wave of the women's movement historiography and proposing a new framework for analyzing the multiple feminist insurgencies of women of color, the first two chapters on the Third World Women's Alliance and the early Chicana feminist organization, las Hijas de Cuauhtémoc, begin the work of constructing a history of the formation of a U.S. women of color political identities and projects. Moving into a larger historical context surrounding questions of difference within regional organizing, I explore the ways in which alternative transnational counterpublics have been forged by multiply situated actors, such as black and indigenous women and lesbians within transnational women's organizing in the Americas. The last part of the dissertation, based on a oral histories with the Coordinadora Nacional de Mujeres Indigenas of Mexico, examines the struggle for indigenous women's presence within the larger national indigenous movement, within their own communities and at the international level in order to understand how linkages between these arenas play a role in political subject formation and the discursive strategies employed.

Title: Styling a nation: Theatre and belonging in Québec
Abstract: How is a nation invented? And how does that invention come to be lived as fact by those who would be its nationals? These two questions are fundamental to scholarly work on the nation in the social sciences and in postcolonial studies. “Styling a Nation: Theatre and Belonging in Québec” proposes that some of the more productive and provocative answers to these questions are supplied by the practices and analytical tools of theatre and performance. I take as my case study the production of le fait national (the national fact) and its attendant identity in the postcolonial “cultural nation” of Québec, locating these processes in the material practices of québécois theatre and cultural performance. I propose the concept of “style” as the means for investigating the naturalization of the invented nation. I argue that québécois style, or québécité , as practiced in and disseminated through theatrical and cultural performance, is the means by which the national fiction is reproduced as fact. “Styling a Nation” examines the changing contours of Québec nation-ness, or québécité , from 1967 to 1999 in relation to national movements within Québec and Canada and to global systems, including anticolonial political movements, intercultural theatre, transnational capitalism, and immigration. Through extended analyses of four different performance forms, this dissertation queries performance's various contributions and challenges to the indépendentist nation project and examines its potential for modeling new forms of québécité . Chapter one analyzes the concept of the nation across a range of disciplines, using the 1967 World's Fair as a locus of competing national discourses. Chapter two analyzes dramatic realism as the preferred style of québécité during the cultural nationalist period of the early 1970 in Michel Tremblay's Les Belles-Soeurs . Chapter three focuses on dance-theatre troupe Carbone 14 and their performative investigations of québécois history during the 1980s and 1990s. Chapter four considers the trans-national style of Montreal's globe-trotting circus, the Cirque du Soleil. Finally, the Epilogue examines the stresses of immigration and the pressures of linguistic assimilation on québécité through two manifesto-poems: Michèle Lalonde's “Speak White” (1971) and Marco Micone's “Speak What” (1986).

Title: It's our culture: Global process, community development and language survival in Louisiana and St. Lucia, Part I
Abstract: The dissertation research explores the survivability of Louisiana French and St Lucian French Creole (Kweyol). Most sociolinguistic research on minority languages has focused on language death and has ignored global process. However, the continued and renewed salience of ethnicity as a social organizer gives reason to expect that the death of many minority languages may be arrested or reversed. The Louisiana and St Lucia cases are significant in that Louisiana French and Kweyol have both been the object of organized efforts at revaluation since the 1960s. The cases are also significant from a comparative, global perspective because of their integration into broader pan-cultural movements and the different positions they occupy within the world-system. This study investigates in relation to each case: (1) the global processes that are associated with ethnic revival, (2) the nature of ethnic revival and (3) the association between the ethnic revival movements, on the one hand, and patterns of language use and language attitudes, on the other. The project uses a comparative approach to identify common themes and to isolate phenomena unique to each case. Data from secondary sources inform global process, the ethnic movements and the sociohistorical narratives of each case. Interviews with randomly selected residents and the protagonists of linguistic preservation and promotion in Louisiana and St Lucia furnish data on ethnic revival and on the sociolinguistic status of Louisiana French and Kweyol. The findings support the thesis that Louisiana French and Kweyol ethnic revival is associated with changes in the hegemonic status and the integration of the world-system. However, ethnic revival in Louisiana and St Lucia has only partially arrested the decline in the use and viability of Louisiana French and Kweyol. English remains the predominant language of social discourse in all public domains of language use, although Louisiana French and Kweyol have made some gains. Moreover, despite the revival movements, English continues to usurp social space from the ethnic languages in private domains of use as well. The greatest effect of ethnic revival on the survivability of Louisiana French and Kweyol lies in the positive changes of people's attitudes toward the languages.

Title: Disciplining men: Cultural studies of the men's movement
Abstract: Based on prolonged participant-observation research in men's groups in Kansas City, Missouri, and Birmingham, United Kingdom, Disciplining Men: Cultural Studies of the Men's Movement explores the workings of gendered power in advanced capitalist countries through a cultural studies analysis of the contemporary men's movement. It argues that by and large the men's movement is best understood as one of many techniques of postindustrial gender discipline by which men are rendered compliant to the requirements of global capitalism. However, its specific focus is on forms of resistance to such discipline to be found in profeminist men's groups. In this way the project seeks to contextualize the lived experience of profeminist men amid the power relations that constitute the contemporary gender order as a whole. In their personal and public lives, profeminist men attempt an explicit rejection of hegemonic masculinity, yet their example indicates that men's anti-sexist practice is fraught with contradictions and extremely difficult to sustain over time. At the heart of the dissertation is a critical exploration of whether and how men may overcome such contradictions and contribute collectively to progressive gender and social change.

Title: Global energy shifts: Future possibilities in historical perspective
Abstract: This study adopts a macro-comparative, world-systems perspective in order to shed light on the dynamics that led to a global shift away from primary reliance on coal and towards over-reliance on petroleum. It is argued that the interaction of three global dynamics, those of geopolitical rivalry, commercial competition, and social unrest, undermined the nineteenth-century international coal system and paved the way for the consolidation of an international petroleum system in the twentieth century. Specifically, the historical analysis presented in this dissertation shows that: (1) intervention by state agents was absolutely crucial in the early development and later expansion of the international petroleum system; (2) private coal companies attempted to prevent the consolidation of an oil-based energy system, but these older companies were out-competed by newer, multinational petroleum corporations; and (3) waves of labor unrest in established coal industries played a key role in prompting a relatively rapid shift away from coal and towards petroleum. Indeed, a key conclusion of this study is that pressures exerted by such social movements as labor unions, nationalist movements, and environmental coalitions have played as important a role in influencing energy trajectories as the more commonly-recognized actions of governmental and corporate actors. By examining contemporary patterns of state and private investments in a cluster of new energy technologies, as well as the growing influence of environmental regulations it is argued that global dynamics are beginning to favor a shift towards new, more environmentally sustainable energy technologies. The fuel cell is highlighted as one new energy technology that is poised to enter into widespread diffusion in the coming decades, though potentials for expansions in wind, solar, small-scale hydro-electric, and modern biomass systems are also examined. Although significant hurdles must be overcome, this study concludes by suggesting reasons why a shift towards a more sustainable global energy system can be carried out in the twenty-first century.

Title: Leadership, ideology and the community living movement
Abstract: This is a study of the international community living movement to enable people with disabilities to either leave custodial institutions or be supported to live improved lives in the community. It is examined from the vantage point of the closure of a local mental retardation institution in western Massachusetts. This local example was seen as being a microcosm of a larger social movement and was deeply influenced in its broad outline by the ideology of normalization (now increasingly referred to as social role valorization theory). The study examined the identity and role of fourteen local service delivery leaders who both helped propel the aims of improved community living and eventually close the institution by the early 1990's. The study revealed the important role of ideology as a mobilizer of change, the influence of other contemporary social movements in providing a broad framework for change, the commitment of governments to the expansion and adequacy of public services in the 1970's and 1980's, the shift in professional opinion towards a preference for community living, the induction into the system of dissident young people in large numbers, the family and related advocacy movements and the key role of pivotal professional leaders in service and government roles. The study revealed the fragility of being able to sustain this movement into the future notwithstanding the remarkable success in closing institutions for several decades at an increasing rate.

Title: The virtual poetics of resistance in Chiapas
Abstract: This dissertation examines the development of a “virtual” space for resistance parallel to the physical space of Indigenous rebellion in Chiapas, Mexico during the period 1994–2000. I document the explosive growth of this hybrid, transnational discursive space and identify the social sectors participating in it. I analyze the principal discourses occupying it in relation to specific historical and political circumstances in Mexico as well as in relation to processes of globalization. Through a discussion of the nature of emerging links between the “Chiapas” space and other spaces containing discourses of social and political resistance worldwide, I consider the ways in which the power and significance of acts of writing and multimedia symbolic production (often via the Internet) blur the traditional distinction between writer and reader, artist and viewer, or actor and audience. My reading of multimedia texts in these new dual local/global spaces of resistance involves the navigation of contradictions manifest in the digitizing of intersecting and colliding narratives of modern and postmodern identity. The Chiapas conflict is mediated not only by the physical bodies in resistance in the Conflict Zone, but also by the body electric. I identify a unique symbiotic relationship between material acts of resistance to oppressive social structures in Chiapas and the “virtual” nature of these acts as they are represented and circulated in cyberspace. This dual material/technological phenomenon leads me to explore the “cyborg” nature of the neo-Zapatistas as data constructs and as symbolic reminders of the materiality of humanity at the turn of the millennium. While the Zapatista Cyborg traces its origins to an Indigenous autonomy movement, it also transgresses boundaries (geographic, class, ethnic, political) in order to challenge us to re-assert our common humanity and develop new models of solidarity and human rights in an age framed by “post-human” technology. The origin and circulation of this rebel cyborg icon in traditional and electronic texts provides a useful case study from which to analyze the nature of new hypertext multimedia discursive spaces and to theorize about the future possibilities of such spaces for social movements as well as for literary and interdisciplinary research.

Title: Sam Gilliam: The making of a career, 1962–1973
Abstract: This dissertation explores the early work and career of Sam Gilliam (b. 1933). It begins in 1962 when Gilliam moved to Washington, D.C. to pursue a career as an exhibiting artist and teacher, and ends in 1973, by which time he had secured a reputation on the national and international art scenes and achieved a level of curatorial, critical, and marketplace success that few African American artists had attained at the time, especially those living outside New York City. The project's fundamental purpose is threefold: to situate Gilliam within the artistic and social milieus from which he emerged as an artist; to explicate his major art-historical contributions during this period; and, finally, to understand how the contexts in which he circulated impacted his early production and its reception by the art world. After establishing the context for Gilliam's arrival in Washington in 1962 and describing his subsequent development there, the dissertation compares his emergence in the capitol to that in New York City. In Washington, Gilliam's overtly nonrepresentational, non-political style was embraced by critics seeking out the best of the new in Washington Color School painting, the city's only art movement to transcend its regional confines. In New York, Gilliam's paintings were more obviously embedded in the political fray that characterized the period. There, his work suggested a liberal viewpoint characteristic of civil rights era thinking at a time when liberalism was being challenged by more radical tactics for social change, most important the Black Power Movement. Gilliam's art attracted wide-ranging interpretations and represented a crossroads of meaning, a site where art history, aesthetics, and political and social influences intersected to generate a historical significance that extended beyond the art's elemental modernist purposes. In addition to being the first major in-depth scholarly study of Gilliam, an artist who is described in the thirty-four volume art-historical encyclopedia The Dictionary of Art (1996) as “the most prominent African American abstract painter,” this dissertation provides a case-study examination of the cultural politics and issues of regionalism that shaped the U.S. art world of the 1960s and early 1970s.

Title: The near northwest side story: Gender, migration, and everyday life in Chicago and San Sebastián, Puerto Rico
Abstract: This dissertation critically examines the role of gender in migration through a study of the multiple meanings and motivations of migration among Puerto Rican migrants in Chicago, Illinois and San Sebastián, Puerto Rico. Its aim is to understand circular/transnational migration historically and ethnographically. This anthropological study does not assume that poverty and economic uncertainty are sufficient causes for transnational migration. Instead, it explores how gender, generation, culture, and economy shape transnational practices among first and second generation migrants. Using 1946 as its point of departure, this study begins by examining the origins of Puerto Rican migration, paying particular attention to the role of local and national governments and private business in facilitating movement and settlement of Puerto Rican migrants. By the late 1940s, these institutions collaborated to recruit workers as contract laborers, guarantee low airfares from Puerto Rico to New York and Chicago, and disseminate information on the island about work opportunities on the mainland in order to promote the relocation of Puerto Rican workers abroad. Such state-sanctioned migration was key to Puerto Rico's industrialization program and was trumpeted by local and national leaders as the answer to the mainland's labor scarcity and the island's unemployment and “overpopulation problem”. This dissertation documents and analyzes how attitudes about migration and migrants shifted over time with changes in the local political economy in Chicago and Puerto Rico; the growth and consolidation of a Puerto Rican neighborhood in Chicago; the rise of return migration to towns like San Sebastián; and Puerto Ricans' transformation from a “model minority” to members of an alleged “underclass.” This ethnography also investigates how contemporary perceptions of migration, place, space and culture shape transnational practices in distinctly gendered ways. This study is based on a two-year, dual site project employing historical and ethnographic methods. Using local newspapers, government documents, in-depth interviews, and kinship and household analysis, it details the migration patterns and life histories of members of 22 households as they migrate, settle, and return in Chicago and San Sebastián; the shifting meanings and motivations of migration; and the social, economic, and cultural consequences of these movements.

Title: Golf, Zapata, and the Tepozteco King: Cultural struggles in contemporary Mexican social movements
Abstract: This study of the successful efforts of activists in Tepoztlán, Mexico to prevent the construction of a golf course in their municipality (1994–1999), demonstrates the viability of critically using theories of cultural hybridity as a tool in analyzing oppositional political movements. It also exemplifies a methodology in which the study of culture is concretely related to the experiences of everyday life, by examining the pragmatic ways in which non-elites make sense of and construct their visions of a just and sustainable society. In this case, what began as an apparently simple conflict over land use issues, turned into a larger debate about local democracy, cultural integrity, ecological sustainability and human rights. The thesis documents the events of the conflict, analyzing them as a type of theater through which townspeople confronted more powerful adversaries and (re)claimed the significance of various public spaces and symbols. I analyze the conflict in terms of local and historic developments, global influences, and the viability of such movements as agents of social change within the political realities of contemporary Mexico. I argue that activists in the conflict were successful because of their abilities to effectively move between and blend the different and sometimes contradictory cultural codes which compose their everyday public lives. On the one hand, activists built on local symbolic and organizational mechanisms to solidify internal support for the movement, framing the conflict as an attempt to preserve a distinctive, historically grounded way of life. Simultaneously, however, they used their knowledge of and contacts within the national and global arenas to garner support from sympathetic organizations involved with environmental and human rights protection. While such a strategy was at times contradictory, it nevertheless made sense to most townspeople, whose everyday lives (outside of political conflict) is marked by a constant negotiation between local, national and global influences. I conclude that people do not passively accept all cultural codes which are thrust upon them, but rather they are able to select those aspects of competing logics which suit their needs.

Title: The causes and consequences of patriotic youth mobilization in Vichy France and Indochina during and after World War II
Abstract: This dissertation explores French colonial organization of para-military and patriotic youth associations for its citizens and subjects. In an unprecedented manner, World War II prompted the French state to innovate in building youth organizations and sporting leagues so as to regenerate a defeated society and to prevent youth from joining subversive political movements challenging its rule. In addition to providing a full and systematic description of these policies and organizations, and their postwar legacies in various settings, this project uses comparative and historical methods to analyze transnational political and social changes, building on the work of scholars such as Benedict Anderson and Charles Tilly. The thesis also examines the legacies of French policies in later youth programs in various regimes in Laos, Cambodia, and Vietnam.

Title: Converting to spiritual profits: CEO faith and corporate environmental performance
Abstract: Global environmental concerns have prompted attention to necessary changes in religious and corporate cultures, and raised new questions about human relationship and responsibility to the natural world. A new religious movement called “ecotheology” seeks an interdependent relationship between human beings and the earth, and a theology which will restore not only human souls but ecological balance through policy and action. This coincides with the emphasis on environmental ethics in business, some of which is tied to the faith of individual corporate leaders. In some cases, spiritual beliefs and practices are literally changing the way corporations do business. This dissertation expands the concepts of ecotheology into the narrative on corporate environmental performance. It hypothesizes that the spiritual values of leaders can strongly influence corporate cultures to focus on a sustainable environment and socially responsible business practices. It traces the re-emergence of ecological principles within Christianity, reviews the history of the corporate social responsibility movement, and defines the potential for and the extent of the relationship of these movements to leadership and to the improvement of corporate environmental performance. It then discusses interviews with corporate CEOs to explore whether and how CEOs with a strong faith influenced their organizational cultures in order to improve corporate social and environmental performance. It assesses the influence of the emerging dialogue on ecojustice and corporate social responsibility on corporate leaders, and reaches some conclusions about the cultures and conditions in which the faith of the CEO is most likely to have a positive influence on corporate environmental performance. CEOs of strong faith were found to have a strong influence on the corporation's environmental record, however, significant economic and legal barriers remain to achieving full corporate environmental responsibility. Therefore, suggestions are made for additional economic, political, and cultural incentives necessary to achieve a corporate culture that is structured to contribute to a sustainable environment. This work will be of interest to those interested in the subject of spirituality and leadership, to advocates for sustainable environmental business practices which incorporate the principles of social and economic justice, and to those working for the transformation of corporate culture.

Title: “Between the difference”: Trinidadian women's collective action
Abstract: This dissertation answers three questions. What are the ideological and institutional contexts that shape the issues and practices of women's collective action in post-colonial, multi-ethnic Trinidad? What are the relationships between the community-based, national, regional and international organizations that constitute the transnational networks of a global women's movement? And, in what ways do these transnational connections affect Trinidadian women's political ideas and action and pose a challenge to contemporary structures of power in Trinidad? Drawing on social movement theory, feminist theories on women and the nation state, and Caribbean ethnography of inter-group relations, this research is based on multi-sited fieldwork research within Trinidad, West Indies. The research method includes life histories, structured interviewing, participant observation, archival research, and network analysis. Findings show that women's collective action in Trinidad has emerged out of a broader context of gender relations, related to colonial racialized gender ideologies and their legacy institutionalized in post-colonial cultural policy, politics and ethnic identity movements. Research further traces how present day ethnic-based kinship and class differences play out in the Trinidadian women's movement in terms of who participates, how that participation is manifested, and how its issues are defined. It shows that while regulation of women's labor, women's sexuality and motherhood were means of controlling populations in the colonial period, these are the sources of Afro-Trinidadian and Indo-Trinidadian women's economic, social and ritual power in the contemporary period. Furthermore, women's collective action in Trinidad, over the last 20 years, builds on these aspects of power. Finally, the dissertation traces connections between local, national and regional levels of activism of a global social movement, demonstrating how issues, strategies and consciousness move between these three levels whereby local issues become relevant to a global movement and a global movement maintains relevance to local community-based organizing. In claiming a space “Between the Difference” of Afro-Trinidadian and Indo-Trinidadian history and practices, women in Trinidad pose a challenge to state politics divided along ethnic lines.

Title: Globalization and the linkage of trade and environmental issues: A comparative analysis of the Canada-United States and North American free trade
Abstract: This dissertation analyzes the linkage of trade and environmental issues in two free trade agreements. The Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement (CUSFTA), passed in 1988, has no environmental protection measures due to complacency regarding the similarity in levels of economic, legal, and environmental protection development between the two countries. By contrast, the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), passed in 1993, is notable for its linkage of trade and environmental issues due to concerns over the disparity in development between Mexico and the United States and Canada. In an effort to placate environmentalists critical of NAFTA, Canada, Mexico, and the United States added environmental side agreements, creating three international bodies to monitor and aid in the correction of environmental problems. This work explains the process in which trade and the environmental issues became linked, and it argues that economic integration, has led, in a limited way, to legal harmonization and integration as well. This dissertation analyses the dynamic interactions between corporations, social movements and state actors in debates over free trade. Following from Joseph Gusfield's (1981) analysis of the culture of public problems, it shows how trade debates are shaped in ongoing meaning construction, and uses theories of international relations and globalization, and political sociology and public policy to explain variations in the linkage of trade and environmental issues. The importance of resources, opportunities, and problem recognition is emphasized in social movement theory, and in political sociology, this work examines theories of the social, political, and economic influences on public policy. This study of CUSFTA and NAFTA indicates a process in which actors attempt to define goals under changing circumstances, focusing on the ways in which actors develop arguments about trade and the environment. Accordingly, it examines rhetoric and action pertaining to both broad conceptions and specific outcomes of the relationship between world trade, comparative economic advantage, and environmental protection.

Title: (E)Racing the model minority: Racial ideology among young urbanized Asian -American professionals
Abstract: This anthropological study examines how a marginalized population unwilling to accept its stigmatized status simultaneously reifies and contests the standards of the dominant society to achieve greater financial security and social prestige. Utilizing the strategy of “the wolf is sheep's clothing,” young Asian American professionals in Los Angeles adapt middle class standards to reach positions of power in mainstream society. While their objectives may be self-serving, they do attempt to increase the proportion of Asian Americans in positions of power through mentoring, social networks, and community activism. Shaped by childhood access to class privilege, the racialized identities of these young professionals problematizes the concepts of Americanness, Asianness, and the marginalization of Asian Americanness and the Model Minority. Specifically, this population challenges the homogenizing effects of American Anglicized middle class ascendancy, Asian diasporic allegiances and Model Minority status, while offering an alternative basis for cultivating an Asian American identity not rooted in working class ideology, the 1960s and 1970s Civil Rights movement, and pre-early-twentieth century Asian American pioneer experiences. Among this population of native born Americans, the development and maintenance of a distinct racialized American identity embedded in middle and upper class privilege is not only complicated by race and gender, but also regionalization, parental educational attainment, international travel and social networks. Whereas many immigrant generation and working class identity formation is developed in the ethnic enclave, the racialized American identities of these professionals are sustained through a deterritorialized and spatialized community of kinship and friendship networks that cross-cut local, national and international parameters. While the population in this study represents a fraction of the overall Asian American professional population, I contend that their experiences and perspectives are an early indicator of what might exist among the growing and increasingly influential population of privileged young Asian American professionals in this country. Their perspectives and subsequent impact on American society may be an indicator or reflection of the attitudes and perspectives of other similarly privileged African Americans and Hispanic/Latino Americans.

Title: Migration, colonialism, globalization: Histories of the free -subject and the sovereign nation-state
Abstract: The global monopoly of a system of states over the international movement of people seems an unremarkable fact in the present world. This project is concerned with how this came to be the case. I examine archival documents on Indian migration from 1834 to 1917 to provide a history of state regulation of international migration. I consider both the nineteenth-century migration of indentured Indian labor to replace slave labor in the British plantation economies, as well as the early twentieth-century movement of non-indentured migrants to white settler colonies (specifically Canada and South Africa). My focus is on the emergence of certain “technologies:” specifically the juridical labor contract, installed to distinguish indentured migration from the slave trade; the modern passport, instituted to control migration along the axis of racialized-nationality; and the marriage contract, required of women in order to stake their claims to mobility. I chart how these technologies emerge from a circuit of connections and contestations between colonial state formations, prevailing ideologies of race and gender, and competing nationalisms in places as diverse as India, Mauritius, Britain, Canada, and South Africa. I draw two main conclusions from my investigation: First, that colonial migration helps produce and institutionalize the very categories—of free labor and nationality—that undergird bourgeois political economy and the nation-state, which we now not only privilege in studying migration, but which are among the salient categories that organize our social world. And, second, that the normative content of the technologies that govern migration are irreducibly raced and gendered. I argue that since these technologies operate today, often in largely unchanged form, they help secure the continuing resilience of the colonial conjuncture between discourses of race, gender, and nationality. Current discussions of migration, diaspora, and national identity often concentrate on the malleability and hybridity of the cultural dimensions of identity. In contrast, my research suggests that we must take account of the force exerted by the regulatory technologies of modern migration that help (re)generate, rather than undermine, the colonial conjuncture between racialized-nationality, gendered nationalism, the “free” subject of bourgeois political economy, and the colonial genealogy of the modern state.

Title: Global feminism and human rights
Abstract: The primary purpose of this dissertation is to document and explore the significance of transnational feminist activism in the 1990s and, in particular, its utilization of a universal human rights framework. Toward this end, the Global Campaign for Women's Human Rights (1990–95) is used as a case study in contemporary feminist organizing that has significant implications for how we approach feminist projects and human rights practice in a globalizing era. The dissertation aims to arrive at a deeper understanding of a number of important projects and themes. These include: linking theory to transformative political practice; examining how “global feminism” can address internal critiques of the feminist project; arguing the importance of the universal (in terms of the particular); elaborating feminist critiques of traditional human rights thinking and practice; situating the feminist project in a context of globalization and global trends; and (re)defining accountability for the arbitrary exercise of power in a globalizing era. It is argued that unpacking the different moments of the Global Campaign offers the possibility of mapping out a “theory of feminist practice,” which is called Global Feminism. In explaining the success of the Global Campaign, five mutually constitutive moments are identified that have worked together to create an effective and expanding social movement linking diverse women and perspectives. These are (1) a global consciousness and analysis that examines and questions the exercise of power internationally; (2) an overarching ethical framework with global resonance; (3) a “common issue” of concern to women across diverse boundaries; (4) purposive networking and building of linkages toward activism; and, (5) concrete opportunities with a global dimension around which to collaborate conceptually and strategically. Special attention is given to the issue of violence against women, which is used as a point of departure to elaborate feminist critiques of traditional human rights practice. In doing so, the dissertation explores what is required to achieve accountability for violations of human rights by private actors, in private contexts. Finally, Globalizing forces and trends, particularly understood from a gender perspective, form the socio-economic and historical context with which the dissertation is primarily concerned.

Title: From Ottawa Treaty to Southern Africa development: Non-governmental organizations and the global movement to ban landmines
Abstract: Southern Africa exhibits most landmines issues raised at international fora. This thesis explores the Southern Africa context of the global movement to ban landmines from perspectives of human security, environment, arms production, transfer and use, human rights and humanitarian law, health care, rehabilitation, demining, and development. This research also explores the shift from the politics of mobilizing nation-states to sign a treaty to the dynamics of uplifting development ethics for communities and countries engaged in implementing the treaty. How has the impact of landmines in the region, coupled with the presence of campaigners linked locally and globally, changed the global movement? In turn, how have the challenges transformed campaigns, and led to different degrees of capacity-building among partner organizations. The parties to this transnational social movement are particularly interesting because of their impact on change and the overall tone of collaboration between nation-states and civil society.

Title: East -west: Interactions between the United States and Japan and their effects on community development
Abstract: This dissertation aims to shed light on the creative interaction of Eastern and Western culture in the current global transformation. Exploration of this broad theme focuses on two places where this process plays out: the Jamaica Plain section of Boston, and Zushi, in the Tokyo-Yokohama region. This inquiry begins by pinpointing convergent characteristics of contemporary development in Jamaica Plain and Zushi: a movement toward organizing collective action through networks bound by a shared image of a healthier, more sustainable community. Next the focus widens to consider this phenomenon in the context of the global system. The theoretical framework for this macro-historical sociological investigation emphasizes the globalization of counter-hegemonic tendencies, predicated on the notion of utopian alternatives as a force for social change . The concepts of utopian realism and glocalization explain how this works, and shape a lens to view civic innovations in Jamaica Plain and Zushi that may stem from ideas with deep roots in the West and Asia: an image of the ideal decentralized community, based on cooperation. A narrative weaving description and analysis traces the evolution of these ideas of planning and community from similar historical origins in the US and Japan, along separate paths that become increasingly interconnected with the rise of a global system, as the glocalization of innovations within this tradition of utopian realism . Since the mid-nineteenth century there has been intensive interchange among American and Japanese artists, architects, planners, scholars and others, particularly between Boston and Tokyo-Yokohama. The narrative zeros in on particular individuals who served as key intermediaries of this exchange, moving out from them to examine the development of syncretic bodies of thought in both East and West, notably within the planning arm of the modern movement. Jamaica Plain and Zushi serve to illustrate the role of particular actors and ideas which affect community development. This findings of this research illuminate why connected communities in the US and Japan are particularly good sites to study theories of globalization. The revelation of the influence of Japanese aesthetics on participatory planning and community design, an on-going process, opens up an entirely new field for investigation and theorization.

Title: Animating cultural politics: Disney, race, and social movements in the 1990s
Abstract: The ideological power of popular culture, and especially of movies, has always prompted public dispute. Arguably the leading producer of popular culture today and a corporate global giant, The Walt Disney Company has mass marketed animated features since 1937. While some of these films are still remembered for their racist elements, the company took a new creative turn in the 1990s, producing three animated features depicting racial Otherness: Aladdin (1992), The Lion King (1994), and Pocahontas (1995). Each film produced a different critical outcome: the American Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee surprised Disney with a successful challenge of Aladdin 's most egregious representations; Disney avoided the multicultural challenge in The Lion King with minority participation and anthropomorphicization; and in the eyes of many, Disney met the multicultural challenge with their story, their casting, and their animation in Pocahontas . Drawing upon interviews with leading figures and archival research I use an eventful sociology of culture to explain these varying critical fields and the conditions for social movement challenges. The debates inspired reveal a struggle over what counts as racist as opposed to what counts as ‘ multicultural ’ or ‘ Politically Correct .’ These cultural contests cannot be neatly polarized, however, into struggles between a corporate producer and the victims of Disney's hegemony. Disney limits its multicultural liability to the extent that it incorporates actors, activists, and experts from communities associated with those it claims to represent, and to the extent that the filmmakers avoid explicit identification with any community through their animation technique or story lines. Movements tend to remain beyond Disney's multicultural account when community participation is excluded and when the movement maintains solidarity and effective management of the media. In highlighting the conditions of movement mobilization and the production of Disney's hegemonic multiculturalism, I conclude that Disney's increasing sophistication in marketing and producing animated multicultural fare invites new alliances among minority movements. In addition, while blatantly racist representations and exclusions still motivate movements into action, the complexity of racism in the multicultural media market suggests that movements attend to new forms of cultural critique in their production of an alternative politics of representation.

Title: Democratization and the *environment: Understanding the determinants of state environmental policy outputs in communist and post -communist societies
Abstract: This dissertation endeavors to answer the question: what are the primary determinants of positive national environmental policy outputs in communist and post-communist societies? There are three prevailing views in the literature that have been used to explain why states have better environmental policy outputs. The first approach focuses on the positive impact of democratic regime transition on environmental policy. The second approach discusses the relationship between environmental social movements and state policy. The third approach analyzes the impact of global eco-politics on domestic environmental policy. One democratizing post-communist state (Hungary) and one communist state (China) are used to empirically examine these theories. Each of the above approaches has been used with varying effectiveness to explain why states adopt positive environmental policies. However, many questions remain unanswered. One question of particular importance that is raised by the case studies is: how do internal state actors influence variation in environmental policies? In response to this question, this study offers an additional alternative theory called state environmentalism, which examines how the presence of strong intra-state advocates of environmental improvement can impact state policy outputs. This analysis finds that, in the case of Hungary, social movement actors, democratic regime transition and internal state environmental advocates had relatively little effect on the promulgation of positive state environmental policies. Rather, policy changes were largely driven by pressure and support from the E.U. to improve environmental policies as part of a larger process of Hungarian accession to full E.U. membership status. Regarding the case of China, this study finds that the active advocacy of environmentally conscious intra-state actors played a crucial role in pushing forward environmentally friendly policy outputs. Long-term engagement with global eco-political Actors also had an important effect on changes in Chinese domestic environmental policies.

Title: Buying time and getting by: The voluntary simplicity movement
Abstract: The voluntary simplicity movement took off in the United States in the late 1980s and early 1990s. It spans the boundaries between self-change aimed at bringing personal practice into alignment with ecological values and a focus on cultural change that rejects consumerist values and careerism to concern with producing broader cultural and economic change. The primary mechanisms used by the movement in its contemporary phase are struggle over cultural meanings and self-change. The broader changes simple livers aim to bring about are a sustainable global environment, sustainable communities, increased equality in access to resources (though no explicit demands for equality of control over them or their distribution are laid out), and economies aimed at human quality of life rather than profit. This analysis brings together reflexive empirical analysis that explores the coconstruction of race, class, and gender and analysis of cultural movements. This approach fosters balanced consideration of the influence of the dominant culture and institutionalized power (Benson 1978; Bourdieu 1984; Collins 1990) and the importance of the dynamic identity work of transformative cultural movements (Neitz 1994; Swidler 1995; Schwalbe 1996; Taylor 1996) and shows how the cultural work of the voluntary simplicity movement is shaped by class, race, and gender relations (Collins 1990; Walby 1990). The consideration of multiple and intersecting forms of power as constituting elements has largely been missing in much of the research on new social and cultural movements. And in those cases where inequality has been considered, usually one form of inequality has been given salience rather than the intersecting coconstruction of the categories of class, race, and gender through which power moves and is structured. This analysis finds that the voluntary simplicity movement draws on external, preexisting culture and traditions that are structured in very significant and limiting ways and that the movement is constrained by their influence. At the same time, movement participants make use of the diverse and rich possibilities in the culture at hand as a source of agency to construct an alternative (Hays 1994).

Title: Transmigratory subjectivity in contemporary Latina fiction
Abstract: The principal contribution of this project to Latina literary criticism is the concept of “transmigratory sensibility” as a theoretical lens through which to comparatively read Chicana, Puerto Rican American and Cuban American women's fiction. This reading practice enables the theorization of different forms of resistance manifested by the tropes of migration and exile and facilitates analyses of the relationship between gendered, raced identities and physical, social, economic, and psychological movement. Most crucial to my use of transmigration theory is what I have termed a transmigratory consciousness: the abstracted, cultural connection with the country of origin, as well as returns to that country which transcend tourism, signifying personal transformation and a reversal of exile. Immigrants with a transmigratory sensibility can, through their individual, emotional, and/or politicized ties to their country of origin, challenge core national narratives of inherent superiority. Returns can be infrequent, single, or even imaginative, but what constitutes transmigrant sensibility is the resistive nature of (re)conceptualizations of individual and national identities. The concept of a transmigratory consciousness defines the nature of the recent shift in Latina writing concerned with the representation of bicultural identity in a transnational context. Latina texts that depend on the trope of movement and the act of return to demonstrate the development of an agentive female agency represent an emerging paradigm within a Latina literary discourse. The novels presented in this study figure resistance against psychosocial othering through the themes of the American Dream, biculturalism, migratory experience, and return. Chapter One examines the Chicana novels Trini , The Memories of Ana Calderón , and Cantora for the ways in which they trope return in demythologizing the American Dream as exploitive nationalist ideology. Chapter Two analyzes A Perfect Silence and América's Dream as Puerto Rican American novels that trope return to create a viable bicultural identity and that contest the Americanization of their originary culture through the Latinization of mainland culture. Chapter Three looks at The Agüerro Sisters and Singing to Cuba to comparatively read the ways in which Cuban American fiction redefines exile through the thematization of return and the American Dream.

Title: How wide the circle of we: Cultural pluralism and American identity, 1910–1954
Abstract: This study examines the efforts of the International Institute movement to implement cultural pluralism in the United States during the first half of the twentieth century. Created by the Young Women's Christian Association (YWCA), the International Institute movement began in New York City in 1910. The goal of the Institute movement was to welcome immigrant women and girls to full participation in American life by easing their transition to a new country and culture. The International Institute movement provides a unique opportunity to witness the creation of an interethnic cross-class organization that tried to create real social change and justice in the early twentieth century, a period rife with an often-violent resurgence of nativism and racism. The founder and first executive director of the International Institute movement was Edith Terry Bremer. Bremer was a dynamic and charismatic leader whose vision shaped the first forty-four years of the Institute movement's existence. Bremer's commitment to immigrant women and girls was shaped by her own experience as the daughter and granddaughter of ministers. Steeped in the Social Gospel, Bremer experienced first-hand the influence of the settlement house movement. She worked with luminaries of the early Progressive era. Women like, Julia Lathrop, modeled for Bremer not only the professional possibilities available for women but also the impact women could exert on changing societies' most oppressive structures and practices. Under Edith Terry Bremer's guidance, the Institute movement rapidly expanded. By 1918 there were sixty-two International Institutes in operation. Bremer believed that the Institutes could best serve the needs of immigrant women and girls by hiring immigrant women themselves. “Nationality secretaries” were the primary staff members of each International Institute. The International Institute movement encountered the myriad contradictions of life in the first half of the twentieth century. They provide a rich and compelling entree into issues of race, class, gender, religion, and region.

Title: A critical study of the Seventh -day Adventist health teaching tradition in light of the contemporary situation of public health and globalization
Abstract: This dissertation is a study of the Seventh-day Adventist church's health teaching tradition. The church has members in 205 countries recognized by the United Nations. It operates educational institutions, medical clinics, hospitals, publishing houses and food production companies throughout these various countries. This study examines the tradition of health reform as church leaders developed it in the mid 19 th century. This study more broadly examines the various cultural and social influences of American popular religious and health reform movements as the basic context from which the Adventist health teachings emerge. Since the establishment of the health teachings as a principle of faith, many advances in medicine, science and health along with radical social, cultural, and global conditions provide an opportunity for reassessing the health teaching tradition in light of contemporary life. With the global expansion of the denomination and poor health conditions in those countries where the church is rapidly expanding, this dissertation calls for renewed scholarly interest in the Adventist health teaching tradition in order to understand, appreciate and access its moral wisdom in our contemporary circumstances. Three principles agents of the denomination namely, the clergy, publishers, and health care workers promoted the advancement of the teachings. The dissertation shows that the advancement of health reform within the denomination was not without problems, difficulties, tensions, and controversy. The controversy over the control of the health ministries of the denomination would culminate in the John Harvey Kellogg event when church leaders and denominational agencies separated themselves from the public health ministries established by Kellogg and his associates. With this separation, Adventist concerns for health reform and the health teachings became privatized under denominational evangelistic interests while Kellogg's public concerns for the poor, orphans, and the destitute in many large cities were relegated to non-religious social institutions. This dissertation argues that the global expansion of the church and the challenges of contemporary life, particularly for the poor, orphans and marginalized persons in countries where the church's evangelistic ministries have been most successful, call for renewed interest by Adventist scholars in the public practices and concerns that Kellogg made a part of the Adventist health teaching tradition.

Title: Women's struggle and female migration into Japan in the 1980s–1990s
Abstract: The dissertation investigates: (1) the degree to which female immigrant workers into Japan in the 1980s–90s are not merely passive victims of unequal development but autonomous subjects who use international mobility to improve their lives and; (2) the ways in which the mobility of female labor power has contributed to the expansion of capitalism in Asia. In building a theoretical model and carrying out empirical work, the study employs the two-sided analysis of the autonomist Marxist tradition as a central, guiding theory and method. The study was conducted between 1992 and 1998 in Japan and the United States. Following an introductory chapter, Chapter 2 clarifies the significance of international migration in global capitalism not merely as capital's manipulation of labor power but also as workers' autonomous movement across the artificial barriers of nationstate borders, which defies their categorization of “factors of production” being shifted around within the global factory. Chapter 3 explains women's work from the point of view of the entire circuit of capital, using the autonomist Marxist concept of “social factory” and describes women as a “wage division” in the wage hierarchy, which plays a crucial role in the social factory. Chapter 4 analyzes the peculiar feature of female immigration in Japan, i.e., migrant women come from Third World countries for sex work and housework. Chapter 5 examines the link between female immigration and Japanese women's struggle, the most conspicuous of which are a rapid decline of birth rates and a tendency of later marriage. Chapter 6 reviews the struggle of women in Thailand's export-led economic development. Chapter 7 presents the results of a case study of Thai migrant sex workers in Japan. The results bring together individual-level determinants, suggested by the views of workers' autonomy and subjectivity, and structural-level dynamics, derived from the concepts of class composition, political recomposition, and decomposition. The dissertation concludes that Asian women migrate to improve their lives and the level of struggle in Japan and that Japanese women's struggle, particularly their refusal to produce and reproduce labor power, is one of the factors for the increase in immigrant women from other Asian countries.

Title: Waiting 'till the midnight hour: Black political and intellectual radicalism, 1960–1975
Abstract: The modern Civil Rights Movement represents one of the most heavily studied social movements in recent American history. During the past two decades a proliferating body of historiography has emerged chronicling both the local and national impact of the movement's quest for African-American citizenship. More recent scholarship has, in a laudable attempt to bridge the gulf between top-down studies of national political leadership and local studies of grassroots organizing, emphasized the ways in which local and national struggles were in fact connected. However, despite these successful efforts to fashion a multi-dimensional narrative of civil rights history, existing scholarship has failed to interrogate the impact of black radicalism on the movement. Premised on the assumption that African-Americans remained relatively quiescent until the emergence of the Black Power Movement during the second half of the 1960s, black radicalism's impact on the modern Civil Rights Movement has experienced historical neglect. The silencing of radical discourses that had a transformative effect on the movement has allowed for the Civil Rights and Black Power Movements to be viewed as mutually exclusive. Ignoring the continuities between black radicalism at the height of the modern period of the Civil Rights Movement disallows for a substantive portrait of one of the most important social movements of the twentieth-century. This dissertation examines the impact of black radicalism on the Civil Rights and Black Power Movements, effectively re-periodizing these periods through an examination of the historical antecedents of Black Power radicalism. Through an analysis of historical figures, including journalist William Worthy, trade-unionist Vicki Garvin, theorist Harold Cruse, and activist Bill Epton, who contributed to the formation of a radical Black Public Sphere during the height of the modern movement for civil rights, the study argues that the Civil Rights and Black Power epochs must be seen as fluid rather then separate and distinct time periods. Drawing inspiration from international decolonization struggles, black radicals navigated the slippery slope of Cold War liberalism via an underground network of journals, newspapers, and political organizations. Entering the national discourse on racism, colonialism and white supremacy through a backdoor reserved for the disfranchised, black radicals constructed spheres of dissident activity that overcame inadequate resources, political demonization, and intra-racial ideological struggles, acquiring a growing influence that culminated in the 1972 black political convention in Gary, Indiana. Constructing an oppositional politics that mandated placing the struggle for black America's civil rights within an international political milieu, the radical discourses that proliferated during the peak of the southern movement's heroic quest for political and social enfranchisement provide an historic context for Black Power politics that characterized the first decade of the post-civil rights era. Against a political backdrop of global decolonization movements confronting the harsh dictates of the Cold War, black radical discourses shifted from marginal to central within the Black Public Sphere. These radical discourses were greatly impacted by debates over black feminism and the role of black women in anti-racist political struggles. Consequently, black women articulated discourses that challenged and critiqued black male patriarchy within, and outside of, Black Power organizations. Examining the discourses and debates that led to this dramatic shift between 1960 and 1975 this study re-establishes the historical significance of once-powerful political discourses that continue to haunt the contemporary American political imagination.

Title: Reconciling Belfast: The politics of faith and peace in Northern Ireland
Abstract: This dissertation investigates the local political effects of the international Charismatic movement in Belfast, Northern Ireland. In Belfast, the historical alignment of religious affiliation, cultural heritage, and political allegiance has produced a division between two ethnic communities: Roman Catholics and Protestants. This binary has been consequential over the past thirty years, contributing to the low-intensity sectarian war in which the political future of Ireland is contested. The degree to which the sectarianism is a fundamental structuring principal of society in Belfast is reflected in the exclusion from public discourse of other dimensions of social difference, such as socioeconomic class, and socioreligious plurality. Rooted in endogamy, divisions between the communities is sustained by mutually-exclusive, stereotyping practices that include residential and educational segregation, various religious, cultural, and political practices, sundry acts of violence and terrorism (or the tacit support of these), and other discursive strategies that isolate “us” from “them.” The role of religion in this process remains under-investigated, despite its apparent centrality. I argue that a distinction must be made between popular faith and religious orthodoxy. Charismatic Renewal in Belfast is a revitalization movement wherein middle-class citizens ritually dramatize “reconciliation” between the two communities. Such drama re-constructs personal and social identity by performing what participants consider to be pan-Christian ethics, worldview, and embodied or effervescent experience. These stand in opposition to the orthodox, post-Enlightenment rationalist practices of the traditional Christian denominations. In so doing, Renewal empowers people who might otherwise have little influence on changing an atavistic and remorselessly violent social order. Ritual constitution of new identities that are pan-Christian involves: (1) the re-imagining of the urban and rural landscape as imbued with the dynamic and sovereign Holy Spirit; (2) the re-construction of Christian and Irish history to show where and how supernatural forces have been active in Northern Ireland; (3) the rhetorical constitution of Northern Ireland as a sinful, “ill” society in which Satan creates hate and intolerance; and (4) the performance of healing in which sin and sickness are expelled from the body by the healing and boundary-destroying power of the Holy Spirit.

Title: Migrant subjects: Race, labor and insurgency in the Mexico -U.S. borderlands
Abstract: “Migrant Subjects” examines the relationship between mexicano expressive culture and the practices sustaining labor and social movements. It contends that mexicano counter-modernisms mark the particular condition of migrant subjects' induction into nation-building projects of development. In Chapter One, “Vernacular Aesthetics and the National Question in the Works of Américo Paredes,” I read Paredes' last published novel, The Shadow (1998), to discuss the effects of Mexican and U.S. nation-building projects of development on the border subject of Paredes' work. Chapter Two, “Reading Gender Conflict and Repression in the Communitarian Narratives of Salt of The Earth and El Movimiento Chicano,” argues for the recovery of mexicanas' full political participation in labor and social movements as workers and activists in their own right. It links the 1954 film to subsequent debates over the place of Chicana feminism in the Chicano Movement during the 1960's and 1970's. Chapter Three, “Richard Rodríguez as Public Intellectual,” addresses the work of a complex figure who since the early-1980s has sought to position himself as an interlocutor for mexicanos in the United States. I offer close readings of Rodriguez' two memoirs to suggest how his formation as a gay Chicano intellectual reflects broader shifts during the 1980's. In Chapter Four, “On the Borders of Solidarity: Race and Gender Contradictions in Contestations to Global Capitalism,” I use the case of a cross-border organizing effort to support striking workers in Tijuana, Mexico as an occasion for studying the place of mexicano labor in current narratives of development and U.S. union opposition to globalized capitalism. Chapter Five, “Narrative Acts: Figuring Critical Consciousness in the Global Assembly Line,” then examines the division of labor at the border to address the representation of maquiladora workers within certain postmodern Chicana feminist discourses. Finally, “Migrant Souls” examines the political efforts of mexicanas in the maquiladoras during the period following the ratification of the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1994. I argue that articulations of a distinctly female bordered subjectivity may direct us to forms of critical agency not beholden to the developmentalist logic of nation-states or globalized capitalism.

Title: Re -routing /rooting the nation -state: The Karakoram Highway and the making of the Northern Areas, Pakistan
Abstract: The western Karakoram mountains have evolved through four different spatial configurations—“frontier”, colonial agency, post-colonial liminality, and national territory. However, each of these phases are not fixed objects with identifiable definitions of what constitutes a “frontier”, a “liminal territory”. Rather, each represents a series of processes—processes that reflect upon the encroaching (integrative) nature of the state and how encroachment (integration) transforms not only “localities” but also the state itself. The region first entered the realm of colonial frontier policy with the creation of modern Jammu and Kashmir in 1848. In 1889 the British created the Gilgit Agency, transforming the region from an amorphous “frontier” into a territorial unit. Until 1947 a variety of policies were implemented territorializing the Gilgit Agency. However, that movement towards fixing the region as a territory was never finalized. At the time of independence of Pakistan in 1947 the Gilgit Agency was frozen in a territorially liminal state—recognized as neither part of Pakistan nor India, administered by Pakistan yet claimed by India. Pakistan administration of the region was a continuation of colonial practices, but within the rubric of a nation-state rather than a colonial state. In 1972, the nomenclature of the region was changed from the colonial “Gilgit Agency”, to the “Northern Areas”—territorially fixing the region as part of Pakistan. Since 1972 a series of policies have been implemented to make that claim real. Most important of these is the construction of the Karakoram Highway in the 1970s. The highway links local, national, transnational, and global processes and is the avenue along which space, mobility, and the nation-state are produced in tandem. Through my research I have found that the changing patterns of geographical mobility of people, goods, and ideas are key components in spatial transformation. There is a “dialectic” relationship between geographical mobility, the constitution and reformation of physical spaces, and the nature of the state that (attempts to) administers human activities and controls social spaces.

Title: What is a social movement? The Action Canada Network and free trade opposition in Canada, 1983–1993
Abstract: Free trade opposition in Canada can be said to have emerged in the critiques of the Mulroney Government economic agenda in the early 1980s. It ended upon the ratification of NAFTA by the Chretien Government on December 2, 1993. The dissertation examines the experience of the major anti free trade forces in Canada during the debates around the Canada-US and North American Trade Agreements: the Action Canada Network, its international networking partner Common Frontiers, and Citizens Concerned About Free Trade. The primary question concerns the nature of a social movement. The Action Canada Network claimed to represent and to embody a national movement for economic and social change. It is therefore compared to a framework for social movements developed out of new social movement theories and international environment and development policy and politics. The central questions asked are, was the Network a social movement? Did the goals and strategies it pursued correspond to those of a social movement? How did internal perceptions of the role of the Network affect the success of its anti free trade campaigns? What legacy did it leave for Canadian social and political discourse and action at national and international levels? It is argued that the Network confused itself with the social movement it claimed to represent and therefore blocked the possibility of its emergence. As a result, despite the movement potential exhibited by the Network during the 1987–88 anti Free Trade Agreement campaign, when it can be said to have been the closest to truly constituting a national social movement, it failed to achieve its goals. The so-called Free Trade election of 1988 was lost, and the next round of NAFTA opposition saw a much lower rate of public participation and support for the Network platform, despite polls indicating Canadians blamed the Canada-US Free Trade Agreement for a poor economic outlook. Finally, it failed to influence a new era of social politics in Canada. Little public space exists today for a credible challenge to the neoconservative ideology which underlay the agreements and which prevails today.

Title: The political economy of the state and social forces: Changing forms of state -labour relations in Turkey
Abstract: The dissertation is a study of the Turkish political economy since the end of the 1970s, with the focus on state labour relations. It argues that despite the political regime changes in Turkey in the early 1980s (overthrow of democratic institutions by a military coup in 1980, and the passage to parliamentary civilian rule in late 1983), there were fundamental continuities in the Turkish political economy and the substance of state policies through the 1980s. Neoliberal restructuring of the economy, suppression of labour demands by direct state intervention in industrial relations as part of this economic restructuring, and marginalization of labour's representation in the state, characterized both the military regime of 1980–83 and the subsequent period of parliamentary civilian rule. Thus, unlike most of the writings on the recent wave of democratization, this study examines the issue of the continuity in the form of state despite the political regime change in the context of the Turkish case. The dissertation also shows, however, that the type of political regime was still important. It had an independent effect on the development of social forces and the particular nature of their interactions with the state. After studying gradual changes in the trade union movement's strategy and actions in relation to the state and employers, the dissertation argues that the state's persistent anti-labour policies and its frequent direct interventions in the system of industrial relations in favour of employers inevitably generated counter-reactions from the labour movement. These counter-reactions took the form of the union leadership's adoption of a more active stance in defending labour interests, and rank-and-file militancy at the end of the 1980s. I argue that there was an important attempt at a new social settlement inclusive of labour and other subordinated interests, but without abandoning the neoliberal economic strategy of the previous decade. However, this attempt failed because of the structural contradictions of the neoliberal economic model in Turkey, diminished autonomy for government policy as a result of the Turkish economy's further integration into, and dependence on, global financial markets, and reluctance of Turkish capital to make some concessions to labour interests. This study situates Turkey within the context of the global political economy, and systematically examines the nature of relations between the Turkish state and major domestic social forces on the one hand, and international institutions and major western states that Turkey has close relations with, on the other. (Abstract shortened by UMI.)

Title: A crisis ‘in’ conflict for international relations: The case of the Turkish /Kurdish War through neogramscian lenses
Abstract: This thesis takes an alternative approach to understand the social basis of regional conflict. As such, it bridges the fields of Comparative Politics and International Relations. It builds a ‘society up’ model as a lens for an extensive case-study of Kurdish nationalism in the Middle East, with a particular focus on the Kurds of Turkey. The thesis provides a critique of the statist assumptions in International Relations and Comparative theories, suggesting that ‘top down’ theories lack the precision required to grasp the social basis of ethnic and national conflicts. From there, an examination of the profound transformations in global politics in the past fifteen years is tabled to reveal the need for an approach that can better capture the redefined agencies in global politics that are a result of globalization. A neogramscian theoretical framework is proposed, asserting that the Kurdish identity has been defined historically only in relation to how the Kurds are different from the dominant Turkish social order. Using an historical sociological methodology, the thesis moves to a history of Kurdish ethnonationalism, assigning agency on the Kurdish peoples themselves, rather than at the level of those empires and states that ruled over them. It is suggested that the Kurdish people were instrumental to both the collapse of the Ottoman Empire, and the consolidation of the modern state of Turkey. This historical sociology then examines the evolution of Kurdish identity construction under the domination of the Turkish state, and looks at the transformations of both Kurdish social forces and of Turkish society. In the final section, the dialectic of hegemony/counter-hegemony is used to provide a detailed examination of the multiple processes of social conditioning that the Turkish majority have upon the Kurdish minority, and vice-versa. The repressive measures taken by the Turkish state have internationalized the Kurdish conflict, and the responses by Kurdish nationals have been to deterritorialize the conflict through the development of cyber-nationalism. This has led to the establishment of a truly transnational national movement. This is a phenomenon that ‘top down’ theories of global politics are unable to capture effectively.

Title: Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam and the cultural production of nationalism and violence: Representing the integrity of nation and the choice for armed struggle
Abstract: Emerging from a history of state-sponsored violence and discrimination, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) are leading the contemporary Tamil nationalist movement for the creation of a separate state in the northern and eastern regions of Sri Lanka. As a social and political movement committed to armed struggle, Tamils participating in the LTTE movement for national self-determination have been marginalized as “terrorists” by the Sri Lankan state and have been denied participation in political processes toward a resolution of conflict that has escalated to civil war. Cultural productions of nationalism play an important part in mobilizing and voicing nationalist sentiments. This dissertation focuses on an examination of LTTE cultural productions of nationalism in the form of political posters, songs and radio dramas. As such, this dissertation asks: What can we understand about the self-representations of the Liberation Tigers by analyzing their cultural productions of nationalism? Nationalism, resistance and violence intersect in the everyday experiences of Tamils not only in Sri Lanka but also in the immigrant and refugee communities of the Tamil diaspora. The LTTE are attentive to these lived experiences of violence within these national and transnational Tamil communities. LTTE cultural productions have emerged as a means of organizing Tamil experiences of violence and nationalism while also creating a dialectical space in constructing the integrity of self, community and nation. Situating my research within the theoretical paradigms of post-colonial criticism, I analyze the choice of violence as a means of dialogue within the context of nationalist struggles. I discuss the “geographies of war” as they are constructed by the Sri Lankan state while examining the language of “terrorism” that is invoked in popular and academic debates about nationalism and violence. Integrating the tools of feminist methodologies, I engage my experiences and my subject positions as a Tamil woman from Jaffna, as an anthropological researcher, and as a “Native-Other” to inform my analysis. As such, I examine the position of the researcher as an informant.
