Title: The ethnic teaches back: Identity formation and academic status of foreign-born women academics in the United States
Abstract: The dissertation crosses geographical, historical, and cultural boundaries in its exploration of the interconnectedness of gender, race, ethnicity, nationality, and education through the prism of identity formation and academic status. It incorporates an innovative qualitative methodology described as decolonizing, “culturally hybrid ethnography” with oral historical components within feminist framework. The study is based on in-depth interviews with thirty-four women who were born outside of the U.S. and currently are professors in a major American research university. Whereas most studies in the area of race, ethnicity, and gender issues have focused on a separate country, region, or time period, my analysis covers women's diaspora narratives from twenty-two different nationalities from the 1920s to the early 1990s. Primary areas of focus include women's background and education before their coming to the U.S., their immigrant experiences, academic career, development in the U.S. higher education system, and gender roles in the context of American and academic cultures. It draws on cross-cultural, immigration, ethnic, post-colonial, and development theories, among others. The significance of the study is that for the first time in the American scholarship the focus is exclusively on immigrant women academics. Within the increasing body of literature on immigrant women, little has been done to study immigrant women who are skilled labor or who belong to the group of professionals. Second, this study contributes to the scholarship on women and minorities in the academic profession. There is no available research on women academics that are both minorities and immigrants. Third, the dissertation is cross-cultural in design. It provides the unique possibility for studying women from different cultural, ethnic, racial, educational, and social backgrounds. The study of the experiences of an international group of women contributes to an understanding of international feminism and women's movement.

Title: Remaking gender and citizenship in a Mexican indigenous community
Abstract: This dissertation examines the changing parameters of gendered citizenship in contemporary Mexico, particularly in the context of globalization and rapid neoliberal reform. Through a local political ethnography of the shifting discourses and practices of citizenship, I contribute to wider debates on the relationship between globalization and democratization, as well as literatures on women and politics in Latin America. This project is based on fieldwork conducted in Cherán, Michoacán, Mexico over a 14 month period in 1998–1999. Key methodological techniques included in-depth interviews and participant observation. Particularly through women's life experiences and narratives, I trace how women re-imagined themselves as political actors during opposition party electoral mobilization in 1988. Women's unprecedented participation in extended mass action and civil disobedience shifted how many conceive of politics and their own role in them. I conclude the opposition party mobilizations between 1988 and 1989 (in favor of the PRD— Partido de la Revolución Democrática ) unleashed qualitatively different kinds of political vocabularies and meanings in the community of Cherán, and fostered the emergence of new political identities. These political discourses provide an alternative understanding of citizenship and political authority, in comparison to the historical dominance of personalistic and clientelistic political cultures. In addition to the focus on the experiences and narratives that emerged in 1988, the second line of my empirical inquiry examined the ‘sedimentation’ of these political identities and vocabularies within a variety of formal and informal political spaces over time. How did the identities and political vocabularies unleashed in 1988 shape how people do politics on a daily basis ten years after the mobilization? My investigation and theoretical analysis contributes to expanded understandings of citizenship, including new insights into the scales of political identity embedded in citizenship as well as the transnational implications of Anglo-European notions of liberal democracy as re-appropriated and re-worked in post-colonial contexts. Finally, I draw on concepts found within social movement theory, and contribute in new ways to that literature by conducting a place-based analysis that moves beyond the movement as the central category of analysis.

Title: The 1999 pension reform and a new social contract in South Korea
Abstract: This study challenges the economic explanation of pension reform, by comparing the contrasting pension reform processes of the Kim Young Sam and the Kim Dae Jung governments in Korea. The economic logic school argues that the recent wave of pension reforms has stemmed from economic globalization in which economic factors, such as domestic savings and financial burdens, have determined whether or not a country has opted to reform its public PAYG system. Contrastingly, this study highlights the underlying coalitional dynamics, which generate different strategies to manage the terms of globalization and the way to tackle the pension reform agenda. Despite the drastic economic liberalization and the World Bank's direct involvement in the pension reform process, the Kim Dae Jung government dropped the neoliberal pension reform plan of the Kim Young Sam government and vigorously expanded the ‘traditional˚’ pension system to cover urban informal sectors. This study traces the abrupt change in the reform strategy to the demise of the conservative developmentalist coalition and to the rise of a new ruling coalition after the economic crisis and power shift to the center-left opposition party in 1997. Labor and civic movement groups joined the new ruling circle and constituted the core of the new social policy network. The new ruling coalition sought to complement the external strategy of economic liberalization with an internal strategy of compensation. This led to a new social contract in which the state assumed an extensive responsibility for its citizens' well-being in the form of strong social safety nets. The theoretical implications of this study are threefold. First, the impact of globalization on social welfare is filtered out through domestic political dynamics. Compensatory responses to globalization, which were manifested in many small European open economies, are still feasible. Second, the influence of the international financial institutions is relatively weak in the social policy area. The nation state retains a considerable level of policy autonomy. Third, the negative impact of globalization on labor power can be offset by democratization and growth of civil society. This signifies the continuing relevance of the power resources model in the welfare state theory.

Title: The origins of the Chinese Communist Party and the role played by Soviet Russia and the Comintern
Abstract: This thesis examines the origins of the Chinese Communist Party, making full use of primary materials, especially newly published Comintern documents and British archives. In making a comprehensive survey of the international background of the foundation of the CCP, the author proposes that the establishment of the CCP was a part of the Bolsheviks' global strategy of world revolution, of the Comintern's efforts to expand Communist forces into the East; it also served Soviet Russia's interests in the Far East. The study reveals the important role that Soviet Russia and the Comintern played in the establishment of the CCP. During the period 1918-1921, Soviet Russia and the Comintern dispatched numerous emissaries to China and recruited many agents there. These people made wide-ranging contacts with Chinese in different organisations and factions regardless of their political beliefs, party affiliation or social strata. They conducted intensive agitation and propaganda by various media and means, including supplying news and publicity to the press free of charge and publishing Communist booklets and journals in Chinese. They had a hand in directing important student and worker organisations which emerged during the May Fourth Movement, and later urged people who had a little knowledge of Marxism and who belonged to anarchist organisations and the Guomindang to organise socialist and communist organisations and parties. The CCP's important founders, Li Dazhao and Chen Duxiu's conversion to Bolshevism and their creation of the CCP only happened after the Bolshevik agents' persuasion and instruction. Therefore, the thesis concludes that the establishment of the CCP was not, as official ideologists claim, the outcome of the combination of the dissemination of Marxism-Leninism and the labour movement in China, but actually the result of political direction and financial support by the Bolsheviks. In consequence, the CCP was built along Leninist lines from the very beginning. This research further analyses the internal causes allowing Bolshevism to be transplanted into China and points out that the ideology which the CCP embraced during its founding period still has far-reaching influence upon politics in China today.

Title: Intercultural theatre: Two Beijing opera adaptations of Shakespeare
Abstract: As major theories and praxis of theatrical interculturalism are disseminated from experiences in Euro-American theatre, contemporary Asian theatre is conscious of developing its own strategies and discourses on adapting foreign (particularly Western) theatrical elements into native traditions. Historically, intercultural theatre in Asia emerged as a result of Western dominance and Westernization which started in late nineteenth century. Since the nativist movement and nationalism spread in the 1970s, Asian artists have consciously used interculturalism to express their cultural subjectivity and to revitalize their declining traditions. Some even see it a vital means by which to take part in a larger, more universal “world culture.” Thus the seminal issue which defines the task and goal of Asian theatrical interculturalism is how to achieve the equilibrium between borrowing Western playwriting and staging techniques, which gives social significance to modern audience, and preserving Asian forms and aesthetics, which provides cultural roots and a sense of continuity with the past. This thesis singles out two distinctive traditions—Beijing opera and Shakespearean drama—and examines their confrontation and reception. This process is surveyed from a historical angle, including: (1) the impact of Western cultural and theatrical models on China; (2) Beijing opera's adaptation of specific Western dramaturgical elements under various social and political environments; (3) Shakespeare productively received as a literary, cultural, and dramatic paradigm in China and Taiwan. Although the cross-cultural fertilization between the two proves to have been more sporadic than systematic, it indicates the beginning of a much more intense and sophisticated intercultural movement involving the adaptation of Western non-realistic theatre by Asian traditional forms. Through adapting Shakespeare, Beijing opera in late-1980s Taiwan has moved towards three major directions: to a form which requires little “preknowledge” of artistic conventions in the audience; to a form which balances musical perfection with scenographic expression; and to a literary theatre which emphasizes structural tightness, character complexity, and relevant themes. These shifts, along with the opera's newly-gained international significance in world tours, have released Beijing opera from its artistic conventionalism and political propagandism, and opened a new vista for future development.

Title: Developing new solidarities: Unions and the internationalising state
Abstract: This study examines the responses of unions to the changing forms of the internationalisation of the state. These forms include the international agreements of the World Trade Organisation, the European Union, the North American Free Trade Agreement, the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation Forum the International Monetary Fund and the Multilateral Agreement on Investment. The study traces broad comparative themes in the development of supranational institutions and agreements and in the responses of unions to them. The neo-liberal restructuring of states and the internationalisation of some of their functions followed the economic crises of the nineteen seventies in the context of the growth in size and influence of transnational corporations. Neo-liberalism establishes favourable conditions for investment and profitability at the expense of labour rights and the social safety nets of the welfare state. National governments negotiate international agreements and are accountable to national constituencies. There is a growing crisis of legitimacy of supranational agreements negotiated without democratic accountability. Unions have been weakened by the internationalisation of production and the labour market deregulation which has accompanied it. International union organisations have sought, representation in the supranational organisations and have sought labour rights clauses in international agreements. This has achieved only limited success. Some unions have resisted aspects of international agreements in the nineteen nineties. Resistance by unions and social movements contributed to the collapse of the negotiations an the Multilateral Agreement on Investment. Effective union organisation in this context has been based independent unions with strong organisation in the workplace and alliances with other social movements at the local and national levels. The most successful responses to international institutions have built on this form of social movement unionism. These responses have included cross-border links between unions and cross-border links between, unions and social movements, using networking forms of communication through the internet.

Title: Obstructed labour: Race and gender in the re -emergence of midwifery in Ontario
Abstract: Responding to the admonition of numerous scholars that contemporary social and political formations in the West must be viewed in relation to histories of colonialism and contemporary relations of neo-colonialism, this study undertakes a contrapuntal reading of the production of white First World women as acting political subjects through their material and discursive relationship to Third World women and immigrant women of colour. Focused on a very specific feminist initiative—the movement to revive the practice of midwifery in Ontario, Canada—this research untangles the paradox represented by the conspicuous under-representation, relative to the their numbers in the Ontario population, of immigrant midwives of colour in the ranks of the province's newly-legalized midwifery profession. Moving from an examination of (global) macroprocesses of power, to an explication of institutional forms of racist exclusion and concluding with an examination of microexpressions of racism, unequal relations between women are shown to underlie the successful challenge to patriarchal medical authority mounted by provincial midwifery activists. Through the examination of substantial empirical evidence, including state documents, movement publications, and data derived from forty-seven interviews with practising and non-practising midwives, this research traces how racist exclusion operated to construct the Ontario midwifery movement and the bureaucratic structures which superceded it, as normatively white spaces. The (re)production of racially exclusive spaces can be seen to result from both deliberate choices and seemingly-benign inertias, neither of which are necessarily linked to an intention to enact racism. Rather, it is argued, racist exclusion must be understood as unavoidable when race-blind epistemologies guide actions. The epistemological stance within which the Ontario midwifery initiative was locked dictated that women were oppressed in similar ways and that race and other critical dimensions of social identity only complicated a foundational gender oppression. Such a stance does not require that hierarchical relations among women be taken into account. This research illustrates that the failure to inquire after the differential impact of feminist political strategies on women positioned unequally in the social field dooms those seeking to address the “universal needs of women” to reproducing global and local structures of domination and subordination.

Title: In search of global civil society: A critical exploration
Abstract: This study explores and critically examines the global civil society construct. In this period of economic globalization, there is tremendous optimism that non-state actors, such as transnational social movements, can take a leading role in representing the world's poor and marginalized to challenge the existing structures of oppression and exploitation. This study explores the diverse and contending meanings of global civil society, and argues against any attempts to advance a simplistic, uncritical adoption of the term. In contrast this study contends that the global civil society construct is fraught with ambiguity, contradictions, biases, gaps and euro-centric assumptions. Hence, although there is a need to make sense of the changing landscape of international politics, this study reveals that global civil society is a more problematic, than useful construct to employ, in order to explain and explore the processes of international activism and resistance to globalization.

Title: The development of co-operative ideology: From social transformation to organisational survival
Abstract: George Melnyk (1985) has argued that the practice of Co-operation has developed through three different phases, Utopian, Movement and System. Co-operatives have shifted from small, decentralised, utopian communities which where attempting to build a new world one village at a time, to large centralised conglomerates trying to keep abreast of their private, for-profit counterparts. Despite this and other critiques there remains an implicit and overarching set of values expressed by the Co-operative movement that Co-operatives are agents of social change. The co-operative principles are commonly thought of as the source and embodiment of these values. This thesis examines whether the Co-operative movement's own expression of its ideology, as expressed by the International Co-operative Alliance three reviews and declarations of ‘the Co-operative Principles’, has followed this same shift from social transformation to organisational survival.

Title: A Swedish dilemma: The Social Democrats, the Center Party, and the European Community, 1957--1994
Abstract: Sweden's main problem in its relations to the EC has always been balancing its economic needs and the policy of neutrality. This is what I call “The Swedish Dilemma.” For a long time, Sweden regarded neutrality as an insurmountable obstacle to membership, but the Eastern European revolutions of 1989 created new conditions. The deep economic crisis in the early 1990s forced the politicians to seek solutions to domestic problems outside Sweden, In October 1990, the government announced a sudden policy change and in July 1991 Sweden formally applied for EC membership. The mission of this thesis is to chart, explain, and compare the EEC/EC/EU discussions within the Social Democratic and the Center Party. The investigation starts with the 1957 signing of the Treaty of Rome and closes with the 1994 Swedish referendum on EU membership. During this period, the two parties changed from a negative to a positive attitude towards membership. Both also have close connections to strong organised interests, namely the trade union movement and the farmers' organisations respectively, Members of these organisations form the core groups of the parties. Argumentation analysis is used to structure the discussion to discern continuity and change over time. The arguments are also related to ideologies and interests. Three processes influenced the discussion: the development of the European integration, the Cold War, and the economic, social, and political changes in postwar Swedish society. A conclusion of this thesis is that the EC question was essentially a domestic political matter. The two parties made similar judgments about the external processes. It is principally the third process that explains differences between the parties. The political actors' perception of EC membership's effects on the core groups and interest areas was very important for their attitudes. After 1989, neutrality was no longer as urgent as before. Party specific arguments, which had been only vaguely discernible before, now became more pronounced. For the Social Democrats, these arguments concerned labour market and social welfare. In the Center Party, agriculture and regional policy were central themes. A condition for the traditional Swedish policy in these fields was a high degree of national economic independence. A negative attitude towards the EC therefore accorded more with the two parties' ideologies. The new standpoint of the party elites caused a wide gap to their voters, In order to ease the tensions within the two parties, each of the party leaderships launched an ideologically impeccable vision of Sweden in Europe. The Social Democrats emphasized the EC's so-called social dimension, which they described as a necessary counterweight to market forces and international capital. The Center leaders seized upon the principle of subsidiarity. They equated this vague principle to the idea of decentralisation, which was fundamental for the party. This did not at all convince the parties' members and voters, which was clear in the campaign leading up to the 13 November 1994 referendum.

Title: ‘No God, no master’: The strike in Lawrence, Massachusetts, 1912
Abstract: This study investigated the relationship between church and labor, and the implications of this relationship in the development of a normative social ethic among religious institutions. The strike of 1912, popularly known as the Bread and Roses Strike, was chosen as the focal point of the study because it marked the culmination of years of social and economic change. From the turn-of-the-century to 1912 the church struggled to develop an ethical standard for industrial society. The triumphant theological idealism of the Social Gospel movement had reached its high water mark. Social Gospel followers believed that they could transform the world into a just and harmonious social order through the teachings of Jesus Christ. In that same year, 12,000 workers in Lawrence, Massachusetts, disgusted and discouraged by years of poverty, filth and injustice, marched off their jobs on strike and cried: ‘No God, No Master’. The study revealed that, although the development of a normative social ethic was an important feature of theological discourse at the beginning of industrialization in the U.S., in practice with regard to labor strike, mainline churches accommodated secular culture and used principles primarily borrowed from ideas of noblesse oblige . Religious institutions at the time of the Bread and Roses strike offered few substantive challenges to the capitalist system in support of labor. The conclusions drawn from this historical examination of the relationship of the church and labor revealed that although in its theological discourse religious leaders attempted to address labor problems, in practice, religious leadership found itself supporting capital as a bulwark against the threat of ‘atheistic socialism’. The legacy of 1912 is apparent in three significant obstacles to labor organizing that exist today. They are the newest challenges to religious communities' participation in organizing efforts: (1) the lack of a cohesive identity for working class people, (2) the growth of capitalism in global markets, and (3) the growth of the contingent work industry and what might be called, “the disposable employee”. The development of a universally accepted normative social ethic, especially with regard to labor issues continues to be an elusive goal for religious institutions as well as for U.S. society as a whole.

Title: Renationalization of the Hawaiian Islands through the historical law of aloha, Hawaiian national laws, and international law
Abstract: Pre- and post-colonial laws governing First Nations indigenous people occupying islands and continents throughout the world prior to European discovery have been generally overlooked in the renationalization processes occurring today. In South Africa, for example, Nelson Mandela used only western governance and promised government-generated solutions. Sovereignty movements in Hawai'i have utilized western governance forms. This form of government disregards indigenous values and has two major problems. First, it creates social and financial dependency on government. Second, it gives decision-making power to only a few. In August 1994, the United Nations Sub-Commission on Prevention of Discrimination and Protection of Minorities adopted a draft declaration covering the rights and freedoms of indigenous people (UN The Rights of Indigenous Peoples , Fact Sheet No. 9 (Rev. 1) p. 8). However, if First Nations Indigenous people give up their rights through acculturation to western colonial values, they give up these freedoms. The real question is: How, in this ever-evolving global economy, can a people survive socially and economically while maintaining the integrity of their “cultural characteristics and distinct identities”? Is it even possible? The aim of this dissertation is to attempt to answer this question by showing how cultural integrity and the use of existing laws can provide a solid social and economic foundation for the renationalization of first nation people in this global society, using the Hawaiian Island government, and its present problems, as an example. Methodology included the extrapolation and definition of ancient and modern laws through a study of history. Thereafter, the application of these laws were used to formulate a theory for renationalization. Included were ideas for responsible internal social and economic self-rule; reclamation of land through the use of ancient and Hawaiian Islands national laws; and equitable international relationships between both the Hawaiian Islands, the US, and their citizens.

Title: Oscar Micheaux as social reformer: Propaganda in early Black films
Abstract: Oscar Micheaux as Social Reformer: Propaganda in Early Black Films casts the most prolific maker of race films in the role of master manipulator and, by analyzing the content of his forty-eight films, concludes that his was one of the more persuasive—and strident—voices in the early civil rights movement in this country. It addresses the simple framework on which he built his filmic campaign of social elevation that spanned the period from 1918 to 1948. The planks were individual and community development and no less than parity with white America. He answered D. W. Griffith's vitriolic 1915 film The Birth of a Nation with his own concept of nation, a separate-but-equal, parallel black nation and his films showed people how that nation should look. The study examines the propagandistic model and how Micheaux adapted it for his own use. Further, it looks at some of the methods international filmic propagandists used to alter public thought and behavior at precisely the time Micheaux worked in this country. It looks at his public struggle with religion, important because it informs the most fundamental issues on which his morality plays depend. The study demonstrates that Micheaux was an influential, often controversial, prophet who preached a message of social possibilities via the medium of early-day motion pictures.

Title: The Coalition of Progressive Electors: A case study in post -Fordist counter -hegemonic politics
Abstract: This dissertation is a can study of The Coalition of Progressive Electors (COPE), a municipal political party in Vancouver, British Columbia. Founded in 1968, COPE claims to represent a coming together of “ordinary citizens” united around a programme of people's needs. In direct opposition to its chief political opponent, the corporate-sponsored Non-Partisan Association (NPA), COPE has attempted to articulate the diverse issues and objectives of progressive movements within the civic electoral arena. Following a neo-Gramscian approach, the research highlights both the internal and external challenges confronting COPE throughout the party's long history in Vancouver politics. A neo-Gramscian perspective emphasizes the process of coalition-formation—that is, the creation of a broadly inclusive and widely endorsed counter-hegemonic project. In the advanced capitalist democracies, the task of building electoral coalitions has generally been taken up by political parties that have either tried to gain the active support of social movements, or dismissed their concerns as unwelcome ‘distractions’ from the main goal of winning state power. However, as the limitations of conventional party politics became increasingly apparent, and as new social movements began to challenge established political boundaries, many experiments in constructing a “new” kind of party have taken place. I have examined COPE as an instance of a “new politics” or movement-oriented party. My research focuses on COPE's efforts to articulate the aims of “new” and “old” political agendas, and to adopt a new social movement style within the realm of electoral politics, thereby serving as a counter-hegemonic vehicle within the local political context. The analysis begins with a review of the concrete practices and experiences of several exemplary movement-oriented parties in various political settings. Based on this literature, the conceptual framework of the study is narrowed to a focus on the content of political debate and the style of political action expected of a movement-party. The COPE case study is also situated within the political-economic context of Vancouver's development as a post-Fordist “global city.” Systematic examination of COPE's archival documents, observation of the group, and interviews with COPE members reveal that, in its present form, COPE does not rise to the status of a counter-hegemonic force in Vancouver politics, although its particular experience is instructive. Analysis of COPE underscores the necessity of coalition-building around multiple issues and identities, and the need to reconceive the notion of politics to include both electoral and extra-parliamentary struggles. An examination of COPE's historical evolution also points to the need for a greater degree of political flexibility in order to effectively respond to the limits and possibilities presented by specific historical moments. In a post-Fordist as, COPE's electoral appeals to “working people” or “ordinary people” assume a homogeneity among progressive movements that is belied by interrelated processes of economic polarization and political demobilization/exclusion, as well as by the social diversity of the global city. A post-Fordist counter-hegemonic project requires a vision and a political strategy capable of bridging the gaps between disparate interests and movements.

Title: Liçoes de abismo: Vida, obra y pensamiento de Gustavo Corçao
Abstract: A first attempt to relive the figure of Gustavo Corçao, Brazilian writer and thinker that lived between 1896 and 1978. The work is divided in four major parts: an introduction to his historic and social context, a biography with personal and professional perspective, a more detailed analysis of his work and the influences on his thought and finally a compared vision about the author's last and most polemic years. The study is grounded mainly on primary sources—oral and original documents—and includes a wide research done in Brazil, Portugal, USA and France. It presents also plenty of illustrations as well as an extensive bibliography concerning the theme, the intellectual history and the philosophical-religious context of the time. Corçao represents a truly original interpretation about the general situation of Brazil in the twentieth century. He is a disciple of Christian humanism and social catholicism and consequently he very much participates in the philosophical/cultural reality of the world in our days. A scientist, a layman, a convert, a philosopher and a journalist, a writer of international fame as well as one of the greatest names of the so called modernist movement of Brazilian literature, a professor and an intellectual leader, Corçao deserves to be studied and analysed as being one of the deepest and more important voices of Latin America in the XX century.

Title: The materiality of concordance: Social movements, solidarity and the debate over international family planning
Abstract: When two major groups interested in population control and human rights reached an agreement to form an alliance, one might assume that their policies would be mutually beneficial to all concerned. However, in the case of family planning policy, the alliance and the planning that followed from these policies was actually harmful to the rights of women around the world. This thesis uses the case study of international family planning to examine two opposed movements agreeing on a pragmatic solution to a specific human problem (family planning) that renders them dependent on one another. The purpose of this thesis is to explain the boundaries between social movements and how a seemingly beneficial policy to facilitate women's rights was rhetorically appropriated by population stabilization advocates and used at the expense of women.

Title: On economic globalization and developing countries' destiny
Abstract: Trade liberalization, production internationalization, financial globalization and regional grouping constitute four major fields of current economic globalization. Since 1990s , international trade has grown so rapidly that the total volume of world trade amounted to one fourth of world output in the early 1990s from one eighth in 1965. This shows that with more and more products involved in world trade, trade and industry have been closely integrated. Especially the establishment of World Trade Organization (WTO) in 1995 has further reduced tariff, sped up the process of free trade, kept service trade, intellectual property rights and investment measures concerning trade within bounds and expanded the scope of free trade commodities. Moreover, transnational corporations have been unprecedentedly prospering -the scale of foreign direct investment has been growing, the production network has spread to every corner of the world and the optimum distribution of resources has materialized all over the world. Meanwhile, their intention and extension of integrated production have grown so fast that the coexistence of various mode of production has emerged such as integrated production, specialized production, globalized management, cross-border mergers and acquisitions and strategic alliance. With financial business and institutions, breaking national bounds world economy has been increasingly financially integrated. Finance has become an independently operating key resource and a central link of various economics. Huge transactions are carried out around the clock in the global foreign exchange market; Capital can not only realize cross -border movement in the same markets (e.g stock market) but also be swiftly transferred in different markets (e.g foreign exchange and stock). Regional organizations are emerging one after another. With more and more participant countries, they are constantly expanding their scope and have spread to every corner of the world. There is no such distinctions as social systems and ideology because all the countries accept one unified economic rule ; Regional economic organizations are tremendously increasing, progressing to higher levels and uniting with each other. This indicates the trend of global integration. All these form an marvelous picture of world economy and merge into an inexorable historical tide. But how can developing countries make full use of opportunities, avoid risks and realize economic take off ? The factors of external environment and internal elements are essential. First, a new interpretation of North--South economic relationship is needed. Theory of center-periphery, theory of underdeveloped growth, idea of marginal capitalism and theory of attachment , all there advocate the idea of cutting ties and breaking with developed countries, so they are not desirable against the back ground of economic globalization. Reality proves it wrong that the more connections a country has with developed countries, the poorer it will be . On the contrary, those countries which stick to the closed-door policy will definitely get stuck in the marginal situation. Similarly, developed countries can't live without developing countries' resources and market. Without these, they will wither and stifle. Therefore, I believed, we must look at the North-South economic relationship in the age of economic globalization in an interdependent point of view. Second, we should reconsider the approach to establish a new international economic order. Third, a new intention should be given to developing countries' strategy of economic development which has altogether taken the form of import-substitution strategy, export-oriented strategy and the strategy of comprehensive economic and social development. In my opinion, we should promote this comprehensive development strategy. By giving it new intention, we should put emphasis on the equal stress of domestic and international market as well as domestic saving and utilization of foreign capital. When importing foreign capital, we should control the proportion of securities investment; When raising foreign debts, we should control the proportion of short-term debts and make sure that the amount of debts coordinates with the capacity to earn foreign exchange through export. Fourth, the national financial security system should be established.

Title: The movement and development of the fictitious capital:a study on the status Quo and the countermeasures for the development of the securities-market in our country
Abstract: Accompanied with the appearance of the joint-stock company, the fictitious capital emerged and developed in the 17th century. It has developed into an enormous family after several centuries' development and plays an important role in the social economy today. It is obviously necessary to study the law of its movement and development, to propel it to make positive contributions for the social economy as well as to serve for the national economy's stable continuous development, and to limit and eliminate it's unfavorable influence to the social economy. The thesis includes four parts. It systematically elaborates the fictitious capital's movement and development. In the last part, on the basis of the analysis on the securities-market's present situation in our country, it puts forward several countermeasures.The first part: The basic theories about the fictitious capital. This part makes a systematic exposition of the fictitious capital's foundation, concept, type, character and social nature as well as its function. The fictitious capital includes the most general and essential characters, it also includes all kinds of fictitious capitals. Thus the fictitious capital should be defined as this: some right or right certificate which is regarded as capital could bring some income for the owner, and be invented as the capital possesses value. It's m a in characters are: First, it is only the right certificate of the capital; Second, it is based on the real capital, at the same time, it is independent on the real capital; Third, it has the unique law of the value operation; Fourth, it is often speculative. The fictitious capital' s social character reflects in three hands: The commodity's social nature diverts to money; The money changes from symbolized to fictitious; The increment changes to fictitious and external. Its functions to social economy are both positive and native. It could promote the optimized distribution of the resources; could impel the social idle changes into produce capital by concentrate the capitals; could save the circulation costs and accelerate the circulation; also it could increase the enterprise's benefits. On the other hand, however, if it had developed excessively, it would cause the social economic crisis; It would aggravate the investor's speculation in the securities-market, and make the securities-market can not act as the economy forecast; Also it would produce finance foams, and destroy the national or the regional monetary system, even it would lead to the global financial crisis.The second part: The movement of the fictitious capital. This part contacts and compares the fictitious capital with the real capital and the real economy, as well as elaborates the law of the movement of the fictitious capital's value and the development tendency. On the basis of this, the thesis analyzes the cause of the foam economy by the Keynes' supply-demand model. Looking from the fictitious capital's value movement, although it is based on the real capital, with the development of the modern's credit, it further separates from the real capital. The fictitious capital's price is determined by returns and interest rate, also the expectation, the speculation and the relation between the supply and the demand in the market could influence its change. In market, its price operation follows the special law-"Giffen phenomena". The fictitious capital tends to increasingly extricate itself from the individual production and increasingly be closely related with the world economy. The interaction of the fictitious capital's movement and the real economy could be reflected in two hands: One is individual production, the other is the whole economic condition. The different types of the fictitious capital's movements directly or indirectly contact with the individual production or the whole capital's movement. The fictitious capital is the base of the foam economy. The precondition of the foam economy is that there's enough money entering the securities-market, and that the increment of price of the fictitious capital higher than the goods' price must result in the foam economy.

Title: On the theory and practice of Austrian Social Democratic Party since World War Two
Abstract: The research object of the article is on the theory and practice of SPO since World War Two. The whole article consists of four chapters, the preface and the conclusion. Being the background material, the Preface not only illustrates the research substance, method and significance of the article, but also reviews the brief history of Austrian social democratic party from its founding to World War Two ago. In Chapter One, the author inquires into the development process of SPO since World War Two in order to show the significant status of SPO in Austrian politics and society. Then the author inquires into the practice of SPO in socialization, social welfare, class cooperation and the labor movement. The great influence that the practice bring to Austrian politics and society is integrating Austrian politics and society not renovating them. In Chapter Two, the author deliberates the theory wellspring of SPO--Austrian Marxism and the inheritance and development of important theories of SPO from Austrian Marxism to Austrian democratic socialism in the standpoints to the state, democracy, the society the nature of SPO and the Communism according to the important programs of SPO and the , thought of the great theorists of SPO. In the development process, the radical and revolutionary tint gets more and more weak while the mild and reformatory tint gets more and more strong, which is the result of adjustment and compromise of SPO according to the reality whenever necessary. In Chapter Three, the author inspects the most characteristically domestic policy of SPO---the social partnership in all aspects. The emerge of the social partnership in Austria is because there are some profound historical background, the organizational, political and economic prerequisites in Austria. The social partnership is a complicated network of formally and informally reciprocal action among the four advantage blocs, among the four advantage blocs and the state. Its special organization form is the Parity Commission. The social partnership exerts great influence to policy formulation in the domains of price and revenue policy, macroscopic economic policy, social welfare policy and etc. Although the social partnership has made great contribution for Austrian steady politics and economic development, there are many problems since l980's.Its importance gets more and more weak We not only cannot sketchily negate the social partnership, but also cannot unilaterally affirm lt. In Chapter Four, the author inquires into the characteristically foreign policy of SPO-- the perpetually neutral policy Austrian perpetually neutral statute is the diplomatic choice in order to resume and defend its sovereignty and independent under the situation of the keen struggle for Europe by America and the Soviet Union. During Cold War Austria has effectively Protected its advantage and enhanced its international status using the perpetually neutral policy and formed its characteristic compared to Switzerland's. Following the disappearance of the antagonism of the West and the East in Europe and the far-reaching development of European integration process, SP0 has begun to adjust the perpetually neutral policy that is facing more and more challenge. Austria has actively joined the EU and come close to the NATO. Austrian perpetually neutral statute will not easily change in the foreseeing future. The conclusion summarizes the characteristic of SPO compared to other social democratic parties and its worldwide influence, the historical origin of the democratic socialism of SPO, the isolation of the theory and practice of SPO and the enlightenment of the theory and practice of SPO to the construction of Chinese characteristic socialism in a sense.

Title: Studies on the legal system of international adoption
Abstract: International adoption is a conspicuous social phenomenon in modern international society, and its occurrence and development has become a brand-new subject that confronts the legal circles. Therefore, it is of great significance, both theoretically and practically, to explore and research into the legal system of international adoption. In this dissertation, the author makes a comprehensive and detailed study of the historical development, the organic constitutions and the unification process of the international adoption law. The dissertation is composed of seven chapters, four parts. There are about 280,000 chinese characters in all. Part one probes into such issues as the occurring mechanism, the definition, the nature and sources of the international adoption law by surveying the evolution course of the adoption systems of different countries. Part two exposes the reasons for law conflicts in international adoption and expounds the theory and practice of its law application and other related issues on the basis of a systematic and comparative research into the concrete rules on adoption in domestic laws of different jurisdictions. Part three is focused on a historical and theoretic investigation into the unification process of international adoption law, and especially on a positive analysis of the Convention on Protection of Children and Co-operation in Respect of International adoption law, is adopted by the Hague Conference on Private International Law. It also anticipates the bright future of the unification movement in this field. Part four looks into the interregional conflicts of the adoption laws in China and looks for its solution methods through an analysis of the status quo of the Chinese legislations on the foreign-related adoption and the counter-measures for its improvement. The possibility and practicability of China's participation in the unification process of international adoption law are also inquired into in this part.

Title: The role of the European SME as a means to combat unemployment and social exclusion in the context of the dual economy
Abstract: The specific research aims to evaluate the European SMEs strategy and see if and to what extent it provides an effective and appropriate public response to unemployment and broader social exclusion. Our analysis, reflecting upon the increasing economic concentration in various sectors of the global economy, has considered the possible impact of the "dependency" and oligopoly - implied by Robert T. Averitt's "Dual Economy Model" - on this strategy's effectiveness. Juxtaposing the free-market model, within which recent SMEs' policy responses have been formulated, and the alternative dual economy framework, this thesis seeks for the empirical evidence that assess both frameworks' relative merits in offering a better understanding of contemporary economic structures and informing more realist policy designs. The research undertaken so far indicates that the SMEs policies, informed and designed on the basis of the free-market paradigm and flexible specialization approach, have not captured sufficiently the "real" nature of industrial and labour changes taking place at a European or global level since the mid-70s. Accordingly, they have failed to recognize the pragmatic macro-, meso- and micro factors influencing SMEs' employment-inclusion capacity. On the contrary, Averitt's Dual Economy model appears to come closer to describing the global capital movements and production trends, and to interpret in a more realist and creative way the marginalization of small industry and secondary labour markets. In overall, the European Union's SMEs policy has been proven ambiguous in nature and of limited effectiveness in combating unemployment and social exclusion. Moreover, this thesis' evidence-based Dual Economy approach has shown that there is no ready-made formula for entrepreneurial solutions capable of addressing the structural barriers being behind broader society's exclusion. However, this research has made clear, that a comprehensive and solid framework approach to social problems can open new, complementary ways in conceptualizing entrepreneurial initiatives likely capable of addressing real social needs. The implications of our research outcome for alternative public policy responses to realist social needs and different multi-criteria evaluation approaches are discussed at the end.

Title: A reappraisal of the American eugenics movement, in the light of German eugenics (1918-1945)
Abstract: The accepted version of the history of eugenics - put forward by Kevles, Allen and Barkan amongst others - is that the example of Nazi eugenics contributed to the decline of the eugenics movement in the USA. This dissertation challenges that view and argues that Nazism was irrelevant to that decline. In so doing this work argues against the widely held chronology of American eugenics. Whilst most historians suggest that the older (orthodox) style of American eugenics was weakened by 1933 and then killed off by Nazism, this work argues that it was already finished by 1933. Historians have argued that the newer (reform) eugenics movement began to decline and transformed itself into new fields and organisations partly because eugenics was so widely discredited by Nazism. This dissertation suggests that reform eugenics was not a coherent ideology, but was rather a collection of reactions to the older type of eugenics. As such it could only exist while there was an older eugenics movement to react against. It then voluntarily transformed itself into new fields, as it was too diverse to survive. The fields which developed using parts of the eugenics ideology included population control movements, birth control and family planning, human and population genetics. Orthodox eugenics collapsed because of changes in scientific and social scientific knowledge, the emergence of birth control, opposition from groups like the Catholic Church and changes in economic circumstances. By 1933 the programme of the older generation had not changed, but all of its concerns had been removed from the scientific field to the area of social and cultural concerns. Furthermore, there were tangible and clear-cut distinctions between American and German eugenics, in terms of policy and there were fractures in the international eugenics movement that led to a formal distance between German and American eugenics.

Title: Zeny a Aktivismus: Czech women and gendered activism
Abstract: This project is a qualitative, interview-based, exploration into Czech women's organizing. The purpose of this project is to begin to understand Czech women's conceptions of activism, feminism, and gender issues and to contribute to the growing dialogue between Czech and American scholars and activists on the nature of women's activism in international and non-western contexts. Interviews were held in Prague with 10 members of a Czech women's organization. The results of this project, gained using constructivist inquiry and grounded theory methodology, suggest that existing literature on Czech women and social movement theory inadequately explains participants' reasons for organizing and the diversity of their opinions regarding feminism and activism. Findings suggest that Czech women are actively defining feminism, activism, and organizing in a manner that reflects their experiences with socialism and democracy building.

Title: The <i>zapatista</i> movement: A political process approach
Abstract: This thesis analyzes the Mexican rebellion in Chiapas from the perspective of social movement theory in order to illuminate the movement's novelty and relevance. Using the political process approach in general, and the Sydney Tarrow model in particular, reveals diverse elements related to the zapatismo that surpass the results of simple economic and social approaches to the conflict in Chiapas. The zapatista movement has persisted for more than seven years, and during this time it has seduced numerous left-wing intellectuals as well as advocates groups around the world. The zapatismo has been able to adapt itself not only to changes in the political circumstances of Mexico, but also to the different expectations of diverse national and international groups.

Title: The reform -conflict paradox in Northern Ireland, 1963–1972: Constitutional logic and transnational dimensions of ethnic political contention
Abstract: Ironically, efforts to promote social equality in ethnically divided societies have resulted in armed conflicts while armed conflicts have given rise to the pursuit of social equality. Two factors explain this paradoxical relationship. First, actors commonly view social equality and constitutional change as two sides of the same coin. Second, shifts in national and transnational level processes generally interact with ethnic contention in ways that expand the scope of policy reforms and heighten levels of political violence. Using archival searches, interviews of key informants, and a protest event database, I examine relations between the largely Protestant, Unionist majority and the mostly Catholic, Nationalist minority in Northern Ireland. The prospect of ending the partition of Ireland motivated several activists playing key roles in the formation of a civil rights movement in Northern Ireland. Mass mobilization in the later part of the 1960s triggered a backlash by Unionists concerned about the constitutional implications of civil rights demands. Reforms enacted by the Northern Ireland state increased violence by militant Unionists. In the face of repression and vigilante attacks, a large section of the Nationalist population revolted in the pursuit of a united Ireland in the early 1970s. Intense, prolonged political violence subsequently encouraged initiatives aimed at accommodating Nationalists. The ability of activists to create pressure on behalf of civil rights demands depended upon the resources, organizational capacities, inter-organizational dynamics, political opportunities, collective action frames, and forms of contention of rival transnational networks of organizations with competing policy agendas. While researches have emphasized factors internal to Northern Ireland, shifts in external factors also significantly affected the trajectory and policy consequences of civil rights contention. Changes in: (1) the levels and dynamics of transnational mobilization; (2) international media coverage of contention; and (3) relations between states, initially promoted reforms but subsequently undermined efforts to sustain policy progress, to prevent rebellion in the face of violent opposition, and to restrain counter-insurgency measures. Insights gained by focusing upon the dynamics and transnational dimensions of ethnic issue contention point towards the need for analytical reorientation and conceptual retooling within the fields of ethnic studies and social movements research.

Title: Translating participation in informal organizations into empowerment: Women in rural India
Abstract: This dissertation research analyzes the degree to which poor women are socially empowered because of group participation. I address three main questions: (1) what has been the strategy of the state vis-á-vis movement organizations in addressing women's empowerment issues? (2) How have current trends in globalization supported collaboration between the state and community based initiatives for women? (3) What are the effects of such group based initiatives (structure and functioning) on individual women's empowerment? The research model integrates gender theory and social movement theory to examine how poor women organize as informal groups. I focus on a specific state initiative called the Mahila Samakhya Karnataka Program in India engaged in organizing women's groups (called sanghas ) in villages. Combining qualitative and quantitative methods, and based on a quasi-experimental research design, the field-level data collection spanned about four months (September 1998–January 1999). The data collection involved identifying key state reports, field level participant observation of 10 group meetings and observation of program activities, and structured interviews with 605 individual women (502 participants and 103 women from villages where groups have not been formed) and 31 group facilitators. Using basic statistical procedure, OLS regression, HLM, and interpretation of the qualitative data my analyses suggest that participation in groups is socially empowering for women facing multiple systems of oppression; class, caste and gender. The framing of opportunities to define new interests facilitated by the interactive linkages between the macro and micro levels (global-national-local) create conditions for the emergence of new movements. At the theoretical level, my findings emphasize the need to understand the social basis of poverty and empowerment. I identify and define three types of empowerment as critical for social change for women: socio-economic, purchasing power, and social empowerment. My findings suggest that organizing facilitates women's participation in groups. Individual membership duration and perception of importance of issues discussed in meetings have a significant and positive effect on social empowerment. Collective action is likely in informal groups and group level characteristics explain about 64 per cent of the variance in the social empowerment of individual women.

Title: Protest journeys: Vermont encounters in a campaign of translocal solidarity with the James Bay Crees
Abstract: The Great Whale Campaign (1989–1994), in which the James Bay Crees disputed plans to build new hydroelectric facilities in their territory, is an example of new indigenous resistance efforts disputing externally imposed development projects. This study represents an effort to understand how indigenous activism is building connections through transnational networks of people-to-people and local-to-local activism with counterparts in the United States. It examines the specific responses to, and constructions of, that indigenous activism by groups seeking to support those indigenous efforts. These responses, as they occurred in Vermont, center on a series of encounters and exchanges, or what the author identifies as “protest travel,” by Crees and Vermonters. The acts of protest travel are illustrated in a series of exchanges of narratives and physical journeys that produced and cemented translocal alliances. The result of such alliances is that indigenous activism against development is increasingly being acted out in global marketplaces. Vermonters responded to the social dramas represented by the Crees, in coming to Vermont both with the establishment of unique local actions and with a reflective process of questioning the efficacy of key local values and self-representations. The encounters and exchanges that precipitated this reflective process are viewed through a lens drawing on Turner's exploration of pilgrimage and Dirlik's presentation of the transformative action of recreating local spaces. The actions of both indigenous and nonindigenous communities in the Great Whale Campaign are held up as a counterpoint to globalizing forces. The research suggests that it is critical to rethink the role of joint local activism between U.S. and indigenous communities as a potential transnational “local-local” parallel to globalization. It raises important questions of whether a new politics of citizen-to-citizen activism is possible and whether it offers a new space for social action that creates an equality in the relations between localities. The role of the physical and metaphorical journeys between localities emerges as an important bridge linking resistance and protest movements in joint action to dispute the development discourses now dominant in the world.

Title: Possessing the past: Legacies of violence and reproductive illness in central Mozambique
Abstract: This dissertation examines the experience of violence among displaced and formerly displaced persons in north-central Mozambique. Through an ethnographic analysis of the forms of reproductive illness and spirit possession that have proliferated in the region following the official end of the armed conflict between the Frelimo government and the Renamo rebel movement, this study demonstrates how the violence of displacement and gendered and generational struggles over power has become embodied by young women in the region. The dissertation begins with an overview of population movements throughout the region during the past four centuries and traces the relationship between displacement and the development of a gendered Sena ethnic identity. An overview of the history of spirit possession in the area demonstrates the origins of many forms of possession in the violence and ethnic confrontations fostered by regional imperialism in the nineteenth century and later by European colonialism and capitalism in the twentieth century. Four case studies of spirit possession in Mutarara District illustrate the centrality of possession in local attempts to comprehend and interpret the continuing violence of the recent armed conflict and the social and economic transformation of the past three decades. During this period, gender and generational relations in rural Central Mozambique have undergone substantial change as power shifted from local male authorities to the centralized state and eventually to international organizations as well. Women have been blamed locally for the social instability of the last quarter century and the HIV/AIDS pandemic is held up as the culmination of both destabilization and gender equality. An overview of the gender policies of Frelimo since the struggle for independence shows that government and international aid policy converged with the local patriarchal point of view to blame the rise of the illness on female sexuality. Using ethnographic data gathered from interviews, participant observation, and a household survey, this dissertation documents the sustained role of violence in the lives of the residents of Mutarara.

Title: Local struggle in a global environment: The Internet and the Zapatista Movement
Abstract: The Zapatista movement demonstrates the paradox of global networks. Transnational corporations intensified by NAFTA are drastically reordering local cultures in Mexico. The study explores the social historical factors that shape the Zapatista Movement, and the discourse of the movement—interviews, communiqués, Websites and postings, mainstream news stories and scholarly literature. It argues that the Zapatista movement is able to gain leverage in support of its local-national cause by using many of the same technologies that are facilitating economic globalization today. Access to computer networks in particular provides Zapatista supporters with the means to represent themselves, to retain significant control over information vital to the movement, and to forge links with global political networks that support their cause.

Title: Restructuring religion and the new Los Angeles mosaic: An ethnography of the Los Angeles Church of Christ
Abstract: The Los Angeles Church of Christ (LACC) and the International Churches of Christ in general have generated significant controversy in the twenty years since they began. Religiously conservative, culturally innovative, socially engaging, globally directed and racially integrated, this movement is qualitatively analyzed through the individual experiences of its members. Several, if not all, of the above themes were found to resonate with social cultural and religious inconsistencies that the predominantly young adult members experienced in their lives prior to joining the LACC. This analysis applies a cultural theoretical framework for understanding the subjective motivations and meanings constructed through the church and the social and cultural responses that the church provides or adapts from new members in order to keep the movement and its members energized and diverse. The micro-management of everyday life through strict interpersonal relationships is legitimated through religious teachings. At the same time, the consequences, transformations and lifestyles that are consistent with these teachings provides a lived authenticity that counteracts the hypocrisy that many members perceive in other religions. Micro-management through interpersonal relationships also provides a series of checks and balances that attempt to offset the secularizing influence of pluralism and diversity within the group and the engagement with secular and popular culture that many members maintain. In doing so, the LACC explicitly encourages social, cultural and ethnic diversity within the relegated boundaries of their religious tenets. This diversity is then used both organizationally and individually as a unique tool in attracting new members to the movement. Race and ethnicity are especially salient in this regard. The author coins the terms strategic diversity and strategic ethnicity to account for the ways in which various identities can be alternately highlighted and downplayed depending on social circumstances. This malleability of identity improves the movement's ultimate motivation of making more members. The negotiation of identities and engagement with various cultures and social activities within the parameters of an interactively maintained set of religious beliefs has broader consequences for navigating contemporary culture.

Title: Lo más mexicano de México: Popular arts, Indians, and urban intellectuals in the enthnicization of postrevolutionary national culture, 1920–1972
Abstract: Mexico's contemporary mestizo identity appears as the natural outcome of the country's supposedly seamless history of racial and cultural mixing. This identity, however, did not emerge as early or as naturally as is often assumed. Rather, Mexican national identity was “ethnicized” by postrevolutionary intellectuals who strove to culturally integrate the nation through the promotion of things “authentically Mexican” (namely, those traditions derived from the rural indigenous masses) and through the rejection of their predecessors' Europhilic orientations. This movement toward cultural integration emerged as a loose set of ideas put forth by intellectuals, journalists, artists and others who drew inspiration from the recent Revolution. Popular arts were singled out as one of the most authentic manifestations of the national soul, and were therefore a focus of the project to create an ethnicized Mexican identity. The intellectuals' initiatives were eventually absorbed by the state and grew beyond the control of its founders. The dissertation addresses how the project to integrate and ethnicize the nation was enacted, who was involved, why and how it unfolded as it did, and, finally, what the outcomes have been for those whom the project has sought to incorporate into the Mexican nation. As a corrective to hermetic treatments of Mexican culture, the dissertation places national integration and the valorization of Indian culture within the context of Mexicans' interactions with global transformations. It argues that foreign input cannot be separated from the postrevolutionary impulse to link contemporary indigenous cultures and national identity. And, contrary to the common view of Mexican art and culture as epiphenomenal of “real” politics and economics, this research demonstrates that the cultural reorientation that valorized “Indian” popular arts as “Mexican” created economic and political opportunities (as well as limitations) for artisans, and altered local and national social relations. Finally, the dissertation reveals the often-surprising ways local communities became integrated into national and international transformations. It makes an important contribution to Mexican and Latin American historiography while speaking to broader cultural and political debates.

Title: From sweatshop to model shop: Anti -sweatshop campaigns and languages of labor and organizing, 1880–1934
Abstract: Between 1880 and 1930, Eastern-European Jewish immigrant garment workers as well as policymakers, public health advocates, and German-American Jews made what they called the “sweatshop” the focus of labor organizing and reform campaigns. By targeting sweated labor, workers created a labor movement anchored by the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union (ILGWU) and strengthened by ties to social reformers and politicians, that between 1913 and 1926, enjoyed unprecedented power in determining the conditions and location of production. Between 1926 and 1930, however, this labor movement seemed to be collapsing under the pressures of internal political factionalism. Immigrant workers and their allies in the social reform and public health movements attacked sweated garment work, insisting that it disabled workers' bodies and disrupted their family lives. Yet in their organizing, they entrenched gendered inequality and traded radicalism for reformism. Despite their allegiance to socialism, Jewish labor leaders tended to stress factory inspection and healthcare over a revolutionary remaking of the wage relationship. In alliance with progressive reformers, they created tuberculosis sanitariums, experimental model workshops, and factory-investigating committees designed to safeguard the health of workers and to maintain the sexual division of labor. Jewish workers, both male and female, worried that men sickened and reduced to penury by their sweated labor could not be breadwinners, forcing married women to return to wage labor. The eradication of the sweatshop became linked to the curing of occupational disease and to the preservation of the ideal of the male breadwinner. Women struggled to find a place in a labor movement that worked to maintain workplace patriarchy. As male workers insisted that only single women should work for wages, they organized against married women's homework and represented female workers as merely temporary employees. Women found themselves forced to defend their legitimacy as workers and unionists. While women did succeed in creating organizing programs to address their particular health concerns, they rarely gained access to trade union power or challenged men's primacy as breadwinners.

Title: The regionalization within the International Co -operative Alliance. Specific analysis of the situation in Europe
Abstract: The general object of analysis of this investigation is the International Co-operative Alliance (ICA), (London, 1895), whose aims are the promotion of the worldwide Co-operative Movement and the safeguard of its values and principles. It also claims the attainment of a fairer economic and social system, based on the Co-operative Idea , facilitating the development of economic relations and the promotion of the economic and social progress of the person. Specifically, the research is centered in the process of transformation within the ICA to assure its survival and to guarantee the best attainment of it. So, after a brief reference to the Alliance's first stages, the precedents of the statutory change of 1992 are examined: the process of decentralization and sectorialization after the Second World War and the grave crises that happened in the 80's. The new Statutes created a new system based on a triple decentralization: sectoral , based on eight Specialized Organizations representing different sectors of economic activity; technical , based on Regional Offices, the operative arms of the ICA in each region; and regional , where the political and decision-making power is divided among a global structure and four regions: Americas, Asia-Pacific, Africa and Europe. After a brief reference to the constitution and the first stages of three of the regions, the second part is devoted to the European. Where, in spite of the demands to cover the needs of representation and lobbying due to the constitution of the Economic European Community (EEC), and because the inactivity of the ICA, nine Sectoral Associations and two coordinating centers were constituted in Brussels. That is why the constitution and evolution of the EEC regard to co-operativism, as well as the Sectoral Associations are described, to continue with the study of the European region of the ICA: precedents, constitution, working plans, as well as its relationships with other Institutions. Nowadays this region faces a new stage as is fully consolidated so it needs to evolve. So, an analysis of this possible future, the challenges which the Institution faces, and what should be ICA Europe evolution in the future years is done.

Title: Gender and the German autumn: The representation of terrorism and the female terrorist in social discourses, literature and film
Abstract: In the 1970s in Germany, an urban guerilla movement arose following the decline of the student movement and parallel to the women's movement. The emergence of armed resistance groups was shaped by international anti-colonial liberation movements, the historical exigencies of postwar Germany, and in particular Germany's National Socialist past. One aspect of the phenomenon of armed resistance in Germany is that at least half the members of underground groups were women, a fact that is echoed in the over-abundant figure of the female terrorist in social discourses, literature and film of the 1970s and early 1980s. This study is a reading of this historical fact, the often hysterical fascination it elicited, and the ways in which individual and political identities among the spectrum of the left and the women's movement were constructed in relation to the figure of the female terrorist. This figure had an important ideological function in which the politics of the new German nation, the New Left, and feminism in relation to gender and German history can be read. Through a formal analysis of specific representations, I show how fears of and fantasies about terrorism and in particular the female terrorist addressed underlying social, political and individual conflicts particular to this generation of political activists. Terrorism raised points of doubt, contention, and anxiety relating to issues that preoccupied the 68 generation: guilt and atonement for the National Socialist past, alternatives to the nuclear family and changing gender roles, and the role of the new media in transmitting message about these issues. The object of this study is an elusive phantom of various discourses (social, political and legal texts, popular culture, film, and literature) but also a group of historical subjects whom I approach in a final chapter that focuses on autobiographical writings and oral interviews with women who were involved in the urban guerilla groups Bewegung 2. Juni and the Red Army Faction.

Title: The body and the ambiguities of desire: Interpretations in twentieth -century Chinese literature and film
Abstract: The dissertation examines literary and cinematic embodiment through a group of carefully selected representative texts produced in twentieth-century China. It considers the literary and cinematic representation of the human body as a “social text” revealing issues of class, gender, sexuality, and ethnicity. By tracing the political-ideological imperatives of different periods that determine the body's representation, it maps the cultural practice of meaning production with a close attention to the complexity of form in both literary and filmic significations. The dissertation analyzes how the body-in-text is imagined and lived in key moments of Chinese history, covering an extended period starting with the New Culture Movement up to the nineties, when global capitalism begins to commercialize Chinese culture. It presents a critical reading of “nation and narration,” an intervention into the politics of subaltern, gender, and ethnic representation, and a study of the theme of social alienation.
